A dark police drama with the war on drugs and a cold-blooded Mexican cartel just across "The Bridge" - is compelling, gritty, and extremely well-written and well-acted.  The cast just seems to mesh together with a wide variety of quirky characters.  Loved every episode.  Hope it continues for many more seasons.

Ok, these are weird looking to be sure, but they are ideal for the purpose for which I bought them - flying my Boeing simulator.  They stay firmly on my feet when I'm operating the rudder pedals, and that's very important at landing time!  Cushioned and comfortable.  My only wish is better arch support, but that is not something you find much in any sandal or slipper.

I had high hopes for this item, as a good carry-on that might be fully-compliant with International airlines' carry-on measurements.  Truth is, it leaves something to be desired from several perspectives.  #1, it's noticeably HEAVY.  For a 'carry on' bag, this bag seems to be at the heavy end of the spectrum.  I disliked its heft when I removed it from the shipping box.  The handles on top and at the side are fixed position, and don't flatten out when placed in an overhead bin.  The 'alligator jaw' opening is awkward to load clothing into, and non-intuitive.  The zippers, which "look" robust, snagged and were difficult to open/close right out of the box.  The wheels are uni-directional (not spinner).  This puts a load on your shoulder/arm when you are lugging it behind you.  Spinner luggage is easily pushed with the handle, thus unloading your body and arm.  Although this bag seemed to meet size restrictions better than some other brands, its design characteristics led me to return it.

Extremely high-quality golf ball, and the softest ball I've ever played.  Ideal during cold weather, clicks off your putter softly and reduces hooks/slices.  If you're a 'senior' golfer, this is DEFINITELY a ball worth buying.  We older gents cannot generate the swing speed of our younger brethren.  Thus if we buy the typical "PRO-V" ball which is HIGH COMPRESSION, we cannot hit it very far, because the ball doesn't compress enough upon compact to then leap off the club face.  The Bridgestone e6 ball is a joy to hit and to putt.
Bought it to make videos with my cell phone.  This item is OK for lighter/smaller cell phones, but can't handle the big clunky ones like my Galaxy Note 2.

I'm a man, and I'm color impaired (red/green) like many men are.  It's a nightmare for me trying to color-balance ONE monitor, let alone 3 in a surround-display for my flight simulator.  ColorMunki got it done perfectly in about 15 minutes total time (5 minutes per monitor)!!!For the first time, color is uniform across all the displays!!  This is huge in flight simulations... you don't want brown grass on one screen and dark green on the next - it does NOT look right and ruins the impact of triple-monitors.WORTH EVERY PENNY.  If you're sitting on the fence - BUY IT, you won't be sad!  I was conflicted, it seemed like a substantial cost.  The old saying of you get what you pay for still chimes true and doubly-so here.  If you can't do it with the eyes God gave you (and I surely could NOT), then let XRite's ColorMonki bring it home for you!HINT:  Download the latest software and drivers direct from XRite's site. Simple to use.  I never touched a manual.  The on-screen directions made it child's play.  Balanced all 6 computers.  They didn't look this good when the monitors were new!  Eliminated the white light 'bleed' at the sides and bottom of the screen!  That was worth all the money all by itself!MUST OWN item.
My phone is HEAVY and will NOT fall out of this wonderful gear.  Attach to your home tripod or one of the smaller tripods and you'll be shooting quality vids with your PHONE!

Superb performance and mind-numbing frames rates, whisper-quiet, and best air cooling solution of all video card manufacturers.  Buy it - and don't scrimp on the VRAM, buy the 4GB model (especially for X-Plane 10).  Overclocked by default the moment you plug it in.  MUST own!MSi has spent a lot of effort designing an elegant and highly-efficient dual-fan cooling system "Twin Frozr" - and you will NEVER be disappointed by it!  I regard this card as a stellar performer and an incredible value.  I bought a pair of them to anchor the main display's GTX Titan, and honestly speaking, these cards seem equal to  the Titan- and cost less than half what a Titan does!There are only a handful of electronics items I rate as "BUY NOW" - this product tops my list!  If you're a gamer - you'll love this card!  If you're a flight-sim enthusiast- you'll REALLY love it, particularly if you fly X-Plane 10.  Note to Microsoft Flight Simulator X pilots:  Sadly, FSX is NOT optimized for today's high-end graphics card.  IMHO, this card won't do a whole lot for you.  X-Plane 10?  Exact opposite.  This card does HDX rendering with per-pixel lighting and handles all the texture load I can throw at it, with the exception of non-optimized ortho graphics that were ported over from FSX to X-Plane and poorly optimized.This card has NEVER disappointed me.  "nuff said"
Compelling drama with enough skullduggery to satisfy and keep you coming back for more.  Good character development, and superb acting.

Small enough to fit into 'off-the-shelf' happy meals (example: DELL XPS 8500), this powerhouse will do what you want at a reasonable price point, and drive those speedy (but power-hungry) upper-end video cards!  Semi modular design means install time is greatly reduced, and no worries trying to re-invent the wheel in terms of cable routing!  Only major trick is newer mobos only have 4 power pins for the CPU, whereas older machines have 8.  You have to pay attention to plugging in the big 8pin connector onto your 4-pin motherboard header.  This WORKS and is actually BY DESIGN.  I discovered how to do it by Googling.  There is NO 4-pin connector 'per se' furnished with the 'modular' cables.  Those are 2 6-pin/8pin PCIe cables for video cards  (each cable has 2 8pin plugs, so you would only use BOTH if you had DUAL video cards installed)Could be better:  The modular cables are not sleeved.  No big deal.  Sleeving is more for looks than for robust performance.Whisper-quiet - and reliable.  Like all Corsair power supplies.  Cost a little more, but they work!

I was reluctant to change from my beloved HP2711x monitors, but this beauty made me smile from the moment I turned it on!  Razor-sharp graphics and text, and a wonderful price point.  Great viewing angles due to IPS LED technology.  Love this monitor.  MUST OWN!  Tilts back for nice viewing angles!  VERY SLIM bezel, looks edge-to-edge glass when powered off.  Only minor knock, no VESA mount holes on the back.  I believe you can buy adapters to connect to VESA stands.

Bought these for 3 reasons:1- Trust MSi 'frozer' cooling design- simply the BEST in graphics cards, period.2- Wanted max frames in X-Plane 10 - 1 PC w/ this card for EACH monitor.  (3 PCs total)3- Price vs. value received - This is a reasonably sized card that I was able to plug into my Dell XPS 8500s "Happy Meal" PCs that I got from a big-box club store.  The stock video card, albeit a nVidia GT620 was absolute disappointment compared to THIS beast!  For a sub-200 price point, I am able to get higher frames on my dedicated surround monitors than I'm getting on a faster PC with a GTX690 dual-GPU graphics card!  I am linking up to my YouTube video made with these video cards.I was reluctant to purchase these cards, feeling I might have been going too cheap.  But I love the cards, and they FIT inside today's smaller case Big-Box retailer PCs by companies like HP, Dell, Lenovo.  Even with the dinky standard power supply, this card runs cool and QUIET.  You CANNOT hear it!Frames were dazzling.  I kicked X-Plane up to near MAX with HDR rendering and very high anti-aliasing settings (watch my video).  NEVER EVER looked so good!

Bought this when my old Logitech Harmony 1000 Universal Remote died after years of heavy abuse, including greasy fingerprints, cleaning with Windex, and more!  This unit is simple to set up and program, and replaces a basket full of remotes, including the remotes for the Tivo, Sony Blu-Ray, Panasonic TV, Pioneer A/V audio, subwoofer and Bose Surround, Roku Internet Radio, and JVC A/V switch.  Needless to say, pressing just ONE button on this unit beats running around the house chasing all those other remotes and pressing buttons on EACH of them to turn the devices on/off, change channels, etc.Logitech apparently has abandoned this nice-sized unit in favor of smaller units that cost the same or more.  My advice is to buy this NOW, while you can.  It's a great device!  It can learn signals from your existing remotes, I only had to do that with the JVC A/V switch, everything else just enter the device name and model number.Runs off an Internet website, so it's a no-brainer to set up and then send the programming to the unit while it's plugged into your PC.Must own!
Fits my Remstar Pro perfectly - and great price.  Highly recommend.  Should replace filter no more than each 60 days.
Famous quality and ultra high speed.  Love this drive.  10,000 RPMS is the fastest speed available except for Solid State (SSD) drives.
Inexpensive and vital connector cable for PC builders.  Trust Startech brand.  I have purchased any number of StarTech products and always been satisfied.
We've all had the experience of wanting to upgrade a small hard disk to a larger new one.  This tool is must-have for IT folks.  Can handle notebook hard disks too - SATA drives only.
Works great and inexpensive.  What more can I say?  Dual Layer is a must nowadays.  Couldn't be happier with it.

Completely satisfied with these - have ordered and re-ordered them from Amazon.  I use them to make backup copies of some of my 'lesser' blu-ray disks.  These are single layer (25GB max) disks, which are not large enough to fully back-up a complex blu-ray with a lot of 'bonus features' on it.  Those generally are double-layer (50GB) disks, which I also buy from Amazon and have reviewed as well.  But if you have a pretty simple movie without a lot of extras, this is a great way to cover yourself against the kids scratching it or jamming it in the blu-ray player and damaging the recording surface.  Like any blu-ray disk, you must handle these carefully, don't touch the shiny side, and buy some kind of cover for them (plastic cases are best, but paper sleeves will do as well).

Like many bachelors, I dislike sewing on buttons, and due to machine washing and heat from the dryer and the steam iron - over time buttons pop off.  I have searched long and hard for a quick down-and-dirty way to 'rivet' a button back onto a shirt in lieu of sewing.  So I opted to purchase this item.  Sad to say, the reality did not live up to the concept.  One look at the construction of the device told me what other reviewers have already said:  This device is not ready for prime time.  It uses the plastic "T" fasteners you see in retail stores holding price tags on your garments with those little nylon strings through the label.  You cut one end off when you get home to remove the price tag.  Great for pricing clothes, not so much for attaching buttons.  At the time I bought the device, I also ordered a pack of these refills.  Both items went back to Amazon refund desk.

2:07 MinsI have long trusted Logitech brand for all of my peripheral needs, they make excellent wireless keyboards/mice, and a nifty game pad (The G13).  Their speakers with powered subwoofer are legendary, so when it came time to buy a USB headset, I jumped on this one- and you can listen for yourself and decide if it's all that and a bag of chips!  I think the answer is YES.  The microphone rivals the quality of any high-end desktop microphone I've ever used, and the earpieces and headband are reasonably comfortable and produce crystal-clear professional audio, which is ideal for when you're piloting a heavy jet with a lot of interior noise in the cockpit. I use this headset exclusively to produce my YouTube videos, a copy of which is attached in lowered definition to meet Amazon video file size limits.The one suggestion I have for this is to build your own windscreen to cut out the 'popping' of your voice with hard consonants, such as "K" or "P", etc.  I took a piece of soft shipping foam used to pack hard disk drives for shipment, and cut a rectangle which I slipped over the microphone.  Works perfectly - no voice 'pops' (see video).  I have a large head, and this headset is comfortable, and the earphones cover my ears and are padded, I can wear them for 1 and 2 hour flights without problems.  Build quality is great for this price level.  Beat my expectations, and I'm betting will easily meet yours too.You can silence the microphone by pressing in on the right earpiece, press once more to turn the mic back on.  This unit has been in heavy use for nearly two years now, and I could not be more satisfied.  I like it so well I have recommended to many other simulation pilots, I would endorse it for other game-play as well.  For the modest price, you will NOT be unhappy with this purchase!  You hear my voice as the pilot talking to Air Traffic Control on my way from San Diego to Las Vegas.Besides games, I think this unit is stellar for other voice applications that require high-quality rendition (Skype, Recording Training Videos, etc)

This aux-in cable allows you to connect your smartphone to your stereo, or car audio system though a mini-jack.  The plugs are designed to accommodate a wide range of cell phone or mp3 cases which oft-times have the earphone jack too deeply recessed which in turn makes a problem connecting a jack like this.The quality of this cable is high. I could hear a much clearer sound when I use this cable than the cheap cable I bought at (The Shack).It does what it is intended for, is long enough to reach my car radio and allow me to hide my smartphone in the center console.Good purchase. I'm satisfied.

I am on my second pack of these disks, which I purchased from Amazon (and were fulfilled by a Japanese vendor).  Allow extra shipping time as they are imported from Japan!  They work very well with my blu ray burner drive, and for about $3 a disk- you can't beat the price for 50GB of data on a single disk!  (Double Layer).As always, use care when handling these disks, keep your fingers off the shiny side.  The label side can be used in some inkjet printers (requires a CD/DVD adapter tray), or you can easily write on them with your felt pen ("Sharpie").Purchase some paper sleeves or higher-end plastic cases to protect your finished disks for maximum shelf life (also available from Amazon).

Bought this so I could make backups of my extensive blu-ray disk collection.  Works well and is simple to install, yank out your existing DVD burner/Player and pop this in - or if you have a spare full-size slot in your case,  you can add this as a second optical drive.  Reliable and reasonably priced.  Keys to making successful blu-ray or DVD disks:* Good drive (this one works well)* Good quality blank disks!  VERY IMPORTANT!  Cheapy blu-ray blanks can result in cheapy drink coasters!  I buy disks from Amazon that come from Japan.  They work well and are by and large reliable.Blu-Ray disks are more sensitive to scratches and fingerprints than their DVD cousins - this is particularly true of 'double layer' or double-density blu-ray disks.  Be careful when handling- and keep them in protective sleeves when not watching them.

You remember that late-night sidewalk convo in The 'Burbs, or the ever camp but somehow compelling interchanges between the three male leads or that creep-out moment with Henry Gibson and his red paint? The mood, somehow silly but somehow serious and ever so very much fun to watch, was one I'd never seen before on film (as I was a child when that film was released). Well, in viewing this, wacked-out, crazy lightning strike of a film, one Space Milkshake, I found myself coming back to those moments, in feeling and mood and in the childish giggles I heard coming out of my mouth, as I stared in amazement at a perfect comedy unfolding before me.Comedy is remarkably personal. It never has the universal resonance we find in action or your standard super-hero films because comedy strikes us all in such different ways. What one person finds hilarious, another will find horribly grating or annoying, which is why I nearly never read reviews of comedy films. Nothing in cinema is so divisive. And so, all I can tell you that will be of any actual help is that this film, in many ways, reminds me of The 'Burbs and in many ways reminds me of Grabbers (another of my five star favorites) in tone and in feeling. In going further, it manages to evoke all the joy of watching the endlessly fun Futurama and Hyperdrive while simultaneously feeling very serious in that "this is really happening" kind of way. Like Red Dwarf in that it is a space farce but also not because it contains so much of that Stargate-like sense of genuine danger and excitement. Basically, it is the funniest thing I've ever seen, which is meaningless to anyone other than me, but if you loved any of these programs/films, you will most likely enjoy this film, if not adore it. If you disliked or hated any of these, you will most likely dislike or hate this.I loved it so much that, after watching five times free through Prime, I shelled out the eight bucks and bought the thing, just so these people will get paid. If you do watch this outrageous and lovable comedy, I hope you love it as much as I do, but if you don't, I hope you find another that makes you feel as happy as this film makes me feel every time I watch it.

Warning: Not so much outright spoilers as hints here so don't read if you haven't seen this season.To put this plainly, this is the season of male writer/showrunners expressing unexplained hatred against women through a once well-loved television program. The bizarre personality swapping of the lead females on this show resulted in a character who, among other things, is the show's only resident rapist becoming one of the team and the beloved of our hero becoming a horrible and violent person, as though good people just become horrible when you add a little power and personal difficulty and rapists just become good when motivated to do so. I get that it's a fantasy program but it is supposed to take place on the same planet we all live on.This once wonderful, well integrated series, has degenerated into yet another "women just suck" diatribe against love, trust and marriage with a strong focus on the following basic story-line:  when you give a woman power, she becomes a monster and the only way to deal with her is to stick a gun in her face, threaten her life and see how much angrier it makes her (answer: very and understandably so) but, in the alternate, when you take a woman's power away, she becomes a nicer, more subservient person, obedient even. This new anti-female season-long story arc culminated in the most horrible of all "spousal abuse is good" statements when the lead male character turned to his gang of friends and instructed them to kill his ex the next time they see her, as he had failed to do so the last time he'd put a gun in her face. Not surprisingly, every character was on board with this "how to permanently end a failed relationship" solution. And the story played out, as it has in so many courtrooms across America, the man no longer loved the woman so, naturally, he had her killed, only this time, the writers of the story cast the murderous man as a hero, making every woman in my circle swear off this show and any future shows written by Greenwalt and his band of misogynists.So, basically, if you are a man, a fan of radio shock jocks that hate women, a fan of Chris D'Elia style, hating everything about women except the actual sex part "comedy", then Season Four of Grimm will probably appeal to you as a vicarious experience of allowable violence against women. If you are a woman who loves women, your friends, your family, your co-workers, and you happen to find women wonderful in most ways (as I do), then this will most likely leave you feeling a bit sick and somewhat depressed.As for me, I used to love this series and the Nick and Juliette story was enjoyable to me, in large part, because it echoed reality in a way that fantasy shows often forget to, by showing a relationship between two adults for what it is in reality. This turn of events has left this show feeling completely unreal and, if I can't suspend my disbelief, there is no point in watching.As always, this review is only meant to inform, not to hurt the feelings of any super fans (of which I used to be one) and I ask that you please not take my disgust at the meta-communication of this season personally. Good luck in making your choice to view or not to view this horrid shift toward misogynistic storytelling from a previously woman-friendly program.

Firs off, I loved the books and the first series, for what they were. This is not a review of Poldark the story or the other adaptations. This is a review of this series based on one critical error: FALSE ADVERTISING. The advertising on PBS (in the US, not the BBC One commercials, as I am in America), has portrayed this series as something entirely different from what came before, a new take on the story with a clear focus on the romantic elements (which are not the crux of the Ross Poldark section of the books nor the first series). However, that is not what this series is about and represents a clear attempt to manipulate viewers into thinking that this series is something more akin to Outlander and the like and less akin to the endless "business" focused series currently airing on Masterpiece. I'm sorry to say that it is this dishonesty that ruined this series for me as I viewed my copy expecting to see something new and different, taking the Poldark books as a jumping off point for a story focusing less on money and more on romance, a modern telling if you will. I figured, if you aren't going crazy with the telling of Poldark the rapist then, of course, you can change other story elements. Unfortunately, this is still a money-centered tale and the romantic element is significantly downplayed, as compared to what is promised in the commercials they are currently running.So, for anyone who doesn't know, as to what Poldark is, originally. Poldark is a sweeping epic encompassing the lives of too many characters to mention and their descendants. Business, finance, plague, love, hatred, competition, and so on, provide the emotional backbone. There is a decent wiki article which covers this so I won't bore you except to say that, if you love complex epics, the books are superb. However, this series is the story of a man's quest for wealth and the similar quests for wealth of many people around him, to put it plainly. There are many characters in this story, from the books of course, but, much like the other "wealth" and "business" concerned programs on Masterpiece today, including The Paradise and Selfridges, money and business, the trials and tribulations of gaining wealth, keeping a business going, keeping from going under, and the like, are the primary concerns, not romance. Secondary concerns of romance, changing affections and one man's long term obsession with a woman he doesn't get (except by force) are also important but not as important as the money aspect (at least in the unedited version I saw from BBC One). I should note that, thankfully, the hair-pulling, rapist elements of the books have been left out to make way for a more sympathetic lead male and, for the record, I greatly appreciate that, as there can be no romance at all if a man is engaging is such horrific abuse of women. However, these kindnesses do not make up for such a focus on the business element at the expense of the lead relationship, in terms of screen time and development.Now, this is not a bad series, overall. If you like stories that revolve around business, finance, competition, a region and all the businessmen in that region and their competitions over money and women, debt collection, trying to pull each other under, and so on, you will love this, as it has plenty of that going on. However, this was advertised as being DIFFERENT from the original series (1975 and 1977, which was wonderful as an adaptation of a portion of the book series and quite enjoyable, even if you haven't read this fantastic series) but this is NOT DIFFERENT. Is there romance? Of course. You can't have Poldark without the romantic entanglements of the lead men and women. But this was marketed as focusing more on or, rather, playing up the romance between Ross Poldark and Demelza, focusing more on them, in fact almost exclusively, with other story considerations playing out in the background, and comparisons have been made to Outlander (for no reason I can fathom) and this is simply just not the case. The whole landscape of class struggle, economic upheaval, propriety and fitting in with the wealthier crowd come to the forefront, with money and respect for having said money as a primary concern. This sort of ideology fit well in the era of the last series, leading into the 1980s, the decade of rampant greed, but, today, watching a woman work to fit into a group of snobs rather than conquer them with how different and special she is, not surprisingly, rings as false and uncomfortable and, again, anything but romantic.Please don't mistake me, this is a wonderful series. As a well-rounded, filled up, cast heavy, character laden drama series goes, the new Poldark does not disappoint in what looks to be the first of several seasons. But, for those concerned with what was promised them in the endless commercials now playing, this is a terrible series as a romance and, again, given how much is going on in this series and how many characters swirl about through each episode, this cannot be called a romance. Like The Paradise and Downton, there are romantic elements, but, overall, it is another money-centric series. I took the time to watch this, having seen the original, a spectacle that I really didn't need to see remade, specifically because this new version was marketed as being different, as giving me more of the romantic element I wanted to see explored in this version. That is just not what this is and I can't figure out why PBS has been advertising it as such. There is far too much economic concern, dead babies and male competition, not to mention the unfortunate ending, which you can feel free to look up elsewhere if you like to know how depressed you will feel at the end of a series like this, for this to ever be a "romance". And so, while this is wonderful for what it is, with high production values and wonderful performances throughout, the money, the death, the depression, the lack of focus on the romance between the two leads in an effort to include nearly every character from the books involved here, it is not up the standard set by, of all things, the commercials for this very series. I almost wish I'd watched only the trailers for this, scenes of which come from only the earliest episodes of only the first season, rather than ruining the experience of the romantic element here, by viewing the entire series. The best I can offer is that, If you are interested in this series, and you well should be if you are not looking for a purer romance, then you can find enjoyment in it if you remember that this is a full series, like Downton Abbey with many plots and subplots and a lot of down time from the main characters. The romance is played out by the end of episode three (and there are eight in this first series/season, alone), and if sometimes it seems Ross Poldark loves another woman or his business more than the woman you want him to be focusing on, it is only because he does as, again, this is not just a romance.Please remember, this is not meant as a critique of the whole Poldark universe, just this series' false claims and failure to live up to what was promised. I don't mean to offend anyone or for anyone to take my criticism personally as this is meant only to inform, not to harm. Thank you for your time and good luck in your viewing. I hope you are able to love this for what it is, as sweeping epics do have a place of honor and appreciation in our entertainment world as well as great value in our lives. And I hope that, if you've read this, you won't find yourself disappointed by a failure to live up to what PBS has promised with an unfortunately deceptive advertising campaign.

First off, the source material for these films was very low quality and, from what I see here, Scream Factory did a fine job of sharpening the image and correcting for color issues. That having been said, this is not the highest quality Blu-ray you will ever own and you should know what you are getting. Second, Scanners III received an independent release where Scanners II did not. As such, in America, this is your only Blu-ray option for Scanners II. Having said that, this is a quality 50 GB disc with each film taking up a fair share of their respective 25 GB, a size we often see very high quality transfers compressed onto so, in my opinion, the picture was good with minimal compression artifacts and, overall, it was certainly an improvement over what I had before. Third, these films are available on Blu-ray from other countries. So, if you love them, you may wish to research the other editions before you decide which version (with which type of color correction, etc.) you prefer, based on your taste. I find this a charming release and am pleased to have it in my collection.Good luck making your choice.

Yes, I'm still poor and, yes, I purchased this. And here's how much I love it: I don't regret that purchase. This is a wonderful, beautifully produced, special Blu-ray edition set from Scream Factory. As you know, the Theatrical and Director's cuts along with extensive special features and goodies are added here, so, I won't bore you with what better reviewers can give you in, well, a better review. What you should know is that there is no end to the production value on this set and, where I would normally say "Nothing can be worth that price", I have to admit, this time, this one really is. This rivals Criterion quality and then goes above by adding a second version of the film and so much love in the packaging. I've never seen a set like this and I find myself wishing they'd done this for Lifeforce. I love this. That's all there is. I just love it. Someone at Scream Factory is as big a nerd as me and I thank them for pushing for this release to be as spectacular as they could make it.

I bought one in Red and one in Brown, Decaf and Regular, I know it is predictable but I couldn't resist. First off, one arrived broken because it was crushed by something that weighed forty pounds. In other words, it took something that weighed forty pounds slamming into it to crush it and, get this, it was in large pieces. So, I think it is safe to say that this is strong glass. Second, upon replacement, I tested the two units and found that they not only perform as described but are strong enough that when I accidentally slammed one down on the counter (much harder than I would ever do with anything made of glass) it survived unbroken and un-cracked. As such, I am giving this the highest rating. What else can I ask of a product? It does what it promises and it doesn't break easily. I highly recommend this to anyone seeking an easy cold-brew option for coffee.Good luck in selecting the right product for you.

I ordered multiple units and all arrived damaged or broken. They were packaged well so this was not the issue. The problem here is that these are fragile and no amount of packaging can perfectly protect something this delicate from the beating packages take on their way to our homes. There are plastic alternatives to this and, if you can't find one of these delicate and highly breakable units in a brick and mortar store, you should make sure you have plenty of time to when you need to use this such that you could get replacements in time for use if they arrive broken. For me, these are just too delicate. They are pretty though, when you hold the pieces together and squint to fog out all the cracks and break lines.Good luck finding the right product for you.

It is very hard to find a 100mg dose on Sam-e since everyone decided it is such an important supplement. Like with so many others, individual pills of Sam-e are often over-dense. Rather than taking a lower dose two or three times a day for maximum absorption, dosages ranging from 200mg to 800mg (much of which we just excrete without using) have dominated the market.Now Foods has been, in my opinion, generous enough to produce a low cost 100mg option, not only for people like me who want to increase the benefit by spacing out doses, but, also, for people who wish to use this with pets. This pill, whole, can be given to medium and large dogs and, cut into quarters, can be easily given to cats and small dogs, always followed up with water or watered down food in a syringe or spooned into their mouths, of course. I cut this into eighths and place them into size four capsules for administration to my hepatic cat several times a day and his condition is improved (with regard to his liver, not, unfortunately all of his problems as we'd both prefer).This is an excellent product, in line with what you expect from Now Foods but, more importantly, the dosage is what really makes this special. It is suitable for use with pets when cut down and, as it isn't too high a dose to begin with, cutting it down is easier. A cat can have 50mg but will gain greater benefit from 25mg a couple times a day and starting at 100mg makes that much easier to cut down to the right size for use with small dogs and cats.Good luck in finding your product.

This is another excellent formula from Thorne Research for pets. The formulation is safe for use, as of this writing, and the pills are just small enough for a cat. That having been said, because the pills are capsules they can be split open and put in food or, as might be necessary for a very small dog or small cat, the pills can be divided between two size 4 capsules either to dose two or four times a day or to make administration easier on you and your pet.The supplements contained herein are specifically beneficial to the liver, including Milk Thistle, which is among the best liver supplements on the market. I combine this with a form of Sam-e that has a lower dose than the average human labeled product (such that the dosage is safe for aiding in feline and canine liver health). Overall, this is one of the best combination products out there and, unlike many human products that are at least half rice-starch, they didn't use too much filler, rather than give us a nutrient dense pill.Please note that Hepagen-Fc is the smaller option (for cats and smallish dogs) from Thorne and, as four of my five babies are small, we use this formula for convenience. The company does offer a larger size for use in large dogs, also nutrient dense instead of filler dense, but in a much larger capsule.Good luck in making your choice.

This is the best formulation I've found for thyroid suppression (via binding) in a cat. L-Carnitine is known to be useful in binding thyroid hormone and, with supervision of a veterinarian and liberal blood testing (the same testing that must be done with use of prescription thyroid suppression methods to monitor the decline of T4 levels), this has been very successful in lowering levels in animals with milder hyperthyroidism. The problem, however, is finding a dose that will work for a small animal. A large dog can take this 250mg capsule whole. But a small dog or, as is usually the case with pets suffering hyperthyroidism, a cat, cannot. This pill has two benefits: it is a capsule you can open to gauge lower doses and deliver them throughout the day and it is a lower dose to begin with (250mg as opposed to 500mg or 1000mg which would be too hard to split accurately). I give my boy about 125mg split throughout the day into smaller doses and add to that a low dose of a pure melatonin capsule at a dose of 1mg per day (split up, of course) and he is back down the four points he needed to get "normal" again and not be hyperthyroid. If his levels increase, we already have a plan for slowly increasing the L-Carnitine and Melatonin to match the illness and keep him healthy and, to be clear, that would not be possible without a high quality 250mg capsule of L-Carnitine. I trust this brand, have used it for years not only for myself but for my animals. This L-Carnitine is also perfectly sized for cardiac support in our 70 pound dog and he can swallow it whole.Good luck in making your choice.

Warning:  Do Not Use Probiotics In Liver Compromised Animals (or humans for that matter) Without Carefully Selecting Strains.The enzyme formula here is excellent and well balanced and, while I certainly recommend that portion of this product, I cannot recommend the product overall as this formula also contains probiotics. Probiotics are both helpful and dangerous in cases of Liver Disease, certain viral infections that can harm the liver, certain bowel conditions and in cases of portosystemic shunting, even acquired shunting which is less severe. The helpfulness of some strains, specifically some strains of lactobacilli, has been established as actually aiding in reducing the process that results from other strains of gut bacteria (both good and bad strains), up to a point and the effect is dose specific. To be clear, the process by which bacteria, including some probiotics, can harm animals, in opposite of the help certain lactobacilli generally provide, is the production of ammonia as a byproduct of the bacteria's normal functioning. This ammonia exacerbates the illness in the animal, illness that you must confirm is not present before you use this or any other probiotic formula.The production of ammonia is not a side effect you can undo by adding lactobacilli if you are forcing other strains into the animal at the same time, though the inclusion of certain lactobacilli in certain amounts can help keep it from being worse, by offering, essentially, bacterial competition. However, ammonia will continue to build up, unlike in healthy humans and pets where a healthy liver is able to process the ammonia out. In an ill animal, the liver cannot detoxify the body and the animal becomes ill as the ammonia builds up. If cat or dog is young and healthy, this product is wonderful. If they are older and you have them tested regularly and are confirmed to have absolutely perfect liver values (low-normal to mid-normal but never high-end normal), then they will benefit from this formula and it will aid in their digestion. If, however, your baby is like one of my babies, suffering a weakened liver, this product could be harmful to them and you should discontinue use.If you wish to aid them with probiotics, select a limited strain formula of exclusively "lactobacillus" strains, knowing that you are still taking a risk as this "helpful" bacteria is not always helpful and has not been studied in animals for safe dosage in hepatic pets.As to the enzymes, at this time, I am still looking for a product with enzymes that does not contain any probiotics, save a low dose of specific and isolated strains of lactobacilli to test and see if he gets sick again (as other formulas, including this one, have proven harmful to my little cat.I should state that I am using this product without difficulty in two dogs (young and healthy dogs).My one star rating is for the failure of the manufacturer to warn of the danger to liver compromised animals and, quite frankly, for forcing those who need enzymes to also use probiotics when so many animals just can't have them, even strains beneficial to hepatic humans. In any combination product, the bacteria should come exclusively from forms of lactobacillus bacteria, which they appear to have achieved, however, as too many owners cannot afford to constantly monitor ammonia levels and liver enzymes absent active illness (vomiting and the like), it is not acceptable to force probiotics with no warning (or at all).Good luck in finding a products that meets your needs. I will update this if I find a product that works for my hepatic cat.

This is among the highest rated surge protectors by independent testers looking at the level of surge the unit can withstand before failing. As such, I bought one. Our home had a large surge only weeks later and my television and computer are safe and sound. I am so glad I bought this.

As nearly everyone else has said of this brand, the Cables to Go Cat5e series of shielded ethernet cables is amazing at minimizing interference. These are the best I've tried, in all lengths, and I've never had a problem with any of them. Good luck.

This is a fantastic little unit with one caveat:  "400 pound load capacity" does not mean "400 pounds per shelf" as with many NSF rated units. This unit is actually rated at 135 pounds per shelf. Again, it is a great little trolly style unit and I absolutely love it but I saw 400 pounds, misinterpreted, based on having so many chrome units in the garage, and made the mistake of telling someone the weight rating. This resulted in that someone and another someone piling their behinds onto the top shelf to test it out (on each of two units) and top shelves are now toast. So, just so you know, 135 pound load capacity per shelf and not five pounds more. Other than that one issue, this is the sturdiest cart of this type on the market for the price. You can't beat an NSF weight rated chrome storage unit... except when you add wheels to it, making it absolute magic in the house. I already can't believe I ever worked in this house without these things. Good luck making your choice.

This is a solid indoor performer for average usage. I wouldn't use it with an air conditioner or a table saw but for a drill or window fan, this is a nice, simple option that does the job advertised. Good luck.

I've used one of these for a year and a half to connect an air unit in the front of my little old house to an outlet in the back, opposite corner of the house. (Yes, I have a terribly outdated wiring harness and no, I can't afford to rewire.) Using this to extend the power supply from an outlet on a different circuit, to allow for use when I have lights on and, dare I say, even a coffeemaker, has greatly improved me quality of life but, also, taught me about the importance of having a large, heavy duty electrical cord, in the correct length (to minimize resistance so it doesn't heat up or catch fire) with the correct ratings that will be compatible not only with the devices used on the cord but the power supply the cord jacks into. This is the best cord I've ever owned and, consequently, the only one I use on high wattage devices. Good luck.

As pill poppers go, this is the best design ever. It grips the pills like no other and, owing to a slick surface on the end piece, allows for easy sliding down the back of my cats' throats. They no longer gag as they did with the little blue-tip white ones (that look like a stick) or the little short ones that never worked. Also, having these has allowed me to up dosages on supplements without my little boy pulling that move where he induces vomiting to show me he objects to me giving him so many separate pills. He takes them with greater ease and doesn't object except on rare occasions. Good luck.

This is not a review of this sweet little film which I clearly loved enough to shell out money for, though it is a good watch, in case you didn't already know. This is a review of the item sold here, the DVD of Driving By Braille released by Green Apple.When I first ordered this, I received a damaged copy and, initially believed it to be due to the disc coming loose or damage sustained during shipping, because the item was open box and scratched with a cracked case. I did a return and got a replacement, basically, immediately, and it was identical in flaws, something that, truly, never happens.I couldn't conceive of how this could occur and proceeded to order the cheapest used copy I could find and then call the friend who alerted me to the fact that this film had been released on nearly two years ago and, somehow, I hadn't noticed. In consulting with her I was surprised to discover, from her story of her search for this film, that the data side of these discs are very often scratched, from poor production standards and packing issues, that is to say, they are damaged at the source, not during shipping. When she bought hers, she got several loose in package and scratched up, just like the two I received, but also got ones in cracked cases and two of three were open box. She then got one that was not loose and was just scratched up in exactly the same place as the loose ones only so very much more scratched than the loose ones.I remembered, in talking with her, that discs don't just magically appear in a case to be shipped to our homes. DVDs are processed through layers of equipment and then placed in cases by people who don't always check for damage to the data side before placing the disc inside the case as they are looking for print errors on the picture side. As such, a friend received three scratched up discs and I got two, so far, out of five ordered from three different vendors, and they were scratched in the same places from what appears to have been equipment malfunction, not from having been loose in the package, as not all of them were loose.So, it turns out, sadly, that this release seems to be packaged in very cheap, easily cracked/broken cases with very poor quality control in inspecting the discs. This DVD release sometimes comes without shrinkwrap, which makes it appear used when it is, in fact, new and has probably not even been opened to check for damage. And, worst of all, it is often so scratched, all around the innermost centimeter to inch of the DVD data side (readable side), that it won't even play correctly on older equipment. These appear almost as though the discs have been fed through a disc cleaning device from the mid-1990s (that we all know not to use anymore), and there is no clear explanation as to how this happened but it is a manufacturing error you should look out for.To be clear on playback, neither of the discs I received would play because my player is, quite frankly, not that good, but when tested on a Blu-ray player, they would play, one with minimal skipping and one with more skipping. My friend reported to me that her first discs were like that but the last one, according to her, the worst scratched of all, plays perfectly on her DVD player, Blu-ray player and computer so the scratching may not be the source of the playback errors.I wanted to post this so that you would know, if you get this in the mail from any seller, you should test it first before concluding it is a bad copy due to scratching and before deciding to return it due to it appearing damaged, as this DVD release was not prepared as professionally as I think all of us are used to at this point. It is not Amazon or the seller's fault if there are scratches around the center and so, if you are lucky enough to get one that plays well, you should hold onto that copy, and remember how many copies just two of us have encountered with problems due to manufacturing errors. For future readers, she purchased in late 2014 through early 2015. I purchased for the first time in April 2015 and will update this when I find a copy that plays.Again, this is one of those rare times when you should test a so-horribly-scratched-I-don't-even-want-to-look-at-it type of disc, even though it looks terrible and used, before you consider returning it for damage as you may have one of the only playable copies being produced right now.. Amazon has no control over the product this vendor sends out to them so a playable copy, new or used, is a real find on this film, at least right now. Just call it a diamond in the rough, the little DVD that could, and be thankful.UPDATE:I've received my third copy of this and, once again, it is scratched all to you know where. It won't play without freezing on my DVD and Blu-ray players. It played last night on a friend's player though so I just gave this last copy to him and am, of course, returning the first two. Disappointing (due to whatever manufacturing error caused this) but I have now ordered one from that site we all go to, hoping the feds aren't watching. Looking forward to my illegitimate copy which I can watch whenever I want. It is a lovely film.

This fan may not last forever but, for the price, it is the best I've found. A nice, simple, easy to control fan, this pulls air in when I want it and draws it out when needed. The company has priced it low enough to be replaced every couple of years or as needed but has also put in the effort to minimize control errors or degradation by using manual switches on these. Errors, like those from digital controls that notoriously break faster than manual controls are why I threw out my last window fan and why I was lucky enough to find this one. We have several and they work well. Vacuuming gently (when off) to remove dust will help these last longer and, of course, pulling them down when it rains or there is heavy condensation. Good luck with making your choice.

This is another I tried at a friend's. I liked it quite a lot for style as compared to my classic style Bodum, however, the classic style, with the straighter handle, seems to fit better in my hand. I should note that she loves the curved handle on this, as compared to the more squared off and straight edged handle on the other model so it is probably an issue of preference you can figure out before buying by testing some coffee mugs in your kitchen. The glass carafe inside was the same thickness as on my Bodum that broke so I'm giving it the same three stars (assuming it will shatter like mine did). I may never figure out the best way to make coffee but I keep looking.Good luck with your search and please don't send me hate mail if you own this and disagree with me. My opinion of this item is not meant to offend but to inform.

This is the classic Hario, tried at a friend's house and again at home (after I borrowed it) an excellent little kettle with a couple of drawbacks. Like the Fino, the gooseneck was slightly larger than some I've tried and I felt I had to pay closer attention to what I was doing. Also, even though the handle is nice and far out from the kettle, keeping my hands from getting to warm when I tried it, the contour was kind of annoying against my fingers after a minute. Very good, but not perfect.

I really liked using this little goosneck kettle. I borrowed it from a friend (who also owns the other size of this kettle). It performed well in my efforts at doing pour over in my cramped kitchen. However, where the larger Fino was slightly too cumbersome for me and this smaller unit was more of what I'd call "my size", I found that this unit has the same gooseneck attached and, therefore, like the larger kettle, the neck is just slightly bigger or wider in diameter than some I've tried, resulting in my having to pay closer attention to what I was doing. Not at all a bad kettle for pour over and  the handle is far out from the kettle so my hand didn't get too warm. It is very good, just not perfect and I'm still deciding if pour over is something I can deal with every day.

This performed well in my efforts at doing pour over in my cramped kitchen. However, it was a bit large for me, a bit cumbersome, and I found I preferred the smaller Fino over this unit. After borrowing the smaller unit (from a friend who also loaned me this kettle to try) I found that the two kettles suffered the same issue, for me. While the handle is far out from the kettle so my hand didn't get too warm and the neck was decent, even good, I found that the neck was also a bit large in diameter, being the same neck as on the smaller unit, which resulted in my having to pay closer attention to what I was doing. Not at all a bad kettle for pour over. Just not perfect.

I had one of the classic glass-style Bodums and, first, let me say, it did last for nearly two years. That having been stated, it shattered in my hands sending hot coffee and grounds all over the floor and, of course, me. I didn't expect this to happen as I'd never had a French Press explode before and I decided to replace it with this cheap model, the Primula Tempo. Unfortunately, the Primula is a "get what you pay for" alternative that is cheaply made and broke in about a month. I then purchased a stainless steal option, thinking "This will last forever!" and boy was I wrong. The stainless steel models all suffer from a horrible flaw. Where the plunger contacts the stainless steel interior, as it must, over time, with more and more plungings, the plunger becomes slightly more angled and ends up scraping the side of the interior, harder and harder until stainless steel powder is being scraped from the press every time you make coffee. Essentially, stainless steel models produces a fine metal powder that you end up drinking with your coffee and it only gets worse with time because the interior coating has been stripped and is revealing soft, easily scraped metal with every use. With mine, this scraping actually happened in multiple locations over time until most of the interior diameter, about sixty percent, was being scraped. I thought my coffee was tasting different over time but, being a bit of dummy when it comes to this sort of, "if it was fine when I bought it, then it must still be fine" kind of thinking, I didn't check the unit without liquid in it until it had been happening for months. I re-purposed my stainless steel model (the Il Mulino) and am currently using another glass Bodum while testing pour over gear. It isn't perfect but it probably won't kill you. If you are looking for a glass one, check out the Bodum and don't bother with this as the glass is thinner and breaks far too quickly.Good luck with your search and please don't send me hate mail if you own this and disagree with me. My opinion of this item is not meant to offend but to inform.

I had one of this classic style Bodum French Press and, first, let me say, it did last for nearly two years. That having been stated, it shattered in my hands sending hot coffee and grounds all over the floor and, of course, me. I didn't expect this to happen as I'd never had a French Press explode before and I decided to replace it with a cheap model I found called the Primula. Unfortunately, the Primula is a "get what you pay for" alternative that is cheaply made and broke in about a month. I then purchased a stainless steal option, thinking "This will last forever!" and boy was I wrong. The stainless steel models all suffer from a horrible flaw. Where the plunger contacts the stainless steel interior, as it must, over time, with more and more plungings, the plunger becomes slightly more angled and ends up scraping the side of the interior, harder and harder until stainless steel powder is being scraped from the press every time you make coffee. Essentially, stainless steel models produce a fine metal powder that you end up drinking with your coffee and it only gets worse with time because the interior coating has been stripped and is revealing soft, easily scraped metal with every use. With mine, this scraping actually happened in multiple locations over time until most of the interior diameter, about sixty percent, was being scraped. I thought my coffee was tasting different over time but, being a bit of dummy when it comes to this sort of, "if it was fine when I bought it, then it must still be fine" kind of thinking, I didn't check the unit without liquid in it until it had been happening for months. I re-purposed my stainless steel model (the Il Mulino) and am currently using another glass Bodum while testing pour over gear. It isn't perfect but it probably won't kill you.

This is the second of two I actually purchased (and returned) to replace my old Il Mulino that had developed a scraping point and was producing metal powder I was ending up drinking and, unfortunately, I found the same flaw on the two models I purchased, those tested in friend's homes and those tested in store. If the plunger base (where you find your fine mesh filter on all French Presses) comes in contact with the inner wall of the stainless steel unit at any point, which it will, the ring/rim of the mesh portion of the plunger will scrape the side and take tiny flecks of stainless steel with it, a fine powder of metal that you will be drinking with your coffee, as it is so fine as to easily pass through that metal mesh filter. Cancer, liver failure, dementia, take your pick. You'll be poisoning yourself if you use this or any other stainless steel unit that is not glass lined (and glass linings can crack or break).For the record, this Mira along with the Frieling, Bodum, VonShef and all other stainless steel presses I tested produced a fine powder of steel particles when tested and are not safe to use.Note: All of the French Presses I tried were units that had been plunged again and again and, as a result, had at least one point of contact resulting in scraping and the production of the fine, stainless steel powder. The safest version of the metal I found was a chromium and nickel mix, both of which are toxic in higher than very low milligram doses and are not intended to be ingested as metal shavings. If you have a stainless steel French Press, please check it before each use to make sure it has not developed one or more points of contact where the metal inside is being shaved off into the cup. My old Il Mulino press has been retired to non-food use because, as it turns out, it has a point of contact. The worst offenders, with 100% of the surface of the interior being scraped in this fashion by the mesh/plunger assembly, were the Bodums and the Frielings that I tested, possibly because they are the most popular brands.I was asked by a manufacturer to be clearer on the circumstances of my trying of their unit. To be clear, I found that my Il Mulino was shedding this fine steel dust. I asked two friends, both of whom manage local coffee houses to post a sign asking people to bring in their metal French Presses on specific days. A number of people showed up at each house on each day and we tested all of their units and wrote down the names of the units tested at the time. All units had the same flaw, as all had been used enough to develop it. None were reported to be over two years old and nearly all were reported, by the owners to be less than one year old. Reports of use ranged from "once in a while" to "daily". Not all units had names on them but they were matched based on owner report and pictures on Amazon to the units I have reviewed. I have not reviewed any units that were not seen in person and will not, though I suspect they suffer the same flaw. I will not retract my reviews due to the inconvenience it may cause some manufacturers because this is an issue of the health of the consumer. I only looked at my Il Mulino press because I tested positive for heavy metal poisoning and my doctor specifically asked about sources of Nickel in my home. That press was a source and, very possibly, the source. However, I will reiterate that none of the presses I examined were brand new, all had been used, and all were tested simply by inspecting the carafe, making sure there was no steel dust, pushing and retracting the plunger ten times, then removing it to see if steel dust had been deposited. All units inspected (including many duplicates of two Bodums that I can only review once) had the same steel-dust production problem. I hope this clarifies the issue and puts an end to the not so pleasant messages.As an aside, if you are still reading reviews of stainless steel presses, you may be interested in Kamerod, Hobbie and Anderson's, "Stainless steel leaches nickel and chromium into foods during cooking" from The Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry (J Agric Food Chem. 2013 Oct 2;61(39):9495-501. doi: 10.1021/jf402400v. Epub 2013 Sep 19.) Or perhaps Dan and Ibong's, "IMPACT OF COOKING UTENSILS ON TRACE METAL LEVELS OF PROCESSED FOOD ITEMS" from Annals. Food Science and Technology. These are just two of the more recent articles on this issue. It is well known that the FDA allows higher levels of toxic chemicals in everything from household cleaners to make-up than most developed countries. Unfortunately, this extends to our cookware as well.Good luck with your search and please don't send me hate mail if you own this and disagree with me. My opinion of this item is not meant to offend but to inform.

This one I did not try in a store. It is well known that the FDA allows higher levels of toxic chemicals in everything from household cleaners to make-up than most developed countries. Unfortunately, this extends to our cookware as well.Good luck with your search and please don't send me hate mail if you own this and disagree with me. My opinion of this item is not meant to offend but to inform.

I tried this in a store recently, along with several others, and found the same flaw on all models. If the plunger base (where you find your fine mesh filter on all French Presses) comes in contact with the inner wall of the stainless steel unit at any point, which it will, the ring/rim of the mesh portion of the plunger will scrape the side and take tiny flecks of stainless steel with it, a fine powder of metal that you will be drinking with your coffee, as it is so fine as to easily pass through that metal mesh filter. Cancer, liver failure, dementia, take your pick. You'll be poisoning yourself if you use this or any other stainless steel unit that is not glass lined (and glass linings can crack or break).For the record, the Cozyna and Bodum and VonShef (and all other stainless steel presses I tested) produced a fine powder of steel particles when tested and are not safe to use.Note: All of the French Presses I tried were units that had been plunged again and again and, as a result, had at least one point of contact resulting in scraping and the production of the fine, stainless steel powder. The safest version of the metal I found was a chromium and nickel mix, both of which are toxic in higher than very low milligram doses and are not intended to be ingested as metal shavings. If you have a stainless steel French Press, please check it before each use to make sure it has not developed one or more points of contact where the metal inside is being shaved off into the cup. My old Il Mulino press has been retired to non-food use because, as it turns out, it has a point of contact. The worst offenders, with 100% of the surface of the interior being scraped in this fashion by the mesh/plunger assembly, were the Bodums and the Frielings that I tested, possibly because they are the most popular brands.I was asked by a manufacturer to be clearer on the circumstances of my trying of their unit. To be clear, I found that my Il Mulino was shedding this fine steel dust. I asked two friends, both of whom manage local coffee houses to post a sign asking people to bring in their metal French Presses on specific days. A number of people showed up at each house on each day and we tested all of their units and wrote down the names of the units tested at the time. All units had the same flaw, as all had been used enough to develop it. None were reported to be over two years old and nearly all were reported, by the owners to be less than one year old. Reports of use ranged from "once in a while" to "daily". Not all units had names on them but they were matched based on owner report and pictures on Amazon to the units I have reviewed. I have not reviewed any units that were not seen in person and will not, though I suspect they suffer the same flaw. I will not retract my reviews due to the inconvenience it may cause some manufacturers because this is an issue of the health of the consumer. I only looked at my Il Mulino press because I tested positive for heavy metal poisoning and my doctor specifically asked about sources of Nickel in my home. That press was a source and, very possibly, the source. However, I will reiterate that none of the presses I examined were brand new, all had been used, and all were tested simply by inspecting the carafe, making sure there was no steel dust, pushing and retracting the plunger ten times, then removing it to see if steel dust had been deposited. All units inspected (including many duplicates of two Bodums that I can only review once) had the same steel-dust production problem. I hope this clarifies the issue and puts an end to the not so pleasant messages.As an aside, if you are still reading reviews of stainless steel presses, you may be interested in Kamerod, Hobbie and Anderson's, "Stainless steel leaches nickel and chromium into foods during cooking" from The Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry (J Agric Food Chem. 2013 Oct 2;61(39):9495-501. doi: 10.1021/jf402400v. Epub 2013 Sep 19.) Or perhaps Dan and Ibong's, "IMPACT OF COOKING UTENSILS ON TRACE METAL LEVELS OF PROCESSED FOOD ITEMS" from Annals. Food Science and Technology. These are just two of the more recent articles on this issue. It is well known that the FDA allows higher levels of toxic chemicals in everything from household cleaners to make-up than most developed countries. Unfortunately, this extends to our cookware as well.Good luck with your search and please don't send me hate mail if you own this and disagree with me. My opinion of this item is not meant to offend but to inform.

First, the owner of this carafe brewer is furious with me for not loving it as much as she does. Second, she can't believe I would dare to say that coffee from it is the same as from any other cone because, "It is so elegant, using it is an experience". Well, I'm sorry to say, I don't want an experience. I just want a tasty cup of coffee and, as much as I love you, person who shall not be named in an Amazon review, I found this no better at making a pour over than any other pour over cup. First off, this is a combination of the mug and the cone, whether plastic or porcelain or ceramic or any other kind of pour over cone, that you would use in your standard pour over kit. Second, it is far prettier than any other pour over kit on the market. (There, I admitted it.)In testing this, along with the Melitta plastic "Joe" cone, the Bonavita (a friend's immersion cone that I may have to save up for due to increased strength from full immersion) and a Kalita ceramic/porcelain (didn't catch the material) and a Bee cone, I found this made coffee that tasted identical to the other cones, using the same filters, coffee and pour over "artist" (scare quotes included because I'm no artist compared to the girl that owns this overpriced carafe cone combo). Setting any of the other cones on top of a mug, prepping the filter with pre-wetting and warming with hot water, blooming the grounds and pouring for the same length of time, this was just identical, with one exception. The Bonavita was stronger coffee, owing to the extended brew time from full immersion.For the specific Chemex review, I found it very attractive, of course, but I was terrified of breaking it, not just because I was testing a friend's new Chemex in her kitchen but because it is so insanely expensive and delicate (glass). My BPA free pour over cone produces identical flavor to my ceramic which produces identical flavor to this and the plastic one costs about $6 to replace (the ceramic about $20 and both of mine are Melitta).If you are rich, this is the unit for you, stylish, looks wonderful sitting on the counter next to your favorite pour over, gooseneck kettle, easy to shell out another $60 to replace when it shatters or cracks. But, if you need your money for things like gas in the car and a night out once in a while or, if you are like me, and just need it for medical care, food and a roof over your head, think about what you are getting before you get this.Good luck with your search and please don't send me hate mail if you own this and disagree with me. My opinion of this item is not meant to offend but to inform.

I tried this in store, where I was actually allowed to put water in it (that was nicer than the standard, walk around with it and see if it feels "good" test) and found that the handle, like many others, suffers from a case of form over function. It is pretty, however, the handle is too curved to be comfortable to hold for a two to four minute pour over. Additionally, the handle curves starkly down toward the kettle, keeping your hand closer to the kettle than is desirable when pouring hot water between 175 and 200 degrees. Beyond that, the handle is metal, with no non-slip sheath meaning it conducts heat from the water in the kettle through the wall of the kettle to the handle and to your hand. This fails to pass the two minute pouring test.Good luck with your search and please don't send me hate mail if you own this and disagree with me. My opinion of this item is not meant to offend but to inform.

I tried this in a store. The handle is awful. Because it curves downward, toward the kettle itself, it holds your hand closer to the kettle. After a few seconds, your hand will start to heat up, at least mine did, as this one I was allowed to try with hot water (not boiling) and after only a few more seconds, it became uncomfortably warm and I had to set it down. When a pour over takes at least two minutes, usually closer to four, a kettle must be comfortable for a long period of time. While it does have a nice non-slip grip, that heat issue and the little prong for between your first and second fingers, which also became annoying quickly, makes this a no go.Good luck with your search and please don't send me hate mail if you own this and disagree with me. My opinion of this item is not meant to offend but to inform.

Tried this in a store. Please remember that with a pour over kettle, you will be holding it for a minimum of two minutes, while pouring. While this handle has a nice non-slip grip, it was so uncomfortable, due to the shape, that I couldn't stand it after about thirty seconds, with no water in it. Ask yourself it you can stand that oddly curved handle, everyday, for the next ten years. Yes, it is pretty, but can you use it?Good luck with your search and please don't send me hate mail if you own this and disagree with me. My opinion of this item is not meant to offend but to inform.

Whatever strength you choose, this is a high quality product. Jarrow is a well known brand for quality control so, skipping over that, what you need to know is that this is a dry formula. Because of this, it is more shelf stable. You don't have to worry about ordering this from Amazon or even a marketplace vendor because, as long as the item you receive is sealed and far enough away from expiration, if it was stored at a slightly higher temperature, say the temp in an Amazon warehouse, you don't have to worry about rancidity. Unlike a softgel, the oil in which can go rancid in a hot warehouse within a month, this dry formula will not go rancid and, therefore, it will not cause stomach upset or damage to your liver. This is one of the best options out there in a world of oil-mixed Co-enzyme Q10 softgels, a simple dry capsule.Good luck.

This Ratchet is as described so I won't bore you repeating all of that.Basically, what you need to know is that this is a high quality, heavy ratchet, of the type your father used, with one clear alteration. Instead of having one end, with one ratcheting fitting, you have four, three of which are your standard, most commonly used sizes, the last of which is the coveted screwdriver attachment. In other words, this will work for pretty much anything you can throw at it.It is heavy duty, thick, heavy, so it won't bend when you are using it in a setting requiring a higher level of torque (my last ratchet was pathetic and actually bent rather than force that bolt in that last sixteenth of an inch so I bought this and it had no problem).It has the screwdriver attachment which allows for use of all your standard bits in tight spaces.Ratchet dials are non-slipping, unlike a cheaper, flimsier or mini ratchet, so you have to hold the bit on the back in place when you switch from right to left. In other words, again, it won't slip off of the setting while you are using the ratchet, resulting in a sudden failure of the unit, requiring a reset.Essentially, this is the best ratchet I've ever owned, going back to my first, which was made in the 1940s and used in a Long Beach factory that churned out airplanes in the war, all the way up to the first I purchased, a Home Depot, ten dollar, thin handled, 3/8" model, jumping forward again to several minis and another thin handled model from Lowes. This is just miles ahead of those.The only con here is the temptation to over-ratchet, the same as with any quality ratchet. It works so smoothly, you have to pay attention to that slight tightening you get at the end, when you are supposed to stop turning. With a cheap ratchet, it will often stop working before you get to that point, where you might over-tighten. Boo hoo.Good luck.

No need to prick the egg? Try again. All egg steamers on the market either "require" (how are they going to force us, stomp into our kitchens and scowl?) or "suggest" that we prick each egg with a needle prior to cooking to avoid explosion, all units except for the Chef's Choice Egg Cooker. This unit is marketed with the claim that you should prick or pierce the egg and I decided to test that claim for this and two other machines.I purchased the Chef's Choice Egg Cooker and compared it to the machines of two friends. One bought the Dash-Go (she paid $20) and one has the $60 Cuisinart. Basically, they are all exactly the same, operating on the same principle of filling a base with water and steaming the eggs in order to cook them. Where the difference lies is in the controls and in the "prettiness" of the counter-space sapping device. While the Cuisinart could do more eggs at once, it didn't cook them as well when we did more so we found that six or seven was as many as we would do in that machine so we were back to each machine cooking the same number of eggs and, once again, that issue of pricking the eggs was our greatest concern.And so we tested, six eggs in each, several times. We tried a batch of unpricked in each machine and one or two cracked and cooked outside the shell in each unit.for each of two tests. We then pricked the eggs, using a sewing needle (because the little needle cups they send out with some units get lost so easily that they may as well not even send them) and, low and behold, all batches in each machine came out perfect, that is to say, un-cracked and cooked identically.While on the Cuisinart the flaw was evenness when doing more eggs, with the Chef's Choice, the flaw was the control lever. The instructions on the side of the unit, the timing and selection on that control lever, seemed more of a suggestion than actual instruction. The eggs never seem to come out exactly as the label would suggest and, at least on the machine we tested, the unit had to be set higher in order to cook to the lower level. The Dash-Go was simple and easy to use, cheap in appearance and price, and did the job equally as well.I won't tell you not to get the Chef's Choice or the Cuisinart, if you are in love with the visual design of one or the other (as how a thing looks on your counter can often ruin your day, if it is cheap or the wrong color). However, if you are not desperate to have the exact stainless look of the Chef's choice or the tall egg shape of the Cuisinart sitting on your counter, I strongly suggest that you consider other cheap models first, starting with the Dash Go. The stainless is just a waste of money if you are purchasing it for anything other than appearance.As to the one distinguishing characteristic of the Dash Go that makes it the best, in my opinion, the handle on the Chef's Choice unit is only on one side which can (and does) lead to attempts at lifting followed by immediate dropping. The handles, that's right, there are two, on the Cuisinart, are positioned too close to the base of the lid which leads to steaming of your hands as you open the unit. I found this uncomfortable. The handle. and we're back to one, on the Dash Go is a knob on the top of the dome. All you have to do is lift it off and the handle you are using to do that lifting is as far away from the outflow of steam (coming out from around the rim when you open the unit) as it can possibly be on one of these units. You could even tie a string around it if you wanted and lift it off from even farther away, as it is a shaped knob with a thinner portion below a larger, door-knob portion, allowing for a string if a string be what you need. I found that the knob on the top was adequate to protect my hands from the steam, all by itself.Also, as with all units you should use distilled water, as the bases, like a tea kettle, will become covered in calcium within a few months which is very, very, un-pretty.

The world is under attack, and the only ones to stand up to the villain known as The End are 11 gifted people lead by Sho.  But as they climb, The End has a message, there are traitors in their midst.  Can you fight your way to the top and defeat the enemy, all while weeding out those who will fight you in the end.I enjoyed this game, strategy combat with resource management and the main focus to weed out the traitors before the end.  Now each game the traitors will be random and while one may be a friend on one floor, they could change on another.  I would definitely suggest this for anyone who likes strategy games

Bell has survived his latest adventure and the tricks that Lilly pulled.  Now he is trying to get stronger, but does not have an idea how.  Can the one he wants to catch up to give him some help, and can he survive her training methods?  But Freya still watches from up high, and she has a plan to make Bell hers, using a past encounter to encourage him,.  Can Bell survive this, and if so what will happen to his future as a Dungeon crawler?This was one of the best stories of the lot, with many twist, and the usual humor you come to expect.  I can not wait for the next one and the next season of the anime.

The holiday exams are coming up and Mei is helping Yuzu study, but Yuzu is still thinking about their kiss.  But when an old friend of Yuzu's shows up and causes trouble, can she protect Mei from her machinations and can she figure her out her own heart.This one brings many things out and to a head.  As Yuzu tries to figure out Mei and her heart, she also has to deal with her friend who also has feelings for her.  And at the end, Mei's confession will bring things to a forefront, making fans anxious for the final story.  You will enjoy this if you are a fan of Girlfriends.

The battle for the holy swords begins, as the crazy priest Freed attacks the Occult club and their allies from the church,.
