Tastes good and has a smooth consistency even after refrigerated.  I was concerned it might set up like cement in the fridge after opening (like some organic peanut butters).  It does thicken when cold, but I was able to stir it, even with the tendon problem I have in my hand.

I have a lamp on a low side table.  The top of a regular bulb is nearly blinding when you walk past this lamp.  This bulb is nice and bright for reading in a seated position and eliminates the blinding light when viewing the lamp from a standing position.  I am happy as can be.  The only way I would like the bulb more is if it cost less.  I will update if I have any issues with durability.

I purchased this for my 22 lb, slightly chubby pug.  It fits, but is hard to put on, but easily removed.  It is a vibrant fire truck red.  It looks particularly good on a black pug, and appears to be well made.  I think it will certainly keep my little buddy warm once winter is here.

Purchased for my pug.  I put a small spoonful of peanut butter in each end and it keeps him entertained for about an hour.  It comes in handy when I need him to settle down when he gets too hyper.  He chews on it some, but mostly works to lick out the peanut butter.  For chewing he prefers his Boss Treat Loadable Chew Stick (small).  I purchased the larger size of this DuraChew (the Souper) for my boxer.  The boxer both licks and chews on his DuraChew.  I think this is just a little too hard and large for the pug, compared to his favorite chew toy.  Still, it is well made and well liked by my dog.
Replaced original (2008) battery in my Logitech Harmony 1100 Universal Remote.  Old battery  wouldn't hold up for an evening of prime time television.  This one works great and holds a charge.

This treat loadable rubber chew toy is very hard to find, and it is my pug's absolute favorite toy.  I initially loaded his original Boss Treat Loading Chew Stick's little crevices with hard cat treats, but after he chewed on it a few times, I didn't have to reload it with treats.  He chewed the original one Santa put in his stocking down to a nub.  We finally had to throw it away when it became small enough to be a choking hazard.  I looked everywhere for a replacement, and finally found this one.  The listing said this was Diggers Soccer Ball Dog Toy Vinyl when I made my purchase, but I took a chance that the description and picture were what I was actually purchasing ( The BOSS Treat Loading Chew Stick Toy).  It was and my pug is forever thankful!

Streaming was more expensive ($6) for this movie than other titles.  I had expected to enjoy the movie, and thought I would want to watch it again sometime, it so I ponied up a few more dollars to buy the title.  Big mistake.  I didn't hate the movie, but I don't think I will ever watch it again.  I feel like my upgrade to purchase over rent was just a charitable donation to the fat wallet movie studios.Despite the wild fantasies and the beautiful cinematography, the movie felt slow.  I have read the short story, and the movie is a complete rework and departure from the original.  The audience at our house consisted of three adults and two preteen girls.  The girls one after the other decided to go to bed rather than finish the movie, and both men fell asleep watching the movie.  I was the only person of the five who watched the whole film, and I was far from dazzled.  I wish I had saved my cash and just waited to catch it on cable TV.

If a warranty or customer support is important to you, purchase your faucet from a different seller.I purchased this faucet from Yodel.  The faucet was fulfilled by Amazon.  Shipping was prompt, and item was well packed.  Faucet is beautiful and works great.My complaint is that the description clearly states lifetime warranty.  No warranty information or manufacturer contact information was enclosed.  A manual for a different faucet with very little information was the only documentation enclosed.  I contacted Amazon, who offered a refund and also the contact information for Yodel at yodelsales@gmail.com.  I wrote to Yodel on March 15.  It has been 40 days, and I have still not received a reply.  I wrote to Amazon again on March 31 letting them know that Yodel was unresponsive.  Amazon has been wonderfully responsive, offering refund or discount.  I had already paid a plumber to install the faucet right after receiving it, so a refund isn't a viable option.  I have accepted that my beautiful faucet will likely be a "disposable" faucet should it ever have a problem.If you don't mind having a disposable faucet, I think the faucet is wonderful.  I wish I had bought one like this design years ago.  However, if having a seller/manufacturer stand behind their product is important to you, I recommend buying from someone other than Yodel.

I drew the name of a very caring and giving Christian friend for a Christmas gift exchange.  The man is always sacrificing to help others.  I felt this scripture fit him to a T.  I was nervous about ordering something like this -- afraid it might look cheap.  Fortunately, I was pleased with the appearance of the sculpture once I saw it in person.  The gift recipient, as well as a few other friends who saw it prior to me wrapping it all gave it a thumbs up.

This mascara is clumpy, crumbly, and for lack of another word, gummy.  I bought waterproof hoping to avoid raccoon eyes.  No luck here.  It goes on kind of clumpy, possibly because the brush is so over sized -- and I have somewhat large eyes.  After it dries it takes on a kind of gummy texture and crumbles onto your face and into your eyes, and also smudges under the eyes.  I have tried changing my cleansing routine, powdering my eyelashes, not powdering my eyelashes, but all for naught.  I think this is just a bad product.  I like a "plush" type brush and am looking for a long lasting mascara.  I really like a washable one if I can find one that doesn't smudge over the course of the day.  Any recommendations from fellow reviewers would be greatly appreciated.

This bike folds to fit in a relatively small space.  It seems well made.  I have had it for about a year, and thus far no problems.  Assembly took less than an hour for me working on it by myself.  It is extremely quiet, so you can hear the TV while riding.  The seat is reasonably comfortable.  All in all, I would buy it again.

This was a gift for my dad.  It is a beautiful thing to look at, and it smokes great too.  After visiting and doing some meat smoking with my dad, my brother was so impressed with it, he bought the next size smaller vault for himself.  Assembly was a little bit challenging, but overall not too bad.  It took maybe 30 minutes or so for two men to put it together.
This was a gift for the in-laws.  They have said they love it.  I am considering purchasing one for my bed this winter.

I purchased this when I recently experienced terrible low back pain.  This did provide some relief.  The unit is not as strong as the large "industrial" TENS unit in the chiropractor's office, but it is strong enough for me.  Neither my husband nor I can tolerate it on full strength.  The device offers different levels of strength and different pulsation patterns.  The size fits easily in a pocket or purse.  My husband likes it even more than I do.  I plan to lend it to a family member with MS to see if it can help her with her leg spasms.

I purchased this to use monthly to enhance the finish of my tables.  I have read that Pledge isn't ideal for quality wood furniture, and found this as an alternative.  I polish once a month and then use a very slightly damp cloth followed with a drying cloth to dust in between polishing.  So far this is working nicely.  I apply the polish with a soft shoe polishing brush and buff it off with a lint free cloth.  It buffs to a fairly high gloss.  I have a game table has seen some abuse, and this cream really helps its finish.
Americas Test Kitchen is always guaranteed to satisfy!  My inner geek loves all the research that goes into developing the perfect recipe.  I bought this to complete my collection.
This was a bonus gift I received with my purchase of the Hands to Go TENS unit. (B007R9D34M  The adhesive works well.  My husband likes the unit even more than me.
Good value for the price.  I appreciate not having to buy an entire test kit to get the solutions I needed.

I have to put a towel under the right hand edge of it to keep it from rocking.  It does lie flat on the counter, so I imagine they did not quite customize the board's routing for the outside lip being higher than the center divider of the sink, or perhaps my Kohler sink is defective.  I always have a towel at hand, so it is easy to slip it under the right hand edge.  The towel also acts as a nonslip surface that further stabilizes the board, so I don't mind it at all.  I could probably adhere a small silicone cabinet door bumper to accomplish the same thing, but haven't tried that yet.

My good friend was longing for a pressure cooker, so I thought I would surprise her with an early birthday present.  She says she really likes it.  It is nice looking and has the same footprint as the 4 qt. cooker (which is nice in a small kitchen).  She brought some beans she made in it to a cookout, and they were delicious.  I think it is a good value for the price.
These cost a fraction of what the same number of batteries would cost from my local discount stores.  I have not had them long enough to comment on durability.  I will update if there is any problem.
The hooks work great in my 2013 Ford Edge to hang a jacket or a handbag.  I have only had them since July and I have already lost 2 of the 4 rubber tips.

John Taylor Butcher Block Conditioner appears to protect my Kohler cutting boards from staining.  My Kohler boards are made to fit my sinks, so I want to protect them from damage, especially since one board is no longer available for purchase. I looked at several brands of butcher block conditioner, and this appeared to be the best value, offering quality at reasonable cost.  I am happy with my selection with no regrets.  Unless something changes, when I use this bottle up, I will likely buy this brand again.

My friend has a 1st Gen iPad and her original case was coming apart.  She mentioned it to me, so I started looking to see if the RooCase I had previously purchased for my iPad 1st Gen was still available.  It wasnt, so I did a little research.  This one had good reviews and a reasonable price so we ordered it.  The first one arrived warped and would not fit on the iPad.  It looked like it may have been exposed to high heat.  We sent it back, and Amazon promptly sent a replacement.  It fits perfectly, and she says she really likes it.  She is still using it after almost a year, and it still looks nice.

This was a gift for hubby.  He likes to watch this every so often.  I enjoy it too.  It is a quirky offbeat dark comedy that I think laid the groundwork for future dark comedies.  I love seeing the reversal of roles where Belushi plays straight man Earl to Akroid's over the top Vick.Great for an evening of light entertainment.

A coworker told me about the Victor BlackBox gopher trap recently when I was complaining that our exterminator had retired and the gophers were starting to move back into our orchard.  Other coworkers chimed in to say they were having gopher problems too.  I ordered traps for myself and 4 friends with my Amazon Prime.On my coworkers' recommendation I purchased two.  He told me gophers often have two exits at angles from their mounds.  He told me to use a long screwdriver or similar to poke around in the hole under the mound.  He said there would be little resistance where the underground tunnels are.  He said set the traps at the openings of both tunnels.  For the mound we had, this held true -- we found two tunnels at about 80 degrees from each other.  He also told me to put a leaf or something similar over the top with dirt to cover the mechanism holes to block all light (he said if I used dirt only, it could fall through the holes).An online video recommended putting peanut butter in the trap.  If you have a dog, I don't recommend this.  My dog evidently smelled the peanut butter from afar and dug out the traps.  We had to clean the traps and keep the dog in or under careful watch to keep him from wanting to check the traps again.  I was worried he might get his tongue caught in the trap (think super strong mousetrap).  We were able to catch the gopher just fine without the peanut butter, so if you have a nosey dog that likes peanut butter, leave it off.My husband has only had to use the traps twice since we bought them, but both times they were effective in just a day or two.  I have heard back from three of the four people that ordered traps with me, and all have reported successfully catching gophers.  One also recently reported finding a skunk in his trap -- fortunately it didn't spray anything. That was certainly unexpected!!

Works perfectly for text or web browsing on my Samsung Epic, but if I don't revert to a different input, Swiftkey crashes my email every time.  It happened with the trial, but I liked it so much for texting that I bought it hoping the paid edition didn't conflict with my email.  I didn't get that lucky.  Anyway, I LOVE it for texting using it in the swipe mode.  I just wish it would work with email.  If they can fix this bug I would give it five stars.

I have four Scat Mats now.  Two 30 x 16 inch mats that are approximately 10 years old or so -- given to me by my mom after her cat passed, and two more I have since purchased from Amazon, 48 x 20 inch mat and 12 x 60 inch mat.The old mats still work just like new.  They are grey, while my newer ones are clear. My batteries have lasted over a year now, but I don't use the mats 100% of the time, because I move them around and have "decoys" (see below) that help stretch their effectiveness.Because I work, I cannot always monitor to make sure the pets aren't doing things they shouldn't.  I use a 30 x 16 mat to keep dogs off of the loveseat, and the 12 x 60 mat to keep them off of the couch.  The other 30 x 16 mat has been useful in preventing the housecat from waiting beside the front door in order to dart outside as people enter.  The mats can discharge static through thin fabric, so I put a pillowcase over the mat by the door.  The cat associates the pillowcase with the sensation, allowing me to use the pillowcase as a "decoy" by the door when I want to use that mat to prevent the cat from clawing the carpet at the threshold of a closed off bedroom or jumping on some other surface.  The mat also worked when placed under a relatively thin tablecloth (slightly thicker than a tea towel).  The 48 x 20 inch mat works great to keep cats off of the counter.  I move the mats around on counters and tables so the cats never know when they jump up if they might get a surprise.  This keeps the little mischief makers guessing.The units have a 3 setting lo-med-hi.  I use medium and it is strong enough to get my attention if I forget and touch an activated mat for more than a second.  I would describe it to being similar to dragging your feet on nylon carpet and then touching something grounded like a TV.  It smarts, but isn't life threatening.  The sensation is adequate to keep my headstrong boxer and pug off of the sofas and to keep the cats from miscellaneous mischief.When not in use, I roll the mats up and store them upright in a bin.  I think folding them could damage the delicate wires within the mats.

The movie had good effects but a thin, lackluster plot.  My 10 and 11 year old nieces liked it OK - probably 3.5 stars.  The adults liked it less - more like 2 stars.  I suspect the film came out in theaters with 3D, because much of the action seemed like it was geared for the 3D format.  I wish it would have been one of my free selections on Amazon Prime.  I don't think it was worth the rental $.

When recently using my regular sized bowl #2785 (after discovering I had forgotten it in the back of my cabinets)  I found it didn't seem to chill any better than a regular plastic bowl.  I held it up to strong light and could see that the gel inside appeared to have shrunk and developed dark spots that from what I could see looked like mold.  I wrote to Pampered Chef about the problem.  They replied that it was out of warranty - i.e.:  I was out of luck.  I always hand washed it and it still looks just like new (I even still had the paperwork stored with the bowl).  Pampered Chef  had a good reputation in my opinion, so I was disappointed with their answer.  Considering how pricey this was for what little use I got out of it, I probably won't buy any more of their merchandise.

I didn't even know they made something like this. This is so totally cool! If you (or someone you know) is serious about ping pong, this is a great way to practice. Much like an automatic tennis ball feeder, you can use it to practice your forehand or backhand swings. Kids will also enjoy this for unintended purposes...this is a great little gadget for all ping pong fans!

This vacuum is the bomb. It is best for small homes or apartments but I find myself using it in place of the normal vacuum most of the time. I have never had a cordless vacuum before (at least one larger than a small handheld one) or even thought about getting one but this one is amazing. It takes up virtually no storage room yet is powerful and operates cordlessly for easy movement all around the house. Electrolux is a trusted name in vacuums so I feel confident it will continue to operate as designed for years to come. Yes, it also looks cool. What an awesome little vacuum!

This is a good budget cover. We are using it mostly as a cover to keep out leaves and excess moisture when the cart is not in use. This cover is not as thick and high quality as the type of cover you would want for regular golfing in the rain. We are happy with it but we are essentially using it is a cover while parked. I don't think this is the best cover for golf course use.

Definitely works as advertised on flaky skin. It works as well as expensive powder exfoliants in this regard. I did not see a noticeable difference on smoother skin where there are wrinkles/scars/etc. The price seems a little hefty but I expect that it will go down in the future. Easy to use and store and seems to be made with quality. I like it but I don't love it.

These are NOT made by Lego. These are knockoffs. I hope that Lego and/or Marvel/DC takes action soon to remove these listings but until they do, please do not make a mistake and buy them.Some of you may ask: Why is this a problem? Let me tell you:1. These items are of inferior quality to Lego and many Lego accessories will not work properly with them. These items do not have the fit and finish of Lego items and genuine Lego accessories such as helmets, weapons or hair will either not fit properly or not fit at all. Additionally, in person they do not have the same appearance as genuine Lego items.2. These items willfully violate both Lego and Marvel/DC intellectual property. These items are mass produced in Asia and are currently flooding flea markets and other online sites. They are cashing in while they can before they are shut down by Lego, Marvel/DC and other copyright holders. You may not have a problem with this but we do have laws for a reason whether or not you choose to care about them or follow them.3. These items are sold to many people who think they are getting genuine Lego items at a discount price because at first glance they look so similar to the real thing. They are made with the express purpose to deceive. These items are listed on this site and others using Lego and Marvel/DC copyrighted search terms so that when people search for genuine Lego items they will see these listings as well. This is further proof of the intent to deceive on the part of these sellers.4. These items are getting mixed in with genuine Lego figures in collections and sets which will erode public confidence in the value of these sets going forward. Again, you might not care about this now but years from now when your Lego sets aren't worth much because people have no confidence in their authenticity you just might.These are but a few of the reasons that come to mind. Maybe some or all of these reasons matter to you, maybe they don't. I just want to make sure people understand what they are getting when they purchase these items.Full disclosure: I do NOT work for Lego or Marvel/DC and I have never worked for any company that has any association with the manufacture of Lego or Marvel/DC related items. I have no vested interest in this matter other than my desire to see these knockoffs taken off the market. I am a huge fan of Lego--have been for decades--and it pains me to see that these items are now flooding the market. It pains me to think that some people are getting tricked into buying these items for themselves--or more likely their children--and because of the relatively small price the vast majority of them will not take the time to send them back.I ask you respectfully to please not purchase these items and help perpetuate the already large problem of their existence.

These are fine wrenches when used the right way. I saw another reviewer issue a negative review because they were not good for oil changes. I do not know any mechanics (who work on cars every day for a living) that would want to use a wrench this short to change oil. A long double box end wrench is best for oil drain plugs because they are often put on too tight by inexperienced techs at quickie oil change places. You need the extra leverage that a long wrench provides when you perform oil changes every day. As far as the quality of the wrenches themselves: i would rate the quality as roughly comparable to Craftsman tools. No, these are not Snap-On quality wrenches.The wrenches are fine and will perform admirably when used the right way. What is the right way? First of all, don't use these for oil changes if at all possible. You will drive yourself crazy. Most important: do not use the open end to break bolts free or tighten them down. Use the box end for those tasks. Use the open end for ratcheting the bolt in and out of place. Use the box end only for the first and last part of the tightening/loosening process. The open end is subject to expanding under intense pressure and this will damage the wrench and potentially the bolt as well. This is a fine set of budget wrenches which should last forever if used properly.

Once again we are beyond pleased with the fit, feel and quality of Venum brand Gis. These are clearly the way to go if you are in need of a GI. My husband is beyond thrilled with how "badass" this Elite version is and he is now wearing it to Jiu Jitsu practice in place of his previous Venum brand GI (which is also a fantastic GI). This is a great company that knows how to make martial arts gear the right way. They look nice, feel nice and perform nicely.

Really clever design here. Installation takes literally a minute. This size is perfect for a Roku size box, or you can do what we did and use two of them (one at each end) to hold speakers up above the TV. We waited a while for the perfect product like this to show up and now it's here.

Great little umbrella. We can never have enough small umbrellas for our home and autos. This one is definitely made with a higher quality than your average compact umbrella. Since we usually lose these before we wear them out I am not sure if we will ever know how long this one is built to last, but if anything negative transpires I will return and update the listing.

We have found that Cutter works better than "Off" brand (that's "Off" brand, not "off brand") when it comes to insect repellents. None of these products are fail-safe and they do need semi-regular reapplication if you are outside sweating a lot, however as I said we have used both Off and Cutter and I feel as though Cutter is superior. My only complaint would be that these products are on the expensive side.

It is indeed a very smooth mousepad. I am not sure if I notice an increase in precision movement from the mouse and/or pointer, but I like this mousepad nonetheless. The price is really not that bad so if you need a new mousepad this one will do the job nicely (and possibly better than other mousepads?). The design is also cool.

This is not really my cup of tea (pun intended). I am a big fan of floral teas and I am a big fan of green tea, but this mixture does not impress. The green tea aspect tastes a little bit watered down or overpowered by the floral notes of the jasmine. The jasmine, for its part, is changed into something odd by the green tea presence. It tastes like a quality product and I do think some will like this combination (hence the three stars) but it was not for me. I look forward to trying other offerings from this company.

Compares very favorably to the Otterbox line, and seems to do the job with just a tad less material.The Otterboxes can be very heavy and cumbersome (which is the trade-off if you want full protection) but this seems to do the same job with a little more spring in its step. The price is heftier than the Otterbox, however, so keep that in mind. Bottom line, as far as the advertised purpose it fulfills it perfectly so 5 stars are in order.

First of all the unit functions as advertised. As I have said before, I have yet to have a Seagate drive fail on me during my 2 decades of PC computing. I was a little surprised at how bulky/heavy the unit was; I was hoping for a lighter and smaller unit. This defeats a little bit of the purpose in my opinion; it is easier for us just to pack one of our tiny USB drives for a trip. At home, we already have a standard size wireless backup drive so this one becomes yet another backup for backups. The setup was fairly straightforward and took around 10-15 minutes. We like this unit but it is just a little too narrow or our purposes. As I said it is now just another redundant backup but most people would find this too expensive for that type of usage. Please understand that the item is high quality and works as designed. If you need a somewhat small portable wireless backup drive this should fit the bill nicely.

This is a fun item and I would probably be more enthusiastic about it if it wasn't something that costs $40-$45. We were surprised how light and thin the package was when it arrived. We both remarked that the company has basically found a way to sell a small refrigerator or washing machine box for $40. The thing is, though, if it was one of those boxes it would be much thicker. This thing is very, very thin and light. It is not going to hold up very well long-term. If this only cost $20 or $25 this would be a much better deal. Or, charge $40 or $45 and actually provide double wall cardboard so it would hold up. This is single thickness cardboard that bends very easily. The toddler is happy now but we don't think it will last. For $40 or more we think it should last.

I REALLY hate to write this negative review but this company needs to know that some things are not working.1. The paint quality: The entire item is painted red first and then some of the parts are painted black. This *might* not be an issue except for the fact that the black paint does not bond well with the red paint. This means that the slightest rub up against something causes the black paint to flake off, exposing the red paint below. Initially, we liked this design so much that we ordered 4 more (planning on giving them as gifts) before this first one even arrived. Unfortunately, all of them got here in such a poor condition that we had to return them. Black paint flaked off of the spots, the legs, etc, exposing the red paint below. It looks really bad and we can't give them as gifts anymore. I also can't help but wonder what will become of these when used as feeders if the paint comes off so easily. Animals perching/pecking would surely also make the paint come off, right?2. The box: The problem is that there is none! These items do not come in a box at all! They are just loose with a small paper hang tag for a store rack. Would a $0.10 thin cardboard box or a plastic clamshell really be a big deal for the company? A box or clamshell would help guard against paint loss and also it would make these more attractive to give as gifts.The bottom line is this: these are really cute and really clever design-wise. This is why we initially ordered 4 more on top of this one. It is a crying shame that both issues have rendered them useless to us. I would like the company to please post a response when they have corrected these issues so that we can order them again.

These taste great. As a cookie, they succeed well. As a nutritious item they are not bad, but they aren't great either. There is only 1 gram of fiber per bar/cookie. The 4 grams figure assumes you are eating 4 cookies. They are very stiff so they break easily so they are not good to eat in the car because you will end up with crumbs all over your outfit. I am giving them 4 stars because they taste great but just know what you are getting: you are getting brittle cookies.

I have many thoughts/observations on this machine so I thought I would group them primarily in the form of a pro/con list:Pros:1. The machine is insanely fast; so fast it doesn't even seem to be breaking a sweat. The fan noise is always at a bare minimum no matter what task is being performed. I would compare the level of fan noise to what I recall  the level of noise being in a MacBook Pro; the fan noise is just barely audible. This laptop is replacing my Acer 17" 2.3GHz i5 with 8GB of ram (which I will mention for comparison a few more times) which is far, far noisier in comparison. I didn't even realize how noisy the Acer was until I started using this machine; it's a huge difference. File transfer is also super fast with the combination of a SSD and USB 3.0 ports.2. The weight is not as bad as I expected given that this is a "desktop replacement" laptop. My old Acer (which I never found heavy) weighed a little over 6 1/2 pounds; this one weighs a little over 7 pounds. So, not a huge difference for me. This is not even in the parking lot of the MacBook Air ballpark so if you need something that light you are looking at the wrong machine.3. There is a 256GB PCIe SSD installed as well as a 1TB mechanical hard drive. The nice thing here is that there is an available empty PCIe bay open so that you can install an additional PCIe drive (or PCIe card of another type perhaps?) if you wish. You could also replace the spinning platter drive with an SSD so you could theoretically have THREE discrete SSD drives in the same machine! Pretty impressive. You are limited to one SSD in every MacBook Pro currently offered.4. The built-in speakers are a quantum leap forward for laptop speaker sound quality. They are far and way the most amazing and powerful laptop speakers I have ever heard.5. The case is built like a tank and is not garish looking in any way. There are several different lighting schemes available so the machine can either look like a normal laptop without any lights or you can let your freak flag fly and allow multicolored lights of your choosing to shine from where you want them to shine from.Now for the cons. I hope you can learn from my mistakes and save yourself a lot of time and heartache. And before you call me an idiot who doesn't know what they are doing, please keep in mind that I am a former certified Apple technician and I used to own my own computer repair business. I have extensive experience with Apple and PC computers. So, the cons:1. The machine arrived with a tiny loose part rattling around inside. I hope that Dell/Alienware reads this so they can improve their quality control process. It's not the end of the world except for the fact that this machine costs $2K. I think the average person spending that much on a machine would hope that there would be no rattling when they opened the box. I wouldn't care myself except for the fact that if it is a small metal part that is loose inside it could set up a possible situation where a circuit board gets shorted out. So, I decided to take off the bottom ram/hard drive cover and see if I could shake it out of the bottom before turning on the machine. Sadly, I never could get the part to shake out of the bottom. The part is somewhere on top of the motherboard and I never could get it to move around to the bottom so I could get it out. I hope that it never becomes an issue in the future. This brings us to point number 2...2. The bottom ram/hard drive cover is insanely difficult to remove. I proceeded very carefully, patiently and gingerly but was still unable to remove the cover without breaking off one of the plastic tabs and slightly warping the cover. After reinstalling the cover it no longer sits perfectly flush with the bottom of the machine. I am just going to have to live with that I guess. In any event, here is the proper procedure for removing the cover: First (obviously) remove the two small Philips head screws. Then carefully snap that section of the cover off/upwards. The next part is where it becomes tricky. There are several remaining tabs, some of which are meant to be snapped upwards and some of which are meant to slide out backwards and not snap out. So, you need to always be attempting to slide the cover backwards as you pull upwards. This is very difficult to perform just right (in fact so difficult that I couldn't do it successfully without breaking something). I really wish that this this design had been rethought before the final production stage.3. The machine does come with a minimum of bloatware, but the software it does come with can be quite frustrating at times. I want to focus on two of them in particular. It comes with a very high-strung and controlling program that is supposed to fine-tune the performance of the wireless and wired networking cards. It is supposed to deliver the fastest internet speeds in a variety of conditions. I found this software to be cumbersome and counter-productive. Example: it will stop you from opening a new web page while a file is downloading. There are many setting you can play with but I opted to remove the software altogether. This is where the trouble started: the software can not be removed without removing all of the drivers for all of the networking cards. So, I learned this the hard way and had to reinstall the programs after I found that the networking cards were rendered driver-less by its removal.4. The second piece of software I had a problem with was the proprietary light scheme software. This is the software that controls the color and the location of the lighting on the laptop. As I alluded to before, the available lighting would make the lighting technician of a Phish or Grateful Dead concert blush. You can choose a wide array of colors and you can shine them from virtually any and every part of the laptop in any kind of combination or array that you wish. This feature is not important to me so I turned all of them off. That would be great except that my punishment for depriving the machine of its desire to put on a light show is a really annoying pop-up that I have to click on EVERY TIME I restart the machine that informs me that I have all of the lights turned off AND reminds me that I can turn them back on any time I want to. I have to click on an "x" in order to close this pop-up every time. Is this really necessary? UPDATE: I found a Windows setting that blocks messages from this program so I no longer have to see these.As you can probably tell from my star rating, the pros of this machine FAR outweigh the cons. I list the cons in order to be thorough, not to nitpick. I also hope that Dell/Alienware might learn something from them. So far, i really love this machine and I am sure that I am only just beginning to realize its potential. Given the choice between this machine and a MacBook Pro with a comparable MSRP, I would choose this hands down.

First of all, the diapers do their primary "collection" job well (I will let you guess at what I mean by that). These diapers are also easy to put on and take off. These diapers specifically are engineered to make it easier for the baby to move around in. By this age (presuming your baby is size 4) they are moving around a lot and most are walking. This (the flexibility) is what makes these diapers truly excellent. The price is also relatively competitive vs other brands so I can't say a single negative thing about these diapers.

The book and sound/light features are somewhat limited but our 19 month old does not seem to notice or care--he is loving every minute of playing with this toy. He has been playing with it off an on for the past several days, much more than with his existing toys. So, this could be because it is new to him or maybe it is just that awesome of a toy; I'm not sure. In any event, he is enjoying himself so I guess it is a good toy.

This mount is just great. Most importantly of all, they use a high-quality adhesive that sticks strong and hard and doesn't come off. Furthermore, the angle can be adjusted and locked into place with the screw knob. The whole device is made with an OEM standard of quality. This little guy is just awesome and it made my most recent long trip much better.

I think some of the people who are criticizing this movie may have missed the point. In my opinion anyway, this is not a film about music school or the mechanics of drumming. I have not been to music school and I am not a drummer but I am sure the film gets several things wrong about both. Music school is merely the backdrop--and drumming is merely the conduit--to tell a story about excellence and the pursuit of greatness.The real story of this film is this: what are you willing to do to be--or try to be--great? What are you willing to do in the pursuit of excellence?The film examines what one young man is willing to do in that pursuit, as well as what lengths his teacher is willing to go to in order to drag him there. If you allow this film to grab ahold of you and take you along for the ride (as I did), you might just find (as I did) that the result is an inspirational story that sticks with you for days and weeks after seeing it. The film challenged me to think about excellence and how much I am willing to invest in its pursuit. It also challenged me to think about many of my past and present life choices. Yes, for me this film was that powerful. Not many films are this powerful.And yes, it was also quite entertaining and surprisingly hard to guess where it was going. Additionally, it was relatively clich-free. It is one of the best films I have seen in the past few years.

People regularly tell me that they hate country music. I tell them that there are two types of country music: modern/pop country (not actually country music) and real country. Modern country music is simply pop music with a slide guitar riff or twang added faintly in the distance so as to "legally" qualify as country music. This band plays real country. There is a heavy folk influence so it is not exactly "country and western" but it is real country nonetheless. Please support real country music by buying this awesome CD or going to see them live. They are on tour right now.

The cream seems to do what it says it will do. I remain somewhat skeptical about products like these in the long-term but in the short term it seems to make the skin look and feel smoother. The price is quite high so I am also somewhat concerned about that but I suppose if this works for you then you are willing to pay the price. I do find that as a moisturizer it works quite well. Maybe this is really the key to helping the skin seem smoother and a little less wrinkly. In any event, I am happy with the product but as I said I do have concerns about the high price and long-term effectiveness.

We love all of Barilla's products and this one is no different. The pasta tastes great, cooks up right every time, and is about as healthy as this type of pasta can be. We never have to wonder with Barilla if we are getting quality ingredients that taste great. 5/5 stars.

We love all of Barilla's products and this one is no different. The pasta tastes great, cooks up right every time, and is about as healthy as this type of pasta can be. We never have to wonder with Barilla if we are getting quality ingredients that taste great. 5/5 stars.

I like case logic's products generally but this one has a very narrow purpose. Basically, if you want a backpack to hold your laptop, your tablet and a few other small-ish items then this is for you. What this is NOT: a backpack to hold your laptop and DSLR, your laptop and school books, your laptop and clothes for a trip. As I said, this has a narrow purpose; just your laptop and a few other small items. I usually need a larger backpack for this purpose or else I just carry my laptop in a small laptop only case. Anyway, as long as you know what you are getting you should be happy.

You simply won't find a more sturdy and professional looking folding office table. This is a multipurpose table that could serve as a desk for seminars/classes or it could serve as a wall table to hold printers, food or food supplies, etc. The price is hefty but this is no el-cheapo folding table that you would buy at a discount store. This is truly professional grade. This might be useful to some people: this table is extremely heavy.

Always the best quality from Barilla. The pasta cooked up easily and tasted great with meat sauce. It's nice to know that getting a serving of vegetables is o easy, too. With tomato or meat sauce I doubt anyone would complaint about the taste, but frankly we liked the taste of these noodles on their own. 5/5 stars.
This remote is far from universal. If you have a late model major brand garage door then you will probably be happy but this did not work with a 20 year old Overhead Door motor.

These labels fail at both tasks that I need a shipping label to perform. First of all, they do not stick very well at all. They stick only slightly better than a plastic window cling sticker sticks to glass. Second of all, in my laser printer (late model Brother with Brother brand toner) they fail to maintain the printed text. So if you rub even gently with your finger across the address it starts to flake off. I had a package returned to sender before I realized this. Unfortunately, it seems that you get what you pay for and I guess I am going to have to splurge for Avery labels after all which I hate to do (they are way too expensive).

Another great network device from Linksys. The wireless speeds are as fast as a wired connection; I can't tell any difference. Setup is as easy as one can expect from any router (basic to intermediate computer skills needed). The router is providing wireless internet to every device in the house flawlessly and a printer is also on the network working fine. No complaints. 5/5 stars.

I like the design of the stand that mimics iMacs and Apple displays from the last 10 years or so. It would be nicer if the case matched the stand but I guess due to the nature of the material black was needed as the primary color. The charging works perfectly as expected. This is a neat gadget if you are looking for this sort of thing.

This is a top of the line Blu-Ray disc player. You won't find a better picture from another player if you try. That being said, it is disappointing that a Blu-Ray player sold in 2014 does no have WiFi built-in an does not have the ability to play Netflix an Amazon instant video. If you are purely after a fantastic Blu-ray picture quality, you can't do any better. If you are going to be adding this to a decked out Pioneer rack system then this is the way to go. I'm not sure if this is the best standalone player, however, due to the lack of Wifi and streaming services.

The scale is sleek, stylish, sturdy and best of all it is very easy to store out of view. I'm not sure if it has the accuracy of a 30 pound steel Healthometer scale but i seems accurate enough. The 400 pound limit means there is plenty of breathing room. 5/5 tars.

A nice set of measuring spoons. the best part has to be the half tablespoon. If you d any amount of regular cooking you will know that many recipes call for a half tablespoon. My old set of measuring spoons didn't have this size, but this set does. Nice little set!

As they say, it's dead simple to use. It seems to be sturdily built and delivers a nice even spray. This is a good household sprayer for light occasional use; this is not a professional grade sprayer. Cleanup was fairly simple, as far as these go. This is a great sprayer for decks which is what we used it for. We have not yet tried it indoors.

This is an amazing set. It ended up being much larger and amazing looking in person than I expected. It even comes with a mounting string on the back to hang it on the wall between use. The US map puzzle is a must have for anyone with small kids and this one is beautiful an large. 5/5 stars!

I guess Mr Coffee has finally decided to chase the high-end coffeemaker market. This is a massively advanced and over-engineered coffeemaker that is, well, simply awesome. The looks are on-par with high-end coffeemakers sold at high-end kitchen stores. You are welcome to brew a standard pot of coffee the standard way if you wish, but this machine is also programmable and controllable with your smartphone. So, you can start the machine working from your bed when you wake up, not at a pre-decided-upon time that you programmed in the night before. This machine will please just about any hip and discriminating home coffee brewer.

Top-notch Canon scanning and printing quality. The latest wireless technologies and the old standby wireless technology. High quality physical build and stylish looks. This might be the best all-in-one color inkjet you can buy. If there is a nicer one I have not yet seen it. The bottom line: another pro-sumer home run from Canon.

The perfect assortment of Nutri-Grain bars. You get 6 of each of the key flavors. If they make other flavors I am not aware of them, but these are all the flavors my household is interested in. You get 16 each of Strawberry, Blueberry and Apple. These are delicious bars which are great for breakfast or a snack on the go or a light/healthy dessert. 5/5 stars!

Super high-quality construction; probably higher quality than needed. Works exactly a designed. I cut off the covers because they seem to just get in the way and I can't remember the last time no having a cover for a car outlet was an issue. 5/5 stars.

We own two first generation Ionic Breezes from Sharper Image, so that is pretty much all we have to compare this unit to. Our thoughts are this: this unit does a better job of filtering than the Ionic Breezes. So, if filtering is your primary concern this unit should do a better job. The downside is this: the Ionic Breezes are virtually silent. This unit is not silent. If that is a problem for you then you need to look back at the Ionic Breezes. Holmes is a company that I used to look at as a low-end company but they have been making higher quality products as of late, so that is good.

It's a nice case. It works in every way that it is designed to work. My only complaint would be that the gloss finish does get scratched/scuffed fairly easily. I think a matte finish would have been better. It's a great card/case, however, as long as you don't case about a scratched finish.

A nice addition to the ever-growing line of castle/fantasy-related Playmobil toys. The LED lights are cool but the price does seem a tad high, especially since only one figure is included. I think 2-3 figures should have been included for the price. Typically high-quality German engineered toys, however.

This case strikes a good balance between having little or no case and having a full-on Otterbox. If you were looking for a case that occupies this sweet spot, then look no further; it's the perfect case for you. The design is somewhat masculine but some women will obviously not care about this. Bottom line: a strong functional case that doesn't add the kind of weight to the phone that the Otterbox does.

This is super high quality packing tape. We are heavy users of packaging materials so we use all types of packing tape. You won't find better tape than this. it is super strong and it is crystal clear. This is truly top of the line packing tape.

This is a neat little device, albeit for a very narrow audience. As other have basically said, don't expect to dump a box of milk bones into the hopper. The items need to be fairly small and fairly uniform in size (the rounder the better!) I am also concerned that the dog is not going to associate the treat with us since the treat is not coming from our hands...Anyway it's a neat gadget for remote treat dispensing, just make sure you need a device like that and have a treats to load that are dryish, smallish and roundish.

This is a cool book, but I do think it is more for expert builders. I don't think the very young or intermediate Lego robotic enthusiasts are going to get a lot out of this book unless they really apply themselves. We own the 2nd edition Lego robot but we will be getting the EV3 this holiday season if Santa sees fit. I look forward to putting the book through its paces more comprehensively at that point (and will return later to update this review) but an initial skimming of the book shows a fairly complicated and technical-heavy experience. The average Lego enthusiast under 13 is going to have a hard time with this book. This book is clearly intended for people who want to take the EV3 experience to a higher level.

I read this on Kindle and would like to briefly comment on that before the book review.  This book is perfect for the Kindle. There are footnotes but they are references only and come at the end of each short chapter.  Many of the references are to her own books (I think On the Political and Hegemony and Socialist Strategy are mentioned and cited in every chapter) and so do not have to be looked at after the first chapter.  The only reason not to buy this on Kindle would be if you could find a cheaper paperback.The opening chapter of this 2013 book lays out the groundwork of her theories of agonistics, hegemony, the political, etc.. The following chapters discuss the applications of that theoretical framework to international relations, the European Union, the current political situation (which she sees as dominated to the Neoliberalism of Thatcher/Reagan and what she calls post-Fordist capitalism), and how the arts might contribute to the struggle against the current Neoliberal hegemony.  The final chapter of the book is an previously published interview wherein she goes over the basic arguments again and gets to add one or two more insights.I am somewhat swayed by her thinking but I also have lots of qualms about it so I think I will initially just try to give a quick summary of the first chapter, suggest one or two problems I have with it and then someone on Amazonia can further educate me in the comments.I see her thinking as a reaction to the work of Carl Schmitt, Antonio Gramsci and Jacques Derrida. And that, my friends, is a yeasty dough.  Chantal Mouffe (hereafter CM) believes that individual identity is socially formed and is grounded in the passions.  We create our identities as part of an Us that is defined in opposition to a Them.  These identities have some rational component but they are largely affects. As per Schmitt, they all too frequently end up as a Friend/Enemy polarity that results in violence.These identities are maintained by hegemonies that serve particular power relations that are played out in the economic/social forms of our societies.A lot of CM's polemics come out of that basic line of thinking.  Liberals like Rawls have gone wrong because of their focus on the individual instead of the social nature of that individuality.  Rawls and Habermas have both gone wrong because of their rationalism: they believe that our disagreements can be ultimately resolved. CM, like Schmitt, asserts that the affective grouding of our identities renders that hope utopian.  We frequently are dealing with issues that are not resolvable but are true either/or choices.  In the US, abortion remains one of those issues.  We sometimes are faced with issues that seemingly can only be resolved through violence and forcing one side to change.  Again from the US, the antebellum period of our history is a good example.  From the Missouri Compromise until the Civil War, one issue after another became so poisoned by the overarching issue of slavery that the war began to seem inevitable.But this is where CM breaks from Schmitt.  She believes there is a continuum that issues lie on that ranges from the easily resolved to the violently antagonistic.  But toward the middle and there latter end is the region of agonistics- the region where struggle is meaningful, between two hegemonies contending to win out but still constrained by institutional rules and by mutual acknowledgement of each others right to contend.  This is what she calls the political.  Because this is the contention of hegemony and counter-hegemony, this is a passionate and meaningful struggle. Hegemonies are not just ways of thought, they are ways of acting, of creating in the world. I believe in abortion, marriage rights and the right of the public to constrain corporations.  Many of my friends do not.  What we contend about determines what we, our friends and our children will be able to do in their future lives.For CM, the realm of the political is the realm of meaningful (and never-ending) struggle that eschews violence.Her problem with the current world situation is that the Neoliberal hegemony has increasingly limited the political options to the point where it doesn't really matter who is in office.  This results in a indifferent attitude to politics as practiced. Enter our old friend, The Return of the Repressed.  That passionate need for communal identity starts to seek other forms of expression.  CM feels this has resulted in the rise of New Right parties in Europe, in the rise of identification with fundamental religions and with the occasional angry but aimless explosion of violence that England and France saw a few years back.My major qualms with this line of thought are three-fold.  I think that the distinction between agonistics and antagonistic politics is much harder to maintain than she tends to suggest.  Every period of European history (or American) where the choices were that real and that important were periods of violence.My second problem is the idea of the Neoliberal hegemony.  CM is very good in stressing the pluralistic nature of the counter-hegemony.  That would be a sight of contestation as well with many different POVs being stressed and balanced. But so is the Neoliberal hegemony.  It too is a sight of contestation where (in the US) the oil money if contending with the tech companies and the financial markets are messing with them both while defense industries still think the US government needs to give them more of our tax dollars.  The parts of her book where she discusses Neoliberalism and post-Fordism were among the least convincing to me.My final question is a philosophical one-What is the basis for CM's assertion that identity is always "implies the establishment of a difference"? Why cannot social identities continue to be more and more inclusive without having to be pluralistic?  Is a passionate politics based on the idea of our humanity impossible?But those issues are as much about me as about her thinking.  I learned much from her book.  Not least, she aroused my interest in the contemporary political situation in South America.  She also has some interesting thoughts about Badiou, Negri and Hardt.  All in all, very much worth reading, thinking about and discussing.

Since I read this on my Kindle, the first part of my review will address briefly reading it in that format.  The second part will review the book itself.This book is well-Kindlelized with an active index and easy transition back and forth to the footnotes. The major issue is the ease of getting back and forth to the references as these are at the end of each chapter.  Overall I found this an easy book to read in this format.This series of books published by Routledge is intriguing in format.  The idea is to present an thinker such as Ranciere, Badiou or Castoriadis and to introduce/comment on their work by having a group of scholars write short essays centered around the concepts/themes of those thinkers.  For an author like Castoriadis who developed not only his own terminology, e.g. magma, teukhein and legein, as well as put his own characteristic spin on more common words, e.g., autonomy and democracy, such an approach proves very useful.The book focuses on Castoriadis major work, The Imaginary Institution of Society (IIS), and could easy be used as an introduction/guide to that demanding read. For the most part it ignores his earlier, more activist writing (with the exception of the entry on Democracy). It is also a useful intro to some of Castoriadis' later writings translated into English as Figures of the Thinkable, World in Fragments and Philosophy, Politics, Autonomy (I can recommend the latter as a good Castoriadis' starter book).Finally, it serves as an intro to some of that community of scholar/activists who have devoted themselves to working out some of the issues of Castoriadis' thought. Suzi Adams, Johann Arnason, Mats Rosengren, Karl Smith, Ingerid Straume all struck me as worth more of their own work.All in all, for anyone interested in ISS or in Castoriadis as a whole, this is a very helpful read.

The first part of this review will be about the experience of reading the book on the Kindle.  The second part will be about the book itself.I do not recommend the Kindle edition due to several decisions of the publisher and the author.The first problem is the author's decision to not enumerate his footnotes but simply to throw them all in a great lump at the end of the book.To find any one reference, it is necessary to go throw that lump looking for the first and last word of the passage and hope that you see it.Even divided up by chapter, this makes the footnotes tedious in any format but especially so on the Kindle.Secondly, there is the decision by the publisher not to format the index for the Kindle but to suggest instead that you just use the Kindle's search function to look up the "searchable terms".  Doesn't really work for phrases like "disenfranchisement of African-Americans".The Kindle version is paginated except, for some reason, the conclusion.Finally, this book has some nice illustrations which are hard to see on the paperwhite.Overall, if this is a book you want to learn from and put to scholarly use, by all means buy the paperback.As for the book itself, I found it oddly disappointing.  I am a big fan of Lear's previous book, No Place of Grace, and was looking forward to this one.  I agree with many of his interpretations of the period but I found the book to be repetitive, over-reaching and idiosyncratic.  Careful perusal of the footnotes indicates that much of his interpretation is based on secondary sources instead of original research.  I am okay with that but I think that Lears is capable of really good original research and is good at locating quite useful original sources.For example, toward the end of this book, he discusses a novel of Colonel House's, Phillip Dru, which Lear discusses to good effect. I also find many of his insights (even if drawn from the secondary literature) to be illuminating.  For example, Lear's various discussions of the tensions with the Progressive movement between its local versus it national manifestations or between "populism vs. expertise, producerism vs. consumerism, statutory vs. administrative regulation" (p. 309).Lear is also careful to keep before us the various peoples who paid the price for standing between us and our manifest destiny, e.g., the Plains tribes, African-Americans, Cubans, Mexicans and all the 'dark Others' (Lear's phrase) that we climbed over on our way to civilizing the world.I guess my complaint has to do with what I see as Lear's over emphasis on the cultural aspects of the period and an under-development of the economic aspects.Finally, his Bibliographical Note is worth a deep dive for Lear's appreciative discussion of his sources.Overall, a pretty good book but not one that should be read in conjunction with others on the period.

Kindle review:This book has been fairly well kindlized with some important exceptions.  The footnotes work well going back and forth.  The maps are fairly useless unless you look at them on your PC or you have far better eyes than mine.  There are plenty of data tables which are inserted in the text more or less where they need to be.  But there is no clear separation from the text so the transition to and from the tables can be jarring.  This is true also of the 'portraits'- very short biographies of major figures that are interspersed throughout the text and which can be quite interesting.Finally, the book has an index which the publisher has made no attempt to kindlize. Since the publisher also chooses to offer the book without page numbers the index is useless in the Kindle format.  When will publishers appreciate that the more they adapt their publication for electronic formats, the more they will make that format attractive to readers?Overall Kindle (paperwhite) reading experience- 3 stars.The book itself is worth about two to three stars.  I am obviously somewhere in between the two previous reviewers.  I think DiScala does a great job up until WW2 considering the likely audience for the book- college students looking for an entrance to modern Italian history or the lay reader looking for something not too scholarly.And now a personal complaint that may be more about me than DiScala-  There are no footnotes, not even for quotes.  I hate this trend in scholarly works. DiScala provides a very good annotated bibliographic essay that covers every section but there is no way to know who said what unless he (very) occasionally decides to identify the source in the text.  This alone accounts for my downgrading the rating from three stars to two.  If that sort of lazy scholarship is okay for you then consider this a three star review.DiScala does a good job quickly sketching the European context for Italian history throughout the early parts of the book.  He also does a good job talking about the influence of the Catholic church on Italian politics and society.  This part of the book (which takes up five of the six parts or about 5/7ths of the text) can be recommended unless you want to get petty.The last part of the book however is a bit of a mess, at least, to me.Now let me be honest.  As a self-critical reader, I have long noted that when I am reading something that is coming from a POV quite different than my own, that it is far easier to note all the assumptions the author is making and all of the rhetoric they are using than when I am reading something that I agree with fundamentally.I suspect DiScala's politics to be to the right of mine and therefore my hermeneutic when reading this book is more suspicious than generous.  For example, around location 4690, (the first paragraph of Chapter 16) he states that "excessive liberty and the economic and social effects of the [WW1]" help explain the rise of fascism.  Whenever I read a phrase like "excessive liberty", I want a darn good explanation of what that means.  All DiScala offers is the assertion that "Italians probably enjoyed more civil liberties than the citizens of most European countries and the United States". No evidence of any kind is offered in support.Another example from around location 5593 (the chapter entitled WWII and The Resistance):"Journalist Giampaolo Pansa has claimed that the Communists exploited their military superiority and the chaos following the war's end to kill thousands of non-Fascist Resistance fighters in order to eliminate as many rivals as possible for the future political control of the economy."There is no other reference than just the statement of one journalist, there is no reference to that journalist's writing that contains that assertion, there is nothing at all to back it up.  Even if it were true (and I suspect it is at least partially true) this is not scholarship.  This is not teaching by example how to write history.One more example, this one exemplifying how you can editorialize while pretending to just state facts. This is from Location 6126 and is toward the end of the chapter entitled "Years of Lead": [Referring to the PCI, the Italian Communist Party]"Despite declared PCI autonomy from Moscow, many Italians were still unwilling to entrust PCI members with power".  Always be on your guard when someone asserts, "Many people believe.." or "Some experts think..."  They are almost always euphemisms for "I think or believe this but I don't want to be bothered with proving the point".  Again- this is not history.The worst part of all this is that sometimes DIScala has an interesting tale to tell. I found his telling of the scandal of the early 1990s that was perhaps even more impactive than Watergate on American politics to be fascinating.  I have the feeling that DiScala could write a far more coherent history than he has in this book.Overall recommendation: Read it in the paperback if read it you must.  I have a copy of Martin Clark's history of Modern Italy which I will read soon and review.  I can only hope it is stronger. One caveat: If you are more of a centrist in American politics or, may the Dog (Anubis) help you, a Reagan Republican, you may enjoy this book far more than I did.  You will definitely find your politics more in line with the author and that's okay.  The good thing about democracy is that we get to work at least some of this stuff out at the polls.  See you there, my fellow citizens.

I agree with the assessment of the other two reviewers but I thought this book deserved a little more of a descriptive review.Razmig Keucheyan (hereafter RK) starts his book with the assertion that contemporary critical theory is a reaction to the defeat of leftist movements in the 1980s. RK's assessment is that the triumph of the Reagan-Thatcher brand of neo-liberalism, the capitalist turn in China, the fall of the Soviet Union and the rise of Islam as a modern political alternative demonstrated the inadequacies of critical theory up until the 1980s.The tasks of a renewed critical theory are three-fold as I read RK.  There is a need for a new theory of the system or the ontology we are critiquing.  The capitalism of classical Marxism has failed to develop as predicted and badly needs to be re-theorized.  What is the nature of capitalism at the current time? Is the nation-state still the locus of political power or are there trans-national entities that are as oppressive?  Can we understand the current international scene as exemplifying a form of imperialism and, if so, what kind?Is it necessary to address the diffusion of power throughout our lives and cultural experience or is political power the necessary focus of change?RK addresses these questions in Chapter 4 on System by looking at thinker like Hardt and Negri, Panitch, Cox, David Harvey, Benedict Anderson, Jurgen Habermas, Etienne Balibar, Giorgio Agamben and many others.The second major theme RK explores is who is to be the revolutionary subject.  One of the predictive failures of classical Marxism has been the development of the working classes.  RK cogently argues that we must re-theorize critical subjectivity and the relationship between the individual/citizen/outsider/indigene and the critical intellectual.  RK examines the work of Ranciere, Badiou, Zizek, Haraway, Butler, Spivak, Linera, Honneth and others to suggest the way that feminism, native indian movements in South America and ideas about equality and conflictual identities all argue for a broadening of the debate about what the left is trying to achieve and with whom.Which leads to RK's third theme- the need for critical intellectuals to actually engage in political movements and to let their theorizing to develop out of that experience. As we are involved in the actual work of political change, as we come to represent the needs of more and more different kinds of people perhaps then we can begin to theorize an overall subject who is both particular and inclusive.  And as we understand more of how various system impact the live of various types of people, perhaps we will then develop a more systematic theory of how power is wielded.One sign of hope for RK is that the intellectuals who are critical theorists are increasingly non-European or North American. The emergence of theorists from South America, Asia and Africa allows for the emergence of new experiences being brought to bear on critical theory and its relevance.  RK talks occasionally about the political history of Bolivia all of which was a revelation to me.Overall this book has many strengths.  There are terse cogent discussions of somewhere between thirty and forty thinker which serve to orient the reader to further reading.  There are also some wonderful thoughtful observations throughout the book. Consider the following:"...the incorporation of Gandhian precepts into a new strategic reason would make it possible to grasp the fact that violence not only always has a human and social cost, but also adversely affect the very identity of those who use it.  This idea, claims Balibar, is foreign to Marxism, who conception of violence was mainly tactical, not ontological" p. 253.We are what we practice.  The habitual becomes our ontology.  This is a nice insight and essential to keep in mind.RK has some weaknesses as well.  He is a sociologist and so occasionally gets the philosophy or the history wrong.  But these are minor problems that an editor or a good reader should have caught.It is also pretty obvious who he admires and doesn't admire among his discussed theorists.  No one should rely on this book for an introduction to Habermas. But it is hard not to catch his enthusiasm for David Harvey.My major problem with the book is his discussion on feminism.  I am not a fan of Donna Haraway and wished he had used almost any other thinker instead of her.  He apologizes for not being able to further discuss feminism for reasons of space. But if you are going to talk about creating a new critical subjectivity, you had better be willing and able to take a long deep dive into feminist theory.  No other theory goes as deeply into how power and the possibility of violence is expressed in our daily lives.In spite of this flaw, RK's book is successful.  I have great admiration for writers who can some up a thinker in eight to ten well written pages. To do it with this many thinkers is really impressive.  I also believe his overall analysis sets the right course for the further development of critical theory.I would love to hear what others who have read the book think. Please educate me in the comments.

This book is a bit odd.  It manages to mix good historiography with poor.  It has an obvious agenda, to wit, to argue for the world historical importance of Samuel Champlain.  It sometimes borders on an historical novel based on a naive approach to historical sources.  And yet it all seems to work and largely convinces the reader (or at least me) that Champlain was a very unusual and important man.I will leave the charms of the book to the other reviewers and write to three points in what follows: 1. The experience of reading it on a Kindle, 2 some of the issues of the historiography and 3. my assessment of Fischer's viewpoint of Champlain based on his dealings with the American Indians.Do not buy this book for the Paperwhite.  The maps are unreadable and the illustrations are myriad shades of grey.  It might work on the Fire or on you computer but it doesn't work well on the smaller models. It is well-kindelized for the footnotes. The extensive bibliography is hard to get around in the Kindle format.Overall, I do NOT recommend reading this in the Kindle format unless you don't give a hoot about maps, illustrations and bibliographies.  In which case, I don't want to know you anyway.I feel presumptuous making the next claim but it must be said- Fischer makes a lot of claims in this book that are not solidly grounded in the evidence.  Just one example- Fisher relates an incident in The Autobiography of Black Hawk that he claims has to refer to Champlain because "no one else" fits the description. I challenge any reader to go to The Autobiography and to read that passage and to come away convinced that Black Hawk can only be talking about Champlain.  This is a sloppy form of historical thinking- What I call the Argument From Wishful Thinking.  The basic idea is that has to be true because it fits my thesis so darn well.I feel there are many such examples throughout the book e.g., as to whether Champlain was an illegitimate son of Henri IV.I leave the judgement on that issue and how important it is to the reader. To me it is an issue and combined with authors tendency to repeat himself almost verbatim time and again throughout the book and you have the reason for my three star rating.I will give Fischer this- he convinces me that Champlain's approach to the Native American nations was far superior to anything that any of the English or Spanish tried.  Champlain actually seemed to respect and like the Indians from the moment he first met them.  He came far closer to treating them as equals than any other explorer of whom I know.  Fischer is careful to point out the limits of Champlain's vision,e.g.,he thought less of them for not having a King.  Champlain was very much of his time in regard to the great chain of being with each animal and man having his or her place in the hierarchy.Overall, I cannot help but recommend this book.  It has it flaws but so do we all.  It serves to introduce us to a lessor known explorer/founder of North America and makes an argument that he should be better known.

I have, over an undeservedly long life, learned to listen to music in a lot of different ways.  One of my favorites is to listen to something as I fall asleep. Sometimes the result is that I fall into an almost-asleep state where the music becomes the sum total of my perceptual datum or field or however you would put that.Certain types of music are perfect for this type of listening.  Music that is spacious and full of unusual sounds can become a dreamscape that can last as long as the music.This CD is perfect for that sort of listening.  There is no real attempt here to make the music sound foreign or jazzy or exotic.  Instead what we have is four contemporary Chinese composers who seem to regard the instrumentation and their blended musical traditions as assets to be used however they are inspired.The results are outstanding and unexpected.  I have probably over a hundred saxophone quartet CDs and none of them really approach the possibilities like this one does.  Several saxophones using multiphonics blend in with the sheng, the popping of the pads are used as drums and long drone tones blend in with the erhu to create eerie bending of notes.Another facet of this music to note is how equally both ensembles and each player is used.  Their is no dominance to the saxophones except for the occasional passage (like toward the end of Fang Man's wonderful Dreams of a Hundred Flowers).  This is not a concerto for the erhu or the pipa but both are played with great skill and feeling.  Individual instruments wander in and out of the soundscape like characters on a stage.We owe this music to not just the composers but to two wonderful ensembles:The Prism Saxophone QuartetTimothy McAllister- soprano saxZachary Shemon- alto saxMatthew Levy- tenor saxTaimur Sullivan- baritone saxandMusic from ChinaWang Guowei- erhuChen Yihan- pipaHelen Yee- yangqinFrank Cassar- percussionalong with Hu Jianbing- sheng.The Prism Quartet has been around for a long time and has somehow escaped my notice.  Time to catch up.  I would also like to point out a 2CD release that is simultaneous with such jazz notables as David Leibman, Rudresh Mahanthappa and Steve Lehman.I can't wait.

Just want to add my approval to the general acclaim.  Like many frequent reviewers, I get offers to try products for free in exchange for a review.  I mostly say no because I don't need the product. The Spider was different. A device like the Spider should be a standard part of what you keep in your car.I have had to use this thing on my car or those of my friends some five times since I got it and it worked perfectly each time. The carrying case is about the size of a large book. The Spider is very easy to use.  In point of fact, I can think of nothing bad to say about it.I repeat, a device like this belongs in every car.  It is simply that good.

Tom Varner continues to develop as a composer.  He now lives in the Seattle area and this is his second CD featuring a bevy of truly remarkable Seattle musicians.  So first, I give you the musicians:Tom Varner, french horn and composerThomas Marriott, trumpetDavid Marriott, tromboneSteve Tresler, clarinetMark Taylor, absolutely killer alto saxEric Barber, tenor saxJim Dejoie, baritone saxPhil Sparks, bassByron Vannoy, drums.Nine Surprises is the name of a fifteen section composition that makes up most of the CD.  The last three pieces are stand alone compositions.Several of the pieces are brief interludes for Byron Vannoy or for Phil Sparks to shine.  These interludes are quiet and draw you into listening more closely.  There are others for Mark Taylor or Eric Barber to quickly display their prowess on their horn. They serve to set off and to separate the longer pieces, Main Theme, Seattle Blues, Low Guys, Mali King County and Reprise and Finale. These compositions are just extraordinary.  Seattle Blues sounds as good as early Mingus, equally driven by the soli and by the ensemble section.  Contrapuntal weaving, rich harmonies and swing, swing, swing.  I love this piece.  Mali King County is named, I believe, after the African country and the county that contains Seattle.  It kicks off with Byron on the drums, then Phil on the bass and the horns start to dig in after about a minute with Mr. Varner conversing with the rest of the horns.That last remark gets to something I like about the way Mr. Varner writes- so many of his compositions sound like conversations with the different musicians/sections exchanging ideas and getting excited about what is happening. This is especially evident in Mali King County which has a celebratory quality.As for the final composition, I grace you with Mr. Varner's own description, "...a Gil Evans-influenced variation on the harmonic structure of a pop Hawaiian Christmas song, made popular by Bing Crosby. A version of the song by Cyril Pahinui on slack key guitar inspired me..."  Seriously, if that doesn't excite your interest, I don't know what to do with you.Finally, let me note that this is the first recording on Tom Varner's own label.
