He raises the hope that in reflecting on the debates between Bolingbroke and Walpole, Defoe and Swift and on the actions of a Jefferson that we may find our own source of creative tension. It is worth the thinking on it.

As far as I can ascertain from from my brief bit of research this is a somewhat Kindlelized version of Gaillard Hunt's 4 volume collection of Madison's Letters and Writings. My complaints are not against the writings themselves. It is an okay collection, very letter centric.But it is practically useless in this format as a research tool. If you are reading, e.g., Ketcham's biography of Madison and he makes reference to a 1803 letter of Madison to Monroe, good luck finding it quickly. First, you have to find the overall table of contents and link to the right volume, then link to the right year and then page through that year and hope Hunt included it.Slow, tedious and annoying.The Online Library of Liberty has an electronic version of Hunt's 9 volume collection of Madison's papers. Use that instead. Or wait until the publishing world catches up to the fact that while ebooks are cool, they are only as useful as publishers make them to be. At the moment, they haven't caught on to the fact that there is a market for good, well formatted version of the classics in good translations and editions and for American history and political theory in good editions. Until they wake up to that, ebooks like the Kindle will not be a decent research tool nor the basis for a great personal library.

Let's deal with the audio issue first. The sound is at its worst when the horns are playing unison lines (or as close to that as Coleman and Cherry get). Whenever they switch to just the one of them playing, the sound improves noticeably in quality. Even then there are moments when it is noticeable how far someone is from the recording mike. For example, at about the 4:30 mark of Dancing Flower, Coleman gives way to Cherry and Cherry sounds as if he is almost out of mike range. He then must have walked closer to wherever the mike was because the recording slowly improves. It is sad that no one took the opportunity to make an audiophile quality live recording of the reunion of one of the top ten (I would argue for top five) greatest bands in jazz history. What a wasted opportunity.One of the other reviewers noted that this quartet played together on a 1987 release, In All Languages. In 1990, Reggio Emilia, Italy held a three day Portrait of the Artist festival built around Ornette Coleman. (Not to beat a dead horse, but, gosh, wouldn't it be nice if an American city did something like that.) This recording is the complete concert by the quartet at that festival on April 24, 1990. It includes tunes from the original recordings of the quartet and from their In All Languages release as well as Ornette compositions originally recorded by other of his ensembles.The main point I want to make is the same as everyone else's on this page- regardless of your feelings of audio inadequacy there is simply too much great music being played on these CDs to miss out on. My favorite of my present listening is on Magic- Haden has a nice solo and then at about the 6 minute mark Ornette tears in with a fervor with that uniquely yearning tone of his. It is a delight to hear Higgins again in this context. He has always been one of my favorite drummers and what he brings to this grouping is unique.If you are new to Ornette, this is not the place to start. But if you are one of us who grew up and old listening to the music of Coleman, Cherry, Higgins and Haden this is an essential addition to your collection. And, yes, I second the motion for a Prime Time Box.

I have other recordings like this by various violinist and violists, I swear I do. I just cannot find them in the wilderness of my collection. I am referring to the type of CD where a soloist will use a series of baroque or earlier compositions by one composer to frame a series of contemporary compositions by an assortment of composers. Thomas Demenga did a series on ECM of the Bach suites where they are paired with works by contemporary composers such as Elliot Carter.On this particular CD, Matt Haimovitz plays a series of Ricercari by Domenico Gabrielli written in 1689, some 30 years before the Bach Cello Suites. Inbetween the Ricercari are modern solo cello compositions by Berio, Dallapiccola, Sciarrino and Ambrosini. The one ringer (in the sense of not being written by an Italian) is the Capriccio by Brian Cherney. The Berio and the Dallpiccola are both particularly strong. Dallapiccola's piece is typical for how I think of him- half baroque materials and half twelve-tone rows, half tonal and half atonal. I find his work instantly accessible. Berio takes more work. Haimovitz describes the piece as "ruminations on Sri Lankan drumming techniques". Now I know less than nothing of Sri Lankan drumming. But the Berio Sequenza is immediately about the cello as percussion possibility not only in terms of strumming and bowing techniques but in using the cello as a drum. It took me a while to get into this piece but I enjoy as much as any now and hear it afresh every time I hear it.But I must say that everytime Haimovitz starts up one of the Gabrielli, their unabashed tonal beauty is like the sun coming out from behind a cloud. They are simply sweet.Part of their beauty is in Haimovitz' playing and in his instrument. He plays the pieces with extraordinary tone and gravity. He plays them on a Matteo Goffriller that was built in 1710, 300 years ago. 300 years of aging, of mellowing into a sound as musically rich as any instrument can produce.So there you have it. Great instrument, great performer, great repertoire. Music that will feed your soul as well as your mind. Give it a listen.

It is my opinion that this book is the beginning of the end for the claim that the predominant cause of the Civil War wasn't slavery. Slavery was the primary single issue and it was the issue that energized most of the other issues that contributed to the war. Having stated that, I intend simply to summarize how she did her research and some of her conclusions.Manning's book is the beginning of the end for other causal explanations because she relies on the testimonies that should bear the most weight, i.e., the wartime letters home of the men in blue and gray who fought at Gettysburg, Vicksburg, the Wilderness, Cold Harbor, Shiloh and all the other horrific battles of the war.Her research is pretty amazing and should first be assessed by looking at her list of Primary Sources in the back of the book which is organized by state. She traveled to every state that was involved in the Civil War and roamed through 45 local libraries and historical societies. She went through larger collections like those of Military History Institute of the U.S. Army and the Library of Congress. She read published collections of Civil War letters and innumerable state documents relating to the War.Her focus was on the enlisted man and on letters actually written during the war rather than memoirs that were written in the postwar years. She gathered biographical data of the various correspondents whose letters she collected and noted their place of origin, their occupation, educational attainments, etc. She then selected 477 Confederate soldiers and 657 Union soldiers to focus on because their collected backgrounds were representative of the armies as a whole.She also uncovered some 100+ regimental papers (largely published by enlisted men) and used them as well. She then organized this body of material by date. Not surprisingly, she found that opinions shifted with the fortunes of the war.Finally, for any one opinion to be considered dominant, it had to be expressed by at least a three to one ratio (p.11). By the way, all this is explained in the first twenty pages, so any reviewer who claims she used a different research strategy or that she can't back up any of her claims with "facts" hasn't read the book.Her presentation of what she learned is very well written and easy to follow. She largely organized her presentation around the timeline of the war. She then covers what was being discussed in the letters of the Confederate Army and the Union Army both white and black.I think she has three hermeneutics that she deploys on the material. First is the vast ornate interplay of slavery and racism within American culture at the time. Manning is very clear about the racist attitudes of many of the Union soldiers throughout the war and is clear about the way the black soldiers were mistreated, especially initially, by the higher command of that Army. But she believes that their letters show that during the course of the War, that enlisted white Union soldiers went through several shifts in their attitudes toward slavery and toward black Americans. Those shifts she sees as largely progressive and in advance of the chain of command and Northern public opinion as a whole. The War radicalized the soldiers. Most of them had never seen Southern slave society at work and they didn't much cotton to it. Their own racism took longer to be impacted.  But for many Union soldiers, watching black Americans in battle was a revelation and a catalyst to personal change. There was backsliding during changes in the momentum of the War, there was frustration by the white soldiers at how much they were sacrificing and some of the soldiers left their service as racist as they entered it. But Manning is clear that there was a enormous change in the opinion of the white enlisted man as a whole and in the higher command. At the end of the war, the black Union soldier received equal pay and could become an officer. This was unthinkable four years earlier.Manning's other two hermeneutics are more controversial and are probably the source of most of the resistance to her reading of the evidence. Manning feels that she can discern differences in the patriotism of the Confederate soldier and that of the Union soldier. It is her claim that the average Southerner regarded government as justifiable only to the extent it served his needs and that of his family. To the extent that that government began to impinge on his paternal control of his own life and his family was to the extent that the Southerner rejected government. By the way, she sees a related dynamic in the ways that the North and the South responded to the Second Great Awakening and its aftermath in antebellum America. That religious movement created organized reform movements in the North that focused on societal issues (among others, abolition). In the South, the emphasis was on the personal reform of the individual.When the Southern states succeeded, they created a new national government to which the white Southern man had few if any attachments. As the War went on, the Confederate government had to behave in ways that didn't fit in with Southern ideas on government. To that extent, the Confederate soldier felt less loyalty to that government. The difference with the Northern white soldier should be clear. Billy Yank had a history with his government. He regarded that government as part of his larger society that provided services and to which he owed allegiance.This difference cuts across her third hermeneutic which deals with the nature of Southern versus Northern manhood. Manning feels that for the enlisted white Confederate, slavery created a social structure which gave him the space to express that paternalistic manhood. His service on slave patrols, his ability to discipline slaves who were not respectful and other rights that the poor white non-slaveholding man had compared with a slave gave him a sense of equality with the upper Southern masters. Obviously, this is the most controversial portion of Manning's reading of the Southern men's letters but she uses it to explain a lot.Another aspect of Manning's version of Southern manhood was rooted in fear and violence. The South had been traumatized by actual and possible slave rebellions. In some parts of the South, the slaves outnumbered the whites. Race war seemed a real possibility if the slaves were ever to be successfully armed and encouraged. The War and the Union Army did just that. The Southern soldier believed that he was fighting for the physical safety of his own family and for his own farm. Manning feels he fought to preserve the world he knew and wherein he had his place.This reading is how Manning confronts one of the common arguments against slavery being the main cause of the war. The fact is that the vast majority of Southern white men did not own slaves. Why would all these men choose to fight and die over something they had no stake in? Manning's answer is that the Southern man fought for the world he knew and loved and wanted to leave to his children. The Confederate soldier knew that world was built on slave labor.As I implied earlier, I found Manning's book to be utterly convincing. I would offer one more reason for reading her book. She uses an enormous amount of quotes. I detest the way the way we men talk about violence among ourselves- the fight stories, the "then I said" type stories that are told to maintain whatever it is they maintain. But I find the letters that are written home by American soldiers in war to be a unique and compelling literary genre. They are often poorly spelled and grammar is frequently taken to the woodshed but they are frequently funny and have a bedrock humanity which is enormously appealing. Reading some of Manning's quotes will make you wish you knew the men writing and could converse with them. Just another reason to read this very strong contribution to American history.

This is another superb member of the Document Chicago series put out by 482 Music. Like many other members of that series the players involved are part of a Chicago scene that tries to be all inclusive in a lot of ways.All-inclusive in the sense that everyone is a composer whose compositions everyone plays. All-inclusive in the sense that everyone plays on each other projects: groupings form and morph and some groups have revolving leadership chairs. All-inclusive in the approach to the whole tradition of jazz. Many of these people seemed to have absorbed Auden's insight that creative work within a tradition can be a whole lot of fun.Consider the present CD. Paul Giallorenzo is the composer and the pianist, Josh Berman plays cornet, Dave Rempis (All bow in his direction)is on alto and baritone sax, Anton Hatwich is on bass, and Frank Rosaly is the drummer.The review notes above cite early Taylor, Monk and Nichols as influences. O yeah, listen to Twisted Lopes and tell me Giallorenzo doesn't know his Monk. I hear a lot of other 60s piano icons as well-e.g., some of his compositions remind some of Andrew Hill as well. But the nice thing is that there is no sense of being derivative. The best of this generation of Chicago musicians, like Rempis, approach the tradition as a vast resource of knowledge, techniques, tools and aesthetics to draw from in exploring their own sensibilities. They get into the tradition to go further out. Thereby renewing and extending it. What the music called jazz is supposed to be about.The compositions are very strong. Consider Porous (for Quintet). The first four minutes or so are all long doleful tones. Rempis' solos is built around them. But then the band drops out except Hatwich who starts walking that bass. Giallorenzo enters back in with a completely different mood- more swinging but still analytical. This is maybe his strongest solo. The composition ends on Berman and Rempis punching out a swinging unison line until the long doleful tones return us to the beginning. All in all, a very nice structure that brings out the best in everybody.This is a strong debut that deserves a listen. If you are not familiar with the current Chicago scene or the Document Chicago series this is a good place to start. Then simply follow the trail of Berman, Rosaly, Hatwich and Rempis. The whole experience will be fun, I promise.

Once again, I find myself praising the greatness that is Clean Feed Records. Not only does Pedro Costa's company consistently put out great current recordings but they release this 1997 gem of a session. (By the way, if like me, you prefer CDs to the audio horror that is MP3, go to the Clean Feed site where they will be glad to ship you a brand spanking new CD.)Let us deal with the recording details. In June, 1997 in NYC Tim Berne gathered together the following group of musicians:Baikida Carroll- trumpetMichael Formanek- contrabassMarc Ducret- 12 string guitarDominique Pifarely- violinErik Friedlander- celloChris Speed- clarinetJim Black- drumsand himself on alto and mighty mighty baritone sax.This octet was unleashed on two of Berne's compositions. The first one, The Proposal, goes for 36 minutes and the other, oPEN,cOMA clocks in just under 30 minutes.I would really love to know more about how Berne structures these pieces. They have what seem to be obviously composed sections (unless this group of musicians can spontaneously create unison lines) there are plenty of soli sections (Carroll is particularly good on this CD)and what seem to be group improvs. But there is something going on here that is really well done.Perhaps Berne has absorbed his Hegel (quantitative changes eventually become qualitative changes) but these pieces slowly and subtly evolve. One moment you are listening to a group improv then it seemlessly organizes itself into a structured background from which Carroll emerges as soloist then Pifarely or Friedlander enter into dialogue with Carroll and then another group passage asserts itself and then everyone slowly drops out until Black is left to play a percussion piece which then stops. (By the way, does anyone else notice how after listening to a great piece of music, the air seems to vibrate with the decaying harmonics and then how empty the silence is for a bit? No? O, never mind.)Berne does not dominate the music at all, in fact, I would have liked more of him. The string quartet (I include Ducret) use the most extended technique and they all sound great. It is sad that this group doesn't still put out recordings. (Maybe they do. No one is more ignorant than I. If anyone knows of other recordings by this group, please inform me in the comment section.)In the meantime, all hail these musicians and Clean Feed for this hour of listening bliss.

Robert Pierce Forbes' book is a masterwork in American history. His book reinterprets the Missouri Compromise as the watershed event in the first eighty or ninety years of this country's history. As I read him, Forbes is asserting that this country was created with a fundamental contradiction that was so deeply ingrained that our political institutions eventually failed in dealing with it. And then the war came. I am talking, of course, about the contradiction between the universal rights enshrined in our founding documents (and thus in our self-image) and the presence of slavery through out much of the land. We believed that we had created the universal republic and what we had really created was a white republic. We were able to live with the contradiction because most people believed that slavery had been imposed on us by Britain and that it would eventually die off. As time went on two paths began to emerge. The northern states moved slowly toward making slavery illegal (which was very different from making their free black inhabitants full citizens) and the southern states moved toward being (in various ways) slave-based economies. In Forbes' reading of the historical record, the debates that erupted around the Missouri compromise exposed just how deep those differences ran.The spark was the Tallmadge amendment which would have prevented any more slaves being brought into Missouri after statehood and would have emancipated any Missouri born slaves at age 25. Forbes' telling of the resulting debates and the behind the scenes maneuvering that led to the two compromises is masterful and insightful. He develops several themes in this discussion. One is that James Monroe was much more effective a President than has been realized. Forbes shows that Monroe was tireless and adroit in his efforts toward the compromises. Perhaps most admirably, Monroe seems to have simply not cared about credit. He simply wanted what he thought was good for the country to occur no matter who got the acclaim.Forbes also notes that the various arguments that were developed during the debates and the language that was used to soften the compromises were harbingers of some of the horrors to come. The language that Clay used to forge a Congressional acceptance of the provocative Missouri Constitution (particularly the clause that outlawed any free blacks from moving into the state) was to prove the foundation for the Dred Scott decision years later. That language framed the national thinking about free blacks in such a way as to deny any possibility of freedmen being citizens of many Northern states.That last sentence speaks to one of the most remarkable things about Forbes' book. He is clear that the North legalized many forms of racism.  He also really tries to make some of the Southern reaction and/or thinking on racism and slavery understandable.For example, up until the British emancipation of their West Indian slaves in the 1830s, there had never been a peaceful emancipation on a societal level by slave owners. Slavery had always ended in rebellion up until that point in time. So prior to that emancipation, it is understandable that most slave owners assumed that emancipation without exportation of the freed blacks would lead to race war. Their most recent example was Haiti and they also had the slave rebellions of Denmark Vecsey and Nat Turner to support their beliefs.This also explains why the British abolition movement was such a provocation to them. The successful emancipation of the West Indies proved that their fears were not completely justified. Most simply could not accept this.Forbes' discussion ranges far beyond Missouri. He talks about the tariff debates, the internal improvement debates, the (complete and total outrage) of the South Carolinian Negro Seaman Act, the Nullification crisis, the annexation of Texas, the Dred Scott decision and Kansas, bloody Kansas. He discusses the enormous variety of Southern intellectual reaction to these various crisis, the unanimity of the Southern political reaction on the national stage and all the various ways that Northern politicians played the doughface. Forbes provides keen insights into the actions of Monroe, Clay, Webster, Calhoun, Van Buren, J.Q. Adams and Jackson. He provides readings of many of the influential writings of the times whether Robert Turnbull's The Crisis or Thomas Cooper's Consolidation or John Taylor of Caroline's New Views on the Constitution or David Walker's Appeal...to the Colored Citizens of the World. His history ends with the Dred Scott decision and with the compromise of 1850 wherein the Missouri Compromise was abrogated.Forbes discussion is well grounded in original sources and with a mastery of the scholarly literature. He has absorbed Thomas Hart Benton's Thirty Years View, J.Q. Adams' Memoirs (one of the essential diaries in American history) and Hermann von Holst's The Constitutional and Political History of the United States as well as the more recent literature. But it is really in his mastery of the Congressional record and in the letters of people like Van Buren and Monroe wherein Forbes has grounded his interpretations.Rarely, usually once or twice a generation, a historical work comes along which changes a field of inquiry, which sets new standards of research for those who labor in that field thereafter. We have seen such works, in my lifetime, from Bailyn, Woods, Foner and maybe McPherson. It is my belief that Forbes' book may be their equal. Time will tell. But why wait for history's judgment? I guarantee you that you will learn from this book, that it will give you much to think about, that it will make sense of much that confused you before and that it will bring you up against those twin issues in our national narrative that have warped so many events in that narrative- slavery and race. What freaking more do you want?

This is a superb addition to the sax trio tradition. (I am a little unsure of my history here so if I get something wrong feel free to correct me in the comment section below). I believe the beginning of the saxophone trio format was the Way Out West album of Sonny Rollins from 1957. Rollins was a stalwart of the format which is also featured on albums like East Broadway Run Down.It was a format used by many in the free jazz/creative improv tradition. In fact the drummer on Foxy is Barry Altschul who was featured on many a Sam Rivers and Anthony Braxton release during the late sixties and seventies including some in the trio format. Many other saxophonists have delved into the format appreciating the freedom that it gives them whether as the dominant voice or as part of a equal triangle of sound.But few have unleashed a trio recording as powerful as this one. I came to this CD because on my fondness for the group Mostly Other People Do The Killing and for Jon Irabagon's work on sax in that quartet.What we have on this CD is Irabagon on tenor, Altschul absolutely tearing it up on drums and Peter Brendler on the bass. Together they unleash a single masterful 75 minute (more or less) improv that is astonishing and exhausting. It all starts on a fade in and seems to be cut off at the end so it appears to be part of an even longer improv session. I find myself making this observation a few times lately (e.g., in reference to a recent Fred Anderson release) but I have no idea how someone is able to play like this and not just lie down afterwards.Irabagon utilizes the history of the jazz bop and post-bop saxophone as the raw materials for his improv. There is plenty of Rollins quotes to be heard (Note that the goofy cover is a homage to the cover of the Way Out West LP) as well as quotes from others that I would have to hear several times to identify. There is a snatch or two of some Christmas songs or some standards. Irabagon also will land on a phrase or a short figure and rework it as the structure for several minutes of the improv before it leads somewhere else. On one of the tracks (more or less randomly divided into twelve rhymes of Foxy) the result is a three or four note figure that is repeated over and over for five plus minutes while Altschul takes center stage.Altschul is great- thrashing, building up the momentum or tearing it apart to find another pulse. He is the perfect foil for Irabagon.My one lament is that Brendler sounds to my ears to be underrecorded (or poorly mixed). He is as active and creative as the others and never wavers in his ability to match their intensity but he gets a little lost in the mix sometimes.Even with that caveat, Foxy remains just an amazing album. It may not be for everybody, and it won't be for everybody listened to all at once but drop it on the spiral function on your CD player and see if it doesn't blow most of what you match it with away. Or listen to it all on your drive home from work and see if it doesn't clean some of the corporate stain off your soul. Worked for me. But in any case, if you like modern jazz or the saxophone this all too obscure little gem deserves your closest attention.

(The qualification of my title is based on the fact that I haven't heard Forty Fort yet. That and the fact that I am fond of ambiguity.)Mostly Other People Do The Killing or MOPDTK was formed in 2003 by Moppa Elliott and has featured the same personnel during that time- Elliott as composer and bassist, Peter Evans on trumpet, Jon Irabagon on tenor and sopranino saxophones and Kevin Shea on drums. This particular CD is a live recording from a performance at Coimbra, Portugal that took place in May of 2010.Their music is diverse, very riffy but in what is often described as an off-kilter way. It frequently disintegrates into free jazz of various types and then suddenly riffs back into a bluesy bebop. Very nice. I stole my title from Irabagon's description of the band on his website.The musicianship is a wonder. Listen to the way Shea kicks things off on Drainlick. Irabagon and Evans have different styles which mesh well. Evans is more traditionalist, largely eschewing smears or extended techniques. He is a superb player, incredibly fast and inventive. Irabagon on the other hand, loves extended techniques and mixes it in well with a solid traditional technique. Listen to the samples for his The Observer CD to hear just how traditional he can sound.Elliott compositions are consistently interesting and he seems to be mixing them all up in the performance so that the group starts off in one tune and end up with another composition. I wonder if this is the influence of Braxton's '80s quartet at all? Anyway, it works really well for these guys.One other thing. MOPDTK likes to pay homage/mock classic jazz LP covers. Their previous CDs has cover that paid homage to great Ornette Coleman, Roy Haynes or Art Blakely covers. This one is an obvious mock up of the cover of Keith Jarrett's Koln Concert CD. This one feels a little snarkier than the others largely because of their facial expressions. Take a look at the photos and you decide.Finally, I would be remiss if I did not point out that this is one of Clean Feed's first releases in 2011 and that Clean Feed is clearly The Greatest Musical Label of All Time or, at least, one of the very best of the moment. I have over 30 CDs from that label and there isn't a lemon in the entire crop. If you are not familiar with the label or if you would prefer a CD version of this recording, go to their site and gaze upon the richness. It will be transformative, I promise you.

It seems that the early part of the 20th century wanted to forget just how much the issue of slavery warped our political life and history from the very moment of this country's birth. This determination to minimize the presence of slavery in the overarching narrative of American history began to break down during the '50s and the '60s with the growth of the civil rights movement.The change (more properly, the remembering of what the 19th century knew)was strengthened by specialized studies like this one by the great Frederick Merk. Slavery and the Annexation of Texas was published when in 1972 when Merk was in his early eighties. It should be read in conjunction with his Fruits of Propaganda in the Tyler Administration as it continues and expands on his discussion of the Texas issue in that book. By the way, the other book is hereafter referred to as FPTA.His basic thesis for both books is fairly simple. The administration of John Tyler was as expansionistic as any this country has had. Tyler and his Junto (Merk's term)focused on solving the Maine boundry issue, the Oregon Territory issue and the question of whether or not to annex Texas. To this end, Tyler's Junto used propaganda to influence public opinion in the direction that they wanted to drive policy. That propaganda was directed to particular sections of the national audience. They would make one sort of argument to the North and another, often contradictory, argument to the Southern audience.For example, Sen. Robert Walker of Mississippi wrote a famous serial letter/pamphlet that argued that the annexation of Texas would lead inevitably to the mass movement of all of the slaves in America to Texas resulting in the inevitable exhausation of the soils of Texas whereupon the slave owners would be face with the choice of bankruptcy or emancipation. They would choose emancipation and the freed slaves would drift south into the tropics of Mexico, Central and South America as if by irresistable magnetic forces. (I kid thee not. One of the great things that Merkdoes is attach about 130 pages of original source material to each book so if you don't believe me go to FPTA and read Walker's Letter.) Anyway, Merk argues that this argument was perfectly suited for the sort of uneasy combination of antislavery/white supremacy that was common in the North at the time. In one fell stroke, America would be rid of both slavery and black Americans. Poof!!One the other hand, different sort of arguments were made in the essays of Southern newspaper or the mouthpiece of the Tyler Administration, The Madisionian. There the argument was that Texas would serve to preserve slavery against the machinations of the British and The International Abolitionist Conspiracy. The argument was also made that the existence of slavery was necessary to the economic health of the North.Of course, these inconsistencies were noted and led to much of the debate in Congress over the issue of annexation.Merk is superb as tracing all the political manuevering that occurred over the issues. He traces the remarkably stumbling path of Duff Green as a sort of envoy/intelligence agent trying to manipulate opinion in Britain and Mexico. Merk closely follows the negotiation of the original treaty to annex Texas, its rejection in Congress, and the impact on the election of 1844. All of this is very well done and backed up by plenty of original documents in the back of the book.Finally, Merk tells the history of how the Tyler administration and its partners in Congress argued for the annexation of Texas as an act of Congress (thus avoiding that whole 2/3 requirement in the Senate) and the constitutional issues that arose as a result (See the lovely spectacle of the High Apostle of Strict Construction and State-Rights, Ladies and Gentlemen, the right Honorable John C. Calhoun arguing from convenience for the broadest possible interpratation of Article IV, Section 3 and for ignoring the treaty requirement designed to protect the rights of states). There is also the nice little spiteful coda of Tyler sending the annexation offer to the authorities of Texas in the last days of his administration. As soon as Polk came in, he cancelled that offer and then resubmitted it in his name. Vanitas, Vanitas.I would like to end on a couple of observations. I have to admit that it is hard for me to like Calhoun. This book does nothing to help that reaction. Calhoun comes across as someone who is willing to ignore inconvenient facts that counter his beliefs. Merk relates how Walker and others like Calhoun completely hashed the already screwed up statistics that were part of the 1840 census to prove that the free blacks of the North suffered very high rates of incidence of insanity, blindness, deafness and criminality. The untrustworthiness of these stats were demonstrated by members of the American Statictical Association. Calhoun ignored this counterevidence and continued to use the stats whenever it was convenient (see pp. 86 and 113 for highlights of this story). Merk also notes that none of Calhoun's biographers up to that point even mentioned this whole sad history. Neither does John Niven in his more recent biography as far as I can find.The second observation I would like to make is on the first review for this book. It is easy to see what he is talking about. Reading this book and FPTA we are exposed to the sight of an administration searching for the right reason to publically justify their policies in order to disguise their true purposes which have appeal to only a section of the public. We are exposed to them illegally funding that effort with money that is earmarked for another purpose (see FPTA for this part of the story). We see one of the first examples of an administration overstepping its powers to declare war when Tyler promises and one of his envoys orders a naval squadron to protect the Texas coast during treaty negotiations without Congressional approval. So file this book under the evidence for, "The more things change, the more they stay the same".To sum up, this is a great book and an important one. Not just for the interpretation that it offers up of a great moment in American history but for providing the documents that support that interpretation. If also laid groundwork for many historical works to come such as David Howe's recent addition to the Oxford History of United States.

There are many different types of historical works. There are sweeping synthetic works that attempt to convey an entire era. Some of those are quite good. We have recently been treated to two excellent surveys of the antebellum period by Sean Wilentz and David Howe. I call these works synthetic because the authors rely so much on their own secondary reading.But that is where the fun really begins. Anytime you read a great synthetic work of history, note carefully the work that the author relied on and then go on to your own reading of that. For one thing, it will help you determine just how much you can rely on the original author for accurately presenting the works of others.But the real pleasure is in coming across a book like this one. I have noted before in some of my reviews that the readings of the work of previous generations of historians is full of surprises. There are enormous differences in the foci of research and the way certain aspects of a period are emphasized and interpreted. There are also some historians who are worth reading for more philosophical reasons. Plutarch's Lives may be full of errors but it is still worth several readings over a lifetime.Frederick Merk is a worthy read. He published this little study in his 84th year and credits his wife Lois as a coauthor. It was published a year before Slavery and the Annexation of Texas with which it should be read.Both books talk about the 1840s and specifically, the means used by the Tyler and Polk administrations to sway public opinion on border issues between the U.S. and Canada and the annexation of Texas. The last third of both books are original documents that are hard to find and which the Merks depended on in making their argument.The Merks feel that the Tyler administration employed propaganda in order to convince the people of Maine that they should accept a compromise proposal that was being worked out by Daniel Webster (during his tenure as Secretary of State for Tyler)and Lord Ashburton, the British diplomat.The Merks' research amply proves that the Tyler administration reached into a secret fund (that was earmarked for use in foreign affairs only) in order to pay Francis O.J. Smith (a Maine politician) to conduct a campaign to sway public opinion in advance of the treaty. The people of Maine and their government were veryresistant to any movement away from the way they understood the boundary to have been drawn up during the negotiations that ended the Revolutionary War. Unfortunately, no accurate, annotated and signed maps were appended to that agreement and, naturally, over time both Canadians and Maine men begin to interpret the boundary (especially the valuable forests)to their advantage.Webster and Tyler looked back on forty years or so of Maine intansigence that had gotten nowhere and decided to work out a compromise.Smith prepared the way for that by making the argument for such a compromise in advance in anonymous editorials and essays and by conversation with his fellow Maine politicians. When the compromise treaty was publically announced, some of the Maine papers headlined the event as a day of celebration. It was a good treaty, the people of Maine recognized it as such, accepted it and potential conflict along the border was avoided. There was a brief congressional investigation into the story a year or two later but nothing came out of that.The second seciton of the book deals with the campaign to prepare the American public as a whole for the annexation of Texas. The Merks go into much greater detail about this campaign in the second book, Slavery and the Annexation of Texas (I promise a review when complete) but they do discuss the impact of a letter published both serially in newspapers/periodicals and as a pamphlet by Robert Walker (very much an insider in the Tyler administraton). This extraordinary document is appended to the end of the Merks' book and is worth the price of the book in itself.To sum it up briefly, Walker makes the argument that slave agriculture inevitably wrings the soil useless. The result is that slave based agriculture is always in search of new soil. Texas will drain the slaves out of the slave states and the border states by inexorable economic forces. When the Texan soil is exhausted, the slave owners will then be faced with emancipation or bankruptcy. They will emancipate their slaves who will be drawn to the tropical climes of Mexico, Central and South American. The slave issue, indeed, the race issue, will then disappear from the American republic. And all this would take place with 75 years or so.Walker also makes much of the horrific alternatives that will occur if annexation were not to happen. Race war, mass insanity and public insolvency were inevitable if we listened to those who wanted to not annex Texas.By the by, past experience in Amazon reviews has taught me to declare that the preceeding paragraph does not represent my views nor those of the Merks. It is, however, a fair summation of a pamphlet that was very influential is forming public opinion back in the mid-1840s. Blame the people of that time, not me.This is a superb little book. It cast an intense and focused light on two small moments in the history of American governmental manipulation of public opinion. It also just goes to show that some of older historians really knew what they were doing. And that the Bush administration was following in the footsteps of John Tyler! Sorry, I just had to throw that little provocation into the mix.

I have just finished this book and am somewhat bewildered by some of the reviews on Amazon. Foolish me. I have read quite a bit about the history of this period; general histories as well as more specialized, histories written in the last ten or twenty years and the works of previous generations.It seems to me that Howe gets many things about the period 1815-1848 just about right. I offer the following quote:"The most bloody conflicts, however, derived from the domination and the exploitation of the North American continent by the white people of the United States and their government. If a primary driving force can be identified in American history for this period, this was it." (p.852)Please note that "If"...this quote comes after a careful summing up of other possible causal factors: the growth of the market economy, the "awakened vigor of the democratically organized Protestant churches" and the emergence of mass political parties. (849) Howe also spends scores of pages devoted to the transportation and communication revolutions (think canals, trains and telegraphy) that occurred during this period. And he is careful to attribute the impacts on our history of certain transcendent personalities. This period would simply not gone the way it did without the towering figures of Jackson, JQ Adams, Polk, Clay and Calhoun not to mention the lesser lights of Tyler and Wilfred Scott.So anyone who tells you that Howe offers a monocausal account of the period has simply misread the book.But Howe is right to emphasize the issue of race. Since some reviewers have objected to the idea of the 'white supremacy' of the period as being anachronistic, let us just talk about the efforts as being directed toward the creation a white man's republic. As in, '"Ours is the government of the white man," protested Calhoun in opposition to taking All Mexico.'(799) There were arguably five or six major and divisive political events of this period: Indian removal, internal improvements, tariffs, national bank, the territorial expansion of slavery and the War with Mexico. Three of those were racial at their core. Now if you want to pretend that the territorial expansion of slavery was largely about states rights, that is up to you. Howe is not the author for you, and to be frank, I am not sure who is. The same with the War with Mexico, the same with Indian removal.Yes, the majority of Americans back then were racist. Yes, all great countries that I know of have had strong racist themes to their history. Yes, those same great countries have become great by simply taking over their neighbors lands. And so why should we concern ourselves about that aspect of our history? Because it is OUR history and we are still playing out some of the consequences of that history.Being a racist, arrogant, intolerant old man doesn't mean that Andrew Jackson didn't have greatness in him. It doesn't mean that he didn't impact our history for the good. He did. But he was also racist, arrogant, intolerant, violent and he didn't really play well with others. Read Remini's great three-volume biography and tell me different.I will say this again and again. American history is a human history. There are angels aplenty to be found in it, heroes by the score and many a devil. Frequently all wrapped up in the same person. All of y'all who think that American history should only emphasize the angels and heroes need to go back and read your Plutarch (beloved by many a Founding Father). There are lessons to be learned from history but only if we look at it honestly and dispassionately and at its full human complexity.Howe is great at that. Throughout his book, Howe returns to the figure of Samuel Morse as an exemplar of the mixed bag that was the antebellum period. The whole book is a testament to the rich, bizarre, exciting, shameful and wonderful history of that period. Howe's volume is a wonderful addition to the Oxford History of the United States.

From reading Polybius, Livy, Machiavelli and my boy Leo Strauss, the reader learns that the founding of a nation (let alone an empire) is never spotless. In fact, it is frequently the result of one or several criminal acts. For this reason, among others, such beginnings will generate a mythology and a hagiography. You end up with stories about demigods who in epic and heroic action and with the blessings of God (or the gods) founded this or that glorious nation. And so it goes until the next bunch of criminals (or freedom fighters- your choice) come along with better weapons or strategy or a newer and better bunch of gods and they proceed to found their own nation or empire on top of yours.So much for the lessons of Polybius, Livy and Machiavelli. Strauss perceived a necessity to maintain that myth in order for the ruling elites or for the nation to maintain their position. The problem, of course, is the old canard that Truth Will Out.The last twenty years of controversy about how we teach history and what we teach as history to our children in this country are all about the above lessons. The plain fact of the matter is that our country was founded on and our cultural life shaped by a series of invasions, epidemics and the slave trade. Murrin's article sums up the state of the current knowledge (as of 1997) in this area of study and provides an excellent selective bibliography.Before I go over a few of the highlights, I want to address what the history of Murrin's essay. I bought it as a pamphlet of  28 pages published by the American Historical Association as part of this The New American History Series. All of the pamphlets are available in a book edition entitled The New American History. Don't make the same mistake I did and pay the same price for a single pamphlet as I would have paid for the book which Amazon sells quite cheaply.The purpose of the series was to familiarize high school history teachers with summations of the latest research in a variety of subfields of American History. If all the contributions are on the level of Murrin's, the book should be require reading  for all teachers.So what does Murrin provide? The `catastrophe' of his title is actually several-fold. He is pointing out how much the colonists in America benefited from the "the greatest demographic catastrophe in the history of the world" (referring to the decimation of the Amerindian nations) and the slave trade. Murrin cites research which estimates that "the pre-Columbian population of the Americas exceeded 70 million, or about one-seventh of the 500 million then inhabiting the globe" (both quotes from p.5 of my edition). Disease was the largest contributor to the decimation of the Amerindian nations but the European settlers put in some hard labor on the task as well. Most of us are pretty familiar with this part of the story.What I was not aware of was the sheer size of the slave trade. Murrin cites the fact that before 1820, some 12 million people came to the Americas to settle. Of those, 8 million were slaves. Those figures do not include the millions of Africans who died during the voyage. So the true ratio of slave to free immigrants might be more like 3 to 1.Free settlers would not outnumber imported slaves until sometime between 1820 and 1840. "For more than three centuries...the slave trade was no unfortunate excess on the periphery of free migration. It was the norm." (p.3.) I don't seem to recall those facts from when I learned my high school history.Most of the pamphlet deals with the different immigration patterns that developed in different regions of North America and how those differing immigration cultures interacted with the local Amerindians and the slave trade. It is all very well done and introduces the reader to an enormous amount of work and literature to further explore.I hate to do it but I find myself compelled now to buy the book in which this essay was first published. Research of this quality about American History must be absorbed regardless of how we feel about that history. To do otherwise is to knowingly choose to live in a myth. To which all I can say is "Good luck with that."

Please note- The following is a review that was written for the published edition of this book and should be read along with some of the other reviews on that page,e.g., AntiochAndy's review.As the other reviewer's have noted this is one of the classics of the Western literary and historical tradition. It also should have a special place in the hearts of Americans in that the Founders relied heavily for their historical knowledge of the ancient Roman and Greek republics on Livy, Polybius and Plutarch. Anyone who has read Farrand's The Records of the Federal Convention of 1787 or The Federalist knows how much the debates on the writing and ratification of our constitution were based on a reading of those three authors among others.Furthermore, as Michael Neulander points out, Machiavelli's Discourses is based on his reading of Livy. Leo Strauss' reading of Machiavelli is based on his close reading of both Machiavelli and Livy. My point is simple- Livy speaks to us to this day on issues of moral education, individual striving for excellence and virtue and on "the war of the orders" (what we today would call class struggle). Livy is thus one of our oldest resources for political theory.Livy has several purposes. He wants to hold up to the Romans of his own day the glorious virtues of their ancestors. He wants to show how the Romans by sticking to their piety and to their ancestral way of life overcame an unimaginable horde of enemies. When they strayed from their piety and their virtues they met with terrible reverses (see for example, his explanation for the sacking of Rome by the Gauls in The Early History of Rome, the first volume of the Penguin edition of Livy's history). In this volume, read the final section for Book X for Livy's contrast of the bizarre rituals of the Samnites to the auspices of the Romans before the climatic battles of The Third Samnite War (starting around p. 345 of the Penguin, chapter 40 of Book X if you have another edition).So, yes, he writes as a moralist, at times as a hagiographer, at times as a cultural imperialist (or as a patriot, your choice).But one of the really fascinating things about Livy is the way he struggles toward something like a modern historical methodology. The events of this volume go from 389 to 292 B.C. In other words, 250+ years or more seperate Livy from the events of his history. Thus he relied entirely on source material; earlier histories by Fabius Pictor and Polybius, family records, lists of consuls, praetors, the writings of antiquarians, and inscriptions on buildings and monuments. Much of the material was unreliable and Livy knew it as such. Toward the latter books of this volume, it is obvious that he struggled to evaluate different versions of the same events for accuracy. He frequently reports multiple accounts of the same events and states which one he believes.Two final thoughts- one dealing with the differences between Livy and Polybius and one dealing with my reaction to this era in Roman history.Livy had absorbed Polybius. They are telling the same story but with very different purposes. Polybius was a cultured observant Greek looking at the rise of Rome from what he felt was a culturally and, perhaps, morally superior tradition. As a soldier and a politician, he is impressed with what the Romans have done. However Polybius is a little staggered at the human cost.This is not a problem for Livy. He writes as one who is afraid that his contemporary Romans were falling from their place in history. A place that had been purchased in blood. To read both Polybius and Livy is thus to read many of the same events presented with very subtle differences in tone. It is a fascinating education.One of my other main reactions to Livy is a sort of shock. Roman history is bloody; to an extent I had never imagined. To read the first decade of Livy (the first two volumes of the Penguin edition)is to read a story of almost continual warfare. The Greeks might go forty or fifty years inbetween wars. I don't think the Romans (on the basis of Livy and Polybius) went four or five years without being involved in a war. They are presented as continually preparing for war, as defending their territories or marching through and laying waste to their enemies. Their patrician class is also presented as among the first to have mastered the art of distracting the lower classes with foreign wars.Finally, I would be remiss if I did not praise Penguin Classics for this edition. They present the history in full, with maps and annotations and useful introductions. One of the reviewers finds the translation stuffy. He should try the Loeb. He might change his mind. As for me, I find this version a very enjoyable read. I can hardly recommend Livy highly enough whether from a literary or a historical or a political theory point of view. Of how many books, can that be said?

In my review of the first volume of the Modern Library edition of Plutarch's Lives of the Noble Greeks and Romans, I explained my preference for the Modern Library edition as opposed to the Loeb or the Penguin Travesty Edition. Please refer to that review for some thoughts on which edition to choose to read.What I first want to do in this review is to provide a little background to a reading of Plutarch. Hopefully, this will provide an explanation of why Plutarch remains such a vital author in the Western Canon.Plutarch lived from around 46 to 120 BCE. He therefore lived in the Roman Empire from the reign of Nero to the beginnings of Hadrian's reign. He was contemporaries with Tacitus and Epictetus. He lived for a while in Rome but most of his life was spent in Boetia in Greece. He was a priest of the oracle at Delphi for several decades and a prolific writer on philosophical, scientific and ethical themes.In addition the the Lives, Plutarch wrote many essays and dialogues that have been collected together under the general title of the Moralia. The Loeb Classical Library provides a complete English rendering and there are several good one volume selections. I mention the Moralia because I believe that a reading of some of the essays are essential to understanding the ethical explorations of the Lives.Consider the opening to his essay, "On Moral Virtue". Plutarch starts off by distinguishing "moral" virtue from "contemplative" virtue. The differences lies "chiefly in that it has as its material the emotions of the soul and as its form reason" (p.19 of the Loeb Moralia, Vol.6).This gives us a picture of Plutarch as Middle Platonist with an Aristotlean idea of virtue as a mean. The picture we get is of a human world where evil and vice are as real as virtue and reason, where the emotions can work as the energizing element of both virtue and vice and where the achievement of virtue is always the result of education and discipline and is never complete.It is this picture of the world that is then explored so magnificently in the Lives. The Lives focus of the political and military realm of the statesmen and uses the various people discussed as the raw material for the exploration of all the ways that excellent men (and a few excellent women)can succeed or fail at virtuous leadership.One of the themes that I feel Plutarch explores is whether Roman hegemony can be defended on any grounds other than their success at arms. In this, he is writing as a cultured Greek testing the Roman leadership by the standards of a conquered people.He looks at the ways that various personal failings (lack of prudence in a general, an excessive love of drink, uncontrollable lust whether for boys or women or greed or any pretty much any excess) can waylay and overturn a lifetime of achievement.Another favorite theme of Plutarch's is the turning of Fortuna's (or Tyche's)wheel. Plutarch exemplifies the belief that we are laid low or allowed success almost whimsically by this goddess who will surely turn our lives upside down again soon. Just because She can (At least, as far as we know).Against these backgrounds of Roman hegemony, personal failings and the twists and turns of Fate, Plutarch tries to show us the struggle of the individual to serve his city, his Empire or his own petty whims. It is a great theme, one that he writes about with insight and with sympathy for those whose stories he is telling.This gets to my annoyance with the Penguin volumes of the Lives. By separating the paired Greek and Roman lives and by presenting them out of sequence, Penguin is trying to present Plutarch as an historian, a role he explicitly denies for himself. While I think he is a very good historian, he is even more a uniquely great essayist in practical political and personal ethics. This is, I believe, how Montaigne read Plutarch and I think both Jefferson and Madison as well. This is how Plutarch has helped to shape our cultural history. In fact, I am going to make the claim that it is impossible to fully understand the debate around the adoption of the U.S. Constitution unless you have read the whole of both Plutarch and Livy. Anyone who wants to persue that thesis with me, please write a comment.My recommendation is that you get the Modern Library edition and dig in. If you don't like it, wait a year or two and try it again. For Plutarch presents us with the broadest possible experience of the world. You may find, like me, that you have to wait a while for your own experience to grow broad enough in order to really see just what an amazing book this ancient neighbor of ours has given us.

I really, really wanted Sarah to love this food, but, no matter how hard I tried, she turned up her spoiled little nose at it.  I have the feeling that she's a junk food junkie, and this is just way too wholesome and good for her for her tastes.  The ingredients list is chock full of good-for-you stuff and she only wants the dog equivalent of Hot Pockets. But don't let my experience put you off.  Instead learn from me: if you never give them anything but the health food, they won't know the junk food exists.

This is a good looking lamp, that has three light intensity settings: low, moderate, and ouch (YMMV on the last one.  I tend to be a little light sensitive.)  It was pretty much ready to go, right out of the box, just plug the electrical cord into the back and then into an outlet.  It also has a USB port in the back, for handy charging of cell phones and other bedside devices.My only bummer regarding this lamp is that when the bulb burns out, your lamp is done for, toast.  Says so right there in the instructions: Bulb is irreplaceable.  So, enjoy the lamp, but don't fall in love with it, 'cause that way just lies heartbreak.

Sarah, the great dog of dogs, only has one problem with her fabulous life.  She has to share her toys with the cats, and their number is legion, the cats that is, not the toys.  So when this precious little plushie arrived, and was presented to her, she took it in her mouth and then shook it like a snowglobe, pronounced it a Very Good Thing, and promptly absconded with it.  Fortunately, I had had the foresight to remove the tags and a small string loop at the top before giving it to her.  I suggest you do like likewise.  I haven't seen hide nor hair of this toy since she trotted off with it, but every now and then, when it's really quiet, I hear a small squeak from wherever Sarah is, and I think I also hear the sound of doggie laughter.

I have used this oil for the past few weeks, and, while it's nice enough, it doesn't foam up like a ladies' shaving cream, which makes it tough to see while shaving.  But even more than that, it's really expensive for the amount you get, and the aroma is quite strong.  I found the aroma nice, but others certainly will not.  No one scent can appeal to all people.  It softens nicely, but I haven't seen any difference between its softening effect and that of a good lotion.  So, if you're willing to pay extra for it, it's a nice shaving oil.  But really, an inexpensive bottle of baby oil will do the same job.

I don't have any knowledge of the ancient Greek language, so I can't speak to the accuracy of the translation, but I can say these new translations of 4 Greek tragedies from antiquity are beautiful in their language and easily accessible to the reader.  I found Prometheus Bound particularly moving, along with Women of Trachis, which the author describes as one of Sophocles' "problem plays."  But to me, it was the fact that even across the centuries, the ancients reach out to us as humans, teaching us that the human experience is the same across time and place.  Well worth the read.

This mighty T. Rex is ready for an afternoon of puppet fun with his favorite human.  He looks a lot like a much bigger version of the T.Rex puppet made by the same company, only his teeth are not made of hard plastic and he doesn't have plastic claws, either.  He's just the right size for a kid or an adult to play with.  I especially like his shiny glittery scales, they make for added fun!

Although this dinosaur figure is smaller than some of the others I have reviewed lately, it is every bit as splendid as the bigger ones.  The colors and the detail work really make this "baby" Dilophosaurus come alive, and it would play well with some of the other, smaller, dinos in Schleich's collection.  It's a fun addition to any collection, just be aware that if you are expecting a larger dino, this one is a smaller scale, but every bit as fun and fascinating!

From its fearsome clawed  toes to its hinged jaw, lined with crocodilian teeth, to its impressive sail-like spine and hefty tail, this is one great looking dinosaur.  It will be a wonderful addition to anyone's collection.  Realistic looking in detail, the skin is patterned and dotted with color and the pose is ready to strike at any moment.  It is obvious that Schleich spends great time and effort in every dinosaur model it creates.  This Spinosaurus is no exception!

The Schleich dinosaur figures just keep getting better and better!  This Giganotosaurus figure is the biggest of their dinosaur figures I have seen so far and it is awe-inspiring!  (Of course, Giganotosaurus is one of the largest dinos ever found, hence the name).  The hand painted details and articulated jaw are great, right down to the touches of light grey paint on the spines along the back.  Balanced just so, on its tail and two hind feet this model looks like its about to take off thundering across the table at any moment.  Spectacular and highly recommended for any collection.

What a great playset: three fantastically detailed Schleich dinosaurs: a Velociraptor, Carnotaurus, and Quetzalcoatlus tucked into a zippered volcano hideout!  When you unzip the volcano, it turns into a fanciful playmat upon which the dinosaurs can act out various scenes from ye olde dino life.  And there's even more room in the volcano hideout once the cardboard interior has been removed. So you can store more dinosaurs from your collection. You and your kids can play Jurassic James Bond vs. Blofeld.  This is a nifty playset and any kid will have lots of fun playing with it.

These are perfectly serviceable heavy duty bags, and they do exactly what they say they're gonna do.  I have put them to the test with a variety of items designed to stress them: a lot of heavy clothing destined for a thrift store, cardboard boxes of various sizes that I had to break down and throw out, even broken glass, and they held up well under the strain.  They don't have a fancy scent or anything, they are just tough 30 gallon bags that can hold a bunch of garbage without tearing under the strain.

This is a package of two soft cloth covered six -sided boxes.  They are very easy to put together, you just unfold them and push the bottoms down inside until it fits nice and snugly.  The boxes don't have lids, but they do come with little plastic clips that you can use to join them together if you want a pairing of two or more.  They are great for holding small items that might otherwise go walkabout on your desk or dresser.  If this is the sort of thing you're looking for to keep small doodads in a single place, then I suggest you give these a try.

These are some smooth razors.  There are four blades and a nice big head with comfort strips, so it's a nice experience.  No Nicks, no cuts, no errors, as they don't say in baseball.  The handle is well designed and fits naturally in my hand.  The price is quite high, at $3.33 per razor as of this writing, but for smooth, silky legs, it's a great deal.  Well worth the splurge!

Okay, here's the deal: if you like coloring books with lots of tiny details that call for finely sharpened colored pencils or fine pointed colored ink pens, then this charming coloring book is for you.  It seems to draw much of its inspiration from Johanna Basford's enormously popular coloring books, The Secret Garden and The Enchanted Forest.  If you prefer coloring books that have larger, less-finely grained drawings, where you can color in broad strokes, then this is probably not the coloring book for you.That said, if you understand what you're getting, you'll fine this coloring book utterly charming and cute.  Very whimsical.  I like it lots.  But if you color with ink pens, put blotting paper under the pages you are working on so the ink doesn't bleed through.Have fun.  Relax.  That's what this is all about.

It took me a little while and some study to figure this device out, but once I managed to get it in comms with my iphone, I was able to to use it to play music through the phone.  I would have greatly preferred a written instruction manual for its setup and use, rather than the modern method, which consists of go online to find instruction and/or suss things out for yourself.Once I got it working though, it was so loud it scared the daylights out of me and my cats.  But we're all having fun now.  I'm very pleased with  the sound and like its portability.Cool device!

This is a great casserole dish, solidly manufactured, easy to clean and with and even cooking surface.  The first thing I made was a shepherd's pie and it came out evenly cooked and delicious without sticking even a little to the dish.  It's pre-seasoned, so it's easy to clean and you can use it pretty much right away. One thing you ought to know: it's really heavy.  But then, top quality cookware usually is.

I find myself in an unusual position here because I'm having to review a dog food which claims to have superior health effects for dogs, but I only received one can, so I don't feel I can assess those claims properly, given the small quantity I was given to test.  It's sort of like being expected to review the efficacy of vitamins based on a single dosage of the vitamin.This I can say, Sarah certainly did enjoy this dog food, esp. when I warmed it up just a bit for her.  She wolfed it right down.  But is it worth the premium price you pay...I can't really say.

Seeing Grigory Sokolov live is on my bucket list, like seeing the remains of ancient Egypt, the Great Wall of China, and visiting Jerusalem.  He is possibly the world's greatest living pianist, certainly one of the top two or three.  Unfortunately, he will probably never come to the US to play, which is one of the reasons he remains so little known in this country.  He also doesn't record often, which is what makes this new recording such a special treat for his fans.  In his hands Chopin's 24 Preludes are transformed into musical landscapes that immerse the listener so wholly that I recommend that you not listen to them while driving.How I wish he would come to this country and play for us.  Please.

Amazon says that 5 stars = "I Love It," but in this case, it really ought to mean, "She Loves It!"I got this to brush my Cavalier King Charles Spaniel mix, and she just can't get enough of it.  She loves this brush so much, I think she would let me brush her bald if I had the inclination. (Which of course, I don't.)  For other brushes and combs she's never sat still, preferring to be off and away as soon as she can.  With this, she just sits there, contentedly allowing me to brush her.  I think if she were a cat, she'd be purring.I'd purr too, because this brush is so easy to clean.  Two thumbs and four paws up!

This is great fun, easy to set up and even the family dog liked it once she realized she wasn't going to die.  Kids will love this, esp. the little splash at the end.  Just one small piece of advice, though: make sure whatever hill you set it up on isn't too steep.  It is possible to go flying right off the end, onto the grass.  And that's not so much fun.  A nice gentle slope is good.

These are very tasty nut bars, sweet and savory, with a light taste of caramel.  They are a bit on the small side and quite thin, so don't expect one to tide you over for very long.  I greatly enjoyed them, however, especially the frosted bottom.  On the whole, I think they are a bit expensive for the amount of food you get, but if you are in the mood to indulge yourself, these are a good choice!

I am a bit disappointed at the low level of SPF in this facial cream.  Why only 15?  That's not even long enough to get a person through the morning.  If you wear make-up, reapplying this cream after the sun protection has worn off is, well, not possible.  I don't wear make-up, so it's not a problem for me, but anyone considering the purchase of this product should factor that issue in.  I am pleased, however, that it does indeed seem to be fragrance-free.  Not even my cats notice or react to a scent.  I also find that it's a bit thick in terms of its consistency, but others may not mind so much.  Therefore, I have stopped using this in the morning and now use it at night, where it works out just fine!

I'm sorry, I have struggled and struggled to read this book, but the writing is so overdone that it overwhelms the content.  Truly, I'm sure the author has valuable information to impart, but his ideas are bound up in a thicket of words that one needs a mental machete to cut through and I don't have the patience for that.  This kind of writing is self-indulgent.  A firm editor is what's called for here.

The Maven is God's gift to people who use their iPhones to the very limits of its battery!  It is great!  It carries a whole additional battery charged for the iPhone within its slim body, so slapping this puppy on your phone is like walking around with a double-charged phone.  It's incredibly easy to use, and the instructions are fun to read because the writers have a sense of humor.  Oh, and the case also has protective features to keep your phone from being damaged if it is dropped, so...bonus!

This is an excellent hard drive that has worked well for my aging Mac.  The old Mac was slowing down, but once I offloaded a bunch of stuff onto this hard drive, it seemed to kind of breath more life into the old thing.  One thing  should mention is that this drive is too big to fit into my old 'puter, so I bought a case for it and turned it into an external drive.  I got the case from Amazon as well.  It's a Sabrent Ultra Slim USB 2.0 to 2.5-Inch SATA External Aluminum Hard Drive Enclosure [Black] (EC-UK25).  The drive fit into the case very nicely.

It is almost impossible to describe the three days of torment I endured trying to put this mess together before finally giving up and putting it in a heap to go to the dump.  First of all, this is not one of those -easy-to-assemble pieces of furniture that comes with all the tools you need to put it together.  You're going to need things like an electric screwdriver and various other tools that are not provided.  So if you are used to an IKEA type setup, you might want to just move along.  Pick something else that won't leave you crying in a heap on the floor.  Really.  You need to be MacGyver to put this junk together.Second, it is cheap particle board, and it seemed to me that all the pieces were cut out by poorly trained gibbons.  I played merry heck trying to get any of this stuff to fit together. Nothing seemed to fit.  There were mysterious, inexplicable gaps and funky overlaps.Finally, even though I got this for free in exchange for my review, I deeply regret getting it because now I have to dispose of it, and the sucker is heavy.  I don't know any Olympic weightlifters, so getting it to the dump is going to be a challenge.

This is the generic version of Frontline, which means that in terms of its active ingredients, it is no different than Frontline.  Please be aware however, that inactive ingredients may differ from the name-brand product, and your cat may be allergic to some of those inactive ingredients.  But generally speaking, most people's cats, if they tolerate Frontline well, will not have a problem with this product.By an large, this Sentry Fiproguard is much more affordable than the name-brand.  I used this on three of my cats and they all did just fine with it.  It kills fleas every bit as effectively as Frontline, but leaves a bit more money in your wallet.  Which is a nice thing.

Well, where to begin...This facial treatment arrived in a burgundy colored box, with no instructions as to its use and no listing of its ingredients.  The liquid contained within the lovely frosted glass bottle has the consistency of water, and, as far as my face is concerned, about as much effectiveness.  I have used it faithfully for about three weeks now and don't look a lick different than I did when I started.This facial treatment, however, will lighten your pocket by more than $100.00

This is a great 3 hole punch.  It punches through great wads of paper like a hot knife through butter, the punching mechanism is easy to push down (meaning you don't need the strength of Hercules to punch through the paper) and the little round confetti stays in the bottom tray until you are ready to empty it out.  It's really every thing I ever wanted in a three hole punch.  I'm going to sell my old one at a yard sale.

A medium weight skin cream that works really well.  I have been using this cream for about a week and have already noticed that some of the rough, dry patches, like on my heels and elbows, are much, much better.  It doesn't leave me feeling overwhelmingly greasy, but I have noticed that it does leave a noticeable, body-cream feel for about an hour after use.  I have also noticed that it does its best work when I put it on after a shower.  The bottle says it's fragrance free, but my cats disagree.

The unsolved disappearance of Judge Crater was one of the great scandals of early 20th century New York City.  Today, almost 100 years later, it is less well-known, but still remains a tantalizing mystery and the source of speculation.  Ariel Lawhorn takes the basic facts about Judge Crater and weaves an absorbing story around the judge's disappearance and the women in his life.  Well-written and interesting, this is and excellent book.

This is a great little swing for babies.  Easy to put together, folds for portability.  Swings back and forth, as well as from side to side, and has soothing music to help lull the baby to sleep.  One caveat, however, is that once baby hits 25 pounds or so, it's too small to safely hold the little one.  Still, it's a lovely way to soothe a cranky baby, and a cranky mom!

This is a great cardboard castle that will have a lot of appeal for little girls.  It was very easy to assemble, we didn't even really have to look at the directions all that much because it's pretty much self-explanatory.  The doors are functional and fun for kids to crawl in and out of, and they can also peep out of the windows.  It won't stand up to a lot of really rough play, but it is just made out of cardboard.  For the price, this is a great play fort for rainy afternoons.

This is a nice chai latte, subtly spiced, not overwhelming.  I found it a little bit too milky for my taste, but some folks may disagree.  The way I dealt with that is to brew it with a bit less water.  If you use the big mug setting on your Keurig, you're liable to get a very watered down, weak tasting chai latte.

I have to admit I was a little nervous at the prospect of putting a screen protector on my iPhone as I'd heard that it was hard to do properly and easy to mess up.  So I took a deep breath, worked up my courage, and found out it wasn't that bad.  I made sure to read the instructions carefully and followed them to the letter and I was able to complete the task without getting any bubbles.  It wasn't easy peasy, but it was easier than I'd been led to expect.

This Lonely Planet guide to Canada is sort of like the travel book equivalent of Canada's greatest hits.  It contains descriptions and info on those places most likely to be visited by a tourist taking a quick trip to Canada who just wants to see the highlights: Toronto, Nova Scotia, Banff, etc.  If you are looking for information on Baffin Island, in other words, this is not the book for you.  You'll want Lonely Planet's 900+ page guide to Canada, which is much more comprehensive, but not so full of pictures.  Discover Canada has loads of great pictures, though, and is quite good as a handy little guide to the Best of Canada.

Herman Koch's Breakout novel was "The Dinner", a chilling little novel that relied on an unreliable narrator for its effect.  In "Summer House With Swimming Pool", Koch's narrator, Dr. Marc Schlosser, is anything but unreliable.  The not-so-good doctor is completely honest with his readers; in fact, his honesty carries with it a brutality that some readers will find unnerving and repellent.
