His descriptions of his patients, his opinions of them and what they are doing to themselves, may move some to put this book down and walk away, because at first, spending time in the company of this jaded and cynical man is abhorrent.  He's no Marcus Welby, M.D. and he's not a friendly family doctor, despite the facade he presents.  No, this is a man steeped in an intense contempt for his fellow human beings, and that is a characteristic most of us would rather a doctor didn't have.But to walk away from his novel would be a mistake (though there are some parts I skipped over due to intense squeamishness).  In creating Dr. Schlosser, Herman Koch is giving his readers a magnificent display of the first responsibility of any writer: honesty.  As awful as he is, Marc Schlosser is completely honest with the reader about what he has done (some awful, awful things) and the reasons he has done them.  The psychological insights Herman Koch lays bare for his readers are exceeded only by the excellence of his writing.As brutal as it is, this novel was just fascinating.

Of the 4 bags of dog food I obtained for my dog Sarah to review, this is her least favorite.  She sort of noses it around in the bowl and then gives me an accusatory look.  I think she knows it's diet.

I think I may have noted this before in another review, but someone once said that the essence of a good thriller was to get your protagonist(s) up a tree and then start throwing rocks at them.  Well, The Darkest Hour puts its protagonist, John Rossett, up a tree, and then unleashes a landslide of rocks, Nazis, untrustworthy resistance fighters, and possible collaborators on his head.  But don't feel too much sympathy for him, because Rossett is also a collaborator:  he works for the Nazis in occupied Britain (this is an alternate history novel, ala  Fatherland) rounding up and deporting Jews to death camps.  He's a numbed out guy whose wife and son were killed in a resistance bombing.  He knows what he's doing, but he tells himself he's just doing a job.  He himself is the worst sort of collaborator.  He is the good man who assists evil men in doing their filthy work and he grows ever more sullied and further from redemption with each passing minute.Then, the owner of his childhood candy store places his greatest treasure, his grandson Jacob, in Rossett's hands and begs Rossett to save the boy.  Jacob, as it turns out, is also the key to a fortune in diamonds.  Soon enough, the game is afoot, the hunt is on.  Everybody wants the diamonds, but does anybody also want to save the boy?This is the kind of book that beneath its surface raises important questions, not the least of which is: Will Rossett redeem himself?  Is it even possible for him to redeem himself? You'll have to read it for yourself to find out.

Although my dog Sarah loves Beneful's Healthy Fiesta dog food, she's not so enamored of the IncrediBites Dog Food.  I'm not sure why, but I think that it might be because the morsels are smaller.  The bits of food are roughly half the size of the Healthy Fiesta food, and I don't think she gets as satisfying a crunch from IncrediBites as she does from HF.  This food seems to be as palatable as HF, but somehow, she finds it disappointing.

When you give a product 5 stars on Amazon, a little sentence pops up next to the stars that says, "I love it."  In this case, it is not strictly true that I love this dog food, so much as it is true that Sarah loves this dog food.  And love it she does.  I think she likes that the pieces are nice and big and give her more crunch satisfaction.  It's kind of hard to know, because she can't tell me exactly why it is hat she loves this food so much.  All I can say is hat when we put it down in front of her she goes after it with a gusto that indicates that it is her most favoritest (I made that word up) food ever.  And that's all that matters to me.  Because she's my most favoritest dog ever and what makes her happy makes me happy (within limits).

You really can't go wrong with Iams, they seem to have their fingers on the pulse of dogs and cats everywhere.  We rescued a Cavalier King Charles Spaniel mix about two years ago, and when she came to us, she was as skinny as a rail.  Two years later, on our family's "food is love" plan, she's a waddling couch potato.  So we've been looking at weight management kibbles and this one seems to really please her.  She munches on this dog food and doesn't even seem to know it's diet.  She's lost a little bit of weight so far, and seems to have regained some of her old energy.

My car was a mess, I freely admit.  :)  It had been a long time since I gave it a thorough clean, so when the opportunity to test and review this item came my way, I decided it was time to clean the machine.  Einszett Cockpit Premium does a wonderful job cleaning and shining the vinyl dash and other vinyl area in my car.  A few swipes and all the dust and crumbs are gone, leaving behind a spiffy, glossy shine.  I was very impressed!

Paisley Mischief is slightly amusing and aims to poke fun in a P.G. Wodehouse kind of way at the old money preppies of New York and their arcane manners and traditions.  At just over 200 pages, and with a plot so slight and unassuming that it barely seems to exist, this is an afternoon's read at best.  It's not demanding in any sense of the word and it's unlikely to offend anyone's sensibilities.  It's the literary equivalent of a meringue cookie: light and inoffensive, dissolving in seconds, leaving only the impression of there ever having been a story at all.

I got this for my adored one, Sarah, a Cavalier King Charles Spaniel mix, who, despite her royal name, insists on sleeping on the floor, much to my distress.  It's part of an ongoing quest to find a dog bed she'll actually use.  This is not the bed for her, she has ignored it, not even so much a sniff of passing interest.  But that's not why I gave a mere three stars.  After all, just because my particular, picky princess turns up her muzzle at this bed, doesn't mean it's a poor product.No, I gave it three stars because it took three people and the strength of Hercules to put the bloody thing together.  And after we did get it assembled, it was warped.  The warping has settled down over the past few days as my cats have played on it and laid on it, but it was quite disconcerting at first.And what a time they have had!  They play king of the castle on it, they sleep on it, they bat at one another through the holes in the corners.  It has been a huge hit with my young felines.  That is the only thing that kept it from being sent back.Meanwhile, the quest for a Sarah-acceptable dog bed continues...

These are perfectly lovely napkins, suitable for casual family use, or for friends getting together for an informal dinner.  They are very well constructed; I have washed them several times and they have stood up well so far.  They do tend to come out of the dryer somewhat wrinkled, but that's because they are 100% cotton, which makes them highly suitable for the task of wiping away and absorbing stray bits at the dinner table.  If the wrinkling is unacceptable, they also do quite well under a hot iron, and it doesn't take more than five minutes to iron all four of them.In addition, they are quite pretty in an understated way.

Like many people, I hate buying toilet paper, because, well, although it is completely necessary, it represents the flushing of money down the toilet.  So I look for the best bargain I can get, because  the less money I flush, the happier I am.For some folks, single-ply, harsh as sandpaper, 1000 sheet per roll toilet paper seems like the best bargain out there, and that's okay, if you have a hide like a rhinoceros.  But, if like me, you are girl with a more delicate heinie, those bargain brands are not really what they seem to be.  First, because they are abrasive and don't feel good at all, but also because they're thin single-ply, and you end up using great big wads in order to achieve proper levels of absorbency and what I think of as "hand coverage."  Y'all know what I mean by that...Enter the Charmin Ultra Soft Toilet Paper 24 Mega Roll.  A much better deal than superficial analysis would seem to indicate.  First, it is, indeed, soft and plush.  It's angel wings soft, doesn't abrade the bottom or other bits at all.  Feels downright nice in fact.  Also, it's two-ply, embossed, and holds up well, meaning it doesn't separate in your hands.  It's very absorbent and provides excellent hand coverage.  What does this add up to?You can use less of this toilet paper to get the same job done.  With the same level of cleanliness, but much better softness.  That means this toilet paper is every bit as cost effective as the old school Soviet style toilet paper, but with the added bonus of eiderdown softness.I'll take the added bonus, please and thank you.

This is a nice device that is quite up to the task of removing the tops and hulls of large strawberries.  I have found that it has two problems, though.  First, it completely eviscerates small strawberries, just destroys them.  For large strawberries, it's just fine, though.  It's also not that easy to clean, you have to take it apart and put it back together and I find that takes some doing.For my money, the best strawberry hullers is my old reliable Chef'n Stem Gem Strawberry Huller.  I've had it for years and it works like a champ in berries large and small.

'Cause she sure wasn't getting mine!This fits my iPhone beautifully, all the holes line up very well with the openings for headphones and chargers and the like.  In addition, the button covers also work well, I'm able to easily turn the phone off and on, and raise an lower the volume.  I like the grooves on the side that make it easier to grip the phone.  I haven't dropped my phone, so can't really comment on the protection, but given the thickness of the case, I feel quite confident that it would afford better protection than my old case.  I like this so much, I even bought one for my mother to use on her phone.

First thing you should know is that this is a very expensive way to keep your floors clean.  The little bottle of floor cleaner and the pads are quite costly and short of refilling the bottle yourself and making your own pads, there are no cheaper alternatives to the Swiffer brand products.  So although the initial cost of buying the kit seems reasonable, over the long run, it gets quite pricey.That said, if you have many pets and want a simple way to clean up without having to constantly resort to the full on mop and bucket routine, this is a very convenient product.  I found it quite easy to put the mop together and put the solution in the little slot.  I made a rookie mistake, however, in taking the purple printed strips off the pad.  Don't remove those strips, you need them, or the pad won't stick to the mop.  You only get two pads in this starter kit.  Also, you will need 4 double A batteries, which are NOT provided (tsk, tsk).Their customer support is OUTSTANDING.  I had a problem getting the Wetjet to spritz, so I called them up and a very pleasant young lady walked me through a few steps.  Within about two minutes, she had helped me figure out the problem and correct it.  Once it was fixed, the spritzer worked like a champ.  I was spritzing like a maniac and dirt was getting mopped up left, right, and center.  This mop does its job well.  Our wood floors now look much nicer.Thank you, Swiffer people

We've  been using Moen products in our home for many years. They've almost always been trouble free and "just worked" and their warranty service  for the odd issue has always been very good.We're upgrading our kitchen and this is the perfect faucet for us. It's extremely attractive, easy to use and is a huge improvement from our previous faucet. Installation is very straightforward and something that most homeowners who are moderately handy should be able to do on their own in less than an hour. For me, the hardest part was removing the old faucet since it had welded itself together.Before beginning installation, unpack the box and review the instructions and where you put each piece. Most important is the location of the control box. Moen recommends mounting the box near the base of the faucet, but there's an alternate method that requires an extension kit if you can't use the recommended method. I recommend putting the battery box off to the side and ensure easy access for changing batteries. For those who don't want to mess with changing batteries, an AC adapter is available.Using the faucet is amazing. My wife wasn't expecting the Motionsense feature, but instantly fell in love with it. If you need to fill a large pot, you can use the lever to let the water run for as long as you need. Most of the time, we use Motionsense which greatly reduces splashed water under the faucet handle.

There are times when I need to lever something into position and my go-to solutions have been a long handled flat-blade screwdriver, crow-bar, or whatever I could find to fit a particular angle. The problem with all of those tools is that they're not made for that particular job and don't provide a good fulcrum and don't always have the correct angle. More often than not, the tool will slip, I'll bust my knuckles  and I've got to start all over againThe GearWrench Indexable Pry Bar is exactly the right tool to use in most of those situations. The shape of the foot is rounded for exerting the most force and the angle can be set for a wide variety of angles.  When you roll the foot back as far as it will go, it's the perfect angle to lift a motor from underneath.Changing angles is pretty simple, you press the index button, select the angle you want and click it into place. The 16-inch model is a good length for almost any job. They do warn you not to use a cheater bar since that will overstress the bar. I didn't see a force rating listed, but the unit feel very strong and will likely serve me for many years. Now that I've had a chance to use it, I'll buy one or two extras.Bottom line: This thing is awesome

My family has been using OtterBox cases on our phones and tablets for a while now and we've never been let down. My company issued us all iPhone 6 Plus phones and a whimpy little case to keep it 'safe'. Since we're on the hook to keep them healthy and happy, I wanted to add as much protection as possible and chose the OtterBox Defender to do the job.For those that aren't familiar with the OtterBox Defender, it's a large sturdy case with a rubberized bumper surrounding a hard plastic shell with a built-in screen protector and small covers over the ports.Installing my phone was very easy once I managed to peel the rubber bumper from the edge of the case. It latches into the inner shell and can be a bit challenging the first time, but once it's removed things go very smoothly from there. After removing the bumper, you unlatch the clips on either side of the shell and open it up. Once the case is open, double check the phone's screen to ensure it doesn't have any smudges or fingerprints, because once the case is back on, it'll make you nuts until you open it up to clean the screen.Once the phone is safely ensconced inside the case, eassembly is very easy. You press the two halves of the shell together, ensuring that the clips are aligned properly, then work the rubber bumper around the edges until they slide into position. Overall, it's a fairly fast process.The OtterBox isn't a tiny little case and it will add significant bulk to your phone. There's an included clip for attaching the case to your belt, but it doesn't rotate. I prefer to keep the phone in a jacket pocket whenever possible.Bottom line: The OtterBox Defender is probably the ultimate case for those who need to keep their phone safe. Since my family's been using OtterBoxes, no one has damaged any of their devices.

Corel Painter 2016 is the latest in a series of art-oriented tools for the Mac and PC. My last exposure to Painter was with the X3 version and the newest version has many new features that make Painter even more useful than before.The user interface resembles Adobe Photoshop and is fairly intuitive for those that have used similar products in the past. The default set of tools lets you get to work right away. While Adobe Photoshop is great for modifying photos, it's rather limited for creating art by itself. Painter gives you access to a wide variety of paints, pens, pencils, brushes and media textures with a workflow that allows you to work more or less naturally. I highly recommend using a tablet instead of a mouse, but either will work.For those who aren't familiar with similar programs or need some extra help, there are a large number of tutorials available to help you with almost every aspect of the program.One of my favorite features is the watercolor brushes and paper. Although it's not quite the same as using watercolors, it allows the artist to create art that looks very similar to the real thing. I find it most useful for quick and dirty watercolor renderings of photographs by keeping the original photo down at one layer and "painting" over it on another layer. Yes, it's cheating. But it gives a nice result without spending hours of work with physical media. Layers and paths work much as you'd expect.My only issue with the program is the 'lag' I sometimes get when using broad watercolor brushes and move my 'brush' too quickly. Thank goodness for undo.Overall, I think that Painter 2016 is a fine program who want to try their hand at more involved digital art, but the sales price when this review was written is rather steep for a casual investment.

I've been using iHome products for quite some time and have always had good luck. I was happy to find the iHome IX360BC Bluetooth speaker on Amazon and have been having a lot of fun carrying it around with me while doing chores at home.The speaker is slim and very solid feeling. It can be paired using NFC or using the normal bluetooth pairing method on your device. Bluetooth range is good and for those times where bluetooth isn't an option, there's an auxiliary stereo input jack. The speaker comes with a wall-wart type charger which seems to bring it up to a full charge pretty quickly.There are a set of controls that are molded into the top of the speaker and can be used to change volume, turn the unit on and off and  initiate bluetooth pairing. They're a little hard to see, but work as expected. If the unit sits idle for too long, it powers itself down to save the batteries. That's helped a few times when my daughter was using the speaker while washing dishes, and walked off without turning the speaker off.Bottom line: I'm very happy with the iHome IX360BC Rechargable speaker. It's a great way to play and share your music when you're away from home or while doing chores.There's also an iOS application that can make the large "X" on the speaker flash a certain color for things like new emails, messages or what have you. It's very configurable and works pretty well.Sound quality is very good, but as expected, doesn't have much in the way of stereo separation.

SilencerCo makes pretty nice stuff, but not all firearms have the correct length on their threaded barrels. This spacer allows me to correctly mount my Spectre on a CZ 455 Varmint barrel with no problem at all.

This is the fourth Novation keyboard I've owned. No, none of the previous ones have died or had issues. Instead, I find that they're very high-quality, flexible controllers that don't cost a fortune. I have and regularly use the 25 key and 61 key versions of the SL Mk II as well as the 25 key version of the original LaunchKey.I find that the LaunchKey Mk2 controller has the same good build quality as the other keyboards and it integrates very well with my copy of Ableton Live Suite. The lite version this keyboard comes with offers many good features and is a great way to start out with Ableton Live 9.One of the other big improvements is the use of RGB for the pads. My original LaunchKey only had a few colors and was helpful, but the wide variety of colors allow you to quickly switch between tracks which makes workflow much more seamless. I wish that my LaunchPad had the same capability as the Launchkey Mk2 since I find it so useful.Another notable difference between the SL series and the LaunchKey controllers is the keyboard weighting and encoder types. The SL series have full rotary encoders, AutoMap and a Fatar semi-weighted keyboard, while the LaunchKey uses traditional pots, InControl and a synth-weighted keyboard. Doing glisses on the SL is markedly better, but at the price point of the LaunchKey it's still quite acceptable and vastly superior to many other brands of keyboards I've owned in the past. The addition of multiple velocity curves was also very welcome since I hate having to beat on a keyboard to get the attack I want.I was gratified how simple it was to get to work with the LaunchKey MkII. After I updated my copy of Ableton Live, I plugged in the keyboard, launched Ableton and was able to get to work quickly.For the musician on a budget, it's hard to go wrong with the LaunchKey series and it makes a great springboard to their other products later.

The Magpul MOE handguard for the AK-47 is typical Magpul quality. It comes with a good set of instructions as well as a built-in heat shield.Installation was fairly easy, but I needed to do a bit of filing in order to get the upper portion fully installed. This isn't a fault of Magpul at all. They include a bit of extra material so it will fit better to the sometimes inconsistent dimensions between the endless variants in the AK family.Once installed, the foregrip does a great job. My hands stay cool and I'm able to maintain a solid grip. I've added a sling mount point to my foregrip and a matching point on my Zhukov stock.

The Invicta 21484 watch is a solid, attractive timepiece that comes in a two-tone finish. In addition to the main dial, there are three smaller dials that indicate the day, the date and a second time zone. The watch is quite hefty and comes with an strap with a locking clasp. The locking clasp is an improvement on watches I've owned in the past and would pop open if you looked at them wrong, while the clasp on the Invicta latches firmly into place and feels quite secure.One thing that impressed me is the substantial case that held the watch. It's huge and fairly attractive. I don't know if it's real leather or not, but it smells like it is.  The instructions are fairly basic. They show you how to set the watch and what the various dials and buttons are used for. The rest of the literature covers warranty, the various models and whatnot.Even though I don't have thin wrists, I found that there were quite a few extra links on the band. The extras are for those guys with Popeye arms who shouldn't have any trouble wearing this watch. The extra links the old-fashioned way by using a toothpick or paperclip. Make sure you don't launch a spring-loaded pin across the room. It's easy to do if you're not careful. Getting the band reassembled is fairly easy and it took only a few minutes before I was done.Setting the watch follows the traditional model, you pull out the stem and rotate one way to set the hour and minute and the other direction to set the day. The buttons on either side of the stem are used to advance the date and second time zone (N.B. The second time zone dial is rather small and indicates 24 hours rather than 12. This is because time zones that are distant from your own can be many hours off and you'll need 24 hours to show the difference. One can also use the second time zone dial as a way to show a 24 hour clock in your own time zone.Although I like the Invicta very much, there are a few nits that I find bothersome. The first is the bezel. Since they show the watch as being water resistant to 330 feet and has a bezel that looks like one would use for scuba diving, one would think that the bezel would rotate. It does not.  Related to that is the stem. My Seiko Divers watch has both a rotating bezel and a stem that locks by screwing it down.  It is also limited to 330 feet, but I trust it more to live up to that claim than a watch without a lock-down bezel.Since most of the people who are likely to buy this watch aren't divers, those nits probably don't matter.It has a bezel that appears to be usable for scuba diving,

I have a pretty good collection of SOG knives and tools now and their quality construction never fails to impress me.The PowerLock Traveler Multi-Tool is no exception. It's well made, easy to use and has nearly tool I need for most tasks,  but a knife. Since this is a TSA-approved design (for now, there are no promises when dealing with the TSA), it's likely to stay in my possession if I forget to move my tools to my checked bags.Some people (like those that chew their nails) may have an issue deploying some of the tools hidden in the handle, but it helps if you press the locking button for that side to make the desired tool easier to extract. In a pinch, the flip-up handle covers can be removed and used to lift the tool from inside the handle, but you run a good chance of bending the cover and you should avoid doing so if possible.This tool has a stainless steel finish, but there's an oxide coated finished model available. I usually prefer the oxide coated models since they're a bit less slippery, but the stainless steel model looks very nice.The carrying case clips neatly on your belt. I've tried carrying the Multi-Tool in my pocket without the case, but it's fairly heavy and feels bulky, even in a jeans pocket.Grip strength with the pliers is above average and I've used the wire cutter and crimper on many occasions without issue.Overall, this is a great tool. If you want a version with a blade, check out their other models, but if you travel very often, it's nice to have a tool that won't end up in the pocket of a TSA agent.

FoodSaver GameSaver bags are heavier duty versions of the standard FoodSaver bags and have features to help block oxygen and moisture from your food.I've used these bags with my standard FoodSaver without any problems and prefer them since they also stand up better to handling inside a crowded Freezer.

The TP-Link AV500 is a set of devices that allow you to use a segment of an in-home electrical circuit to extend an ethernet network using ordinary house wiring. I'm a bit curious how they can advertise a potential maximum speed of 500 Mbps when the device only has 10/100 Mbps network ports (specs taken directly from their web site). Sometimes, marketing people like to impart magical abilities to devices that have specific physical limitations, so I'd take their claim with a very large grain of salt. To me, it borders on dishonesty.I'm using the set to create a wired network between the home office and one of the guest rooms upstairs. Since they're both on the same breaker and has little electrical noise, I'm getting decent overall bandwidth between the two devices. It's not nearly as good as a direct connection to the gigabit network or even my existing Wifi network. The maximum speed I've seen is around 14 mbps when using the two devices on the same circuit and directly connected to the wall. I've also noticed significant and wildly varying when running a ping between two systems on my home network.I've used a similar set of 10 megabit devices in the past and had terrible luck with those, but my experiences with AV500 have been an improvement.The biggest limitation to devices that use in-home wiring to extend networks is electrical noise and power conditioning equipment such as uninterruptible power supplies and power strips with built-in RF filters.As noted above, I got the best speed when I used the devices with receptacles on the same circuit (both on the same circuit breaker). I did some experimenting and tried a variety of configurations throughout the house. I found that using receptacles on two separate circuits (on two different breakers), resulted in lower overall speeds.  I also found that things like dimmer switches and things like fluorescent lights, fans and motors also caused enough noise on the circuit to slow speeds even further. Since all homes and circumstances vary your experience with the AV500 may be different.At no point during my testing did I ever see speeds approaching the maximum rate implied by TP-Link, but I was able to establish a usable connection with nearly every configuration I tried. Electrical noise seems to be the biggest enemy of bandwidth and as long as you set your expectations accordingly, it's a usable way to extend a network to another room when WiFi or a regular ethernet connection isn't an option.

I've used quite a few different FRS/GMRS walking talkies over the years and I've always had very good luck with Motorola-branded models.The Talkabout T465 has a lot of improvements over earlier models, especially with the batteries. A feature I especially like is the instant access to weather information. That's been very helpful when we're out on a hike and the weather starts looking iffy.The carrying case does a great job keeping all of the parts together and adequately protected.I've had good luck communicating over moderate distances, but one must keep in mind that the maximum distances listed are in ideal conditions with no obstructions between. We've used GMRS modes at Disney a World in the past and a couple of miles was the max. Using the "privacy" modes don't encrypt the data and only work as a way to reduce clutter on the band. Anyone who chooses the same frequency and mode can hear what's being transmitted.Overall, I find this to be a great little set of radios. I'll buy a better set of headphones later since the ones included in the set don't work well in high noise environments. Be aware that a GMRS license is required from the FCC to use the GMRS modes legally.

I use this with an older non-railed P229 which has a slightly different shaped trigger guard than the P229R and initially noticed that the retention mechanism was a bit difficult to engage. Disengaging was much easier and drawing is no problem whatsoever.The main reason I purchased this particular holster is that it's nearly identical to the IWI-made roto retention holster for my CZ SP-01 Tactical and I prefer that all of my retention holsters operate in the same manner.As with the IWI holster, the cant angle can be adjusted by removing the firearm from the holster and inserting the supplied wrench through hole in the release button, loosening the screw and setting the desired angle.Since this holster is similar in function to the Blackhawk SERPA type holsters, you need to ensure that you keep your finger absolutely straight when pressing the release button and drawing the firearm. If you push the release button with the tip of your finger, your finger may find its way inside the trigger guard before you're ready to shoot.Although it's harder to negligently discharging a double-action pistol than it is with something like a Glock, it's still a very good habit to build since muscle memory is what we fall back on when we're stressed. I typically leave my finger along the frame until the firearm is level and pointed downrange and I'm ready to shoot. If I don't intend to shoot immediately, it stays against the frame. Canting the holster forward a bit can help keep your trigger finger up on the frame when you draw, while canting it back too far can result in your finger ending up too close to the trigger and potentially causing issues.Bottom line: It's a great holster, but requires some adjustment and training to be used properly.

I frequently find myself needing a light nailer to assemble picture frames and whatnot. I've struggled with brad hammers for years and there are times that you need three hands to accomplish the job.The Arrow PT18G is a great solution for those who need a well-made brad nailer and have an air compressor with decent air flow. (I use a Makita MAC5200 which keeps up nicely with the demands of the nailer).  I normally run the unit at 90psi, but it runs works at 80psi using 1" brads. The rated maximum pressure is 120psi.The nailer's simple to operate and does a fine job with all of the brad sizes I'm likely to need. It's a very good thing that it's fairly intuitive since I received absolutely no instructions and can find nothing on their web site either. If it's there, it's very well hidden.I put the nailer through its paces and found it easy to load and unload. The nose piece is bare metal which means that you'll need to be careful not to mar the finish of your work. I've not noticed any issues with oil spray on my work, but it's certainly something to keep an eye on as time progresses. One nice touch is the ease of clearing misfeeds using the latch at the working end of the nailer. I've not had any misfeeds yet, but it's always a possibility.Overall, I think it's a great product, but I took away one star for the complete lack of documentation.Update:I contacted Arrow Customer Support and to their credit, they sent me a PDF copy of the PT18G manual. If it was on their site, it certainly wasn't obvious, but I'm impressed that they were so responsive.

While scissors aren't the most exciting things in the world, having a set that doesn't work properly is a pain.The Westcott Recycled 8-inch Straight Scissors do what they're designed to. They cut paper and light fabrics cleanly and fit a wide range of hand sizes. Although I'm right-handed, they work well with my left hand (discounting any uncoordination on my part) and were easy to control.Engagement between the scissor halves is good and I was able to make full, clean cuts along the entire length of the blade without any problems. Since these are lightweight scissors, I'd avoid cutting heavy cardboard or fabrics since it puts a great deal of stress on the pivot pin which appears to be plastic on this set.Given the very low cost, one can place a set of these anywhere one might need scissors so a set will always be close at hand.
While these aren't something you'd want to use every day, the P-51 functions well as a can opener in an emergency situation. I usually have at least two tucked away in my backpack for emergencies.

These are essential for training as well as safely checking the operation of your rifle. I've used several brands of snap caps in the past and the A-Zoom models are very well made and don't get scuffed up as badly as some of the others I've used in the past.

Smartphones and Bluetooth have revolutionized sports-related electronics. However, one of the biggest issues with them is being able to see their displays easily or to interact safely with them when you're in motion. I've come close to disaster a few times when trying to fiddle with my stem-mounted iPhone and once I saw the glasses offered by the "G" company, I knew it was only a matter of time before we'd begin seeing similar devices for sports use.The Recon Jet Smart Eyewear are one of the first sports-related devices I've seen on the market and I was anxious to see how they'd improve my cycling experience. Since they pair with my ANT+ sensors and can upload activity data into various fitness apps for tracking, they'll be a good addition to my fitness plan. Since they're very "high-tech" looking, you might get funny looks from some people, so I don't see wearing them unless I'm cycling or something.Getting them set up is fairly simple. You're first directed to their website where you create an account, then register the device. When you first attach your glasses to your computer (I used a Mac), the firmware is updated and the device is unlocked. Using their software, you can load maps into the glasses for use on the road as well as other apps.The Recon Jet Smart Eyewear build quality seems to be very good. The glasses are fairly comfortable, but required a lot of fiddling around to place the screen where I could see it clearly. The best position for me is to mount the glasses high on my nose and as close to my face as possible. Perhaps it's the shape of my nose, but the only way the glasses fit is where the bottoms of the nose piece are resting against the bridge of my nose which gets uncomfortable after a while.Image quality is good. In spite of it being so close to my eye and my needing reading glasses, the display is perfectly readable when the glasses are in the correct position. One issue I have is that my right eye has an astigmatism which causes some vertical blurring on the display, but that's not the glasses fault. It would be nice to have a stick-on corrective lense to take care of that issue for people (hint, hint).The controls are minimal. There's a forward and back rocker on the bottom of the right side and a touch sensitive pad for scrolling through options. There's also a small 'joystick' for adjusting display position. As others have mentioned, voice control would be nice as would an earbud jack or built-in earbuds.  It's a bit funny that you can control music with the glasses, but not use them to play it back through the glasses.The user interface takes a bit of getting used to, but the quick access mode helps you get to the most-used options fairly quickly. Since I only plan to use the glasses for cycling, controlling music playback and video capture, the UI is fine. Anything more complex would be dangerous to use while you're in motion.The main problem I've had is with the fit of the glasses and keeping them from moving around. The placement of the device is extremely critical and if the glasses slip, you can no longer see the display clearly. This is a big issue when moving my head around while mounted. I ride both a road and mountain bike and I constantly move my head in a variety of positions. I'd love to see different nose pieces available, perhaps even a do-it-yourself kit that lets you make an nosepiece that conforms perfectly to your nose. As an experiment, I took a new set of orange foam earplugs and created cushions that let the glasses fit more comfortably and when used with a retaining strap, stayed in position perfectly. Since they kind of ruin the whole "high-tech Robo-Cop" vibe, I'll replace the orange plugs with something that's not so glaringly different than the glasses. :)A device as complex as this can't be fairly judged within a few days or even a couple of weeks. I plan on updating my review on a regular basis to record the full user experience. Although Recon makes a set of Smart Ski Goggles, I'll take these to the slope when ski season hits and see how they work there.Bottom line: They're very useful for monitoring activity-related stats, but placement and stability on your face is critical. Battery life is good for a couple of hours (it may be possible to keep the unit charged while in use with a microUSB cable and a larger battery pack, I'll test that and report back). The number of third-party apps in encouraging, but I'd like to see integration with a larger number iPhone activity apps.

When I'm out on travel or out of touch with civilization, it's hard to keep your devices like GPSs, E-Book readers, phones and tablets charged. I used to take along a ton of batteries that I could charge from, but those are too fussy and a pain to insert and remove. I also find them useful for running a set of LED lights reading lights and a small USB fan. Before heading out, I charge the device fully and if I'm at a campsite, keep the charger topped off with a small solar charger.A few years back, I began purchasing power bricks while they were a big improvement, the early ones cost a lot and didn't hold that much of a charge.The Monoprice 16,000 mAh Portable Charger is one of the newer generation of power bricks that delivers a substantial amount of power for things like topping off tablets, phones. I received the non-retail packaging version which came packed in a recyclable cardboard box that gave it plenty of protection. The Portable Charger has ports for charging two devices concurrently (one 1 A and one 2 A port) and a microUSB port for charging the brick. There's a charging indicator that also shows the amount of charge remaining by pressing a button and a built-in LED flashlight that's activated by pushing the button twice.The device came fully charged, so I drained it by having it charge multiple devices. There was more than enough power to top off my iPhone 6, my daughters phones and my old iPad 3. I let the Monoprice Portable Charger charge overnight and after 9 hours, it was at 100 percent again.The device is very slim and solid feeling. Although it doesn't have all of the bells and whistles you find on other bricks, it's a lot of power for not a whole lot of money. Given how many people there are in our family, it's nice to be able to give everyone their own brick instead of having to share one or two much more expensive ones. I've been aware of Monoprice for a while now and they always seem to deliver good quality for a reasonable price.Overall, I'm very impressed with the unit and I'll update this review as I put it through its paces.

Although this album's been floating around on the Internet for ages, it was an unfinished piece that was released into the wild by someone unknown party after it languished after being recorded. For a very long time, it was the only way to find the album and I was happy to see that Patty was able to finish the album properly.  Since I like supporting artists, I wanted to be sure to have a fully-legal copy and bought it when I found it for sale on Amazon.For those who have heard the Internet version, this version will be a bit startling at first, but if you're like me, you'll come to prefer it. It's much cleaner and has some very good musicianship on each song.My two favorite tracks are "Silver Bell" and "Little God", but the album stands out as one of Patty Griffin's best albums. I highly recommend it.

I've had a couple of different visor clips for keeping my glasses safe and accessible, but they all seemed to fall apart after a few months.The Chums Grasshopper is very well constructed and easy to use. I've had no problems with it at all and I can insert and remove my glasses with one hand and without glancing up at it.I plan to get a couple more for our other cars

I decided to try using a tab after using a glove for years. I'd hoped that it would give a cleaner release, and be easier to use overall. While I did notice an improvement in the feel of the string, the upper portion of the lower tab began falling apart after I'd shot a dozen arrows with my 31# Golden Eagle and the bottom portion of the upper tab began tearing after another dozen arrows.I love the fit and feel of the tab, but I had serious issues with the thin leather portion of both tabs that contact the string. The backing part of the tab was still intact, but that's not what I wanted to use. If I do end going back to a tab, I'll choose a one-layer tab and forego the two layer design.On the positive side, the finger separator seemed to do a good job keeping fingers apart.

RIngs are one of those things you need in order to achieve good accuracy.You can spend thousands on your rifle and scope and if you get cheapie rings, all bets are off, especially if they're of the quick disconnect variety.The Warne Scope Mounts QD rings are  awesome. They're solidly built, easy to install and return within a 1/4 MOA for my Ruger GSR. I'd originally used their low QD rings but the Nikon scope I'd paired it with had an eyepiece that was a bit too large and didn't give enough clearance for the eyepiece cover.  The medium rings are perfect.Besides easy installation, the QD levers are very well thought out. The levers can be tightened and then repositioned to keep them out of the way with a spring loaded mechanism inside each lever handle. Overall, it's a very well thought out design and a very solid set of mounts.I've fired hundreds of rounds of M80 ball through the GSR and the scope stays locked into place with no drift at all.

I've been "suffering" from ADHD (primarily inattentive) as long as I can remember and while it has its disadvantages, it's also helped me become an "out of the box" thinker whose nimble on their mental feet (how's that for a tortured metaphor?).Since I can't do anything about it other than meds and a few mental tricks for overcoming some of the disadvantages, I may as well have fun with it.Hence the shirt (yay!)It's kind of funny that the first couple of times I saw someone wearing this shirt, I thought it said "AC/DC" blah blah blah... Kind of an ADHD thing, huh?When my brain finally engaged, I knew I HAD TO HAVE THIS SH..... oh!! Squirrel!!!)Anyway... It's well made, has been through the wash several times and is holding up well, fits great and brings a smile to people's face when they see it.

I'm an amateur radio operator and love fiddling with Software Defined Radios, especially when it helps me in my hobby. I've had cheaper versions of the RTL-SDR dongles and they tend to be hit or miss when it comes to oscillator stability. That means that a stable narrowband signal will seem to drift when you're viewing it on the waterfall display and when you're trying to catch a satellite pass, that's an unforgivable flaw. One of the first cheapie dongles I purchased would be all over the place, so much so that it was useless for anything but casual poking around the spectrum.The NooElec NESDR Mini+ is significantly more stable. I use it paired with their upconverter (also housed in a zesty, blue aluminum enclosure). To keep them from banging around, I use adhesive-backed Velcro tape to keep them attached which makes cabling much easier. The only negative with this model is that the board inside the enclosure is a bit loose and sounds like it's rattling around.

After getting hooked on a memory foam mattress, I began to realize my old-schoo pillow wasn't  nearly as comfy as it could be and decided to buy the Linenspa Dual Zone Gel pillow. Although it's a bit smaller than my older pillow, it's SO much more comfortable!It molds to fit my head whether I'm on my side or back and has enough spring to it where I get a good nights rest no matter how I'm lying. Even when I find myself on my tummy, it's much better than before.I'm very happy with my purchase.

Transladies, I highly recommend avoiding this and similar products. Phytoestrogens and herbal supplements are NOT nearly as effective as prescription strength, bioidentical medications. They're not even in the same ballpark.I took pueraria mirifica and other herbals for over six months and saw virtually  no effects whatsoever.When I eventually did get approved for HRT, I wasn't allowed to even begin taking the prescription media until the herbals were out of my system. Which meant a delay of several months.Once I DID begin on prescription HRT, the effects came VERY quickly and continue to this day.I don't want to besmirch any vendors, but the only folks who seem to benefit from these products are those who sell them.

From time to time, I need a small vise to hold art projects steady when I'm bending wire or soldering and the Yost COV-3  works very well.It's made of strong cast iron and has two guide rods on either side of the main screw. There's also a bottom clamp that let you easily attach it to a table for temporary use and mounting holes for more permanent installation.Since I use this with a regular table, I added a bit of adhesive moleskin on the part that touches the table so it doesn't mar the table. Felt might also work well, but might slip if you needed to apply much force to the piece you're working on.The vise jaws are textured to keep parts from slipping, but can mar the surface of some items. I use Delrin jaw protectors with mine to keep that from happening.The bottom clamp and vise handle work smoothly and stay in position during use. Another advantage of this model is that it's light enough for my daughters to use for their projects without needing any help. All in all, it's a nice little vise for the money.

I've been using blades and shaving gel for ages and it always seems like you get nicked at the least convenient moment. I used to have some older electric razors, but they only seemed to work on the flat areas and didn't do well at all with knees or ankles. More often than not, I'd end up with razor burn and I finally gave up using them.The Remington WR5100 Women's Rotary Shaver is a big improvement over the old style razors and the flexible shaving head does a fine job following the curves and angles that were always a problem before. While you could use it with just wetted skin, it seems to do best with a bit of gel for lubrication and it leaves everything smooth and clean. Just be sure to hold the razor under some running water to clean out any gel that may be trapped inside.So far, I've not had any problems with irritation and I'm impressed with how long it runs on a single charge. My old electric razor used to die quickly and needed to be kept on the charger constantly or it would run down between uses.The charger is very clever and when folded, helps keep the razor in contact with the charging buttons in the stand. There's a small cover that protects the rotary heads which is handy when you're packing an overnight bag.I'm very impressed with this razor!

For a very long time, my standard Wifi router was the venerable WRT-54G, but over the years, I moved away from Linksys for a variety of reasons, the biggest being Cisco's acquisition and subsequent diminishing of the Linksys brand. Since Belkin is now the proud owner of Linksys, I have a lot of hope that Linksys will receive more care and attention than it received during the Cisco days.The Linksys EA8500 is a high-end dual-band MIMO router that supports increased bandwidth to devices that support the newer connection models. One of the biggest problems I had with other routers were multiple high-bandwidth connections that throttled things to the point of unusability. One of my recently deprecated routers was especially bad with multiple video streams and has now been replaced with the EA8500 which does a lot better job with multiple devices accessing Netflix and Amazon Prime Video.This model is a huge upgrade from the old WRT days. The router supports MIMO and has greatly improved directional sensitivity. With my previous router, the Wifi signal for the 5Ghz band was extremely direction sensitive and if you weren't sitting in a narrow wedge in the room, you'd lose signal quickly. The EA8500 is significantly better in that regard and I no longer have to cower in one corner of the room while trying to access the Internet.Setup is pretty simple overall and an improvement over the old WRT days. Since I'm dependant on Verizon's terrible wifi router for connection to the Internet, I attach the WAN port of theEA8500 to the 192.168.1.1 inside network of the FIOS router and set the EA8500 network to use 192.168.12.x. It's also a very good idea to fully disable wireless on the FIOS router since all it does is interfere with other Wifi networks. Since the EA8500 is now double-NATed, if you're running any kind of servers inside the house, you'll need to set up port forwards on both routers which can be a little messy. It's also possible to leave the server out on the FIOS inside network and keep everything else inside the EA8500 network for added security.I was happy to see a USB 3.0 as well as ESATA connectivity. This makes it easy to share files/printers and serve media files for the whole household. Another nice feature is a "guest network" where you can limit what visitors can see on the network. I usually leave that disabled unless I have actual guests in the house since I prefer to minimize services whenever possible.While there are less expensive routers out there, The Linksys EA8500 holds a lot of promise and so far has been problem-free.I'll update this review as needed.

Galco makes nice stuff. I have a variety of their holsters for various firearms and I've never been disappointed with one of their products.Build quality is superb, they function as intended, wear well and don't cost a fortune. I purchased a Stow-N-Go  for my LCP to replace a DeSantis IWB holster that had several shortcomings that made it inconvenient to use, didn't retain well and felt unsafe to use. The box shape at the top of the Galco makes it easy to re-holster the firearm and the holster is easy to slip inside the waistband of my slacks or shorts.Highly recommended.

I've used a variety of harmonicas over the years and when I started out, I could only afford one or two keys. Nowadays, those old classics are either discontinued or outrageously expensive and can't be easily repaired.I've switched over to Lee Oskar harmonicas now and they give a great performance, they're durable and I can fix them easily if damaged. The storage cases are a huge improvement over the old cardboard boxes my old harps came in and they're very consistent in regards to their sound and playability.

I already have the Classic Brands Cool Gel 10 Inch mattress and loved it so much, I purchased one for my daughter as well.When the mattress is delivered, it's hard to believe that the box could contain an entire mattress, but once you unpackage it, it unrolls and grows like crazy. There's a slight solvent smell that dissipates within a few days, so if you're sensitive to those sorts of smells, let air out for a bit before using it.The mattress is very comfortable and conforms to your body as you sleep, which really helps reduce pressure points. I've used pillow top mattresses in the past, but they don't do a good job returning to normal when you move and eventually, you end up with divots in the mattress. One other disadvantage to pillowtops is that during hot weather, I feel like I'm suffocating with all of the trapped heat.The Cool Gel mattress is doing a great job with support and comfort and doesn't make me feel stifled during warm weather. And as a bonus, the Cool Gel mattresses cost a fraction of what a traditional mattress costs.

I've been using electronic mufffs for years and they only seem to get better each time.My previous set of 3M Peltor were the Sport Tactical 100 model and while they still work fine, I needed an extra set for my wife.The Sport Range Guard Earmuffs are similar to other models of 3M muffs, they fold down into a compact "ball", are easy to deploy, the on/off knob, microphones and audio jack are all in the same location.One HUGE improvement is the battery door. My previous model was a lot tougher to change batteries and the battery door is significantly better to open and close. The small cord that attaches the door to the headset sometimes gets caught in the opening, but it's a minor nit. Another nice feature is the "boot up" sound when the set is powered up. I used to have to listen to make sure it came online, but the beeps make it very obvious.Comfort is also high and it works well when using a rifle or shotgun. Some bulkier headsets I've used in the past made it impossible to get a good cheek weld, but I have no issues with these for a variety of different stock shapes and comb heights.Overall, I'm impressed and recommend these to anyone looking for a set of high-quality electronic hearing protectors.

Since it had been a while since I'd been camping, lots of equipment has changed for the better. The Klymit Inertia O Zone Air Pad is a big improvement in both weight and space. It consists of two attached sections; a latticed mattress and a four chamber pillow that are inflated separately.You can see the logic behind the latticed mattress portion since it not only saves some weight, but your sleeping bag can expand into the holes in the lattice and possibly give you a bit more warmth. I can't test that idea just yet since it's mid-June, but I'll do so and update this review when I've used it in different conditions.The drawback to the lattice idea is that the Air Pad seems to work best when you're either on your stomach or back. Since I spend a lot of time on my side,  my shoulder doesn't feel much cushioning at all, but the rest of me feels pretty good. The pillow is a bit on the thin side when I'm on my side, but is fine when I'm on my back. I'm 6'4" and pretty broad shouldered, but the length and width of the pad seem to be ok. I didn't notice any issues with my shoulders feeling unsupported, but that's pretty subjective.Build quality is very good. The fill valves do a fine job of keeping the air inside and are easy to manipulate, even in the dark. As a bonus, it's pretty easy to adjust the pillow's internal pressure while still laying on the mattress portion. Setup and takedown are both very easy and the pad fits nicely into the included pouch which also has a smaller attached pouch for the included repair kit (nice touch).Overall, I'm impressed with the Inertia O Zone Air Pad, especially if you're using it for backpacking. For a less remote camp, I'll probably combine this with a foam pad for some extra comfort.

One thing I really like about the iPhone 6 is that it's slim and fits perfectly in my hand. It's a really great device, but it's fragile as heck and if you drop it, it's toast. I've had other cases for the iPhone 6 that offer different levels of protection but at a cost. They're either too thin and offer nearly no protection, or they're thick and cushiony, but make it hard to remove the phone from my pocket and make it hard to touch the edges of the screen.The Volo Cases Slim Protective Cover offers a good solution that offers good protection while keeping it slim and easy to access the buttons and screen. The outer shell is a hard plastic with a rubbery inner jacket that keeps the phone secure, but accessible. Installation was very simple. It just slipped in and clicked into place. One of my previous cases was significantly harder to insert or remove the phone, but the Volo Cases model is great.The advertising says that it's anti-microbial, but that's not a feature that I find compelling although many parents who let their kids play with their phones might find it an attractive feature. Still, it's a "nice-to-have" feature.Another feature that I find essential is the easy access to the headphone and Lightning ports. Some of the cases I've owned were so tight that I had to use a knife to modify the case. I had no issues at all with this case.Bottom line: The case offers good protection for the money while keeping the iPhone's slim appearance and easy handling. Access to buttons and ports is above average and as a bonus, the case is anti-microbial.

I've had a variety of handheld VHF and UHF radios over the years and am an active ham radio operator.My current go-to handheld is a Yaesu VX-8DR, but I don't like leaving it in my vehicle where Virginia winters and summers can take their toll on the electronics, so I have a collection of Baofeng radios (a couple of UV-5Rs and a BF-F8HP) that I scatter amongst various vehicles for an emergency backup capability. Since this radio is so inexpensive, but still relatively capable, it would be unfair to expect mainstream radio functionality from a radio at this price point. I'll review it as such.One thing I've noted with all of the Baofeng radios is that they're "quirky". Their user interfaces aren't usually well thought out, programming them with the keyboard is painful and they don't seem to have the ability to reach out to remote repeaters like more mainstream handhelds, but it's able to hit the WA4TSC repeater in Bluemont 20 miles as the crow flies from my home in Eastern Loudoun County, VA just fine. Receiver sensitivity is also not quite as good as my Yaesu VX8-DR, but if you keep in mind that this radio costs a great deal less than the Yaesu, I can accept a few faults for a backup radio.This model has a few features that I find useful. It's nice that I can easily get to the FM broadcast bands and there's a handy LED light built into the top of the radio. The included headset works, but is pretty basic and feels like it's going to come off my ear at any moment.One annoying change is that the belt clip is now located on the back of the battery. That means that I'll have to come up with another belt clip if I swap out batteries. If I decide I want to use the battery from this radio in one of my other Baufeng radios, the belt clips will interfere since the other models mount the clip above the battery and this one is ON the battery. Minor point since most people won't have multiples.Programming the radio is best done through software, but I highly recommend at least figuring out the basics of programming through the keyboard. It might be a lifesaver if you're out in the boonies and all you have left is your radio. Cables are available here on Amazon and the "Chirp" software is generally well regarded. Once you learn the idiosyncrasies of the radio, it's pretty easy to program, but adding more than a few channels in one session is tiring.I'd originally given the UV-6R three stars, but since it's an improvement in many ways over the UV-5R radios and doesn't directly compete against the more costly mainstream handhelds, I increased it to four stars. For those starting out in ham radio and either can't or don't want to spend more, it's a decent option. Preppers might find it an attractive option since they're so inexpensive, but don't expect the same range you'd find in a higher-end model.Prospective buyers: please keep in mind that this radio will transmit on amateur radio frequencies and unless there's a true, life threatening emergency the FCC  won't be amused.Update:The November 2015 QST magazine has an article on page 74 & 75 that discusses handheld radio spectrum tests performed at the Dayton Hamfest since 2012 and the results are interesting. Of the 264 radios tested at the 2015 Dayton Hamfest, they found that 54% of  the Baofeng radios tested and 14% of Wouxun were not compliant with the FCC standards, while brands like Yaesu, Icom, Kenwood and Connect Systems were found to be 100% compliant. To the best of my knowledge, there are no results for the UV-6R, but given the track record of their other models, it's a factor worth considering when looking for a handheld radio.

It's amazing how modern fabrics and fasteners have totally changed the camping experience. My first tent was an awful little canvas affair that weighed a ton and leaked like a sieve if you even looked at it funny.The Kelty Salida 2 is a far cry from that experience. It's compact, lightweight, easy to erect and take down and with the fly (and an optional footprint), should keep you dry and comfortable in most conditions.Erecting  it was easy and I suspect I could have done it without reading the instructions the first time. It took me about eight minutes the first time I tried and about five after. Taking it down is also easy, but it takes a bit of effort to get it as small as it comes from the factory. I recommend a compression bag if you plan on taking it on the trail.All of the seams and zippers seemed perfect and I saw no defects in the fabric. The stakes were also a pleasant surprise. With some tents I've owned in the past, they either don't give you any or they're the horrible stamped metal ones that bend the first time you find a rock in the soil.Since I'm pretty tall and broad shouldered, I plan on using it as a solo tent. You can fit two people, but it's "cozy". Smaller (normal) people should be more comfortable though.  While the vestibule isn't huge, it's more than enough space to get under cover and be able to remove my boots and store my gear. I'm also happy with the ventilation. There's nothing worse than a tent that feels like a sauna or reeks of mildew.Bottom line: This is a great little tent for backpacking and should work well in all but winter or high wind conditions.

Since our daughter is taking our original Keurig to college, we got one of these to replace it and it's dreadful. Not only do you have to deal with their silly copy protection system so you MUST buy coffee that's been blessed by Keurig, it has serious issues dealing with ordinary tap water and demands that we clean it all the time. Far more often than our first model. In spite of slavishly following the schedule and instructions, it still complains.We've used our original Keurig since 2008 and while it's pretty basic, it does the job and keeps running with only regular maintenance. We'd had high hopes for the updated model, but so far we're fairly disappointed.I've hear there are ways around the copy protection scheme they use, but I really hate that I'm not allowed to use my old pods and old eco-fill. It's galling and most likely a ploy to further cash in on the K-cup revolution.We're going to drop off this model at the local Goodwill and see if we can find another 1.0 machine to replace it.If it wasn't for the protection scheme and the sensitivity to regular tap water, I'd have given this four or five stars. When it works, it works very well and the menus are easy to figure out. Overall usability is good, but I don't want to have to pay a premium for bottled water on top of the already too expensive pods.

If you're looking for a small-form factor Arduino board with good pin access, this is a decent option. It works as intended and I've had no issues with it at all.The only negative I can think of is that it only comes wrapped in an anti-static bag which puts you at the mercy of whoever is packing the box. It's not a slam on the product itself, but mine was thrown into the shipping box with a heavy item and about half of the pins were bent 15-20 degrees. They straightened right out, but it would be nice if the product packaging was a bit better so the product will survive co-shipment with other items.Bottom line: It's a decent little board for the money and it works fine.

Brakes aren't something that should need much attention if they work properly and you don't always need to buy the "best" if you're installing it on a commuter-mobile.The Centric Rear Rotors fit our minivan perfectly and work as intended. I've examined them a few weeks after installation and they appear to be free of any issues.If you're looking to save a few bucks, these are a nice option.

Since I use my R-Pi 2 in a variety of places, I need to protect it from stray shorts and static. This case does a pretty nice job keeping tender bits out of harms way and as a bonus, comes with three heat sinks to help keep the main chips running cool.Assembly was pretty easy. The hardest part was peeling the protective film from each piece. Installing the heat sinks was the only bit of trouble I had since it doesn't seem to be possible to attach the third heat sink to the chip on the bottom of the board. If there were an extra layer of case under the R-Pi, it would fit, but then airflow would be an issue. It's weird that they include three heat sinks, but it's only possible to use two of them. Even their product photos show the same issue.On the positive side, it's quite easy to mount heatsinks to the two chips on the top and there's an opening for each to allow heat dissipation and the case unscrews easily to make changes.Things I'd like to see: An opening on the bottom to give room to install the heatsink and to allow proper airflow. A set of rubber feet to protect table tops from the screwes

When I'm away from civilization, it's sometimes hard to keep my devices charged without lugging around a collection of batteries and whatnot. The Goal Zero Switch 10 set is a great way to keep things powered and can take advantage of sunlight to recharge the supplied battery pack or directly charge USB devices.The Goal Zero Switch 10 is a flexible solution that provides the ability to charge many devices using solar energy and comes with a rechargeable 3300mA Lithium-Ion battery pack and a set of useful accessories such as a 110 Lumen LED flashlight, a micro-USB phone charging adapter a couple of mini-carabiners and a cleverly designed hand-held fan with a rubber blade which detaches for easy storage. There's enough room left over in the zippered pocket of the solar panel to store an LED striplight and another battery pack.There's a small locking collar that you can raise and firmly connect the accessories to the battery pack. The solar panel unfolds to expose the solar cells and there is a zippered storage pouch for the accessories on the back and several attachment loops around the perimeter of the panel set so you can attach it to your backpack and charge your devices while you hike.The set is very well designed and slips easily into your backpack when you don't need it. You can also daisy-chain as many as four panels together to allow you devices to charge faster and there are other output options available on the panel. I plan on using this to keep my iPod Nano, iPhone, GPS, Kindle and amateur radio "walkie-talkie" fully charged while I'm out camping.The  battery pack allows charging from USB as well as the solar panel so you can pre-charge everything before hitting the trail.Although I hadn't had a lot of exposure to Goal Zero products in the past, I was happy to find that most of their products are compatible with one another and many other similar devices. USB seems to have taken over as the defacto low voltage power and charging  solution. I added a small set of USB and iDevice-converters to the back pouch and pretty much all of my needs are taken care of. After acquiring this set, I've purchased two other battery packs and several LED lights on flexible shafts.There's been a revolution in solar panels in recent years and it's nice to see prices fall and efficiency increase. The Goal Zero seems to produce the rated power in full sunlight, which is significantly better than a panel with almost twice the surface area that I bought a few years ago .Overall I'm very impressed with the the portability and flexibility of the set and I can see a variety of uses beyond hiking and camping.

Being a dog owner is great, but has its challenges. One of the hardest ones to solve is having a safe way to transport your pups in a variety of vehicles. Since a regular seat is not always a good option, especially if your pet likes to move around, one of the only options we had was to put our dogs in a travel crate which only fit inside our minivan, but not in our second car.The AmazonBasics Waterproof Car Hammock Seat Cover is a great option for those of us who don't always have space for an appropriately sized crate.The Hammock Seat Cover fits in the rear seat of small to mid size cars and attaches securely to the front and rear seat head rests with adjustable straps with quick-disconnect buckles for easy setup and takedown. It took me about 2 minutes to put the hammock in place even without having read the directions. The seat cover is made of a durable fabric with a waterproof backing and has two openings for securing the lower rear portion with a seat belt. There are also two fabric covered pieces that can be pushed between the seat and backrest to additionally secure it in place. There's a zippered section in the front portion of the hammock to allow easy access to the now-enclosed area.Overall, build quality is very good and I expect it will last many years with reasonable care.

One of my biggest frustrations with my pedal board is dealing with cables. They're either too long, too short or the 90-degree jacks don't point the right way without twisting the cable and it gets snarled and ugly. Even worse is when they get torn up and I have to buy yet another cable to fix it. It's even worse when one fails when I need it most.The Planet Waves Solderless Custom Cable Kit helps solve a lot of those issues by allowing YOU to make cables that are right for YOUR pedal board. It comes with enough connectors for 5 cables up to two feet long. You can mix and match sizes to get nearly any length you need.Most of my cables are very short and the 90-degree connectors point in opposite directions which suites my needs perfectly.The build quality seems great. The set comes with 10 connectors, 10 feet of cable, a nice little cutter and a screwdriver to do the assembly. The connectors are gold plated which should help with keeping your signal clean (I'm SO sick of steel connectors, they're the bane of my existence).Assembly of a cable is extremely easy.  I usually like to attach one end first, then check the length by placing it on the board using the second connector plugged into the next pedal on the board. You can use any method you like, but I'm really fussy about layout.To begin: Back out the locking screw on the connector with the included screwdriver, insert the cable firmly and keep it pressed in while tightening the locking screw. A VERY tiny bit of thread-lock on the screw will help it stay in place, but too much may interfere with getting a good connection between the screw and the body of the connector. Then insert the completed end into your first pedal and run the cable to the next pedal. Once you know your length, use the included cable cutter to cleanly cut the entire cable and attach the second connector in the orientation you need.One thing I really like about the set is that you don't have to strip back the shielding to get to the center conductor and running the chance of ruining the cable or cutting yourself.  I checked the resistance of a completed cable and it showed 0 ohms. That means that both connections inside the connector were solid and will pass a signal without any loss.I'd avoid trying to use this as an instrument cable unless it's an emergency. The connectors are perfect for a pedal board, but don't have a good enough strain relief for a lot of movement. Plus, it'd make a REALLY pricey instrument cable. :)

There are times where I don't want to have to drag a laptop around, but still need to take notes quickly. In the past, I've used a iPad stand and an external bluetooth keyboard, but it all gets very fiddle-y and a pain to setup and take down quickly.The Belkin QODE Ultimate Pro Keyboard Case solves those issues handily by incorporating a keyboard into an iPad Air case that provides good protection to the device and is easy to use in portrait or landscape mode.I've seen and used similar cases in the past, but they've been lacking in one way or another. They're either too bulky, too flimsey or too hard to deploy. The Belkin QODE  uses a set of strong magnets to keep the device securely positioned and can be quickly reconfigured for use in either orientation. If you're just using the tablet to read, you can easily disconnect the keyboard portion to keep weight low, then reattach it when you're ready.Build quality is good, battery life is above average and it's also attractive. I'm pretty impressed.

Works very well for wideband signals.I'm a general-class ham and I purchased this to act as a QRP amplifier for a couple of small software defined radios I've built and it works great. I put some filters on the output to keep my signal clean, but the amp itself is so good that there's not a lot to filter anyway.These aren't really mainstream products and are used, but the used price is quite good compared to the new price and for the hobbyist, it's a great option.Do take care not to overdrive the input. You WILL fry it if you're not careful. You can find spec sheets on the Internet.

There's not a lot to say about a brake rotor if it works as it should. Wagner makes pretty good stuff, so I'm not terribly surprised that it's been trouble-free.These were exactly as described, fit our vehicle perfectly and seem to be holding up well. I had no issues with installation and our van stops as it should with no pulling or funny noises. Now that I've typed the required number of words, the only thing that's left is the summary.Summary: Good fit, packaging and performance. Why pay a bunch of money for factory parts when these work so well?

If you ever need to store things that are easily affected by the weather in a secure container that's durable and inexpensive, ammo cans are a great option.I usually use .30 and .50 caliber cans, but needed something that could hold much larger items.The price for this can was very reasonable and included free shipping. I'd expected it to take a long time to be delivered, but it was only a few days (your milage may vary). The can was well packed and in great shape when it arrived.

I've had ADHD (Primary Inattentive) my entire life and while I'm fairly nimble mentally, I've also struggled with maintaining my focus on things I don't find fascinating and as a result, it affected my school work badly. Unfortunately, when I was growing up, ADHD wasn't a "thing" and those affected were regarded as being either lazy or stupid. Early attempts to "fix" ADHD kids by filling them with tons of pills, but not supplementing that treatment by teaching life skills didn't really help anyone. In many cases, kids were just given pills whether they were ADHD or not. Todays approach seems to be much better tailored to the individual.(NB: My type of ADHD is also known to some as "ADD", but I'll refer to it with the usual four letters).Dr Archer's book is an interesting take on the condition and reminds us to focus on the positive aspects instead of focusing solely on the negatives.  I do take the absolute minimum of medication to help remove the negative aspects of ADHD and have worked very hard to develop the skills necessary to be more effective. That journey has taken years and I wish I'd had this book available when I was a kid. I'm thankful that it has positive aspects as well and the book reminds us of that.I was very happy to see that the author validates my own life experiences and we're taking his advice to heart and using this book as a tool to help our daughter who is now developing the skills and attitude she'll need to succeed.This book is a valuable resource for anyone whose lives have been touched by ADHD and I recommend it highly.

I'm a certified NRA Instructor and we use a wide wide variety of snap caps in order to safely demonstrate the function of various firearms. It's imperative that the classroom remains safe and these help make it so.We usually recommend that our students have a set on hand to practice loading and unloading as well as dry-firing in order to refine their skills and the Tipton Snap Caps are what nearly all of the instructor staff have adopted.They're clearly not cartridges which makes it easy to ensure that everyone is using caps instead of live cartridges.I highly recommend that anyone who owns a firearm to use these to practice safe handling and functioning your guns.

We've used a variety of leads, harness  and collar combinations over the years and find that a slip lead is the best overall for our needs.I first noticed the Mendota lead when we brought home our newest rescue and borrowed the lead from the foster family. I'm very impressed with the build quality and ease of use. It's similar to the old style choke chain collars, but is much gentler and is constructed of a strong rope and leather keepers and slides. The slide helps keep the lead from opening too much and makes it less likely that the dog can slip out of the lead easily.We accidentally purchased the 1/2" model first, but donated it to the rescue organization and bought a couple of the 3/8" models in two different colors.I'm impressed with products that work as intended and are well made and the Mendota Slip Lead is perfect for our two furry family members.

I've been using conventional mattress/box spring beds since I first graduated from a crib.
