I had an opportunity to try a memory foam mattress and knew I had to get one for myself.The Classic Brands Cool Gel mattress comes rolled tightly in a box, and when you remove the plastic wrapping, it immediately puffs up to its full thickness. One word of warning: it's REALLY bulky and a bit heavy. It's best if you can get a bit of help getting it into position. They use a huge amount of plastic film to keep the mattress tightly sealed and it's a good idea to plan the unrolling carefully so it doesn't end up in a awkward position.After giving it a couple of hours to settle, we made up the bed and tried it out for the night. We both noticed that it gave a lot of support and didn't feel as hot as our VERY expensive pillow top mattress. I've been sleeping much better overall. The new mattress also did a very good job reducing, if not eliminating points of  pressure that I'd feel on my shoulder, hip or elbow which helps me be more comfortable overall.Given the reasonable cost and the degree of comfort, it's well worth the price.

I usually rely on several brands of holsters for EDC. My favorites have been Safariland, Galco, DeSantis and a couple of custom holsters from local makers. DeSantis is a brand I've used in the past for other firearms and when I decided to begin carrying my laser-equipped LCP IWB, the DeSantis Pro Stealth look like a good option.One of the first things I noticed was how difficult it was to put in place. The body of the holster is made from a synthetic fiber and has two places to attach the belt clip, one for LH carry and the default position is for RH carry. The clip is so strong that it significantly distorts the side of the holster which makes it very hard to slide the holster over the belt or even just over my jeans.Since the last thing I want to do is to wrestle the holster into place with a loaded firearm in place, I tried placing it with only the empty holster. That was even worse. Once the holster was in place, I found that reholstering my LCP took two hands and a lot of praying that I wouldn't fumble things and hit the trigger.  That makes practicing at the range something that's going to cause me, the RSO and other shooters there some anxiety.I would have liked to see a stiffener in place to make reholstering easier and safer.Other issues I've found are that the unused belt clip attachment point has sharp edges and presses against your body which gets very uncomfortable after a while and that the synthetic fiber is so slippery that the pistol wants to pop out when I'm driving or bent over to pick something up.If I decide to keep the holster, I'll remove the unused belt clip attachment point and find some way to stiffen the inside of the holster to make it simpler and safer to reholster. The retention issue will be a harder nut to crack and I'm beginning to believe that returning the holster is a better option overall.Conclusions:Holster is difficult to attach IWB (potential safety issue)Retention is not assured (potential safety issue)Firearm is difficult to reholster  (potential safety issue)Leather would be better than synthetic fiberUnused belt clip attachment point presses against body and is very annoying.

My daughters are getting to the age where we're getting ready for college and in addition to a laptop computer, a inexpensive printer/scanner is essential. The Epson Expression Home XP-320 fits that bill very nicely. It allows both wireless and connected printing and can be used to print through 'the cloud' or by inserting an SD card from a camera.Setup is exceedingly easy. After powering up the unit, one is prompted to insert the four cartridges, then wait a short time while the printer initialized. Since I like the flexibility of wireless printing, I prefer to join the printer to the local network so we can access it from iOS devices as well as our Macintosh computers.Once the printer is joined to the network, adding it to your Mac is dirt simple. Just open the preferences panel, select printer/scanner and press "+" to add a new printer. The system detects the printer on the network and loads the appropriate drives. From that point on, you just use it to print or scan. The XP-320 allows a variety of scanning resolutions and does a great job for pretty much anything we tried.Print quality is adequate for day-to-day use and having separate ink cartridges means you don't waste ink if you run out of one color before another.Photo quality is not quite as good as my high end photo printer, but it's pretty close overall.For the person wanting a compact home office printer, this is a great option.

SInce I've been away from archery for a while, I wanted to ensure my shoulders and arms were in proper condition so I could prevent injury and soreness.The Bow Trainer is a great option towards that end. You can select one or more tubes to adjust the amount of tension and work up to the weight you'll be using. Since I shoot recurves, I need to be able to hold the full power while I'm getting on target.One thing that's a bit disconcerting is the warning that you should use eye protection while using the trainer. This is in case of a tube breaking and since eyes are fragile, getting snapped in the eye would ruin your day.Even though I'm a righty, I train both sides to have some balance (how many of you have seen bowmen with huge right arms and wimpy lefts? ew!).Of the trainers I've seen, this one suits my needs best.

I used to buy cheap scopes, then complain about optics, etc. After mounting a 4x-16x M-223 on my varmint rifle, I became spoiled.When it came time to find a scope for a scout rifle, I looked at this scope, a Bushnell, a Leupold and a Burris scope. The Leupold didn't have quite enough eye relief for a proper scout rifle (I'm tall and tend to have a longer pull on my rifles), the Burris seemed great, but was considerably more expensive. GIven my positive experience with Nikon and their BDC scopes, I purchased this model and couldn't be happier. While 2.8X is a bit too much for a scout rifle, I'm still able to get on target easily. I'd love to see this scope with 1X, 1.5X or 2X as the low end of the zoom.The scope is very high quality. There's more than enough eye relief and there's an adjustment to tweak it to your exact needs. It zooms easily and keeps its zero very well. Since it's made to withstand the recoil of magnum pistols, .308 Win in a scout rifle isn't a challenge at all.The BDC reticle is very helpful at longer ranges and when coupled with Nikon's Spot-On smart phone app, you'll be hitting your target at a wide variety of ranges. I've been using it for with my 4X - 16X M-223 as well and it works flawlessly.The FOV at 100 yards is very good and I'm able to quickly engage targets at closer ranges very easily. I prefer to keep the scope at lower magnification levels, but having the option of 8X is nice. Once I get some more handloads assembled, I'm looking forward to seeing how well my rifle performs.Couple this scope with some QD rings from Warne and you'll have a winning solution. If you have a Ruger GSR, get the medium height Warne QD rings. There's not much clearance between the eyepiece and the top of the rail and I had to trim the bottom of the lens cover to fit.

I'm returning to archery after a long absence and I'm impressed much improvement there is on accessories such as quivers. My old school quiver didn't hold up well over the years, which is just as well since it didn't do a good job separating the arrows and I'd end up having to fix fletching far too often.The Easton Flipside 3-tube Hip Quiver does a good job keeping my arrows safe, but still accessible. As a bonus, there's a handy pocket on the side where I can keep stuff like string wax, a glove and an extra bow string. Even though I'm a righty, I tested it on the other side and it worked quite well.

When I travel, I dislike having to carry a bunch of cables and whatnot. This little adapter gives me the flexibility to  connect to a bunch of devices without having lots of cables all over the place.

This is the first set of Warne Scope Mounts I've owned and I'm very pleased. I bought them for my Ruger Gunsite Scout rifle and wanted something where I could quickly remove the scope and use the iron sights.The Warne mounts fit my Nikon Force XR 2.5x8 power scope perfectly and I'm able to be back on zero within a quarter MOA every time.So far, they've shown no signs of loosening on their own, but I still give each lever a gentle press before shooting.

When I buy laptops, I usually get them with minimal harddrive and RAM and upgrade them myself which is usually much cheaper than buying factory upgrades.We got this kit for my daughters 13" MacBook Pro (the last upgradable model).It installed easily and has "just worked" from day one.

While I ordinarily like stuff from Spyderco, I found this very disappointing.I like to play with balisong/butterfly knives as a way to keep my dexterity and thought it'd be fun to have something that I can practice with at the office. The BaliYo is far too light to be able to use the same motions and it's not especially comfortable to use in my hands. If I'd paid more, I'd be more disappointed, but the BaliYo ended up in the back of my desk drawer pretty quickly.

Even though I usually have a big mug of drip coffee in the morning, I frequently want some espresso in the afternoon, but don't have time (or the inclination) to go to Starbucks.The Handpresso is very easy to use, doesn't take up a lot of room in my desk or suitcase and I can fling a handful of pods into my bag when I travel. Finding hot water on the road isn't usually too difficult, but finding coffee you like at some hole-in-the-wall is sometimes nearly impossible.Making espresso is a breeze. I usually use the pods, but have used freshly ground coffee as well. I've found it best to pump the Handpresso first, then preheat the water chamber and cup with hot water from the tap while I'm heating the rest of the water in the microwave. Once it's up to temperature, I pour out the water I preheated with, fill the chamber, insert the pod, lock on the top and dispense the espresso. I'm impressed that I can get actual creama this way. I've never been able to make anything even close with an Aeropress.I prefer fresh ground to pods, but either works well in the Handpresso. I've seen some complaints about clogging, but I usually avoid those issues by soaking the portafilter part in some cleaning solution and blasting the holes clean with an old waterpik filled with coffee cleaning solution (there's usually a lot of TSP in them but they do a great job).I've seen a lot of people gushing about the Aeropress, but I vastly prefer the Handpresso

When I first got into black powder handguns back in the 70s, I usually just rammed the ball on top of the powder in my 1851 Navy, then greased the heck out of the cylinder. A couple of shooting buddies recommended these for use in my Colt Walker replica and knowing more about safety, I decided to begin using them.They're the perfect size for the chamber in my Walker and fit neatly on top of the charge. Yes, I still grease my chambers, but I feel extra secure with something else between the powder and the outside world.

Although I don't ordinarily review "lead balls" (we mustn't call them "bullets"), I'll make an exception in this case.Hornady has a reputation for high quality bu.... projectiles and even though these are about as old school as it gets, they consistently meet the standards I've come to expect from Hornady.Usually, I cast my own 'lead balls' but ran out of the appropriate hardness of lead. These work great in my Colt Walker replica and each one has been very uniform and better than I usually produce on my own. I've purchased a couple more packages of these for future use.

One big issue I've had in the past with on-the-ear headphones is that they usually use cheap foam rubber which deteriorates quickly and doesn't do a good job of sound isolation.The Monster NTune On-Ear Headphones have cushions that do a good job conforming to your ears and keep most outside sounds out while keeping most of the music you're playing in. That means I don't disturb my wife with my music (she basically hates almost all of it).In addition to good sound isolation, the headphones are comfortable to wear and even fit on my big noggin quite well. Many times, the headphones won't extend far enough, or squeezes your head like a... lemon (no, I wasn't going to say the 'z' word).Another feature I like quite well is the cord. It's made of good quality material, flexes well, has a small control to start, stop and skip tracks (if your device supports it).  If damaged, it can easily be replaced since it plugs into the bottom of one ear piece. There's an additional jack on the other ear piece so you can share your music with a friend. The headphones come with a storage bag that have enough room for extra cables and whatnot.While I like the headphones a lot,  one area that I find lacking is that they're not "acoustically flat". There is a strong emphasis toward bass and trebles while the midrange is rather flabby. I can equalize that with my devices, but the strong bass and crystal highs are annoying for some kinds of music (jazz, classical, blues) unless you compensate with an equalizer. That said, They sound outstanding for dubstep, electronica, trip-hop and the like. I've also found the strong bass useful when I play my six-string bass guitar through a practice amp into headphones. Most other headphones break up when playing at the low end of the instrument and the Monster NTunes sounded fantastic.On the positive side, I didn't detect any distortion or breakup when pushing the volume upwards nearly to the point of pain. The bass remained strong and clear and the treble side of things was also very good. They actually performed better on those frequency ranges than many headsets I've used in the past.Given the marketing info shown on Amazon's product page, it's clear that they're catering to a younger market (most seem to be clones of my daughter and her friends). That explains the bright colors and the music sharing jack on the other ear piece.Overall, I think they're great headphones for modern music with strong bass. If you listen only to Vivaldi or Bach, consider other products.

"Fiddle for Dummies" follows their tradition of high quality self-teaching books.As someone who's taught themselves to play mandolin, guitar and bass guitar, it's nice to find a book that shows you the fundamentals of the instrument in an easy to understand format and the supplemental material will be helpful to nearly everyone who has an Internet connection. I would have preferred to see a CD or DVD included, but those are more fragile and usually require that you have a computer or CD player close at hand.The lessons are laid out logically and the student is taken through the fundamentals of playing the fiddle. Although it's possible to learn entirely from the book, I still recommend lessons when you first begin. When I taught myself mandolin and guitar, I had developed some bad habits that could have been avoided if I'd used an instructor at the beginning. If you decide to take lessons in addition to the book, I recommend mentioning that you're using this book as learning material and the instructor will probably use it as instructional supplement.If you've not purchased a fiddle yet, the book will offer advice on purchasing one.

When I decided to remove the Series 80 junk from my Kimber 1911, I needed to push the rear sights off to one side enough to remove the firing pin block and spring. I looked at quite a few different options for sight pushers, but decided I didn't need "fancy", I just needed something that'd work without a lot of fuss.I've seen some folks complaining about the coarse threads and I agree to a degree, but the sight pusher did a great job overall.I found that thin cardboard worked well to protect the slide from the jaws, but I found quickly that cardboard wasn't going to work at all to protect the rear sight. After messing with a few options, I found that a standard tortoiseshell-type plastic guitar pick did a great job protecting the sights and could be easily trimmed with side cutters to fit into the space available.Overall, I'm impressed and would recommend this device for anyone who needs to adjust their sights. I would have liked finer threads on the pusher, but I was able to make it work as is.

Most of the USB 3.0 portable drives I use seem to come with cables that are either too short, too cheap or both. The Belken cable lives up to the quality I've experienced with their products and long enough where I can keep my external USB drive in a safe spot while I work.Build quality is very good and uses outer jacket that isn't cheap plastic like other cables I've used. Strain relief on the connectors seems to be very good and each connector has a set of small bumps to help keep a good grip while you insert or remove the cable from your devices.

I am really pleased with these headphones, especially considering the price.  I have a pair that sells for more than twice the cost of these and I would say the sound is equally good.First, I like that these can fold up to fit into a sturdy case for travel.  I sometimes work at home and sometimes work at the office so appreciate being able to just toss the case into my bag as I'm hurrying out the door.  They fit well, maybe a bit on the large side.  They cover your whole ear, so while they aren't noise canceling, they do keep out most surrounding noise when in use.  They're comfortable and don't give me a headache when I've been wearing them for a long time.The sound quality is really great.  I listen to everything from the music I grew up with to what's on the radio today as well as musicals.  All of it sounds very clear with the Sentey headphones.  Whether I'm listening to a thumping base line or a hair band wail or a witch attempting to defy gravity, it all sounds very good.  If you want a solid listening experience without the hefty price tag, these headphones will do the trick.Keep in mind, the controls on the cord only fully work with Apple products.  The volume control doesn't work for me at all because I use these with my Dell laptop or Samsung phone.  My daughter has an iPhone and can use the volume control.  It's no big deal because I can, of course, adjust the volume on whatever device I'm using.  The pause button does work for me.I was provided this product at no cost in exchange for a review.

When first looking at this book, I didn't see an age recommendation in the description.  It's about Minecraft though, so I figured my ten year old Minecraft fan would enjoy it and learn some new tricks.When The Advanced Strategy Guide to Minecraft arrived and I started flipping through the pages, I realized it wasn't written with kids in mind.  The text is quite technical and I didn't understand much of it.  However, I did see some things that looked really neat (like how to set up automated farming) and I figured my son (who is an advanced reader) would be able to figure it out.My son was perfectly able to understand this book because he already knows how to accomplish all of the advanced techniques described here.  He's been playing the game on the PC and the XBox for quite some time and just seems to have a knack for it.  It was disappointing that he didn't find anything here that was new to him.It's also important to note that the last several chapters describe how to do things that aren't available with basic Minecraft game play.  In order to use those particular techniques, you need to download and install Mods.  My son doesn't use any Mods.  He keeps telling me we need a better laptop -- apparently the one he is allowed to use for Minecraft has too much lag.On the plus side, there are plenty of screen shots to demonstrate how to craft different things.  The book starts with some tips for setting up your initial account and other useful tidbits.I'd say this might be a good book for an older kid or adult to learn about Minecraft, but an already experienced player might not find anything here to get excited about.

This is a good football for kids to practice with.  It's easy to grip and the Nerf-like feel is good for kids who may be intimidated by a "real" football.  The ball is smaller than a regulation football and rather light.My husband and our two boys like to throw a ball around in the yard from time to time, but none are serious football players.  This ball is especially easy for my 10 year old to manage.  It's helped his confidence, especially at catching.  The long and short "plays" on the ball are a nice touch.  My husband will point one out to the boys and see if they can follow.  I'm sure this will be part of our annual Kids Vs Parents Thanksgiving Football Extravaganza.

One of the things no one ever told me about getting older was that I'd start to have an issue with facial hair. Around the time I turned 40, I noticed I'd developed a fuzzy little mustache.  Even though the hairs weren't dark, I definitely did not appreciate their presence.  Initially I had my upper lip waxed to keep the fuzz in check, but my skin is very sensitive and no matter how careful they were at the salon or which salon I went to, I'd end up with a bumpy rash along my upper lip.  It was worse than the hair, and by the time it went away, the hair would begin to show.I decided to try Completely Bare's facial hair removal cream at the suggestion of a friend.  I was convinced it would make my skin break out but tried it anyway.  The first time I used it, I wiped the cream off a little too soon and had to touch up the area with tweezers.  After that, however, I figured out that 8 minutes is the exact amount of time needed to easily remove all of the hair above my lip.  I've used Completely Bare's cream several times now and have never had any irritation, rash, acne -- just smooth skin.The applicator tip of this product is easy to use.  After applying the cream and waiting the right amount of time (5 to 8 or so minutes), you simply wipe it and the hair away with a damp cloth.  I usually apply my regular moisturizer after.  This cream has a bit of an odor to it, but nothing that is overwhelming or unpleasant to me. Because it doesn't irritate my skin, I can literally use this product right before going out to dinner and have no worries about my skin.  The effects last several days, at which point I can see some of the hairs growing back in.

I ordered these risers to give our sofa and love seat a lift in order to make it easier for our robot vacuum to clean under them.  We had no trouble installing them, but did need to use a drill to make holes for the screws.  Both pieces of furniture have solid wood legs that are too hard for just a screwdriver to handle.  After predrilling a hole, attaching the risers to the bottom of the furniture feet was a snap.Once the risers were installed, I could see that the robot wouldn't get stuck again. The risers aren't very noticeable though, which is nice.  They also keep the furniture from sliding around on the wood floor.  Every week or so I'd notice the furniture had been scooted a few inches to one side as people get up and down, but that's no longer happening.  I need to get another set for the overstuffed chair, which is high enough for the robot to move under but tends to slide around whenever the kids flop into it.

The Wolverine LED Headlamp is a very useful item to have around the house.  The headlamp itself is small and light, but very bright.  With the press of a button you can cycle between a bright light, a slightly dimmer light, and a flashing light.The strap fits comfortable and seems like it would work for nearly anyone.  My kids can wear it, I can wear it, my husband can wear it -- all without having to adjust anything.  The entire piece is light and doesn't feel bulky.The beam reaches far enough to make it easy for me to keep track of my dog when I take her out at night.  I also like to use this when I close up our chicken coop at night -- I can see what I'm doing without having to juggle a flashlight.  The light moves with your head to automatically light up whatever you're looking at.  It's great for being outside after dark.I received this item at no cost in exchange for a review.

This is by far the best space heater we've had.  Our other space heater is larger, louder, and doesn't really heat the whole room.  The Vornado Vortex Heater quietly heats the entire room and keeps it very evenly warm.You can control the heat settings with a simple dial as well as choose a high or low wattage.  A safety switch on the bottom of the heater turns the unit off if it tips and there is storage for the cord built in to the bottom of the space heater.  It is rather small, so doesn't take up much room.  Unlike the other space heater we have, it really does heat the entire space rather than just an area around the machine.  My daughter prefers her room to feel like a sauna, and the Vornado keeps her happy.  We've also used it to heat the finished area of the basement where it also does a great job.

My husband and I have had a lot of fun with this game when we've had friends over.  The premise is, you are given a phrase and an accent and have to attempt to use that accent when saying the phrase.  Accents range from "redneck" to "drag queen" and pretty much anything else you can possibly think of.  The phrases can be considered politically incorrect at best.With the right people, this is a hilarious game.  Would I want to play this with my in laws or my grandma?  No way!  Would I want my kids around to hear this stuff?  No way!  But with most of our friends and a few beers, this is good fun.  We often end up in tears from laughing so hard.  There are a couple of regulars in our group of friends who wouldn't appreciate this game.  While it isn't exactly like Cards Against Humanity, it is the same sort of humor.  So, judge wisely in choosing who you invite for game night if this is your chosen game.One thing I like about this game is that you can play it with a large group.  You aren't limited to a handful of people.  There aren't complicated rules to learn or anything like that.  I'd suggest this as a good party game for adults who enjoy inappropriate humor.

My husband and I have our own small business with just a couple of employees.  While most of what we do is scheduled on a calendar, there are tasks that pop up from time to time that we have to add in to our daily routine.  I thought this dry erase surface would give us a great place to quickly add "to do" items where the whole office can see them.  I'm happy to say this has worked out well.I hung this up with the help of another person following the included directions.  It was pretty simple.  I ended up with a big bubble in the middle of the surface, but was easily able to peel up one edge to let the air out and smooth the entire thing out.  It's been up for several days and hasn't fallen.  None of the corners or edges have come loose; it's as well adhered to the wall as it was the day we hung it.Anything we've written on the surface has wiped clean easily with either the included cloth or the little erasers on the tips of the markers we already had in the office.  I can tell it won't damage the wall if we take it down and it seems like we'd be able to rehang it if needed.

My dog has been having so much fun with this toy!  She loves to play fetch, but we always use a tennis ball. She had no trouble switching to this arrow/dart shaped toy.You use the slingshot handle to propel the dart across the yard for the dog to chase.  There's a small, soft hook on the dart that you use to draw back the elastic pull on the handle before letting go to launch the toy.  It took me a few tries to really get the hang of it, but once I figured it out, I was able to fling the dart a fair distance.  The trick is to give the handle a bit of a flick with your wrist as you release the dart with your other hand.  You can get quite a bit more distance than just pulling and releasing.My kids had a harder time getting the hang of it.  My son snapped himself with the elastic a couple of times.  The dog doesn't actually care if the dart goes super far or not.  She just goes berserk when she sees one of us getting ready to let the dart fly.  We really wore her out this afternoon, to the point where she'd chase the dart, bring it back, then flop down into the grass on her side.  It was comical, and we all always have fun playing fetch with her using the ChuckIt Ultra Sling.There are a couple of things to keep in mind.  The hook on the dart is soft so it won't hurt your dog.  This means it doesn't seem very strong.  I'm also not sure how long the elastic band will last.  The rest of the toy seems more durable and well made, so only time will tell.  You don't want to let your dog use this as a chew toy -- if she chews the hook off, the sling shot is useless.  We put the toy away after playing so our dog doesn't damage it.  You may also have a hard time keeping this toy in working order if you have to fight your dog to get the dart back.  I'm not sure it would survive many games of tug without the hook being damaged.  Our dog is pretty good about returning what she's fetched, so for us this isn't an issue but it's something others may want to consider.

These chalkboard labels work exactly as described and look great.  What you get is 6 sheets of 8 labels and one liquid chalk marker.  They are meant to be extremely easy to reuse, with the liquid chalk writing removable with a damp cloth.  The labels themselves can also be reused -- just peel off and restick.I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised at how easy it is to reuse the labels.  They easily wipe completely clean without any scrubbing or effort.  The labels stick very well but peel off without leaving behind any residue or hint of stickiness.  The labels come in a few different shapes and are a good size, a bit large for a jelly jar and more suited for larger jars or containers.  They would be great for crafts or gift labels as well as organizing.  I used them on large glass containers for sugar, rice, popcorn, etc.  I like knowing that the labels can be removed when I want to wash the jars and won't become worn and faded or turn into a gooey mess.One thing to keep in mind, the liquid chalk pen doesn't dry instantly.  Once it does dry, however, you can handle the labels without any smearing or smudging.I received this product at no cost in exchange for a review.

From the very first page, The Killing Lessons is dark, brutal, and utterly gripping.  I'll admit it, I spent a good part of the weekend ignoring my kids and putting off household chores because I could not stop reading this book.In The Killing Lessons, San Francisco homicide detective Valerie Hart is trying to track down a pair of serial killers who operate across several states, abducting and torturing women before killing them, mutilating the bodies, and disposing of them.  Valerie is a deeply flawed character, clearly suffering from PTSD.  She drinks too much and is obsessed with the case.  Her personal problems begin to bleed into her professional life just as the case begins to break open.  As Valerie works to track down the killers, they are on the move after killing a woman and her son.  A little girl manages to escape, the killers abduct their next victim, someone is out to ruin Valerie's career (as if she isn't doing that to herself already), and the story basically rockets to a climax without giving you much time to catch your breath.The Killing Lessons is very dark.  The writing is fantastically descriptive and the characters are fascinating, but the author spares us of none of the horrifying details of each murder.  The full scope of what the killers do to their victims is revealed gradually, but turns out to be even worse than I imagined while reading.  This book is not for the sensitive reader -- the violence will pound you over the head.My only criticism of The Killing Lessons is that it unfortunately falls in to the old story of the cop going rogue just in time to save the day.  There was also a big coincidence in a break in the case -- Valerie just happened to see just the right little clue that popped up in an unrelated case on another cop's computer.  It is the one thing that finally sets her on the trail of the killer's identity.  Maybe I'm too much of a stickler, but I do feel like an author cheats a bit when resorting to such a tactic.

A Blossom of Bright Light is a decent mystery/crime novel, not particularly memorable.  I haven't read the previous Jimmy Vega mystery by Suzanne Chazin, but that didn't detract from this book.  The author references some events that probably took place in the first book, but they have no bearing on the plot of this one.Detective Jimmy Vega ignores a call from a local drunk claiming he saw the Virgin Mary in the woods with a baby -- this particular drunk makes these claims wild claims often.  This time, however, there really is a baby whose body is discovered the next day.  Over the course of the novel, Vega tracks down the identity of the baby, the mother, and the people responsible for the baby's death.  In the meantime, he deals with his strained relationship with his girlfriend and daughter and must navigate the close knit, distrustful Hispanic community.  Issues such as illegal immigration, deportation, and the cultural taboo against reporting abuse weave their way through the story.Early on, it's pretty clear who the bad guys will turn out to be and who the next victim will turn out to be.  I thought there were a couple of unlikely coincidences  -- what are the odds Vega's own daughter, out of all the people in the town, will have a tie to the case?  What are the odds Vega's girlfriend will also have a tie to the case?  What are the odd's Vega's ex-wife's housekeeper will have a tie to the case?  Their favorite shopkeeper?  Yep, her too.Plot shortcomings aside, the writing is good with a decent pace.  The immigration issues are timely and tug at the heartstrings.  If you're looking for a rather light read (in spite of the nature of the crime, I wouldn't call this book dark as we are spared the details and the crimes themselves aren't described in any detail) or something to keep you occupied on a lazy afternoon or during a long flight, this might be the book for you.

Solid Gold is a good quality dog food.  I like that it doesn't have wheat, soy, or corn and appears to avoid fillers.  There aren't any artificial colors, and the protein source is mainly chicken, chicken meal, and pollock meal.  The ingredients do include plant sources of protein (peas, pea fiber, lentils), which may be less valuable to your dog than meat based protein.  As far as quality goes, this is something I feel pretty good about giving to my dog.The kibble has uniform pieces, not too small or too large.  My dog seems to like the taste of Solid Gold food -- she certainly doesn't leave any behind.  I mix in some good quality wet food for her morning meal and add a little coconut oil to the kibble when she has dinner.  Her energy level is great, her coat looks soft and shiny, and she hasn't had any digestive upsets while on this food.While I do think this is an above average dog food, I believe there are comparable foods available at a better price.  I would definitely compare ingredients and prices and shop around a bit.

I haven't played with a race track set since I was a kid, and even though it was fun back then, the Real FX Racing set is leaps and bounds beyond those old slot racing tracks.In this box, you get two cars, two controllers, and enough track to build a good size race area.  The cars and track are larger than I expected.  You will need a decent amount of floor space to set this up.  The set up is very easy.  The track sections are flat and connect using simple tabs.  There are several possible track configurations.  The cars sync to the handsets automatically.  As someone who isn't very good at driving anything other than a real car, I really appreciate the AI feature -- the cars sense the track and will even stay on the track without you steering if you don't drive them too fast.  It helps to keep the cars from flying off at the turns while you get the hang of the controls.The controls are fairly simple and intuitive.  You can use the cars in practice mode, championship mode, and RC mode.  In RC mode, the cars don't even need to be on the track.  My 10 year old is by far the best at controlling the cars, probably because he spends a lot of time enjoying them just in RC mode without even setting up the track.The real fun, of course, is in racing an opponent.  Not having your car confined to one lane makes racing so much more enjoyable.  There's nothing like bumping the other car off the track to liven up the race, not to mention the surprise of spinning out because of an oil spill or blown tire.  The handsets make the sound effects and keep you updated on which lap you're on and who's in first place.  In practice mode, the handset gives you the time for each lap and tells you when you've beaten your best time.  Racing with this set is fun and addictive; you always want just one more race!  It really is like the ideal combination between old school racing sets and racing video games.On a side note, when we first received this set we had a problem with one of the cars not working properly.  Wow! Stuff was very quick to respond to my emails and went above and beyond to fix the issue -- great customer service.

Sometimes I feel like the only person who still uses a planner rather than some app on my phone to keep track of appointments, activities, and events.  I work at home and use a planner to keep track of the tasks I need to do for each client on a daily basis.This planner works well for me.  Each month is spread across two pages with enough room on each individual date to add more than one notation. The advantage to this is being able to see the entire month at once, a feature that helps me prioritize my work.  The size of the spaces allows me to write in personal appointments, kids' practices and game, and other reminders. Tabs along the side let you quickly turn to a specific month as needed.Additional features such as a 3 year reference, future planning pages, space to list contacts, room for notes, space to list events by month, and a list of dates when holidays fall through 2019.  The planner is quite thin in spite of these additions to the calendar.  An elastic band holds the planner closed.  The cover has a nice feel to it, very smooth and a little soft.  While it doesn't have the sturdiest construction, it does seem able to hold up to one year of use just fine.

Medieval Lego is a fantastic book on two levels.First, it is visually very impressive.  The large, full color photos of Lego scenes are so much fun to look at.  It's really impressive how creative the author is in recreating each story in Lego form.  Each time I look at this book, I see something new.  My 10 year old is a huge Lego fan and is a very talented builder himself.  Even though there aren't instructions for building these scenes, my son has a knack for figuring out how to recreate elements that appeal to him.  I love that we can all enjoy the Lego scenes in this book while my little Lego fan is able to take an even deeper appreciation of it. You can see the wheels turning when he looks through Medieval Lego and know he is planning his next build.Second, the stories here are really interesting and appeal to a wide age range.  They are all well written (by a variety of historical experts) and accessible for all of us, kids and adults.  My 16 year old enjoys history and is familiar with more historical details than you'd expect, but she still found a lot of new things in this book.  We've had a really good time reading the stories, which cover quite a large time period but are only a couple of pages each.Whether you appreciate history or Lego or both, Medieval Lego is a delight.

Until trying this product, I'd never had ginger tea.  Kazu Ginger Root Tea is 100% ginger root, finely diced and inside a basic tea bag.  It's prepared like other teas, by pouring boiling water over the tea bag and letting it steep for a few minutes.As you'd expect from ginger, the tea has a spicy bite to it.  It is very warming.  I've found that using a bit of honey in the tea takes the edge off the spice.  I've had a head cold the last couple of days and find the ginger tea to be very soothing.  The internet has plenty of articles listing the benefits of ginger tea, from fighting cancer and alzheimer's to reducing nausea and relieving pain from inflammation.Each tea bag is individually sealed for freshness.  The ginger is organic and free of any fillers or added ingredients.  You can tell from the taste that you are getting only quality ginger root in this product.I received this product at no cost in exchange for a review.

This Case Logic laptop sleeve is a great way to protect a laptop.  The color and style make it suitable for school or the office.  It is slim enough to easily fit into a backpack or other small bag and the understated color is appropriate for any situation.  My husband uses this for his laptop when he travels and is very happy with it.The sleeve includes a zippered pocket on one side.  Being a sleeve for a smaller laptop, this pocket won't hold a lot but can manage a small notebook or planner and writing utensils.With metal zippers and seams that feel strong and well made, this case seems made to stand up to regular use over a long period of time.  It hs the quality I've experienced from other Case Logic products.  It will probably outlast the laptop!

We've never had an air purifier, so I was interested to see if this Rowenta model would make a noticeable difference in our home.  This review is for the larger model.Setting up the purifier is a quick and easy job.  The manual is clear and easy to follow.  You really only have to unwrap and install the filters before plugging the unit in.  At first, I mistook the description to mean the purifier comes with 4 replacement filters, but quickly saw that the purifier uses 4 different filters to purify the air.  The filters are:1.  Prefilter:  This filter captures dust and hair and is washable.  Every few weeks, you should vacuum or wash this filter.  You won't need to buy a new prefilter.2.  Carbon filter:  This filter removes odors and, according to the manual, should be replaced once a year with average use.3.  HEPA filter:  This removes pollen, pet dander, mold, bacteria, and other very small particles from the air.  The HEPA filter should last 3 years with average use.4.  NanoCapture filter:  This filter captures and destroys formaldehyde, a common household air pollutant and carcinogen.  The manual doesn't indicate how often this filter typically lasts.  Instead, you rely on a color coded guide to visually check the filter to see when it needs to be replaced.At this time, I can't find the carbon or HEPA filters for sale in order to check their prices. The NanoCaptur filter sells for $59.99 at Home Depot.  At that price, I hope it lasts quite a while.  Average use is considered 8 hours at a day at speed 2; if you run the purifier longer or at a higher setting, your filters may need to be replaced sooner.Other features of the purifier that are very useful include settings to control the air speed, a night setting for running more quietly and with dimmed lighting, a timer, and a delayed start.  You can change the sensitivity of the pollution sensors as well.  The display shows the current air quality.  I prefer to keep the purifier set to auto; it runs at a lower speed until it detects pollutants in their air -- then, it kicks up the speed until it sense the air quality is again excellent.As I've been using the purifier, I've been surprised at the difference it makes.  When walking into the living room (where the purifier is currently set up), the air is noticeably fresher.  The purifier is very quiet and I usually don't notice it.  When I'm cooking, the purifier senses the additional odors and other things in the air and automatically goes into a higher speed.  I'm not sure what that says about my cooking style, but it does show that the purifier senses the change in the air and responds to it.My youngest son has some pretty severe seasonal allergies during spring and summer.  I plan to move the purifier into his bedroom during allergy season to see if turning it on before he goes to bed and letting it run all night helps his allergy symptoms and lets him sleep more comfortably.The only challenge I've had with this unit is deciding where to place it.  The purifier isn't supposed to be under a window or surrounded by furniture.  The layout of the living room makes this difficult; I really had nowhere to put it other than under a window.  Because of the cool weather, the window is staying closed, but if I wanted to open that window I think I'd need to move the purifier.I am torn between giving this 4 and 5 stars; I want to price out all of the filters and see how it works during allergy season before I fully make up my mind.

I've tried a few different products to help my hair air dry into a wavy look, and this is one that I am pretty happy with.  I have long hair, and a lot of it, although it's pretty fine and very soft.  If I let it air dry, it tends to look frizzy, but it the summer it's just too hot to use a hair dryer.With the TRESemme Shaping Gel Cream, I get soft waves without the frizz.  I use a couple of pumps of this product, apply it to my hair, and comb it in.  I then give my hair a good shaking out to separate the layers, scrunch it to encourage the waves, and let it air dry.  It gives my hair a wavy, slightly wild look without feeling crunchy or sticky.

I have long hair with some natural wave to it, but when I let it just air dry it ends up looking frizzy.  I've tried various curling gels and creams, which help give my hair a wavy look without the frizz, but some products feel too stiff or sticky.TRE Semme's UnDone Gelee didn't really perform well for what I wanted with my hair.  The directions on the bottle don't really indicate whether or not you should use the product on wet or dry hair, but after trying it out on wet hair, followed by an air dry, I've decided this Gelee is probably meant to be used to hold already-curled or waved hair.  I went to the TRESemme website and watched the videos in the UnDone series, but this product wasn't featured.  In fact, I am not sure why they call the look UnDone when it seemed to take a lot of time and effort to get some waves.When I applied this to wet hair and let my hair dry, it didn't really help with the waves or reduce any frizz.  I tried using a bit more product, but was left with my hair looking weighed down and feeling crunchy.  I think TRESemme should clarify the correct use of this product and hope they will add it to their website.

My two boys, ages 10 and 12, have really been enjoying this set.  My youngest in particular is a big fan of Lego, robots, and origami, so this set was right up his alley.My kids had no trouble assembling the easier models but were definitely challenged by the more complex animals.  They were able to figure it out, and were really proud of themselves.  The origami style skins make the completed machines look very cool.  My boys are now starting to experiment with creating their own machines and I love seeing how busy and engaged they are.I would highly recommend this set for kids who enjoy building and designing.  It would make a great gift.  Just be sure to stock up on AAA batteries -- you need 6 of them for the remote control feature.

This is a cute, great starter Power Wheels toy for toddlers.  When my own kids were little, their grandparents spoiled them with multiple Power Wheels over the years and my kids never tired of them.  I got this for my niece and nephew to play with when they visit, and they love it.When this small quad arrives, you first need to charge the battery for 18 hours.  I started the battery charging and assembled the vehicle, which was a quick and easy process.  You will need both a flathead and philips screwdriver.  I didn't have any trouble putting the vehicle together and even managed not to mess up the decorative stickers.  The only problem I had involved the way the tracks were packaged.  They are in their own box inside the larger box.  When I pulled the box of tracks out of the larger box, it came open on one side and the tracks fell onto my bare foot -- very painful, and by the next day I had some colorful bruises.  So, be careful and don't trust the smaller box to hold together.Once charged, I set up the track in the back yard and first let my little nephew take a turn.  He really loved rolling around the track.  The quad works fine in our yard, but of course very small children take a while to learn the concept of steering.  You definitely have to supervise until your toddler is able to steer.  I don't have enough floor space indoors to use the track inside, but if you have an open area in your home you can certainly use this for some rainy day fun.  It really is a fun toy for kids and the kind of thing they never seem to get tired of.  It encourages imaginative play and hand/eye coordination.  The quad moves slowly enough to prevent runaway toddlers or dramatic crash scenes.The only drawback to this quad is that it is quite small and will be outgrown within a year or two.  I also wish it had some sort of simple on-board storage.  Little kids love to put things inside other things and take them out again.  A little cubby for storing small treasures would make this quad perfect.

This little bathmat is ok for small bathroom or as an additional mat in a larger bathroom.  We use this mat in front of the toilet and a larger mat that covers the area in front of the shower and sink.  On it's own, it doesn't cover much area so make sure you have a realistic idea of the size of this rug as compared to the area you want to cover.The neutral color is nice and I like the nubby texture.  However, the edges seem like they aren't very tightly woven.  After one washing, they look a little ragged.  Both of our bathrooms get a lot of use, so the rugs in them have to be able to stand up to frequent traffic and routine washing.  I am not confident this rug will look nice for very long.  It would be better suited for a spare bath that only sees infrequent use.

I got these pants for my husband and they fit perfectly.  It's still very warm here, so he hasn't been able to wear them other than for a quick test of the fit.  However, he said they are quite comfortable.  The cuffs are not sewn into a turned up position (like in the photo), so you can wear them without the fleece showing if you prefer.My husband's normal approach to facing the cold, such as when he has to shovel the driveway or when we take the kids sledding, is to wear his fleece or flannel pajama pants under his jeans.  It keeps him warm, but isn't very comfortable.  These fleece lined Wranglers will give him the added warmth he likes when outside on a very cold day.  I've tried other Wrangler products and expect these to hold up just as well to wear and tear, especially because they'll probably only be worn on snow days.

I like this NUXE Shower Oil more than I expected to when I first tried it out.  When opening the bottle for the first time, I thought it had a very summery scent, like warm suntan lotion.  However, when I first lathered it up in the shower on my shower pouf, it had a stronger, perfumed scent that brought to mind my high school typing teacher (not a good association).  However, after rinsing off and dressing, I thought the scent had greatly toned down and was actually very pleasant.  Several hours after showering, my skin still smells clean with just a hint of the scent of this cleanser.The shower oil itself is rather thick.  It doesn't create a lot of lather, but lather is something we all think makes us cleaner when, in fact, it's just for show.  This product lathers enough and rinses away well enough so that I don't feel like I any kind of residue on my skin.  My skin also doesn't feel dry or tight after showering, but during winter that may change.

Girl Waits with Gun is a departure from Amy Stewart's previous works of nonfiction.  If you've had the pleasure of reading Wicked Bugs or Wicked Plants, you'll already be familiar with Stewart's engaging brand of humor and knack for presenting the most fascinating of facts in a way that is both memorable and entertaining.  Girl Waits with Gun blurs the lines between fact and fiction, taking real life events surrounding the Kopp sisters and their nemesis Henry Kaufman and fleshing them out with an impressive mix of investigative details and creativity.When Henry Kaufman crashes his automobile into the Kopp sisters' buggy, a series of events is unleashed that tests the sisters' resolve to live in privacy with their independence intact.  Kaufman turns out to be a despicable man surrounded by unsavory characters.  When Constance Kopp attempts to make Henry pay for the damages, he responds with threats that escalate into very real danger.  Constance is challenged to protect her family, but can't stand by and allow Kaufman to get away with his terrible behavior.  I really enjoyed both the story and Stewart's wry, understated humor.  The Kopp sisters are great characters, and I love how they are the undisputed center of the story.  The men in the book don't come to their rescue or bail them out, but tend to turn up after the fact, shaking their heads as they offer all the wrong kinds of advice (move in with family, stay home and locked away, and my favorite, avoid hotels at all costs!).  As the Kopp sisters try to stay alive long enough to see Henry Kaufman brought to justice, they must face their dwindling finances, the shadow of their deceased overprotective mother, the uncertain future, and the kind of family secret that can ruin them.  The sisters are really memorable and appealing characters.  I wish we could be neighbors.I also enjoyed the added section at the end of the book where Stewart lists exactly which parts of the story are known as fact and which she added herself.  She lists sources for the newspaper articles throughout the book, most of which were reprinted as they originally appeared during the events in the story.  I completely enjoyed Girl Waits with Gun and would highly recommend it.

This Panasonic camera is fun to use and takes great photos and videos.  I have had a Canon Rebel for years and for some time had been wishing it could record video.  The Panasonic is lighter and smaller than I expected but performs very well.Initially, there is more of a learning curve with this camera than I expected.  From a layman point of view, the buttons and controls take some time and practice to figure out beyond the basic, automatic settings.  I really like the touch screen aspect and the many features, such as choosing a still frame photo from a video.  If you aren't an experienced photographer, you will need to take your time getting to know this camera.  Right out of the box (once the battery is charged), you can take photos on the automatic setting.  Anything more sophisticated will require time spent studying the manual.One feature I was excited to try was the wireless photo sharing.  While this is definitely a good feature, it has some limitations.  I can connect the camera wirelessly to my cell phone (or a tablet), using a free app.  With the app, you can transfer photos from the camera to your phone, control the camera, and share photos through social media.  The down side is that when your phone is connected to the camera, you can't be connected to WiFi.  You also can't connect wirelessly to a laptop, which would have been a fantastic feature.  The included software for saving and editing photos is OK, but I do prefer to use the editing software that came with my Canon.Overall, I like the convenient size of this camera and the wide range of settings.  While I am still learning to use this camera to its potential, I am quite happy with it.

I got these pants for my son, who will be 12 next week.  He is tall for his age and has been wearing a size 14 for some time.  Lately he's been saying some of his size 14 pants are feeling too small, but he's not tall enough yet to wear a 16.  I thought maybe a 14 Husky would be a good compromise, although my son is not "husky."Wrangler clothing does seem to be a bit roomier than other clothing brands.  It turns out that a 14 Regular in this brand fits my son best.  He can wear the husky in a 14, but only because these pants have an adjustable waist.  As a parent with fast-growing kids, I always look for pants with the adjustable waist, and in this case it literally makes the pants wearable.  They are a good length and look great, even after washing.  They look nice enough for school but so far seem durable enough to stand up to playtime as well.

I have a 40 pound 9 month old mixed breed (maybe shepherd, beagle, hound?) who loves to chew on soft toys but can't have them because she literally eats them.  I haven't let her have anything other than hard chew toys (like Kong and Nylabone) after seeing her throw up a pile of string and stuffing.This Tuffy dog toy caught my eye with its promises of durability.  I saw it in a pet store and the toughness rating of 9 fooled me into thinking it would stand up to my puppy's love of chewing. Within a few hours, she had unraveled one corner of this toy and in about a week made a hole large enough to reach the stuffing.  Since she doesn't just tear toys apart but actually swallows them, I had to take it away from her.  Unfortunately, I bought this at a boutique pet store and paid $16 for it.You'd probably be OK with this as a toy for fetch or tug, but not as something for your dog to chew on consistently.

I originally chose this book for my 16 year old, but ended up reading it myself.  The premise sounded really interesting -- teens affected by a virus that gives them powers along the lines of X Men or Heroes, some of whom are terrorists and some of whom are otherwise ordinary kids.  The  terrorists use their powers to throw the US into chaos by destroying a wide range of targets.  Blackout is the story of two sets of teens, terrorists and not, whose stories converge.Blackout was a fun, if light, read.  If you're wondering how a book about terrorists devastating the country can be light, it's because the story focuses so closely on the characters and their immediate circumstances that we don't get to see much of the bigger picture.  Sure, Chicago doesn't exist anymore, but none of the action happens in Chicago so it doesn't seem very real.  That being said, Blackout is the kind of easy page turner perfect for a beach day or a road trip.  There's enough happening to keep you interested and waiting to see what happens next.Without their powers, the characters are rather bland, which is one of the weak points of this book.  Additionally, we know very little about the terrorists.  Who set them in motion, and where did they come from?  What is their ultimate goal, and why?  In fact, after reading the book, the big question I was left with was, "Why?"  The ending does lead me to hope for more from the sequel (Dead Zone), which I may pick up from the library.Stronger points of the the book include the action and a couple of interesting twists.  I like the various powers given to the kids affected by the virus as well as the overall idea of the story.  Yes, it could be meatier and answer a few more questions, but it is entertaining.

The Honest Kitchen's line of pricey, yet high quality, dog food is an exceptional food if you can afford it.  Made with a short list of human-grade ingredients, this dog food has nothing in it you wouldn't want your dog to eat.  No by-products, nothing artificial, and no grains.  Dog Food Advisor gives this food its highest rating of 5 stars, calling it "superior."Because this food is dehydrated, it doesn't look like dog food.  It has a flaky, powdery texture with some larger chunks.  You measure out the amount of food based on your dog's weight, add the suggested amount of warm water, and let it sit for a few minutes to rehydrate.  I prefer to mix a few days' worth at once and store the extra in the fridge.  Even after mixing, it doesn't really look or smell like your typical wet dog food.My dog loves this food.  Granted, she loves everything and has been known to eat chicken poop, so her palette probably can't be trusted.  She is very energetic and her coat looks fantastic.  She rarely has issues with gas, her breath isn't bad (as long as she avoids chicken poo), and she even smells good when she hasn't had a bath for a few weeks.  The vet said she's "the picture of health," and I am convinced a high quality diet has a lot to do with that.  When we first got her, she had dry, flaky skin, terrible breath, and an unpleasant doggy odor just a day or two after getting a bath (she was from a shelter in the South).  I really believe changing her to a top quality kibble and supplementing that with high quality wet food has led to an overall improvement in her health and appearance.This 4 lb box of food makes 16 lb of rehydrated food -- still expensive, especially if you have a large dog.  However, I think a top notch dog food pays for itself over the course of your dog's life in good health and reduced vet bills.

My son will be 12 soon and is tall for his age.  He's been wearing a size 14 for several months, but some of his shorts have started to feel a bit small.  I took a chance on these Wrangler size 14 was happy to see that they fit my son perfectly.In addition to the nice fit, these shorts look good.  The cargo pockets don't make them too bulky and they are a shade of khaki that looks great with a variety of shirts.  He can wear these with a basic t-shirt or a polo shirt, sandals or sneakers.  Or socks and those athletic sandals, I'm sad to say.  Who started that unfortunate trend?So far the shorts have washed well and still look great.

The first time I used the SteamFast 3-in-1 steam mop, I instantly became a big fan of it.  I had a steam mop several years ago that only cleaned floors, and while I liked how it cleaned, it stopped working after only a few months.  I wanted to try the SteamFast because it not only cleans floors, but can be used as a handheld steam cleaner and a clothes steamer.Setting up the SteamFast is simple, no tools required.  Just fill the water tank, attach the handle (if mopping), attach the appropriate cleaning tool, plug it in, and turn it on.  It heats up very quickly and begins to produce a constant flow of steam.  You can adjust the level of steam according to the job/surface type.  The SteamFast is light and easy to maneuver and has a very long cord.For floors, it works very well.  I have been trying to cut back on the various cleaning chemicals I use around the house and really appreciate that this mop works so well with just water.  With three kids and a dog, our kitchen floor becomes a grimy mess faster than you'd believe.  As with any mop, you have to sweep or vacuum first.  The SteamFast quickly and easily cleaned up the kinds of sticky spots I'd normally scrub at with my regular mop or Swiffer.  It glides easily across the floor and one tank of water was enough to clean my eat-in kitchen, L shaped living room/dining room area, and both (small) bathrooms.  You get two washable microfiber pads to use with the mop.  They wash and dry well and I like that they can be reused.  The mop handle can be adjusted for length, which is a very nice feature.  It also has hooks for wrapping the cord; for easier storage, you can adjust the handle to the shortest position and wrap the cord around the hooks.When steaming wrinkles out of clothes, you detach the handle and use the clothes steaming attachment.  Until trying this steamer, I had never steamed clothes -- but it was simple and surprisingly effective.Using the steam nozzle attachments makes other cleaning jobs a breeze.  I was super impressed with how the SteamFast cleaned those nooks and crannies in the bathroom that I normally struggle to reach.  I have two young boys, and while I love them dearly, they are disgusting creatures.  What boys to do toilets is unspeakable.  The SteamFast was able to completely clean even the crevices in the toilet seat hinges so thoroughly and quickly you'd never know I live with boys who have terrible aim.  It also worked very well to clean the narrow spot behind the faucet in the master bath and made short work of the grimy places where the counter meets the wall.  In the bathroom, I found it effective to first use the steam cleaner to remove dirt from hard to reach places, then wipe it up with a cloth.  I love how much cleaner the bathroom looks without all the effort of using a little brush to scrub away at those awkward spots.  The nozzle alone is great for blasting steam into small places, while the brush attachments let you steam and scrub at the same time.In addition to the clothes steamer, mop, nozzle, and nozzle brushes, you get a squeegee attachment for cleaning mirrors and glass.  It works ok, some dripping, but is a decent alternative to using glass cleaner and paper towels.  Really, with the SteamFast and some cleaning cloths, you can do a lot of cleaning without using chemicals or paper towels.There are two things I did notice that are drawbacks to the SteamFast.  First, when steaming clothes the steamer drips a lot.  The clothes had no wrinkles, but did get quite damp from the dripping water.  The things I steamed were not going to be worn immediately, so this was no big deal, but it's something to keep in mind.  Also, the metal button that holds the handle in place seems to be a bit flimsy.  You have to be careful when putting the handle on or removing it; the button can become stuck at an angle and not lock into place.  My concern is that over time, it may break.Finally, it would be nice if this steamer had some sort of on-board storage for all of the attachments.  In order to (hopefully) avoid losing them, I put them all in a gallon ziplock bag, with the pads, then used a hanger with clips to hang the bag in the hall closet where I store the vacuum and steam mop.  This keeps everything in one place and easy to find.

I have yet to encounter a dog food my dog won't devour with enthusiasm, and Purina Beyond Natural is no exception.  She certainly enjoys the taste, and I enjoy the short ingredient list.  Each flavor of this dog food contains only a few human grade ingredients and no meat byproducts, corn, wheat, or soy.  This food looks and smells like baby food.  It is easy to mix in with dry kibble and lives up to the description of coating the food without soaking it.The label says to use 1/2 pouch per 20 pounds of your dogs weight.  It doesn't actually say to reduce the amount of kibble to reflect the addition of this food, but I am assuming that's what you'd do to avoid weight gain.  My 40 pound dog gets 1 cup of kibble plus about 1/3 to 1/2 cup of wet food in the morning (and only dry food in the evening), so I use one full pouch with her kibble.The only thing I am not crazy about is the packaging.  The pouches aren't very easy to open.  It takes more force than I expected to be able to twist the top off and I can see that anyone with joint problems in their hands may not be able to manage these.  A simple tear open pouch would have made more sense and used far less plastic.  It seems like Purina is trying to make the pouches look like the squeezable fruit pouches made for toddlers, but in this case the plastic spout isn't needed.  You can always use a pair of scissors to cut the pouch open rather than deal with the difficult cap.

There are a lot of benefits to adding hemp protein to your diet.  This is a complete protein, meaning it contains all of the amino acids, including the ones your body can't produce and can only obtain through diet.  Because it is organic, you know it is grown without pesticides.  In general, hemp is an easy plant to cultivate without genetic modification or heavy use of chemicals.I've been adding hemp protein powder to my breakfast smoothies.  It definitely makes the smoothies more filling.  I do find that a full serving of 4 tbsp of powder in a smoothie creates a somewhat gritty texture that takes getting used to, so if this bothers you, simply use less.  The flavor of the hemp powder is a bit nutty -- when used in a smoothie with cocoa powder, I feel like I am having a chocolate malt for breakfast.  I like that the hemp powder doesn't alter the taste of the smoothie in a way that makes me want to add some kind of sweetener.  It's pretty tasty and makes it easier to get to lunch without snacking.I was provided a sample of this product at no cost in exchange for a review.

If you can handle the cost of The Honest Kitchen line of dog food, it is a high quality food.  The ingredient list is quite short and features human grade food products.  I like the concept of this food and my dog definitely likes the taste.  Rather than feed her only this rehydrated food, I mix some in with her kibble once a day.  She spends quite a bit of time licking the bowl clean long after the last visible speck of food is gone.  Fish and coconut seems like a strange combination, but it must appeal to canine taste buds!The appearance of Honest Kitchen dog food is not what you'd expect.  It looks like a flaky powder, almost like fish food.  You measure out the dried food, add hot water, and let it sit for a few minutes before serving.  I mix a few days' worth at once and store it in the fridge to use as needed.  The food does not look very appetizing, but I have to say it doesn't smell like dog food -- it smells like people food.  Dog Food Advisor gives the Honest Kitchen Grain Free line a 5 star rating, making it a superior dog food option.  If you want to add this to your dog's diet but the price tag is intimidating, consider using it as an addition to kibble.  It will last a lot longer and still give your dog the benefit of adding a very high quality food to his or her diet.

I got these shorts for my son, who will be 12 in a few weeks.  He is tall for his age and has lately been complaining that some of his size 14 shorts are feeling too small.  While he isn't what I would call "husky," being within a normal weight range for his height, I thought these might fit him better than going up to a 16.  The fit of these shorts is definitely looser than I'd expect from a 14 Regular.  In fact, they are too loose for my son.  He didn't notice the adjustable waist at first and put a belt on, but said he likes the shorts and doesn't mind wearing them with a belt.As for appearance, these shorts look great.  My kid is naturally quite handsome, so that helps, but even when paired with just a t-shirt, the shorts look nice.  The cargo pockets aren't too large or bulky.  With school starting soon and at least a couple more months of warm weather, I'm sure he'll get plenty of use out of these shorts.  I've washed the shorts twice and they look great and seem like they will hold up over time, or at least until my kiddo outgrows them.  He's just about as tall as his 16 year old sister and showing no signs of slowing down.

This is the second type of Nutro canned food I've given my dog.  She is enthusiastic about eating it and hasn't had any difficulties digesting it.  I mostly feed her kibble, but mix 1/3 can of wet food into the kibble once a day.  This food isn't so much chunks in gravy as it is chunks in congealed goo, but I'm not one to judge dog food by its appearance.  My dog doesn't care what it looks like, just how it tastes.  I don't care what it looks like, just how good it is for her.Tender Chicken and Rice recipe is actually a mix of chicken, chicken liver, turkey, and beef liver.  Most of the ingredients seem higher in quality than many other brands of dog food.  There are two things that stood out to me, however.  I would prefer a food with brown rice rather than white; white is more refined and less nutritious.  This food also contains wheat gluten.  While high in protein, wheat gluten isn't as biologically valuable as meat as a protein source.  As a dog food ingredient, it boosts the protein total but is less expensive than meat.  Finally, there aren't any probiotics in this food.  I'm not sure I'd feed this to my dog on its own, but I think it is a good additive to her high quality kibble.  Dog Food Adviser gives Nutro Large Breed Canned Food four stars, making it an above average dog food.I am glad I discovered Nutro wet food and will continue to supplement my dog's kibble with it.  She has plenty of energy, her coat is nice and shiny, and her bowel movements are regular and normal.

The charge is fast, taking me about about 3/4 time to get a full charge. The cable is not 3.3 ft. I'm afraid to uncoil it, but the 1.5 ft is fine as I drive a minivan. Don't laugh.It doesn't fit my Otterbox too easily. I had to force it. Snug is a word you may use, but you could also describe the ocean as slightly wet.I've used for several days now with no problems.

This toy is recommended for Children 7 years and older but my 6 year old was able to enjoy it mostly on her own and loved it. She needed help with reading the instructions but had so much fun doing the experiments included in this Scientific Explorer Ice Age Creator Kit. This "toy" is both educational and fun.Kids are able to make make a crystal tree, crystal ice chunk, a batch of instant snow and a frozen lake. The Wooly Mammoth that is included is a lot of fun too. There are several questions and fun facts for the kids to work through as well. Overall a great toy at a great price.

as student bibles go, I hate them. I detest them because they tend to dumb down the student.First, this is the CEB. I don't care much for the CEB, simply because I don't. It is an able translation and one ready to be used by modern English speakers, but not my favorite translation. For me, this is not a review about the CEB, but about the additional material found in the Student Bible.And that material is pretty solid. Based on actual scholarship, it presents scholarly discussions about such things as authorship and redaction. This is great because this is how we teach students to understand arguments against Scripture. Further, it takes various parts of Scripture as a way to launch into a discussion of, basically, what does this mean today? How does St. Paul's argument at Areopagus mean for us when combatting moral and religious relativism? What does it mean that the early Church held all property in common?Overall, the material is presented in a solid, easy to read format going beyond traditional student bibles. If you are a Christian ed director, if you have high school and college students, or if you have a young Christian who needs to know something more about Scripture and how it is seen by others, get this

I got this for my son, 11 year old - 6th grade, gifted.The book is divided into 9 chapter, each filled with several biographies centered on a common theme. Each biography is written well, highly entertaining, and informative enough for me to have been bothered with it for the past month.The book is likewise filled with illustrations.Overall, a well done book aimed for the mature reader, but suitable for the adolescent.

This Girl Scouts Cookie Oven is SO FUN to use! My 6 year old LOVES it. She baked some of the cookies for us and they actually tasted delicious. It's simple enough for her to use by herself with a little supervision from us or her siblings. The oven makes a great birthday or christmas gift, although it is priced a tad bit too high in my opinion. It comes with all the necessary tools and Thin Mint mixes to get you started. The refill mixes are readily available, although on again, priced a little too high.Overall, I would recommend this Girl Scouts Cookie Oven. It's a fun activity for the kids and especially an aspiring baker!

Have you ever noticed that when you need a meter, the space is usually small? Thankfully, Amprobe makes this meter to fit pretty small spaces. Not only that, but it's made to be held. That's right, you can actually hold this. It is lightweight but I had no issue holding it do the rubber fit. The sounds and backlights are great for actually hearing and seeing the readouts. The buttons are rather easy to operate, with no difficulty doing so in most tight spots and with minimal hand movement. Finally, because I'm focused on the tight-spaces, the read outs are rather quick and accurate (0 to 600 V - 1%, 0 to 1000 V 0.8% ).

This is our second (and maybe last?) auto-cleaning kitty litter box. This is our first from Arm and Hammer. The reason we are interested in these are selfish. We have 2 cats. We have 3 children. They take our time and frankly, cleaning out a litter box is the last thing I need to do after discussing the necessity of homework with my 11 year old for the 1123rd time.The set up is easy. I have found that it gives my cats enough time to use the litter box without running them away. I do have two cats, but they have worked out space issues long before we got this one. They get in there and go. Other uses are noting that the rake comes really fast, sometimes with the cat still in there. I have not yet experienced that. There is a timer, so you can just let it rake hourly. And yes, there is a manual rake. This is a improvement over the other brand.The smell is gone, as expected. Clean up is easy as well.What is really nice is that the motor is detachable. With the other brand, it is not  meaning I have purchased a box twice because the motor got fouled up. This one allows me to clean it, in case it does ever get attacked with wayward kitty litter.

this is really my first card game. So any deficit in appreciation is most likely mine.The learning curve is easy (8 pages in the book) and fitting for those who are beginning with card games. It does promote some moral issues  you are supposed to lie and fight with your fellow players, but I guess this should be compared with killing your opponents. The game time isn't all that long and you could probably use the extra time to play another round or 4.This game is not for the quiet or those who do not want to have fun in negotiations. It may be better suited to future crony capitalists.

I think most of us are getting tired of the space a two knob and spout faucet takes up. My bathroom is pretty small and I am always looking for ways to save space, even if that space is in sight only. So, something the Delta 564-MPU-DST fits the bill easily enough. Plus, the length of the spout is just right to fit into the middle of a small sink. The design meets ADA, by the way.The handle is easy to lift and doesn't require a lot of movement to get the water to flow.It is relatively easy to install. It really depends on your sink configuration, but if it is the normal bathroom sink, you should have no problem installing this one, even if removing the old one makes you say bad words. There is the Diamond Seal technology that should keep it sealed (which was one of the reasons driving the exchange  the old seal had simply ceased to exist).
