It is nothing you have to do, just put it on like usual.The chrome finish is the only thing that may be off putting, but I didn't find it too loud and I think it may last a bit.

I am left to wonder, because of the proposed premise of this book, if we aren't left with a more hidden Jesus than before. The second half of the book makes the book worthwhile. It examines the Jesuses of different religions, including the Gnostic, Muslim and American (yes, I did call "American" a religion). In this, the authors (while presenting an evangelical outlook) tackle what Christianity would be if, say, the Mormon Jesus of Joseph Smith, was the dominant Jesus. This "Jesus Outside the Bible" should be expanded more, giving special attention to various other Jesus projects (including the Quest for the Historical Jesus and this book) and how such a Jesus may actually differ from the biblical accounts. In the end, however, this second half of the book is where the premise fulfills itself. If Rediscovering Jesus was only this second half, this book would merit five stars.But it isn't.Rather, the first half of the book leaves me troubled given their often over-Southern Baptist and too-simplistic outlook. The authors, David B. Capes, Rodney Reeves, and E. Randolph Richards, make it clear that they understand the New Testament presents a Jesus of many layers and that "others reinterpret Jesus"  but they fail to see how they do so. For instance, they seem to think that had we only the Pauline Jesus (74-88) we would be missing Christian ethics and so on. I am left to wonder what sort of Marconite sheol this is, given that St. Paul (and Jesus before him) pulled directly from the Old Testament to form Christian ethics. Yes, the point must be made that the Jesus of Christian Tradition is in fact one built by the entire canon of the New Testament (and the Old), but it seems they have gone far  removing the role Tradition has played in not only laying the cake that is Jesus, but in providing the icing.The book is well written, suitable for small group study, with plenty of asides to further the conversation. However, it lacks in its ultimate premise. What biblical introduction to this? Scripture was never meant to be one book, which is why we have Mark spawning Matthew, and so on. The claim that Apostolic Succession would have been lost without Mark is a sad one, given that Apostolic Succession is one of the tools shaping the Canon. But Mark drew from Paul and required that the readers knew of Paul's writings. Is this really biblical, given that examination of a New Testament book is examined not with a critical eye, but a confessing (and an evangelical one at that?) eye? Is it really religious, when the only other comparative religious examination is between the Baptist seminary's view of the Christian Jesus and Gnosticism, Mormon, and Islamic? Why not the historical critical scholar's view of Jesus, the Catholic's view of Jesus, and the Unitarian?This book isn't a complete failure, but my initial excitement quickly faded. I hope that readers do not take the Jesus presented in the first half and suppose that this Jesus is the only layered Jesus for Christians.

You're going to look at the price and go "wow."But then you're going to look at the reviews and begin to wonder.This printer IS ideal for the small office. It has every feature you need, but with 2 years of ink (and the ink is pretty cheap when you run out). It has a really easy set-up - if you use the quick start guide - and I can use it with my 4 home laptops, 2 ipads, and several iphones.The print quality is really high end, even with photographs.

I've long been a fan of TRESemme Hair Care Products and this Expert Selection Weightless Shampoo is no exception. When I use this shampoo I can actually feel the difference in my hair. It removes all of the other product residue that builds up in my hair. It leaves my hair feeling clean, weightless and shiny! I have shoulder length straight hair that I only condition a couple times a month, and I still get residue build up. With this shampoo I don't feel like I even need a conditioner anymore.We recently went on a beach trip and brought this shampoo along for after ocean and after pool showers. It worked perfectly to get all of the nastiness out and leaves your hair feeling light and clean. I highly recommend this product for all hair types and you cannot beat the price for the huge bottle you get!

My daughter has VERY thick, curly hair so we are always looking for hair care products that help make it more manageable. This Dove Advanced Hair Series Supreme Creme Serum helped get a smoothness to her curls that we have not been able to find in other products. It doesn't weigh your hair down like other products and it smells amazing! Even on a humid day this product is doing the trick by keeping the frizz down!! We are very pleased with this product on thick, curly hair. I'm not sure how well in would work on thinner hair, it might be too heavy. The cream is very thick which works great for us when used minimally.

This VTech Magic Star Learning Table is SO. MUCH. ENTERTAINMENT. It will keep little ones happy and having fun for a good stretch of time, which in a parent's world is very much needed and appreciated. Not only that, it's super educational!! There are 6 activities, in both English and Spanish, and appeals to a wide age range, from 6 months to 3 years old. For the non-walkers it sits on the floor, and for beginning walkers or toddlers it stands on legs for easy play.This learning table is super easy to set up and it's even fun for child caregivers to play along. Bonus: the sounds are not obnoxious like a lot of toys are these days. I'd definitely recommend this toy as a lasting item since it's for a broad age range and doesn't get boring. VTech has been a trusted brand for many years and the price of this toy is very reasonable!

Unfortunately, the BLU Studio C will not work with Verizon or Sprint (different system) but does work with AT&T and other services. Check and see if they require CDMA compatibility. If they do, this will not work. Your sim card can still be read, but will not connect to their service.But, beyond that  there is so much more beyond that.Like other BLU products, the accessories you need actually come with it. You get a case, charger, earbuds (with FM radio keyed in) and screen protector. It is dual sim so you can have two different networks. This is helpful for business users, especially. That's right. Forget the cost for a moment. This phone is made to be used by professionals. This is an unlocked phone  it is not tied to a specific carrier. You can choose your own.The camera is one of the better ones on the market. It has a 720 x 1280 HD screen while the camera takes 1280 HD video. Unless you are a professional photographer, you may not need any more. I didn't. These resolutions produce great looking pictures. The editing software is great, although the aperture isn't what I'd like.The phone is pretty light, but not as thin as the iPhone 6. That means you can hold it without the fear of it slipping through your hands.The learning curve is easy. It is an Android and meant to be used right out of the box. I had no issue connecting it to the Google Play store and downloading my first few apps. The storage is expandable  unlike some of the higher end phones (cough iPhone cough).The one downside is that you cannot remove the battery. But, my suspicion is that the battery is going to last a while  well, well, well past the 100 bucks you are going to spend on the phone.

Gents, to be honest, I didn't use this. My daughter did.She does everything to her air imaginable. Flattens it. Dries it. Curls it. In other words, damages it on a daily basis. Her hair is pretty course. She said she uses it longer than the time recommended and in the shower.Her words, "yeah. it works."My wife used it once, although she doesn't damage her hair like my daughter does her's; however, she said she noticed a better moisture to it.And it really comes in handy after a week spent at the beach.

This does not fit the life case but does work on the OtterBox.Amazon basics seems to be an economical choice to Apple and other high-priced charger manufacturers. It is durable, long enough, and it is actually lightning fast when it charges.I've used it in the car and the home and on my MacBook with no problems. It charges fast both my iPhone and my iPad.

I'm not sure I can say anything except WOW.I have the otterbox covers for my iphones - all of them. Now I have one for my ipad. Not only is it the usually rough protection for my rather expense device, but this one provides a usable feature as well.I have put it through the ringer too. And it holds up. I've rubbed the front cover and it doesn't loose texture. The base only works on landscape but for the life of me, I can't imagine why you would need a base for the other position. A base is for prolonged viewing.And it adds weight to the Air. Maybe this is something you don't like, but it has helped me feel less protective of my Air. Now I can carry it like I did my iPad 3.

I wish the OEM would make cables like this. This a great alternative to the usual OEM.If you are using a firewire then you are looking for certain things. I'll keep it brief.This firewire is the upgraded version. Think USB 3.0. The speed shows as does the solid connection. It is durable and fits snuggly - does not wobble.I've used it to connect to my camera and the videos (where I noticed the biggest difference) comes through superfast.

it does work here in West Virginia..I've used it in and around my garden without damage to the vegetables, although I do worry about the corn just a bit. I've used it around flowers and it works there as well. And trees aren't harmed either.My only problem is is that when it rains it seems to last about a month. Not a sprinkle or anything like that but honest to goodness rain. Like summer showers. I've had to reapply it twice. But, it works fast.

They are great for a healthy way to boost your energy around your workout. And...I may have taken it one day last week because the coffee just didn't work. The energy was subtle, but noticeable, last several hours.The taste, tho... is real... a cross between salty and rubber. Not bad, just different.

Simply, this doesn't offer a lot of protection. It is pure and simple a sleeve meant to, in some way, make the Surface Pro seem less bulky. I don't know why, but it does.The material is high quality as is the composition of the sleeve. Even the zipper seems like it'll last the daily pull of using the machine hidden in the sleeve.Over all, I like it  for a decorative sleeve.

This Five Star Locker Mirror + Push Pin Board is great for locker organization. My new middle schooler is using it with a shared locker partner. They can both use the mirror quickly and add a couple notes for the week to it. The board is made of a sturdy foam that is lightweight and easy to install. It is magnetic so it's easily positionable and removable at the end of the school year. This is a great way to start the year out right with good organizational habits!The teal color is great and matches a few other accessories in their locker. The price is okay for what you get. You get extra pins. Another bonus is the mirror is not actually glass, so if it's dropped it won't break. The only con to the mirror is that it's a bit cloudy but perfect for a quick face check between classes!

This Five Star Extra Tall Locker Shelf and Drawer is working wonders in my new middle schooler's locker. He goes to a bit of a crowded school so all of the students share a locker. This shelf created double the space by using the upper portion of the locker. It is super easy to set up and really does hold a lot of weight.The drawer is helpful for holding extra pens and pencils so they aren't getting lost in the bottom of the locker. The color is a bright teal, which looks great and adds a bit of happy to an otherwise boring grey/beige locker. A perfect space saver, I'd recommend these to all middle and high schoolers, even those who aren't sharing a locker.

Finish Powerball Tabs work wonders if my older dishwasher! We were having problems with the dishwasher leaving behind food spots. After trying these dishwasher tabs, I am SOLD! No other dish detergent tabs work this well. They are EASY to use, they come individually wrapped in a dissolvable wrapper. No extra wrappers left in the drawer or thrown on the counter by my kiddos. The price on Amazon is comparable to in-store product. Great price for the quality of cleaning these tabs do. A bag of 48 tabs lasts my family of 5 about a month and a half, that't running the dishwasher once a day. I highly recommend these tabs, especially if you have an older, less powerful dishwasher.

I'm looking for something that is slightly less bulky than the otterbox but still offer something of a solid protective piece. The Guard Dog does move me to that. It is not bulky. It fits well. The hold seems to stay as well, meaning I don't have to worry about the silicon case coming loose. It is a two piece, giving it an added way to distribute the force of dropping the phone, and forcing the silicon (the rubber bit) to stay securely on the phone. The holes are in the correct places, so that the camera is free to use. Nothing covers the side buttons, however. The weight is just right.There is nothing to cover the glass however. The lip will help IF you land face first on a flat surface.

I dig it. The strawberry taste isn't that bad. It is not too sweet if the right amount of water is used. The fiber doesn't clump and doesn't settle. Like other benefiber products, it melts away. So yes, YOU CAN use ICE with this.the packets are great to have on the go so that I don't have a huge container or a plastic bag of white power on my desk.Love it.

This is not a protein or meal replacement bar. The calories are way to high (220) and the protein low (16). Further, don't take it hiking or otherwise. The chocolate melts easily.WIth that said, the bar tastes really good. Rather than a candy bar, this has the taste of something healthy for you  and it should, with all the nuts in it. The chai taste is something I'm not a fan of, but it wasn't overpowering and added to the overall "treat" feel of the bar.I enjoyed it as did the family. But, it is not something I'd recommend for those concerned with calories

This is an entry-level oscilloscope. The cost should be a giveaway here. One of the better features I like about this one (over an older one I have) is the USB ports, allowing me to connect to my computer for data storage. This is digital data.I have used it to verify some sensor parts on my Ford Edge (will they ever fix the door sensor?) and found that it is easy enough to operate  and for those who are first venturing into oscilloscopes, the Tektronix 1052B is a great way to do it. The learning curve is better than most so much so that I was able to let my son (11) figure out some easy measurements.It is a bit slower than some of your more pricey models, but not too terrible. Comparable to the higher priced models, unless you are looking for better interfaces (do you really need them) then this has all the bells and whistles you'll need.If you use an oscilloscope, then you know what they are for and what you are looking for. After a month or so with this one, I think this is going to replace my previous model (even the more expensive one) because of the weight, the USB port, and the screen. Frankly, this may be the last oscilloscope I need.

These jeans fit my slender 12 year old perfectly. Great fit in the waist and the length is good hitting just below his ankle. The denim itself seems pretty durable. We have a problem with holes in the knees after about 10-12 wears but these seem like they will hold up better than the jeans we've been buying. The loose fit is what my son likes and they're pretty stylish. Wranglers have a come a long way from when I was a kid and they were considered un-cool. This is a quality pair of jeans at a great price!

Sure... it is for camping... but you know what else?I has to change my sink faucet and under the sink was dark. So, I broke this sucker out and it did the trick. It was not overbearing, but offered a bright light that stable.I've always used the light for taking pictures. My house doesn't offer the best lighting and I needed it for a food blog. This gave the best appearance of natural light.The recharging doesn't take long. There are several varieties of lights, including red. There is a hook on the base, but it always acts like a stand. The top part is rubber so it won't break when you drop it several times. I'm up to about 6.It is smaller than expected, but over all, the light it puts out is fantastic.

Where do our most pernicious myths begin? Is it something within us, or maybe within our time and place, giving birth to these evil narratives?Where did the Holocaust actually begin? Perhaps we can honestly say it began in late 12th century Norwich, England with the publication of an unfastidious genesis of the blood libel. After all, E.M. Rose, the author of The Murder of William of Norwich, notes that rather than having the blood libel (see her note on terminology, 24142) as a centuries old account only coming to life with a poorly sourced tale, the stories did not begin to take hold until the Early Modern period. And, as she recounts, in a 60-plus year time frame ending in 1935 (p11), there were more charges of blood libel than all the centuries before. Perhaps, then, we see the power of myth  the deep, dark power of words chosen only to inflict harm to a people  and the damage it has done. Rather than a history of the blood libel and damage it has caused, the story Rose so eloquently tells us is about the first audience, the first myth givers, and the cult of William of Norwich.Rose eloquently challenges long-held notions of the roles of Jews in Europe  and how Christians in England and on the continent treated them. Simply put, her historical narrative reveals a world quite unlike Brother Thomas Life and Passion (the first and only surviving account about the trial of William of Norwich) but one of  harmony usually accompanying Jews and Christians. So, how did we end up with a story permeating and fueling anti-Semitic tropes for the past 1000 years? How did we go from a well-knitted social fabric of allowing Jews and Christians to work together to the expulsion of Jews from England and the continued use of this horrendous myth to further subjugate the Jews, almost to the point of extension? As with all stories, there is no beginning ex nihilio .In the first several chapters (constituting Part 1), Rose slowly introduces us to the world of William of Norwich, the cult that sprang up after his death, and the larger world full of failed crusades and rampaging knights intent on eking out a sense of victory, even at the expense of whole peoples. We meet the genesis of the blood libel not as some historical fact  although there are plenty of historical myths and stories giving birth to this horror  but as a genius of a judicial strategy to save a knight from embarrassment, a king his allies, and England her financial due.Rather than having any real basis, the blood libel began as a way to end a trial, becoming quickly a tool to preserve the martyrdom of William (and the financial windfalls of a reliquary), the all but forgotten murdered boy at the center of the story in our mythmaking. Once the charge was made a charge never proved true and never properly investigated  it became alive, with new stories and tales popping up to build upon the case. Rose makes it clear that Brother Thomas, the first transporter of the tale, had no actual first hand information, but relies on, at best, a third-hand recounting. Simply put, the only real thing about the libel is the harm it has caused Jews and Jewish-Christian relationships in the intervening years. The presentation of the small, almost forgettable judicial strategy, makes one believe it was entirely possible to have never encountered the blood libel as a myth. It is, simply, a haphazard point of history, a minuscule argument  a statement so preposterous that we are left to wonder about the legal dullards who bought it. Surely, we moderns say, no one in a country that treated the Jews as well as England did, would believe such a thing.The Murder of William of Norwich reveals nothing tangible about the murder of said lad, but turns us upon ourselves, to reveal our history and fascination with convenient fiction.  Once the die had been cast, the cult of William exploded in Norwich, at the expense of the Jews. The same expense cast relics as prized positions  after all, the local dead boy had done well. He has suffered a violent and tragic death at a time when heroes were needed. His death saved a knight  a knight who was guilty of a murder of a Jew  and promoted Norwich as a seat of mystical miracles. Two deaths  William and Deulesalt  brought riches to Norwich, but at the expense of a thousand-year charge against the Jews of the blood libel. What was most likely a suicide (as Rose notes) became a martyr and what was a martyr became a cause. However, to Romes credit, William was never formally canonized. At least, I think, we can thank our God for that.The book is divided into 2 parts, 4 chapters between them. Part I ends with the elevation of the cult of William of Norwich in East Anglia. Part II takes us through the continuation of the cult by continental kings. There, the blood libel tale was expanded and applied to other youths, creating a mythos taking root in Europe that is still not completely burned out. As Rose points out, the great tragedy is that the death of a Christian individual was applied to the whole of the Jewish people rather than any individual person (237). While a relatively short book (240 pages), the breadth of scholarship is expansive. This is seen in the in-depth endnotes (nearly 100 pages) which includes more than citations. Rather, the endnotes must be read in part with the narrative of the book. They exist as something more than the usual academic footnotes, but more like an annotated bibliography. The storytelling by this first-time author is quite voluble, with the pen of a master narrator. The text is never boring, picking up new lines just when the old ones had run their course. A brilliant entry by this author, leaving us wanting a next book soon.E.M. Roses The Murder of William of Norwich: The Origins of the Blood Libel in Medieval Europe arrives at a time when we see the rise of anti-Semitism in Europe, labeling of whole people in the United States, and an uncertain world seeking someone or something to blame for the chaotic state of world affairs. Everything spoken seems to have a hyperbolic quality. We have forgotten the power of words and stories and how carefully we must choose to employ them for our defense. When the Bishop Turbe stepped into history to defend the depraved knight, he chose to play on the stereotypes of a people. I doubt Turbe believed it would go as far as it did, nor did he have a malicious intent. However, the road to hell, and such as that. Roses work reminds us that things dont just happen. Her intricate weaving of the social context around the death of William, the role of the initial charge, and the elevation of the cult, shows us that sometimes societies are ripe for evil.

There really are no low points with this. If you are looking for a huge flame, or gas-grill taste, etc... THEN DON'T GET IT. However, if you are looking for a safe, easy, controlled way to grill outside (or inside) then this is the perfect item.First, I'm a HUGE George Foreman fan. I have several of the products already and enjoy every one of them immensely.The set-up is easy. Takes 10 minutes if you are drinking a beer.The grilling is a cinch. You can control the temp, no flames, nothing to burn you with. And the surface is non-stick for easy clean up AND you don't have to worry about the losing half the burger to the surface. The surface area is large, but I have no issue with cleaning it in my sink.The drain try isn't as large as it could be, but I've already solved that issue by dumping the tray.It cooks evenly and I really like having the lid which 1.) keeps condensation in and 2.) speeds cooking time.It seems weather resistant (not proof) so I can keep it out and cover without much of a worry.I've cooked chicken breasts, burgers, 'dogs, and some sausage. Rather than cutting the Scriptures up, in the mold of Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Katharine Bushnell stayed well within the principles of Christian hermeneutical tradition and developed a solid theological feminism. Her work deserves to be reread, something Kristen Kobes Du Mez makes not only possible but desirable.Kristin Kobes Du Mezs story of Katharine Bushnell work, Gods Word to Women, is part biography, part literary commentary, and part social commentary  and, completely, a challenge to men and women alike to discover what shapefreedom might take for the twenty-first century. What A New Gospel for Women (NGW) entails, however, is not a mere recounting of an often overlooked person from history, but a significant portion of the life of American feminism encapsulating corresponding stories of the Methodist people, foreign missions, womens suffrage, and what it is like to see fulfillment postponed. Indeed, for an account of events beginning in the 19th century, it reads like current events.I am not a student of feminism, although I have benefited from it. I do know the story of those considered the great pioneers, such as Elizabeth Cady Stanton  but likewise, I know the sad tale of how Christian theology was dispensed with, Scripture was brought low, and the movement suffered because of it. But, through these pages before me I am introduced to a woman who is a scholar, exegete, and theologian rivaling those of the great Antiochian and Alexandrian philosophers long before her. To be sure, by todays standards she is often a mixed bag. At first, Bushnell was an opponent of traditional Christianity (her own version was that of the holiness tradition), only to then become welcomed by even the most conservative interpreters. She was a feminist, but by todays standards  with her important take on birth control and abortion  I doubt she could maintain such a reputation. She was not a mere novel of history, a fortunate accident, but as Du Mez presents her, a truly quintessential prophet lobbying against entrenched power  both patriarchal and even imperial  and for the oppressed. Her life is the absolute fulfillment of Matthew 10.18.The first four chapters are biographical. We are given a well drawn out, never boring, and often times too short account of the life of Katharine Bushnell  and like any good disciplinary attendant, Du Mez gives us the surrounding picture as well. She crafts the narrative about Bushnell by giving us what is going on in the world around her. Bushnell only comes into focus, then, when we see the town of Evanston, the mission to China, the American society, the colleges for womens education, and the birthing of feminism in the late 19th century Victorian age. Du Mez, in these chapters, assemble the puzzle pieces that is Katharine Bushnell and presents a picture of a woman who very much deserves to be better known by people today  not as a historical figure, but as an ever-present reminder of the deep connection between Christianity and feminism, and, more importantly, what a deep exegetical review of our Holy Text may accomplish for those normally considered second-class.Du Mezs fifth and sixth chapters explore that exegetical review. In these chapters we are taken behind Gods Word to Women to see the processes that went into developing the exegesis  which includes something beyond understanding the context of the original page, but so too the context Bushnell lived in. She could see beyond the publication and understand the need of her would-be reviewers and readers to carefully craft, before they could issue their objections, the answers to the objections. In that, she does better than any theologians today. I am impressed with Du Mezs presentation here. Bushnell is presented as a calm and assured exegete of Christian scripture  one who upholds the conservative and orthodox position of Scripture, even to the point of inerrancy, while pushing interpretation into a progressive arena. My heart is quickened to think that this has been done and can be done in such a way as to give American Protestants space to appreciate the work (even if they disagree) and perhaps even accept the work. I am amazed at her craftsmanship, at her skill, at her passion. Bushnell, via Du Mez, holds together the tension of a high view of Scripture, the need to correct Tradition, and the refrain of holiness. I cannot comment on Bushnells work  that is not the point of the review  except to say that in many ways, her work precedes trends in historical criticism prevalent today. Indeed, in scanning my library I see several references to her work as a noted scholar.Du Mezs final two chapters bookend the book, bring Bushnells life to a close, setting it into a rather sad juxtaposition. On one hand, we have a woman who brought justice to both China and India via her tireless crusade against the regulation of vice, the production of a rather important work (Gods Word to Women), and the end of the Victorian Age. On the other, we have the beginning of the divide in American Protestantism, the beginning of World War I, and the emerging New Feminism. What falls through the cracks is an important step in Christian feminism, biblical exegesis, and a huge moment for American Protestantism. Bushnell could have shown us that we did not have to pick and choose between conservative and liberal, fundamentalism and relevancy, but could very well have endured with our faith in tact and an ear to science (and historical criticism). And what a world it may have been  had both sides not retreated away from the feminism Bushnell promised. This retreating is covered unbiased by Du Mez. Neither side wins  as both, conservatives and liberal, create their own repressive anti-feminist movements.As a white male United Methodist, a historical critic of Scripture, and a sometimes-theologian who presses others to examine Scripture in light of the context (both then and now)  and as one who cannot seem to fit into any specific category  Du Mezs A New Gospel for Women is a pinnacle of acceptance and understanding. I sit in awe of what Bushnell accomplished  beginning with the Methodist Episcopal Church  and mourn for what it could have been. Perhaps, as Du Mez points out, the resurgence we see in Christian feminism will again turn to Bushnell and her long overdue reward, as prophet, will finally be given. I cannot help but to recommend this book to every American Christian, especially those in the Wesleyan tradition, and those with a hope that through a high view of Scripture we can dismantle oppressive structures and rather than dispensing with everything around us, construct from the ashes a better system befitting our Christian Tradition.

This item fit as expected - for exactly a 10. I am reminded why sizes are 10/12 rather than just 10. There is no room to grow, sadly - sad, because these pants seem rather heavy duty, color-fast, and nice. My son likes the cargo pants and these aren't just with extra pockets but meet the demands of cargo pants.Overall, very satisfied - just not with the size allotment.

This Bostitch Antimicrobial QuietSharp Pencil Sharpener works efficiently and quietly! It's safe, stylish even and works perfectly! It auto shuts down so that pencils aren't over sharpened and the circle on the front lights up so you can be sure to know it's finished. This sharpener is perfect for the classroom as it is quiet and the shavings tray holds a lot of shavings.There are suction cups on the bottom which alls children to sharpen without touching the top of it, thus preventing the spreading of germs. Plus, the suction cups add another measure of safety since it won't vibrate off the desktop its being used on.This sharpener works wonderfully and I would definitely recommend it to schools, classroom and large offices.

I don't know if it's just my household (family of 5, 3 of which are kiddos) but we can't keep up with a hand held manual pencil sharpener to save our lives. Every time we get one that works for more than 3 sharps it disappears. I'm pretty sure there's a black hole under my childrens' beds that these sorts of things go to die. However, this Bostitch QuietSharp Vertical Executive Pencil Sharpener saves us the after school mad dash to find the pencil sharpener for homework. It sits right on the desk near where the other after school supplies are and the kids can easily use it right there. It's mobile, but not mobile enough for them to lose it like the tiny handheld sharpeners!The little box holds a good amount of shavings before you have to empty it. I would lean toward saying it's better for home use rather than classroom use just because it would need to be emptied fairly often. It is in fact very quiet and it stops sharpening when your pencil is sharp rather than chewing the whole thing down to the eraser while your kid stares off into space. You know your kid does that too!Overall, I think this is a great electric sharpener for homework or small office needs.

This Holmes Smart Wifi-Enabled WeMo True-HEPA Air Purifier works great in that it purifies your in home air. It removes allergens and odors and does so fairly well. It can be operated my your wifi enabled phone, and is very reliable. Visually I think the air purifier could look more modern/neutral to fit into a room seamlessly. The machine is a bit noisy but not annoyingly so.We turned the purifier on in our sons bedroom after a sleepover with 5 boys and within an hour all the stink was gone. I really do like this device in our home. It's not something we would run on a daily basis but it certainly works great occasionally.

Finally, a pasta for me(n).i never let the water boil. so the one REAL con of this griddle is the cord length. I'm not sure that is worth a star-reduction or not, so I'm not going to give it one. Rather, I do think it earns 5 stars. Background: My daughter has problem skin. And she is getting into make-up. I am worried that she will cause damage to her skin with such make-up so we look for cleansing agents that are gentle and may help her skin over all.Cons: What happened to the instructions?Pros: It is very gentle, with the scent not that overpowering. More like a citrus smell. You only need to use it twice a week. And it will make your skin feel soft and clean. It doesn't flake and dry out on your skin. In fact, it starts to vanish after a few minutes and can be taken off with a sponge.I have yet to see any damage to my daughter's face as a result of using it. And I think it is actually helping to lessen some of the problem areas because it helps to keep the face moisturized.

Christopher W. Skinners latest work, Reading John, stands out as a bridge to a wider world of Johannine scholarship.At the beginning of my dissertation process, I had in mind the goal of rendering Gospel of John to a reduction of quotes, citations, allusions, and echoes of Deuteronomy. In doing my due diligence, I discovered the grandness of the Gospel of John cannot be measured by literary sources predating it or completely captured by later Christian theology. Rather, the Gospel of John still has many caveats for those adventurous spelunkers willing to risk calmness in reading and seek to better understand our Fourth Gospel.Christopher W. Skinnners recent contribution is not a grand commentary on the text, or a theological diatribe meant to sway one into reading John as if it contains fully developed Christian theology, but it is meant to be something a quite bit more substantial than an small group study book. Rather, Reading John is aimed at the student, new and old, capturing the current scholarship around the nascent Text that relies neither on Christian theology or the rest of the New Testament canon, but insists that it be understood on its own terms and merits. This doesnt mean Reading John is absent Christian theology or contributions from the study of the Synoptics, only that Reading John examines the Gospel of John as an independent work.Reading John is divided between 8 chapters, with chapters 1 and 8 serving as bookends to the intervening chapters that are focused on the Text itself. It is not a straightforward reading, as in chapter 7, Skinner returns to GJohns third chapter to finally explain the summation of the entire book  Skinner doesnt end John at chapter 21, but in John 3Open in Logos Bible Software (if available). In the meantime, Skinner examines the various theories of the composition of John, including the hypothesis of the two-level drama (chapter 3). Likewise, he explores the possibilities of an identity crisis in John  Jewish or anti-Jewish?  in chapter 4. (Skinner maintains hoi Ioudaioi  is used against the Jewish leaders rather than Jews.) In chapter 5, we read about the uniqueness of language of both Jesus and the narrator (such as the literary aside  Id like to have seen Skinner deal with John 12.33Open in Logos Bible Software (if available), a universally important aside) while in chapter 6, Skinner invites us to explore the rhetoric of GJohn and why people simply do not understand. Along the way, he includes small details that are often left out of books this size  such as literary connections in John and those hidden clues that the narrator is actually writing for the audience to understand (such as the connection between Peter and Judas). Through it all, we are given our own asides via space-saving charts and sidebars, that insure we get our authors point in minute detail. Accompanying each chapter is a plethora of bibliographical notes and sources, containing a wide-ranging view on Johannine scholarship. Skinner does not simply stick to one school of thought, but is quick to bring in various (sometimes countering) viewpoints to give a fuller picture.Skinner does not leave the theology behind, but does not insist that it is the same as later Christian theology. Rather, what you see is the beginning (and I believe a natural trajectory) of a theological strain that leads to current Christian theology; however, that may be my reading of it rather than Skinners intent. Regardless, what is everpresent is sound scholarship, an easy reasoning, and a needed approach to the Gospel of John informing the reader of current academic approaches without a complete deconstruction of the readers cognitive environment.I am always concerned with a book this size (a mere 145 pages)  that a reader will simply not get enough information for it to matter. I am happy to have had my concerns alleviated. While only 145 pages, Reading John is efficacious in dealing with the material at hand, without straying down rabbit-holes or leaving us wondering if there may be more.  Skinner writes with a scholars pen, and a classical pedagogues finesse, delivering to his students (that would be us) a well-lit door into the study of the Gospel of John.Dr. Christopher W. Skinner blogs here, where you will find his engagement with scholars and the wider-world.

It lights up fine. Except...There is no real switch. If you turn it over, it comes on/goes off. This means if the child is using it at night, and somehow it shifts, it may come one in the middle of the night or go off. The light turns off automatically, but that doesn't mean that a move during the middle of the night will not turn it back on.Overall, very happy with the brightness (bright enough to keep the monsters away, dim enough to allow sleep) and the durability. It is lightweight and easy for the child to grab, even a toddler. The batteries are not included.

This 3M Privacy Screen protector works fabulously for providing privacy while you are on your iPhone 6. It reduces glare and keeps your nosy co-workers from catching a peek of what you're doing when they're sitting next to you. The screen protector prevents scratches and smudges. It's super easy to apply and comes with easy to understand instructions. The protector doesn't interfere with phone cases and is easily replaceable if the need arises. The only cons to this product are 1. the protector isn't slick to begin with so your finger doesn't swipe as easily as it could. Not a huge deal in my opinion. and 2. Fingerprints do show up easily but that's just the nature of phone screens. Clean frequently and you're good to go.Overall, a very satisfactory privacy screen protector that I would recommend to any iPhone 6 user.

The sound quality alone will literally, or figuratively if you like the proper choice of words, blow you away.After I set it up (all of two button pushes, on and then connecting the bluetooth), I started to play some Boss (for you younger, tasteless children, that's Bruce Springsteen) and my wife turned around with one word. "Wow."You can control the volume from the speaker, but cannot skip.I use it for my iPhone 5C and 6, as well as my iPad. AND i can use it on my MacBook Pro and Air.It is heavy duty - sorry, not going to test the waterproof bit - and has room for additions, like a solar cell.The battery lasts a long time. It lasted several days. Not continuous, but at least 15 hours.So, I can either repeat the specs of the device or tell you that this is a great speaker because I've used it for several weeks. You're choice.Easy to operate, the sound quality is out of this world, and ruggard. It can be used near a pool or in a shower without fear of damage. Or left out in the rain at least once. And it had better not happen again

The Dog Bone shaped "Wicker" pet toy basket is seriously adorable and very functional. The weave is actually made of plastic so it's a bit more forgiving than actual wood wicker baskets. The size is perfect for storing so many different pet items from blankets & toys to Food and treats. The leather handle works great and the clasp is easy to open and close one handed. This would make a great gift for the pet lovers in your life and especially for city pet owners. Perfect storage solution!

The cons... the rubber ear buds are a bit big for my ears. I have dainty ears, I guess, so this is more of a personal thing. They have included some smaller ones, which work a lot better. So I guess it isn't really a con at all!The sound quality is great. I've tried it on my MacBook Pro, iPhone 6 (with LifeProof case, and yes, it fits), and a pc. All hold the same quality. In using it on the iPhone 6, the call quality is top-notch and the person on the other end of the line cannot tell I'm using the mic. So the quality goes both ways.It includes a bud cleaning piece which is...eww... but necessary, amma right?It also has a volume control on the piece as well, which is helpful in keeping things relatively hands free.The earbuds fit in nicely enough so that I don't have to worry about a lot of outside noise seeping in while I'm listening to Holtz.Very pleased and highly recommended.

This is a durable, easy-to-install, necessity for those long road trips when toddlers are in the back... backseat driving for attention. Seriously, I had it installed and ready to go in about 2 minutes. It is two pieces. The plastic seems to be a hard plastic. The spots were it has to turn seems to have enough friction to withstand a lot of mind-changings of where the table should point.It will not damage your car (if installed properly) and is a neutral color... so it shouldn't stand out too much.Still no enough of a reason to drive across country, but I might not mind it so much about driving to the store.

We are really loving this Fisher-Price Moonlight Meadow Play Gym. In keeping a friends almost 3 month old, we have found the little removable tummy wedge is GREAT for tummy time. It lifts them up a bit so they aren't flailing about screaming and they can actually enjoy their first tummy times with glowing lights and music. He loves looking in the little mirror and the linkable toys are so fun, and you can move them around and add more favorites if need be. The soft overhead arches are great for baby to practice reaching for items and exploring. Plus, they make for super easy portability. This toy is easy to pick up and move around the house and even put in the car for overnight trips. Extra necessary bonus, the removable floor pad is machine washable for when that baby inevitably leaks from one place or another ;-) And can those woodland creatures be any cuter?

yes, this is a vine product but my wife and I were looking at getting my son (soon to be 6th grade) a phone for school. Yet, he is my son. He breaks things on accident. I do not want to get him an expensive phone. Plus, I don't want to pay a contract yet for a phone he'll only use in emergencies.This phone does that and more. It is UNLOCKED. I have used it with my carrier and it was easy set-up. It is Android and so I've connected with the Google Play store and with Amazon. It works great. the WiFi picks up great speeds and so I don't have to worry about data.It comes with everything you need (except for the carrier) right out of the box, even a protective case (but you may want to get a slightly better one). The screen is bright, with a solid resolution. He has watched a few things on it already. No complaints there.It looks, at least from a distance, like the iPhone 6, which makes it an easy sell to image conscious kids. I'm okay with that, for now.This is one the best bets on the market. Fast. Efficient. Easy set-up. And, best of all, inexpensive (but not cheap, if you know what I mean).

I'm not very versed in grass planting or the correct way to do it. However, this Scotts Turf Builder Zoysia seemed to work great for this newbie seeder. I wet the area where I wanted to plant, spread the seed very liberally, raked it over to get it into the dirt then watered a little more. I continued to water everyday (when it wasn't raining) and up sprouted the blades!! I was kind of amazed it worked after reading the reviews here. Granted, it could certainly be thicker but time will tell. I'd recommend this product based on my experience and the price listed. It's worth it!

This works like a charm.I have a deer problem. But, I don't want to do them just disappear. I have a garden. That's the main thing.We put them down without range to keep them away from the garden. We still get to see the deer but they don't come near the garden.So, yes, they work. And, I have yet to notice any burned spots on the green grass.

This La Cuisine Cast Iron Casserole dish is such a nice cookware item. Let's start with how it looks. It's a deep red/black on the outside and the inside is cream. It's made of heavy cast iron and will last for many, many years with the proper care. It really is a beautiful casserole! Aside from looks, it cleans up nicely after it's used and cooks evenly, even on my electric glass cooktop! We made layered Enchilada Casserole by first sauteing vegetables, then beef. It all cooked beautifully without sticking. Then we strained that out and added all of the layers, lots of cheese, then popped it in the oven for 30 minutes. Very little of the cheese stuck to the pot, and the the little that did came off easily with a soft sponge and mild dish detergent.This cast iron casserole is certainly pricey. But, the quality is amazing and it will last for years to come. If you want a dish to cook in, make memories over and pass down to your children, this is the one!

I finally got my otterbox... because I could not afford the Lifeproof case. All my cool friends, tho, had the lifeproof case.I don't know why.The cons:1. the instructions are rather... difficult. there seems to be 2 sets, each telling you something slightly different.2. you need to text the case out to insure water will not get through. I had rather hoped watertight was a given with this, but it is not. I guess, on the other hand, it is better to be secure in knowing it is was watertight at least once.3. the sound quality is greatly diminished. It feels like someone is talking from inside a tin can. It vibrates on the back. the speaker phone has a reverb in it.The pros:1. it is watertight. I go to the beach at least once a summer as well as to my local lake. I'd like to know that if the phone did get dumped into water or placed under a wet towel i won't have to replace it. I feel pretty good about it.2. the case is smaller than the otterbox and a better fit for the hand. I actually prefer the feel of this one to the otterbox and even to the nude iphone 6.3. it goes on pretty easy.All in all, I like it but the sound issue may get to me later.

I live in West Virginia, a beautiful place populated by mountains and a lot of shade. Our house is still still a fixer upper but our yard is worse. Last year, we suffered the blight. No, not a bout of depression, but like the real blight. Like the ones that killed potatoes. So, we have had to dig up a large spot that once served as a small garden. Likewise, we didn't like where the former owners had put flowering plants. Both spots, don'tcha know, included a fair amount of that shade.I've had this for about a month now. We followed the instructions and at the moment, we are starting to see grass sprout where barren and weeded land existed before. If it continues to do this, I will have a nice addition to my lawn, meaning I mean need to replant other spots as well.A few things. Follow the instructions. Follow the instructions even about the geographical location needed for the seeds. It says sun and shade. You will need actual sunlight. We planted it in an area that receives sunlight, barely through the evergreen trees does it drift, a few hours of the day (hillside) and it doesn't work  or at least doesn't work yet. But, as I said, the place where I was able to follow the directions and allow the sun to shine, it works.

This is a great set of Crescent tools! They look great and the finish seems like it will hold up to the test of time. It doesn't chip which mean no rusting that can cause the tool not to work well. This set has a 72-tooth ratchet, which means less turns for you = less work, who can't get behind that?! This is a set meant to be used at home, not for a professional who needs a wide selection of socket sizes. Keep that in mind and I think you will be satisfied with this product for years to come.This set comes with a handy storage case that has proved useful in keeping all of the pieces together in one place. The case is plastic but for light use it should last for many years as well. Overall, a great sent of tools for light use for the home or DIYer.

GoodNites Bedtime pants for girls is really a great product. All three of my kiddos have been bed wetters up until at least age 6. Pull-Ups just won't work once they get that big so having GoodNites available is a good alternative. They are pricey but worth not ruining mattresses, having noisy (and hot!) covers on their mattresses, and washing sheets daily. These bedtime pants really WORK! They never leak, they are soft, not scratchy and my child (5 years old) never complains about having to wear them.The description for clothes size/weight is accurate so buy these based on that and NOT on the description comparing this size (clothes size 8-14/60-125lbs) to leading brand size 4T-5T. That is not an accurate comparison. My 5 year old who would normally wear at 4T/5T bedtime pant is in the 50th percentile in weight and only weighs 47lbs. With that said, these worked on her without leaking. If I were buying them again I would definitely be more aware of this and go down a size.Overall, this is a great product for nightime bed wetters!

You ever had this notion that you wanted to smell like you did in the 10th grade? Well now you can.Okay so it's not like that. The CK1 is a unisex smell which may bothersome. I prefer to smell and to smell differences. But it is just enough of both to allow both to use it.The spray bottle works perfectly and is not clog. It's the spray comes out smooth and even without saturating the clothing that you may be spraying it on.And sprays just so that you're not going to splurge and then I have to buy more just a short time. Do you like the smell this is what you're going to get.

This Kate Space New York Women's watch is just GORGEOUS!! The nude band allows you to wear it universally with all outfits. The size of the band is perfect for many wrist sizes. The rose gold on the watch face is very pretty and in style at the moment. The crystal accents add just the right amount of glam but not so much that it feels too heavy.The packaging for this watch is beautiful as well! It comes gift ready, just add a bow or ribbon and you are good to go. While there are no numbers on the watch face there is a second hand, which comes in handy. The price for the watch isn't bad either, a good value. My wife has been wearing this watch daily and she thinks it's perfect for all occasions!

My 5 year old loves My Little Pony Equestria Girls! She had a couple of the other dolls, but not this one. She loved the short hair pony tail and the long hair clip on. The boots/shoes come on and off and she was able to undress and re-dress the doll with no problems. The removable piano earrings were a cute add on as well! The arms and legs all move so the doll can be repositioned for imaginative play. Overall, this is a great little toy for the kiddos who love all things My Little Pony related. The price is a little steep but that's what you get with popular kid items.

Pull-Ups Training Pants with Cool and Learn work great for potty training. The coolness of the pullup once wet, helps connect the feeling of needing to go. Sometimes they aren't as aware of this as you might think. The training pants fit nicely and will work for a boy or a girl. They are clearly labeled for front and back, sometimes it's not easy to tell with other brands! The design on the Pull-Ups are also really cute! My 5 year old also used these at night since she wets the bed sometimes. They are not great for this, since 3 out of 5 times they leak. Best to use a Pull-Up meant for night time. I'd definitely recommend these training pants to potty training parents and kiddos.

This Honeywell 50-Pint Portable Dehumidifier is an excellent product! It plugs into an outlet right out of the box and is ready to go. The directions for operation are simple and direct. All you do is remove some paper/foam and press power. There are two settings, high or low. You can change the percentage of humidity you want your space to have and it tells you the temperature of your space. There is also a triangle button that lights up one the dehumidifier is full and needs to be emptied. The fill drawer pops out super easily and has a handle for ease of carrying and emptying the water. Another feature I really like is that there is a timer to set for power on and off. This is great for energy efficiency! If the bucket gets full the light flashes and the dehumidifier shuts off. Perfect!This machine works great in our 1,750 square foot house. Our downstairs space would get super damp, especially with rain in the Spring but not anymore. This dehumidifier runs fairly quietly. I would say it's slighter louder than a dishwasher running but quieter than a 110 window air conditioning unit. The noise is white and not invasive, I personally enjoy the sound, especially at nap time ;-) I would recommend this product over and over for a damp house or if you're living in a humid climate.

I'm an iOS guy, I canna lie. I like big screens. You android uses cannot deny, that when I bring my ipad in with its not so-itty-bitty screen you get a bit jealous.But, with that said, Android does have its benefits and I think the BLU touchbook captures most if not all of them. At this point, the first thing one should look for is durability. No one wants to spend even $160 on something that is likely to bend or break easily. This device is durable, sturdy, and of a good weight so that it will not go flying out of your hand. It is rigid, a good size for the hand, and with the proper case should last at least $160 worth of time.It is unlocked, which means you can put it on different networks. I have Sprint, but I allowed someone who knows what they are doing to use it on a different network by simply placing in their SIM card. It picked up the 'net and away we went. Granted, I also have a wifi network so we used that for our downloads. The reception is pretty good as well. I'd say at least as good as your normal android cell phone.The memory is expandable to 64gb via a card. If you are  regular Android user, you know you can store your apps there instead of on the device. (I'm look at you iOS). I found no problems with the card or card reader or moving the apps back and forth. You'd better. Original space is pretty small without the card.The camera is not the best. I'm not sure really why cameras are needed on these lower-end tablets anyway, but I guess if you are out in the woods and a UFO stops to ask directions, you may want to quickly snap a picture. It'll work, but if you want high quality shots of Spock's nose, you will need to use a better digital camera.The screen resolution is really good for this sort of tablet. I've watched Netflix and an HD movie without no real problems. The sound is a bit low, but that could just be me. The apps play nicely, with panning on both smooth.Android is versatile. I have no need to review that.But, if you are looking for a high quality, low cost tablet for the Android, this will do what you want and give you a sense of heavy duty quality

Don't judge me, but I've never seen as many fleas as I have since moving to West Virginia. I don't know why, but we have had to fog our home several times due to flea infestations, where as in our previous State, we did not. So, I am always looking for some non-toxic I can spray indoors. It has to be non-toxic because of kids and indoor pets.This works great, as far as I can tell. We are several weeks in and no fleas. And, it kills other insects as well. The spray handle continues to work and doesn't clog or freeze up even after several rough weeks of use.

I've been looking for a grill cover that fits it snuggly, and doesn't cost too much. I think I've found it. I live in WV, so the weather in fall and spring gets a bit odd. Snow and sun, rain and snow, snow and snow and snow and why did I move from Louisiana? And I like to cook out. And sometimes, I leave the grill out because the shed is too cumbersome to move the grill back into several times a week.You get the idea.With the cover, I don't have to worry about it. I can feel safe that I can leave it out to brave the stupid weather conditions without destroying my grill.The material seems solid and weather resistant. Not proof, but resistant. It fits snug so that the weather isn't finding its way underneath the cover. and for my grill, it comes down to the bottom of the grill area so... it will keep the fire area rust free.I like it and wish I would have gotten it two grills ago

I love my French Press pot... even got a smaller one for the office, but that proved to be more trouble than it is worth. With this one is portable - no extra cups needed - and keeps the coffee/tea warm. Easy to use, easy to clean and really keeps the grinds out of the coffee.

I got this as a Christmas gift (2014) and have used it nearly every weekend since. It is easy, works like a charm, and makes it better when you don't have to figure out how to do gas or charcoal. I'm a man, but I spend my days in front of books. I'm just not that good at stuff like that, which is why I asked Santa for an electric smoker.I haven't figured it out completely, yet, but with what I do know, I've done chicken, sausage, etc... beef, pork, etc... Man howdy. Good stuff. Thus far, it is durable, efficient and somewhat portable.

I'm pretty sure this package is meant to be marketed to men. It is "man sized" and cut to "fit the shape of a man's hand." I guess they have to add that to soap in order for me to feel like they can use it? As a man, I use soap twice a day.Beyond the marketing hype, this new line from Irish Spring is great. It has the same smell  which is the real reason we buy that soap anyway  but it has the added benefit of exfoliating beads.The bar seems to last slightly longer than regular bars, which is good. I would hate for anything "manly" not to last long. Wink Wink.I like the soap and will by again.

This LAX iPhone6 Slim and Protective case is better than I expected it to be. The lip that goes over the front of the phone to protect it from getting scratched or cracked works well without being super bulky. This case is average in protection, I'm not super comfortable with the idea of being able to drop my phone while in this case and it still not get cracked. But, if you don't have 3 kids and crazy pets, and a clumsy gene, this phone case would probably be enough protection for you. I chose the gold design and it is really classy, I love the look of it. The rubber sides of the case allow you to have a better grip on the phone, which prevents accidents from happening. When you put the phone in your pocket it is a litter harder to pull out because of the rubber grips, but I prefer that. Overall, a great case for average phone protection with a very low price.

I've had a laser printer for a while, which I love for most of my printing needs. I have wanted a new ink jet printer for a while for good photo printing at home (from both my computer and my phone). I also like the wireless option because I can put it anywhere in the house and not be tied down to a location.I had the opportunity to try out both this one the MG7720 and the MG6820. Of the 2, the MG7720 was my preferred printer, but only for a few small things that are worth the extra money to me.The out-of-the-box experience is pretty simple. Setup is easy--just take out a few of the packing materials (tape, fillers, etc.), turn it on, and put in the ink cartridges. I started out setting it up sans computer and only used my phone (Android). It was a simple process (the only real work was downloading the app to my phone). I setup the wireless manually and had no initial issues. I was able to easily print from the app to the printer and the photos came out a nice quality.Canon claims you can easily print from Facebook or Instagram, but I could not figure it out for the life of me. There is no mention of how to do it in the manual and there is no way for me to print from either of the apps on my phone. The Canon app does not have any link to print from the apps, either. Thinking maybe it was an Android issue, I tried it on my husband's phone, but still had no luck.As far as the wi-fi connection goes, I had some issues. For some reason when I tried to set it up to google print, the wi-fi would not work. I would keep re-entering the password and it would say connected, but it would not connect to google (I also did a firmware update and had the same issue). I finally had to hardwire it in with the Ethernet cable to get it to stay connected to the network. Not ideal by any means.It also defaults to turn off after 240 minutes (eco saving), so if you go to print something when it hasn't been on in a while, you have to manually turn it back on. I tend to print from other rooms and then go pick up my print out. I did change the settings for this, but it was annoying to not know this was the default setting.I did finally set up the printer and software on my computer. I find the "My Image Garden" software to be a memory hog and hard to navigate a bit. I tried out printing on a CD and then when I finished the window would not close. I do not foresee myself using this software much in the future.What I like about the MG7720 over the MG6820 is that it has dedicated paper trays for both plain paper and photo paper. No switching back and forth between papers. While I probably won't use the NFC option very often, it is nice to be able to just hold my phone up next to the printer and have it print. The output tray automatically opens when you print, so no worries about needing to open the tray to print or it jamming up because it is closed (the MG6820 does not do this).Overall, it has a nice print quality, but I was frustrated getting it to setup wirelessly on my network. It also does not seem to be able to print so easily from all the phone apps like it claims it will do.

I have 3 kids all under the recommended age of 6 for this toy. My oldest is 4 and has played with one of these spinner toys before. The 2 littler ones (almost 3) got to try this one out with plenty of supervision. All 3 love playing with this and creating art. We had no mess, but I helped them out quite a bit. We all did get pain on our hands that didn't come off with one (or some even 2) hand washing. We did not use the glitter because when my son used it in the past, it made a huge mess.What I don't like about this is that the "splatter screen" is just a piece of plastic that looks like packaging. It even has to have a sticker on it that says "splatter screen do not throw away." If it has to have a sticker to keep you from tossing it out, then it is cheap. It also only has spots for 3 paints, but it comes with 5, so two are left sitting out all the time.While this is a whole lot of fun for the kids, I think that it lacks in a couple of areas that would make a huge improvement.

I am always looking for a plug for my tech toys. I like to charge most things next to my bed at night (my phone in particular) and since I have a few things to charge, I need a place to plug them in. I really like this charger. It charges fast and it sits up nicely (I have another similar one that has to lay flat, which is annoying). My only complaint is the bright blue indicator light. It is so bright that it lights up half of my bedroom.Other than the blue light, I love this charger

I have 3 kids that like lots of bath toys. This is a nice sized holder that sticks well to the wall and holds plenty of toys. The toys that come with it aren't anything special, but are a cute addition. I have another one that doesn't have as wide of an opening, so I like this one better. Very nice way to keep all the bath toys out of the tub when not taking a bath.*I received this at a discounted price for an honest review.*

This is a nice mattress that is nice and thick and a little firm. I got it for a bunk bed, so no box springs are needed. I opened it and it expanded quickly with little to no odor. I let it sit for about 48 hours before putting it on the bed to make sure that it was fully expanded. Make sure to put it on a flat surface, because I did notice that it curved a bit in the direction of the packing fold after 24 hours (I had it on top of some pillows that were laying around).I have bought a couple other mattresses that ship this same way. I find it pretty cool how much spring mattresses can actually be shrunk down for shipping. The others Signature Sleep  Contour 8 Inch Twin Mattress and Signature Sleep Contour 8-Inch Mattress, Queen both had a slight smell to them during the airing out/expanding process, but they are both a little better mattresses. The Furinno only has padding on one side, so if you flip it over, then the coils are really rough and easily felt unless you have a pad on top of the mattress.Overall, this is a good mattress, not my favorite, but a good one that is comfortable for my kids.

My son is just starting to fit in size 5 clothes. He is a little skinny, so most are still a little big around the waist. These shorts are a little big in the waist and are long (as expected). These will fit him for a long time.They are well made of a nice breathable material. My son loves them.

My son is just beginning to fit into size 5 clothes and this shirt fits him a little big as expected. It is a very nice, breathable material. My son loves it and I know it will be great for him when playing sports and running around (the kid never seems to stop and sweats a lot for a kid his size).

I have 3 preschool aged kids and have tried lots of different water bottles. This one has a very cute print on it (my boys love Bob the Builder), but that is about the only good thing about this thing. The core has a cheap plastic cover to keep the liquid in, but when I got the bottle the liquid had drained all out and filled the bottom of the cup. The pinhole opening could be filled with water and frozen, but it would be a pain to fill. It also doesn't easily fit into the bottle. Seriously, you would be better off to fill it with ice water to keep the water cold for a while. The cap screws on and off and can easily be lost by kids (especially ones the right age to be Bob fans). The little blue caps for the strap fell off on arrival as well. The water dribbles out, which may be good so the kids don't spill the water, but it frustrates mine who want it faster.This is a cute cup, but is not worth purchasing. I'm sticking with the better brands that are the equivalent price.*I received this item at a discount for an honest review.*

I have quite a few z-wave items in my home and got this and another brand dimmer at the same time (2gig WD500Z-1 Z-Wave Wall Dimmer (White)). Both installed pretty much to same with no issues. I had no problems connecing them up to my system (Nexia bridge) although I couldn't seem to find the instructions on the Leviton on how to connect it to the z-wave system (I might have just missed it, but I did figure it out on my own). They were both installed on switches with LED light fixtures.I actually prefer the other dimmer to this one. I don't really care for the dimmer buttons on the top of this one. I had a regular non-z-wave dimmer in before that had the buttons down the side which was preferable. I find the buttons across the top to be difficult to press and uncomfortable on my fingers. The only good things is that I put this in my daughter's room and it is difficult for her to change the settings (she likes to sleep with the light on full bright and I am trying to drop it down to be more like a night light). This one basically has 1 on/off button and the dimmer. The other has 2 buttons (top and bottom) and dims or brightens when you hold down one of the buttons.Oh, and the cost on this one is quite a bit more than the other.Overall, I think the switch works well and is a good addition to a z-wave system. I prefer the other options to this one.

I picked this printer mainly to print directly from my phone. I take quite a few pictures with my phone and I like to print some of them to give to the grandparents. I don't usually want the big prints and if I do, I just get those from Costco or another local printer.Getting the printer started up was simple and straightforward. If you want to plug it into your computer or camera or connect an SD card, then you are good to go. I thought it would be simple to print from your phone, but I found it to be a little more complicated. The quick start guide sends you to the user manual, which basically tells you a couple of steps to get the printer to print instructions for what to do next (it gives you an activation code that is good for 60 min). Make sure you have some plain paper on hand (I just folded a sheet in half to get it to fit) because you will need to print a couple of sheets out. You will need to go online to activate the printer and it will set up an email address for the printer for you to send pictures to easy to print and I had no problems. You do need to connect the printer up to the wi-fi to be able to set all this up. There is an option to direct print if you are on the go where you can connect your phone directly to the wi-fi of the printer. You will still need the app to print anything, though. (Note: I have an Android phone.)The pictures are typical Epson quality--beautiful and vibrant. It prints quickly and you can choose to have a border or go borderless. For the most part, I don't find this to be quite cost effective if you are printing lots of pictures. I will still order them from places like Costco or shutterfly (who gives away 100 free prints quite often) for large quantities. For an immediate need to print out photos, I really like this option. This is great for giving out photos on-the-spot. I cannot say if there is a better, less expensive option, but this is an excellent printer with great quality.

I have plenty of migraines and sinus issues and really hate to take too much medication. I like to use more natural methods when possible (migraines it is rarely possible, but natural methods may help shorten the time of the migraine in addition to medication). I have used some pillows like these in the past, but they have been more homemade. Honestly, I prefer the homemade ones. They are usually a little less expensive and higher quality material. This is a satin that does not feel like it will last too long. To heat it up, you "mist" it with water and heat it for just a few seconds. The heat only lasts for about 10 minutes, which isn't usually long enough for me.I was hoping for something a little higher quality. This isn't bad, it just doesn't meet my high standards.*I received this item free for an honest and unbiased review.*

The sentiment serving bowl is a beautiful bowl. The colors are deep red and green. It is a well-made and strong bowl. I know it will look beautiful on my counter during the holiday season as I will most likely use it as a fruit bowl for a bit because it is too pretty to only be used for dinners. It will also look beautiful on the dining table for holiday dinners as a complement to many different place settings. It would also make a very nice hostess gift since the price is very good for it.

While I like the idea of homeopathic remedies, for the most part they don't really do all that much. I have used Hyland's in the past for coughs and it helps my kids a bit, but not a ton. As for this one for cold and mucus, my daughter had a cold and I saw no change after giving her this. She does like to take medicine and it has a bit of a placebo affect on her mood at a minimum.I probably will not purchase more of this since I didn't see enough of an effect on my child's cold symptoms.

We use humidifiers a lot in our house. We live in the high desert and it is dry here almost year round (we should have wet winters, but we haven't in recent years). With 3 kids in preschool, we also have lots of colds that run through the house. We have most the ultrasonic (no filter) humidifiers that put out a fine mist into the air. Anything right around the humidifier is usually pretty wet overnight.Even though I am not a huge fan of filters in humidifiers because of the mold issue, I have to say that I really like this one. The filter doesn't just sit in the water reservoir--only a small amount of the water gets to the filter and then the water evaporates into the air. There is no mist, so nothing around it gets wet.I used this in my daughter's room and it last for 2 full nights on one tank of water--one night on high and one on low. I also used the menthol scent pad with it. The smell was strong at first, but after a night was less noticeable, but still there.This is a very nice humidifier that works well in our house. I'm not a fan of the need to upkeep with new filters (around $10 each) and if you want the scent pads they can get a little expensive (I think they want you to replace them daily, but the scent does last longer). I do like that it doesn't get things soaking wet around it, but does increase humidity in the room.

We love LeapFrog items in our house. I have 3 preschool aged children and they all love technology. I'm not a fan of giving them an iPad--not only are they rough on them, but they also always end up in the "in app purchase" of each game they have which frustrates them (and me). They each have LeapPads (LP1, LP3, LPPlatinum) and I love that all the games are age appropriate and there are no extra purchases for them. My biggest problem with them was the lack of ability to play outside videos or games. I have a lot of videos for the kids, but there was no way to play those on the LP and I would have had to purchase them from the LF store to get videos for them. So, I ended up purchasing cheapo tablets for the kids to play on and watch videos for long trips (and yes, one already has a screen that is partially broken).Enter the LeapFrog Epic! It is the best of both worlds! It has a number of the same LeapFrog games we already purchased that work on it (not all of them do) and I can download other apps from the Amazon app store including apps to play their videos we already own. Now, getting the Amazon app store on the tablet was not difficult, but finding the instructions were not easy. I had to hunt them down on the LF Epic help pages. You go through the parental controls, device info, app store, other, and install the Amazon app store. Then you can download any apps you may have already purchased through them or purchase more. I already had our kids' favorite Monkey Preschool, so that got installed and my son was very happy.I do not have any other kid-specific tablets to compare this to, so I can only do the comparison with the LeapPads. I'm overjoyed with the marriage of the LeapPad with a tablet so far. My kids have already dropped this thing a couple of times and it has no issues. I love the LeapFrog durability. I love that everything can be kid appropriate and that parents have lots of control over what apps they can and cannot use (each app can be designated to all or some of the users). No more cartridges, which we rarely use anyway since we use the games on all of the LPs we own.I will be looking at getting a couple more of these for my younger kids at a little later date since we already have the LeapPads. I foresee this lasting longer than the LeapPads since more outside content can be added.As for purchases LF apps and their cost--I always recommend purchasing gift cards discounted (Amazon has them LeapFrog Digital Download Card and they area almost always discounted at about 30-40%) and then waiting for sales on the apps. They can all be purchased for pretty reasonable prices then.

I've read a few of Kristan Higgins books and really enjoyed them because they are witty and fun with happy endings. If you have read her other books, this is NOTHING like them. This is women's fiction and not so witty and fun. It is a deeper look into relationships and more specifically, failed  or failing relationships. Things are not always as they seem on the outside.I picked the exact wrong time to read this book. My husband was sick on hospice when I began reading it and I finished it after he had died and the memorial was over and done and I was on my own. The feelings of sadness and heartache throughout the book were hard for me to read. I struggled to finish it because I was (am) hurting too much over the loss of my husband. Reading about heartbreak was not easy--even if it is did not fit into the mold of my own life. I am so glad that I did finish the book, though. It leads the reader through the path of life and leaves you with hope.A very good crossover for Kristan Higgins from romance to women's fiction. Not my favorite genre, but one I do read occasionally for something like this one.
