I ordered one of these in large/black and when I tried it on I immediately ordered 2 more. The fit is perfect, a bit on the athletic side which, to me at least, is a good thing. On to the material, this is the part I found slightly disappointing because I found it thin and kind of 'cheap', reminiscent of cheap Old Navy shirts I used to buy for work. All in all were the material just a HAIR thicker/better I'd rate this a 5 star shirt no question

The review title sums it up, these fit me perfectly, as another reviewer pointed out they're great 'butt jeans', but the denim is obviously low-grade & cheap looking. The saving grace is that the fading somewhat hides the materials cheapness. For what I paid Im not terribly disappointed especially since the cut and fit are there to wear on a night out w/o the denim quality being noticeable.

This little tool has been pretty helpful so far. The knife end uses mini-blades, NOT standard sized utility blades. The wrench fits over 1/4"-7/16" nuts & bolts AND some oddball shaped fasteners like wing nuts or worn hex heads. Helpful, versatile tool for electrical work and building maintenance.

I've owned 3 pairs of Iron Age & 2  Timberland Pro work boots over the last 12 years and overall I prefer Iron Age so this, my 4th pair, was a no-brainer. The boots fit very well and the steel tip doesn't dig into my toes when I bend my foot (granted, I bought EE width). I've stepped in puddles and worked in the raun and they're definitely waterproof. The only reason I didn't "5-Star" these boots is that the "electrical hazard protection" soles are a bit more slippery on wet surfaces than I expected and the tread is on the shallow side. All in all another excellent pair of work boots by a proven American shoe company.

Versatile revesibility and impermiabilty, w/ great colors and good build, overall an excellent garment but it's a bit too loose and TOO long for my taste. The length is an issue that a simple drawstring along the waist would remedy but the vest just didn't make 5 stars.

Love it, love it. An absolute staple and the mark of fresh, clean scents. This fragrance, to me at least, demonstrates that we are men of refined tastes even during something as mundane as a gym workout. I have worn and loved this cologne since highschool and STILL get asked, "mmm, what cologne is that?", seriously. Still pricey but still trendy, because it's a CLASSIC.

First off I picked these up for under $60.00 which is a BARGAIN for a shoe like this. The fit is perfect, (and I have flat feet...lol), while "breaking-in" period was almost non-existant. This is my 4th pair of Caterpillar casual shoes, all of which have been excellent. The leather on these is kind of 'raw' which to someone with that preference is a great thing b/c we don't have to wear them until raw/distressed, (I like "character" in certain styles of shoe). I've worn these roughly a dozen times in the last couple of weeks and they're as comfortable a shoe as I've had. I'm a "brand loyal" kind of buyer and only use Iron Age or Timberland Pro for work but if Caterpillar's work boots are as kick a55 as their casual line, I'll be wearing CAT at work AND play...;-)

I've used Zippo lighters for almost 18 years and THIS is a knock off. I bought it for one of my bosses for Christmas and the moment I held it I knew it wasn't authentic OR it IS authentic but made of crappy tin w/ a cheap decal. She loved the lighter and uses it all the time (I know b/c she asks me to refill it for her every few days ;-), but everytime I pick it up I feel like I bought a replica. The lighter works well so far so I gave it 3 stars out of "fairness". Zippo has always put out a superior product so if this is authentic, it's my first time disapointed by a Zippo lighter.

I used this surge protector/socket extender when I was traveling to Bonaire (an Island in the Netherland Antilles near Aruba). Hotels never have enough plugs and this was definitely the case were we were staying. We had two cell phones, an iPad, a Kindle, an underwater camera, an underwater light and a laptop computer. With this plug extender we were able to have a "charging station" were we could charge all of our devices charged. Bonaire, were were told, does not have "clean power" and a surge protector is important. This helped protect our devices from damage from power spikes.The compactness of the device was nice as well, since it easily fits in a carry-on bag (that I use to keep all of the electronics in).

Phones are following the path that desktop computers used to follow. Every two years you get more power and more memory.Before getting the BLU Vivo Air I had a Google Nexus 5, which is now a couple of years old. Like the BLU Vivo Air, the Nexus 5 is unlocked. Both phones run similar versions of the Android operating system.  However, the Nexus cost twice as much as the Amazon price for the BLU Vivo Air.Testing phone performance is difficult, so I don't have empirical results. However, the BLU Air seems to be at least as fast or faster than the Nexus, since it has a newer generation processor. It also has the same amount of memory.Like the Nexus, I used the BLU Vivo Air with my T-Mobil account.  The phone is very elegant, with a sharp picture.  Even with a shock casing to protect the phone, it is thinner than my Nexus.  Calls are very clear and, as I mentioned, the phone switches between apps very rapidly. With an unlocked phone the device is not loaded with the junk that the cell phone providers tend to load on to the phone (I was annoyed that my original Android phone had John Madden Football which I could not remove).All in all this is a great mid-price phone.

I'll never forget Frederick Forsyth's first three books: The Day of the Jackal, The Odessa File and The Dogs of War. More than anything else Forsyth has written, these books combine his skills as a novelist with those of an experienced journalist. I've read these books at least twice and enjoyed them again, each time.Frederick Forsyth's The Outsider describes how these books came to be written (although some of the details regarding the Dogs of War may have been left out - I'll get to that later). The Outsider is an autobiographical sketch. Reading the Outsider I was reminded once again what a good writer Forsyth can be.Autobiography is, by its nature, at least partially fictional. Only a rare person has real insight into their own life. We are always heroes of our own story. This makes autobiography a challenge to write. If we're lucky there are long stretches of our lives that would be boring to relate, although they are pleasant to live.By Forsyth's account he is a restless soul and always has been. From a young age he wanted to see fly (for the Royal Air Force) and to see foreign countries. He succeeded in both of these. He managed to hustle his way into the RAF, without a university degree or any social connections.From there, with equal hustle, he managed to secure a position at the Reuters News Bureau, first in Paris and then in East Germany. Forsyth's success at Reuters was aided by his language skills:  He became fluent in French, German, Spanish and picked up some Russian.After his tour in East Germany, Forsyth joined the BBC and got assigned to Africa, where he covered the civil war between Nigeria and Biafra (a breakaway region of Nigeria). As a war correspondent, Forsyth was in danger on a number of occasions. He also developed a deep respect of the Biafran leader Odumegwu Emeka Ojukwu.About a third of the book is on the Biafra war and this was probably the seminal event in Forsyth's life. At the time the BBC was following the official line of the British government, which was backing Nigeria. Forsyth refused to report the "party line" and this resulted in him being forced out of the BBC.After leaving the BBC Forsyth became a freelance journalist, in Biafra and other places. He managed, at one point, to get an interview with the retired Israeli Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion.During the Israeli struggle for independence there were a number of factions. The most violent were known as the Stern Gang and the Irgun. Ben-Gurion despised the violent factions, since he believed that they hurt Israel's cause.  Menachem Began, who was also Prime Minister of Israel, was  part of the Irgun which blew up the King David hotel in Jerusalem.  There were civilian casualties and this terrorist act gave the Israeli independence movement a black eye.  The Irgun later claimed that they warned the British to evacuate the hotel.According to Forsyth he was drinking in a bar in Israel with members of the Israel military. A man, outside the group he was with pulled him aside and asked him if he was British. The man allegedly then told Forsyth that he had something to confess: he drove the explosives into the parking garage under the hotel. It was he who called to warn the British to warn them. But the low ranking military person who answered the phone refused to believe him.Autobiography is fiction and this event seems more fictional than real. Strange things to happen, but this event is outlandish in its improbability.After being forced out of the BBC, Forsyth needed to make some money. While staying at a woman friend's apartment he decided to write a novel, which he says in retrospect was a crazy idea. The novel he wrote was The Day of the Jackal and it became a bestseller, launching Forsyth's career as a writer. The Day of the Jackal was followed by The Odessa File, which was also a great success.According to some accounts, Forsyth's description of the genesis of his third novel, The Dogs of War, may leave out some details.The Dogs of War is a wonderfully detailed account of a coup to overthrow a vicious African dictator. Forsyth carefully researched how arms can be purchased on the black market and how a small band of experienced, heavily armed mercenaries could overthrow a dictator who is kept in power only by a small, corrupt and poorly trained guards.The question with The Dogs of War is whether the research was for a novel or something more. In The Outsider Forsyth writes that The Dogs of War was so carefully researched that it could serve as a manual for such a coup.  And indeed it may have been exactly that.  In his book The Wonga Coup, Adrian Roberts writes:"Forsyth  who adopted the name Mr. Van Cleef  hoped to replace Macias with his close friend, the regional Biafran leader, Odumegwu Emeka Ojukwu. That made sense as Equatorial Guinea, in 1973, was still home to thousands of Nigerian Igbo people from Biafra, skilled laborers who worked in the coca plantations. They would have backed Ojkwu as the new President.Interviewed in April 2006, Forsyth now admits there was a stillborn attempt at a coup. Asked whether he helped plot it, he says his memory is vague: I dont know whether I thought of it, or someone else. As for the relationship between the coup attempt and his novel, he is not sure which came first: It was a chicken and egg situation. Im not sure if the authors of the plot listened to me, or I listened to them We were sitting around in pubs discussing it . people with a lot of beer in them.""He also knew [Alexander Ramsay] Gay  a level-headed Scot  from Biafra, and conceded that the two had co-operated. Yes, we were talking, meeting in pubs, over Fernando Po, he says. He admits, too, giving the police a character reference regarding Gay, after a bag with guns was traced to the Scot. And, finally, he admits passing money to the coup plotters: Yes, payments where made, always cash. Though he suggests this was for information only. Asked bluntly if he plotted a coup in Equatorial Guinea he laughed and suggested you put in the book what you have found.Alexander Gay, his colleagues and their ship loaded with arms was intercepted in Spain. The arms were confiscated and Gay and company were deported back to their home countries (in Gay's case, the UK).  Adrian Roberts writes that the unfortunate result of the failed coup was that the vicious dictatorship in Equatorial Guinea continued for another seven years.Writing is a quiet, solitary, pursuit and Forsyth's life settled down to that of a novelist, not a war correspondent. The last quarter of the book recounts this part of his life. Perhaps respecting the privacy of his wives (he has been married twice and is still married to his second wife), they are mentioned only briefly.As the end of the book nears, Forsyth seems to struggle for material (after all, life is good). He is divorced (he doesn't go into any detail about this) and falls victim to a fraudulent investment fund. He goes sailing with his sons and recounts a scene with a bird that has flown from Africa only to die in Florida. He goes on a trip to Africa where his son shoots a gazelle (which, Forsyth notes, are overpopulating in the area they are hunting).Forsyth recounts a few other adventures to relieve his restlessness.  Forsyth writes that he was asked by the British secret service to exchange documents with a spy for the British in East Germany (during the Soviet period). If this account is true, then the British service is remarkably unprofessional. It would be surprising if the British would put an untrained civilian at risk in this way. In addition to the danger to Forsyth there would be the career ending embarrassment of a prominent writer being arrested for espionage.Forsyth also goes sky diving and at one point travels to the African country Guinea-Bissau. While he is visiting, there is a coup (which he had nothing to do with). In The Outsider Forsyth writes:"The tiny republic was sealed off.""In London, my wife, Sandy, knowing nothing of this, e-mailed a girlfriend to set up a lunch date. Part of her text read: "I'm free this week 'cos Freddie is in Guinea-Bissau"."Someone in Fort Meade, maryland, or maybe Langley, Virginia, intercepted this and her screen went berserk. Her message disappeared. Things flashed up with the insignia of the Great Seal of the United States warning her not to use her laptop under any circumstances."This account is even more unlikely than the account of the Irgun member confessing to the bombing of the King David hotel in a bar in Israel. Autobiography may be fiction but in this case, the fiction is not even plausible.Forsyth's final hurrah involves research for his novel The Kill List. He hires a security specialist who goes by the name of Dom and goes to Mogadishu, in Somalia (the scene of "Black Hawk Down" and the death of US Army Rangers.) Forsyth spends a few hair raising days there, risking death and, perhaps worse, kidnapping.As with most people who are older, Forsyth can see his sun moving toward the horizon in the East. The Outsider provides some insight into the life of a wonderful novelist, who has written some classic works. Memory betrays us all as we get older. What is true and what is imagination can blur. But with Forsyth's writing, it is usually a pleasure to read.

The TP-Link printer server worked "right out of the box".I have an Epson ET-2550 printer. This printer has a WiFi interface, but it does not support wired network printing. Because of my network configuration I wanted to use wired network printing. The TP-LINK has allowed me to do this.The TP-LINK connects to the USB port of the printer and provides an Ethernet port. I was able to connect this to the network and print from both my Windows 7 system and my Fedora Linux system.If you have connected to a printer via WiFi you will have to remove the printer an reinstall it.  Also, note that the TP-LINK device has a USB A connection. My printer has a USB B connection so I needed a cable that had the proper connectors.

I have been reading Ian McDonald for a couple of decades now. He is an innovative thinker and a great stylist. In short, one of the best science fiction writers in my library. He is one of those writers who is so good that I reread his books several times (I want to go back and read Terminal Cafe again).Luna is the first novel that Ian McDonald has written after his Everness young adult trilogy (Planesrunner, Be My Enemy and Empress of the Sun). Planesrunner was a good, but not great book. The series ran down from there. Empress of the Sun was a largely forgettable work. These books did not come close to showcasing McDonald's prodigious talents. Luna does.Luna is McDonald at has best and one of the best books in his long career of writing. The world that McDonald has created is rich and complex. The characters are deeply drawn, with complex motivations and personalities.As with most of McDonald's books, he takes ideas and expands on them. One of these is the extreme libertarian society of the moon, where all things are governed by contract and there is not law outside of contract. This is a world that repels some of the characters in the novel and gives others a chance to create a dynasty.The weekend before I wrote this review I saw the movie The Martian based on Andy Wier's book (which I read when it first came out).Ian McDonald's book Luna made me realize that the fascination with Mars is a romantic one. If humans are to settle space, the Moon is a much better place to start. Sending humans, as opposed to robots, to Mars is madness.Because the Moon is closer to the Sun, there is more solar energy available. The Moon is also partially in the shadow of the Earth, so there is more protection from radiation. And the Moon is much closer.  If an orbital elevator were constructed, the cost of moving material from Earth might be low enough that building settlements would be possible. The cost of sending anything to Mars is much higher.I could write much more about the fascinating complexities of McDonald's Luna. But really, what's the point? Buy the book and read it.So who might not like the book?  There is some violence. The book contains some graphic sex of various flavors. If reading about sex bothers you, then you're not going to like the book. It is not, by the way, erotica, which is designed to titillate. The sex naturally grows out of the plot. Although I admit that one of the sex scenes was hot.The story is complicated and some people don't enjoy complicated plots. There is a dramatis personae at the start of the book and I had to use it as a reference in a few cases. But this is not Bulgakov's Master and Margarita - the plot of Luna is clear, although convoluted in some cases.Oh, and one other thing... The story doesn't end with this book. In fact, the book ends with a cliffhanger. McDonald has planned a sequel.  But this is a feature, not a bug, since it provides the motivation to reread this fantastic book when the sequel comes out.

This product first emerged in the consciousness of the Internet with a YouTube video ad that went viral. The ad tapped into anxieties that are usually feminine: do you worry about that first weekend with your new boyfriend where you poop at his house? Poo-Pourri is there to eradicate this anxiety.Amazing stuff, does exactly what it says it does.  Lasts a long time, since you only use a few sprays.  Great for close quarters like an office bathroom,  hotel or cruise ship cabin bathroom.  We've tried several of the various fragrances offered, they all have a predominantly citrus scent.  Great product!

The Roman Empire rimmed the entire Mediterranean basin, including modern Spain, France, Italy, parts of Germany, Turkey, Greece and the Middle East. For a time the Empire included Britain as well. When the fastest method of travel and communication was the horse, this is remarkable.As a unified entity the Roman Empire collapsed around 400 AD. Commentators constantly discuss the factors that caused the collapse of the Empire. This collapse is ascribe to immorality, the rise of Christianity (Gibbon) or the lead pipes that carried the water for the city of Rome.The fact that it took almost 400 years for the empire to fall apart is surprising.The Empire was expanded by Julius Caesar and his heir, August Caesar, who also sowed the seeds of its demise. By seizing dictatorial power, Julius Caesar overthrew the Senatorial oligarchy that had ruled Rome for hundreds of years. Caesar's assumption dictatorial power and his subsequent murder laid the foundation for Augustus' rule, which started to subvert the rule of the Roman oligarchy. By the time Nero assumed power dictatorial power had degenerated into insanity and bloodshed. The fact that an Empire with this foundation survived as long as it did suggests that the wrong question is being asked. Rather than asking why Rome fell, we should instead ask what factors allowed it to survive for 400 years.Tom Holland's book Dynasty: the rise and fall of the house of Caesar is a rambling account of the Julian and Claudian dynasty. The time span is approximately 130 years, from Julius Caesar's assumption of autocratic power to the death of Nero at the hands of the Roman praetorian guard. Holland's Dynasty covers the reins of Augustus, Tiberius, Caligula, Claudius and Nero, whose death ended the dynasty.This is a huge historical period. There is a vast literature on Julius Caesar, including Adrian Goldsworthy's excellent Caesar: Life of a Colossus. There are also excellent books on August, including Anthony Everett's Augustus: the Life of the Rome's Emperor.  There are fewer books on Caligula, Claudius and Nero. Necessarily, Holland can only provide an overview of events and the players in those events.The result is a rambling history of the Julian Claudian dynasty. The classical world and the outlook of people in that world was dramatically different than ours. At various points Holland branches off into digressions on slavery and other features of Roman society. Some of these digressions are interesting. Holland provides a brief sketch of the poet Ovid, who was a notorious rake in his time (and eventually exiled by Augustus for immorality). Holland leaves out Virgil who was a friend of Augustus. In the section that covers Nero's reign, Holland also provides some of the history of the Stoic philosopher Seneca, who was Nero's tutor and adviser.Holland has written a number of histories and novels. He can be an excellent and engaging writer. In this book, however, his skills as a writer don't shine here, perhaps because of the huge span of history that he attempts to cover. This rambling history becomes tedious as the actors move in and out of the story. Reading the book cover to cover started to become a slog that finally ended in the bloodshed of Nero.

I recently spent a week scuba diving. I bought a laptop computer, an iPad, a cell phone that supported international roaming, a dive computer, an underwater camera and an underwater light. Plus chargers and cables for all of these devices and a plug adapter to provide extra outlets.When I went on this trip I didn't have this backpack.  Everything was piled into a couple of compartments in the backpack.The Thule backpack is the backpack for the world of pervasive computing. It has lots of padded compartments and pockets. The rear compartment will fit a full size laptop. A pocket in front will fit an iPad. There are other pockets for all of the chargers and cables that go along with our devices. Plus additional space for books, pens and notebooks (of the paper variety).The construction of the backpack is very good. It looks like it will survive the stress of being shoved under an airplane seat.The straps are padded and come with a clip that holds the straps together, so it is comfortable to wear the backpack. The backpack also looks nice.This is a great backpack and my new favorite. I wish that I had it years ago.

I have been resentfully buying HP printer cartridges for years. The package of red, blue, yellow and black cartridges at CostCo cost about $60. I've tried to have CostCo refill my empty cartridges, but a refilled cartridge will not work in my HP Photosmart printer.I am happy to say that my days of buying HP printer cartridges are over. The Epson ET-2550 printer is a great printer/scanner/copier and it takes inexpensive liquid ink. According to the box, the ink lasts two years. If I had to replaced the ink today, it would only cost me $28 (including shipping). The savings in HP ink would pay for the printer in a few years.I have tested all of the printer functions: printing documents, printing photographs on photo paper, scanning and copying. The quality in all cases is good as my HP Photosmart 309a printer.An important issue to understand with this printer is that it does not come with a wired network (Ethernet) port. It has a USB type B port that allows it to be connected directly to a computer or it can be connected to the home network as a network printer via WiFi. You can also use the TP-LINK Printer server (or a similar product) to support wired network printing via the USB port (see below).All devices on your WiFi network should be able to talk to the Epson printer. I was able to print from two of our Windows computers that have WiFi connections. You do have to install the drivers from the CD that comes with the printer since this is a new printer and doesn't seem to be in the Windows printer driver repository. The CD also has Mac drivers as well.My network has a TP-LINK wired firewall/router that connects to the Ethernet cable that comes out of my Comcat Cable modem. I support WiFi via a LinkSys WiFi router that is plugged into a Netgear Ethernet switch on the TP-LINK network. The Epson printer connects via WiFi to the LinkSys router.All computers on the WiFi network can connect to the Epson printer and these devices can also see my HP Photosmart printer that is on the wired network. However, the computers on the wired network cannot "see" the Epson printer. There may be a way to route the printer from the WiFi network to the wired network, but I have not figured out how to do this yet. So that all of my computers could use the Epson printer from the wired network, I installed a TP-LINK printer server (see below).When you unpack the printer the first step is to add the ink the ink reservoirs. For some reason this takes about 20 minutes. You really want to pay attention when you fill the ink reservoirs so that you add the right color to the right reservoir. If you make a mistake here I suspect that it will not be good.There are two ways that the WiFi for the printer can be setup. You can plug a computer into the printer via a USB Type B to USB Type A cable or you can set it up from the front panel. I used the front panel setup.The printer comes with a small LCD display, a cancel and select button and an OK button surrounded by four quadrant arrow buttons. To setup the WiFi you select WiFi network in the "WiFi wizard" setting. It will then display the WiFi networks that it sees. You can select yours and then enter your WiFi password. I found this awkward and it took me a couple of tries to get it right. It took me some experimentation to discover how to enter the characters properly. Once the WiFi password is entered, the printer is ready to print.This is a great printer. There are some things that are missing, however. The printer does not have a feed for copying or scanning multi-page documents. As I noted above, it is also missing a wired network port.I was able to get the printer to work as a wired network printer using a TP-LINK TL-PS110U Single USB2.0 port fast ethernet Print Server (about $31 on Amazon). This plugs into the USB port and provides a smart interface to the wired Ethernet network, allowing the printer to act like a wired network printer.To get the TP-LINK printer server to work:- Make sure that you have installed the TP 2550 drivers from the disk that comes with the printer.- Disable the WiFi (if it has been enabled).- If your computer has been using the printer over WiFi you will have to remove the printer and re-add it. I was able to get this ET 2550 to work with both Windows 7 and Fedora Linux. There don't seem to be Linux drivers available for the ET 2550, but I was able to use the settings for the Epson WorkForce 1100.

The pulp fiction cover of the e-book should have warned me that what lay inside was a mediocre book, full of clichd characters. The plot structure and characters reminded me of a television movie from the 1970s, with more sex thrown into the mix. The writing style is not much better than the character construction.The core of the story is the teenage fantasy of sex with a hot teacher. The horror elements of the story involve the abuse that result from relationships with such asymmetric power and experience. The author, Eric Red, does not have the stylistic skill of Nabokov or the narrative intensity of Alissa Nutting in her novel Tampa.The characters, including the "hot teacher" Lynda Hayden are nothing more than cardboard cutouts. Character depth is attempted by describing events their past (the father of the main character, Matt, died when he was eight). The teenagers are fall into clichd categories: good girls, "sluts" who sleep around, jocks, nerds and outcasts. If it were not for the sexual content, I would have guessed that this was an attempt at a young adult novel.The sex in this novel is there as an element of obsession and, ultimately, horror. But by modern standards it is not particularly explicit, since there are no carefully drawn scenes.I would pass on this book. A better example of the "hot teacher" genre is Alissa Nutting's searing novel Tampa.

I suspect that few people who are not already fans of Gore Vidal's books are going to read this biography. Which is a good thing, since those who are not fans of Vidal's books will probably not enjoy this book.In this age of "tell all" slasher biographies Jay Parini has written an excellent and balanced biography of Gore Vidal. Parini was a long time friend of Vidal and this biography reflects both his admiration for Vidal as a writer and his recognition of Vidal's faults as a human. Perhaps chief among these faults was Vidal's towering egotism and its mirror, insecurity.Vidal's grandfather was a US Senator. Vidal was also related to the Kennedy clan and had many friends and acquaintances in the US elite. This gives the impression that Gore Vidal was descended from the US elite himself. An impression that Vidal cultivated.What this biography reminded me of is that the US doesn't really much in the way of an elite, in the way that Britain and France do. Gore Vidal's grandfather was from a working class background. He studied law and become involved in populist politics. As the political winds changed with the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt, he was left in the political sidelines.Vidal's Grandfather become blind and Vidal would read to him, both when he was in the Senate and later. Reading the works of classical Roman history in his Grandfather's library laid the foundation for one of my favorite books by Vidal, Julian.Vidal was gay at a time when homosexual acts were illegal. His novel The City and the Pillar was one of the first US novels to include a homosexual relationship. The novel received generally good reviews, but did not sell well at the time.Vidal's sexuality necessarily colored not only his fiction but also his life. He was attracted to politics and ran for Congress in 1960 and lost by a significant margin. The era when a politician like Barney Frank could be gay and "out" was decades in the future.Jay Parini knew Vidal for many years and he interlaces the biography with accounts of the Gore Vidal he knew over the years. At times this is fascinating, but moving between time periods can be annoying since it gives the timeline of the biography a somewhat fractured structure.I did not find this biography that compelling. This is not a book that you pick up and can't put down, even if you love Vidal's books. Part of the problem is that Vidal was in the orbit of people like President John F. Kennedy, who took part in great events. But Vidal generally didn't take part directly in these events. What we get instead are some literary feuds with Norman Mailer and Truman Capote and intellectual feuds with William F. Buckley. For me, none of this adds up to a fascinating read and by the end of the book I found it a slog.

I bought this light to go with my SeaLife camera. I used it for a week, where I took photographs and videos on every dive.As with all lights, it takes some practice to get illumination in the photograph right. The light easily detaches from the mount by pressing a button and then easily snaps back in place. I experimented both with the light mounted on the camera (via the bracket) and held to the side of the photo. The light can be rotated and angled to adjust the illumination.The light quickly charges, which is great since I would come back from a dive around 11:00 and then dive again at 2:00. It has a double o-ring design that seems very secure and I had not leakage.I did miss the fact that there was no flash feature (I don't think that the SeaLife camera supports a flash). I tried to take pictures of tube worms, which I probably could have done with a flash. However, with the light the tube worms retract when the light illuminates them.The light lasts a long time. I left it on most of the time through a number of dives that were almost 60 minutes. The light never dimmed. It is also easy to turn off and it turns on very fast.All in all a great camera light, that I'm very happy with.

This is my second pair of Jet Fins in the last two years. I have 11 1/2 (US) 4E feet with high arches. I purchased the XXL and spent a week snorkeling and scuba diving last year with these fins. The result with the XXL fins was bad blisters on my toes, although I wear neoprene booties.I purchased these XL fins and also used them for a week this year. I had no problems with blisters, since the fit was better. So unless you have huge feet (size 13), stay away from the XXLs.

I used this lens for a week in Bonaire. As I was taking photographs I put the lens on and took it off, often in a few seconds. I was in warm water, so I was using bare hands (gloves are banned in Bonaire). I had the lens tied to the line that held my Nordic Flash camera floats.  In a few cases the lens drifted into the photograph, but this didn't happen that often. This is an inexpensive addition for your camera and worth buying if you are interested in closeup photography.

These floats are great. They operate well as wrist straps, but they can float your camera if you let go of it.I have a Sealife camera and camera light. It takes both of the floats for the camera and light. You can tie the floats together and the second float doesn't get in the way. This is a small investment to save an expensive camera.

I find Joe Abercrombie a compelling writer. I usually only have time to read about half an hour each night, but I found myself staying up later than I should reading The Last Argument of Kings (as with the previous three books).Abercrombie does a good job of building character. His characters are multifaceted individuals. Whether they are good or bad depends on the situation and the perspective. This can make his stories profound, since they force the reader to think about the nature of good and evil and how they are sometimes mixed.Abercrombie is also good at building suspense and driving the plot forward (the reason his books keep me up late).The downside of this trilogy is that looking back on it, the whole story seems rather futile. But perhaps Abercrombie is making a point here as well.  Some of us feel that life doesn't have an overriding theme or purpose either. The mission and quests that tend to consume fantasy stories exist only in fantasy.There is also a strong element of Deus ex machina in the story, which I found annoying. In fact it is this element of God like manipulation of the story that prompted me to give the book four starts rather than five.I am definitely a fan of Abercrombie and I am going to read his books that I have not read yet. He is an always enjoyable writer who has his flaws.

I have short hair so this hair dryer was field tested by my wife, who has long hair.The dryer is easy to hold and is lighter weight that my wife's old hair dryer. The temperature settings allow blow drying without focusing heat on the hair and damaging it (my wife has delicate hair that gets split ends easily). The hair dryer is not as noisy as my wife's previous drying, but it seems to dry her hair faster. Remington touts the "silk ceramic coating" on the dryer grill. I'm not sure whether this provides the benefits mentioned, but the drying did leave my wife's hair soft. Since we only used to for drying hair we never tried it on the highest setting.The Remington hair dryer has, so far, been a great product. We will probably buy another one for our guest room.

Karin Slaughter is a good writer who has written a book with scenes of graphic and disturbing violence. Or to be more exact: torture. In the hands of such a good writer, this ultraviolence is so disturbing that I skipped a couple of the worst pages.The violent scenes are interleaved through a convoluted plot that is not believable.I don't want to give away the plot for those who are Karin Slaughter fans, so examples are difficult. A minor example is the husband of the central character, Claire. Claire's husband, Paul, is an architect who is vastly rich: Wall Street rich. There have been a number of architects in my family and I grew up around architects. While very successful architects can do well, few architects have fortunes in the tens of millions of dollars (perhaps Frank Gehry). This suggests an author who doesn't do much research before writing her books.The rest of the plot is similarly without thought. The characters don't act in a way that makes sense and they are inconsistent. This gives the impression that Karin Slaughter had an idea and hacked it into a novel without working to create believable characters or a credible plot.The core theme of the book is that men are predators and women are their prey. Sadly there is some obvious truth to this view. Attractive young women have the common experience of being harassed and sometimes menaced by men. Brushing off an unwanted male advance can ignite violence. But the violence in this book goes beyond the threat of rape into the the violence of Argentine torturers. In the book this ultraviolence lurks in the hearts of men all around the women in the novel. By the end of the book the scale of the atrocity is just too large to be believable. Even in Tijuana and Juarez they found the bodies.

Objective Troy is an overly long exploration into how President Obama, a constitutional scholar and critic of the policies of President George W. Bush, came to order the death of Anwar al-Awlaki, a United States citizen, via a drone strike.The author, Scott Shane, is a New York Times reporter based in Washington DC who specializes in national security. The ethical tension between President Obama and the threat presented by Anwar al-Awlaki would naturally draw someone with Mr. Shane's background. Unfortunately Mr. Shane did not explore this topic in a New Yorker article, but in this overly long book.A United States where a US President has the power to order the death, without trial or review, of a US citizen is a horrifying prospect. It raises the spectre of a President assuming totalitarian power and ordering the deaths of dissidents or political opponents.Most Americans would believe that an America where the President orders the death of US citizens is not a United States that they recognize. Yet most people would not be shocked when a kidnapper is shot by a Police sniper as he threatens the lives of hostages. Here the death of the kidnapper also takes place without prior judicial review. Only a senior Police official provides the authority. We accept the killing of the kidnapper because they are threatening the lives of the hostages and there is no other way to protect the hostages.The analogy to a hostage taker is directly applicable to the case of Anwar al-Awlaki. In Objective Troy the reader learns that Anwar al-Awlaki was a threat to US citizens and other than a drone strike there were few good alternatives to bring him to justice.Objective Troy proves a detailed and often repetitive history of al-Awlaki from his childhood in the United States to his emergence as a proponent of violent jihad and eventually a terrorist plotter. Anwar al-Awlaki started out as a moderate and initially condemned the 9/11 terrorists and Al-Qaeda's violent version of Jihad. Al-Awlaki became a Islamic preacher who was always attracted to a conservative version of Islam.Sometimes those who preach against the sins of the flesh are the very people who secretly indulge in the behavior they condemn. This was true of al-Awlaki, who for years purchased the services of female prostitutes. We know of this history because al-Awlaki's emerging connections to the conservative Salifist Islam that inspires violent jihad brought him to the attention of the FBI which carefully documented his adventures with sex workers.Although the FBI officially denies it, Scott Shane suggests that at some point the FBI met with al-Awlaki and told him what they knew about his extramarital activities with prostitutes. If this information became public it would have destroyed al-Awlaki's career as a cleric. What was actually discussed in the meeting with the FBI is not clear, but soon after the meeting al-Awlaki left the United States, first for England and, eventually for Yemen.Another principle of the United States is that a US citizen cannot be jailed or censored by the government for speech alone. For example, the late Fred Phelps who was the pastor of the Westboro Baptist Church called for the death of gay people (among others). As long as speech does not cross the line into a real plot to harm people, it is protected.Once al-Awlaki left the US he started to preach violent jihad. However preaching about the death of gay people or violent jihad is not illegal. What is illegal is when preaching crosses over into active planning.In Yemen al-Awlaki became an active member of Al-Qaeda. Objective Troy makes clear that Anwar al-Awlaki had moved from being a cleric preaching against the United States to someone who was plotting the death of US citizens.As an active member of Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, al-Awlaki was directly involved in planning and organizing a terrorist attempt by Umar Farouk Abdulmutallah, who became known as "the underwear bomber". It was Anwar al-Awlaki who sent Abdulmutallah to Ibrahim al-Asiri, an experienced Al Qaeda bomb maker (whose bomb, fortunately, failed to explode on an airplane).There were few options for the capture of al-Awlaki. In theory, if he had been located a special forces team could have been sent in to capture him. As with any military operation, a special forces operation always carries the risk of death or injury of US service people. In this case it would also have been a direct and undeniable incursion into Yemeni sovereignty. A drone strike avoided all of these problems.On September 30, 2011 Anwar al-Awlaki was killed in a drone strike. The only reason that I know that this was the date of al-Awlaki's death is that I looked it up in Wikipedia. In Objective Trojan we learn what Admiral Mike Mullen's announcement of al-Awlaki's death, but not the date. This is emblematic of a book that is overly long without a clear narrative.Two weeks later, on October 14, 2011, Anwar al-Awlaki's sixteen year old son, Abdulrahman al-Awlaki was killed in a drone strike that the US government says was targeted at Ibrahim al-Banna, a senior member of Al-Qaeda.According to Scott Shane's account, the details of the October 14, 2011 drone strike remain classified. Shane states that the US government provided no details about the strike, nor did they apologize for killing Abdulrahman al-Awlaki, who was also a US citizen. Some people in Yemen were left with the impression, Shane writes, that "the United States killed Abdulrahman deliberately to eliminate the possibility that he would grow up and take his father's path".In addition to the background and history of Anwar al-Awlaki there are long sections on President Obama's evolution as a President whose duties include oversight of the drone program. This is a long and rambling exploration that could be summarized as: when the President was a candidate, he did not have responsibility for the national security of the United States. When he became President, Barak Obama had to wrestle with a variety of complex issues, including Islamic extremism and terrorism. The tools that the president has available include armed drones. After much deliberation and analysis, President Obama authorized a drone strike that killed Anwar al-Awlaki.Objective Trojan covers an important story: the evolution of President Obama's policies and the move from cleric to terrorist of Anwar al-Awlaki. Unfortunately the book is almost mind numbingly tedious. When presented with a book length narrative outside of the purview of the editors of the New York Times, Scott Shane does not seem to be able to tell this important story in an engaging manner.

Along with reading this book, I also watched Prof. Susskind's lectures, which are available on the web. Anyone with some background in linear algebra will have no problem with the math in the book or the lectures. What is difficult is connecting the ideas and mathematics to something in the real world.Reading this book I felt like I was studying theoretical math, that somehow, tangentially, applied to the real world of electrons and particles. This left me with the feeling that something was missing. Quantum mechanics was not born from theoretical physics, in the way string theory was. Quantum mechanics was a reaction to real experiments and problems in explaining these experiments. Yet there is nothing in this book that ties the quantum theory to its history and reality. Even when the experiments were described, I didn't understand how to tie them to the mathematics.Learning theory without anything real to relate it to made it hard for me to hang on to this material. I read the chapters and I think that I understand the math that is presented. But it's all abstract theory without flesh. Yet quantum mechanics is a critical part of the real world. Quantum mechanics helps explain why the transistors in an integrated circuit can only be made so small before they leak charge and become useless from noise. Quantum coherence appears to be an important part of the function of chlorophyll, the molecule on which most life on earth depends, either directly or indirectly. All of chemistry involves quantum mechanics (of electron probability shells). Quantum mechanics is not just an abstract theory, but a critical part of the world around us. But you'd never know it from reading this book.

JavaScript is in the C/C++/Java language phylum. However, JavaScript is designed to run in a browser and is interpreted from source (although there is an effort to develop compiled JavaScript). The nature of JavaScript means that although it has a familiar syntax, it differs from the other languages in its phylum in critical aways.I have long experience developing software in C, C++ and Java. I've been working on a project that involves intensive use of JavaScript, on both the client side and server side (no, not Node.js, I don't think that Node.js is a good idea). This book has been a great reference on the language details.This is a good book if you have experience with another language in the C++/Java phylum. It would probably not be a good reference for someone who is just learning to program.

Closure consists of the Closure compiler and a significant JavaScript library that includes containers and UI components, including a browser based editor.I have used this book only tangentially for the Closure library. The book has been a critical reference for customizing the Closure JavaScript to JavaScript compiler. The Closure Compiler is an extremely powerful platform for processing JavaScript. Using this book I was able to learn how to add passes to the compiler to produce customized JavaScript transformations.This book goes far beyond what I have found on the Web, so if you're going to work with the Closure compiler, this is an essential reference.

This is the second of the Beacon 23 stories and it directly grows from the events in the first story. This is a story that has very little external action. Most of it deals with the Light Housekeeper (we don't ever learn his name). He is a war hero, physically scarred from his war injuries and psychically  scarred from the deaths of his comrades. Alone in the lighthouse, with the gravity beacon which has strange effects on the mind, the lighthouse keepers mind goes in strange directions. If you liked the first story, you'll like this one.

This is a story of a lighthouse keeper who maintains a lighthouse alone for two years. In this case, the lighthouse is light years from anything else and the beacon is not light, but gravity waves. This is a straight science fiction story. It could have been written by the Heinlein who wrote before Stranger in a Strange Land or John Scalzi. There's little influence of our modern technology dreams here. No shipborne AIs, no nanotechnology, no quantum dots. NASA is still around. Although I love Banks, Reynolds and Rajaniemi there's a certain purity in a simple story. This is a story that is well worth the $0.99.

The heroic fantasy that started with Tolken (or perhaps Malory's Le Mort d'Arthur) is pretty much dead, killed off by George R. R. Martin, Joe Abercrombie and Daniel Abraham. I will always love Tolken, but Tolken was the fiction of my childhood. These stories are for older readers. They reflect the harsh reality of the fallen world that we live in.The story in The Blade Itself does not revolve around a single character, but rather orbits a group of interesting characters. One of these is Sand dan Glokta, who is an investigator for the inquisition and a torturer. Glokta is from a noble family and was, at one time, a champion swordsman. As an officer in the Kings Own Guard he fought in a war against the Gurkish Empire. He was captured and tortured for two years. This has left him crippled and in constant pain.Some reviewers have commented on Glokta's character, who has rejected any kind of morality and sympathy. If he were the only character in the story, this would be a problem. There are other interesting characters. Also, while we might not approve of Glokta's abandonment of morality and human sympathy, it is possible to understand how he arrived at this dark place. Glokta's constant pain and dark life gives him a certain strength. He does not court death, but he is completely unafraid of it. When death seems imminent, he does not flinch. This makes him a difficult person to threaten.I was introduced to Joe Abercrombie through his "Half" trilogy Half a King, Half the World and Half a War, which I likes (and are memorable, months after I read them). I then read Best Served Cold, which is set in the same world as The First Law trilogy. Of these books, I think that The First Law trilogy is the strongest, although the Half trilogy comes in a close second.

Middle books in trilogies are often bridges between the start and end of the story. This can make them weaker since the characters are moving toward the story conclusion, but have not arrived. The classic example of such a bridge book is Tolken's The Two Towers, which has been referred to as "slogging toward Mordor".Before They Are Hanged escapes the curse of the middle book. It is at least as compelling as The Blade Itself. The plot drives forward and the characters are interesting and deeply drawn.The Blade Itself reminded me a bit of George R. R. Martin's Game of Throws (the first book). There are lots of plot elements and I was not sure that Abercrombie could tie it all up in three books. I have not read the final book, The Last Argument of Kings, so I can't say yet how well Abercrombie does at tying things together. But after the first two books I'm looking forward to reading the find book (at least we will not have Martin's "story that will never conclude").These books reflect the world that we live in. Some of the events are harsh. Innocent people are tortured and killed. People act through amoral self-interest. The history that unfolds in the books is multi-faceted. Different people have different views of events and the heroes are flawed.With 400 reviews as I write this there's not much too add. This is a series that needs to be read together. So if you have not read The Blade Itself, start now. If you don't mind the harsh elements of the story, I think that you'll like these books.

"Ear bud" earphones/microphone are great for cell phones when you're walking around (you can walk down the sidewalk talking to your very own private voices). But their sound quality and isolation for external sounds is not very good. The Panasonic headphones are a compromise between studio style headphones and earbuds. The Panasonic headphones fold up so that they can fit more easily in a purse or backpack. However, the Panasonic headphones have good sound quality and provide decent isolation from external sound (you can wear then in your "open plan" office to avoid the distraction of your colleagues talking). I tested the sound on both my computer workstation and on my cell phone. In both cases the sound was good. The computer has a better stereo hardware so the sound was richer.They headphones have a built in microphone. I tested it with my Nexus 5 Android phone and the voice quality was good. I'm not sure that you would want to walk around with the headphones on, but if you're listening to music on your phone, you can take calls.I have been happily using the headphones to listen to music while I write software (studies have shown that heavy metal improves software quality) and I am very happy with the headphones.One note: the headphone jack is the longer type, that has both stereo and microphone contacts. It fits cell phones, but it may not fit all computer or stereo systems that don't support the microphone jack.

Palace of Treason is a novel about the core of intelligence: espionage, both by and against the United States. The plot revolves around a member of the Russian intelligence service, the SVR (the modern version of the KGB), Dominika Ergorova, who has been recruited by the CIA in the preceding book Red Sparrow. Dominika is a Russian patriot, but she is disgusted by the naked corruption of Putin and his inner circle. (Although there are some references to the events in Red Sparrow, Palace of Treason stands on its own and can be enjoyed without reading the previous book.)Covert activity, suspicion and distrust seem to be wired into Russian culture. The Bolsheviks who created the Soviet Union started as a covert organization. As the history of Soviet espionage shows, they remained masters of covert operations once they took power. The Soviets are gone, replaced by billionaire oligarchs, but the paranoid nature of Russian culture remains.Much of the suspense in Palace of Treason involves the danger of covert activity against the Russian foe. In the novel, Jason Matthews describes the complex choreography of avoiding surveillance and detection in a hostile environment like Moscow.Nate Nash, in the CIA Operations Directorate, is the handler for the Russian agent, Dominika. They became lovers in Red Sparrow and, as one of Nate's colleges points out, this is not only against CIA rules, but greatly complicates Nate's relationship with his agent.Both Dominika and Nate are in the classic spy novel mold of super agents. Dominika is a trained killer, as is Nate. Both of there are experts at evading surveillance. Jason Matthews manages to avoid the superhuman agent trope that one sometimes sees in thrillers. Nate and Dominika are unusually talented, but they often suffer to achieve success.The biographical sketch at the end of Place of Treason states that the author, Jason Matthews, spent his career in the CIA's Operations Directorate with overseas posting that included Eastern Europe and the Middle East. Although real life CIA handlers don't have beautiful Russian agents as lovers, many of the other details seem like they may have drawn on Mr. Matthews' experience in the field. Mr. Matthews makes reference to a number of the Russian assassinations in the post Soviet era and suggests that the oligarch Boris Berezovsky was assassinated (the evidence is conflicting and its possible he committed suicide).The great detail lavished on communication and evasion in Moscow and elsewhere seems so realistic that I wondered if Matthews gave away any secrets of trade craft. In the acknowledgement Mr. Matthews thanks the CIA's publication review board for reviewing the book, so presumably this was not the case.The only facet of the book that I found annoying involves Nate Nash, as the James Bondish lover who women can't resist and who can't ever say no to a woman. Nate just can't keep his pants on, even when he should. He comes off as unprofessional, without the discipline to say no when he should. But perhaps Mr. Matthews feels that even in a novel with strong female characters, James Bond lives on.

Building a venture capital funded start-up is one of the hardest things that most people will ever do. This is the best book I've found on building a start-up, from funding through exit. If you are founding a start-up or working for one, this book is essential reading.The press reports of SnapChat turning down a $3 billion acquisition offer from Facebook, or an app called Yo (which sends the text message "yo" to your friend's phone) getting $1 million venture funding reflects the mythology of start-ups. The book Hot Seat describes the reality.Dan Shapiro is not some "Master of the Universe" who founded a start-up during the dot-com boom and managed to sell out before the crash. He has built multiple start-ups from the ground up, the hard way. There's no business jargon in Hot Seat, no empty platitudes. He writes about the mistakes he made, along with his successes. He writes about how hard it is to raise money as a first time founder. But he tries to give you some of the knowledge that you will need to succeed.Dan Shapiro is an excellent writer and he presents the critical information in Hot Seat in an engaging manner. He writes not only of his own experience, but of the experiences of people he knows.The first half of the book discusses some of the challenges a start-up CEO will face. Raising money, attracting co-founders and early employees, dealing with investors, some of the critical forms you need to file. This book is so good that I have absolutely no doubt that I will read it again.The second half of the book is about how to manage your success after you survive the early challenges. Dan writes that there are always challenges and risks, they just change in nature. I have to confess that I didn't read the second half as closely because I kept thinking "I should be so lucky". But if I do succeed, I will be rereading the second half.One of the scariest things about founding a company is that there are few guides. This book is one of the best you're going to find.

I have a weakness for finance and Wall Street stories, so I thought that I might like Michelle Miller's The Underwriting.  Unfortunately, the writing was good enough to suck me in, but there's very little substance in the story. In the end it felt like a waste of time.The plot of The Underwriting revolves a Silicon Valley company that makes a Tinder like dating phone app, called Hook. The app has become popular and the company is going to go public (issue an Initial Public Offering for their stock). Most of the characters in the story are either from the investment bank L.Cecil that is working on the IPO or work for the app company, Hook. We learn from the book's back cover and the early part of the story that a young woman dies under suspicious circumstances, which is supposed to add suspense beyond the weak drama of the IPO.I didn't find any of the central characters particularly sympathetic. They are all stereotypes. Almost all of the men in the story are sex obsessed jerks who use Hook to find women for one night stands. The only exception is a Latino software engineer from East Palo Alto. The women are neurotic (the main female character, Tara is taking the anti-depressant Lexapro and Xanax) or joylessly working insane hours (at least the jerk men seem to enjoy their money).Two of the men in the book order for their dates in restaurants, without consulting them (does anyone actually do this?)  Apparently this is meant to be a display of sexual dominance. The CEO of Hook is a sexist software engineer incapable of human connection. His CFO is an empty suit who graduated from Stanford. His classmate, Todd King, who is leading the IPO team from L. Cecil, rates women on a scale from 1 to 10. Early in the book we learn that he tries to bed women who are "eights" because they don't have the confidence of the "tens" and are grateful for his studly attention. As the story unfolds we find that, with one exception, all of Todd ex-hookups dislike him. This is understandable. Todd is such a jerk that he propositions his hot gym trainer and when he learns that she has a woman lover he asks her why she's a lesbian. And finally, to round things off, we have a romantic British investor who has a major position in Hook.There are some strange quirks in the book. There is a two page sex scene with Todd and some anonymous girl he picks up. Various words are blacked out, as if they were redacted as a result of a government classification review. This comes off as weirdly prudish since there's nothing here that Sidney Sheldon didn't write decades ago.I wanted to know how this vacuous story would finally end so I made it though to the end of the book (which by that time felt very long). When I finally got to the end of the book, very little was resolved. The ending is, apparently, meant to be a cliff hanger for the next book. As you might guess, I am not planning to read the sequel.

I got the sample before ordering the graphic novel for my iPad Kindle reader. It take a bit getting used to in order to read graphic novels on the Kindle. On the iPad you tap on the first pane on the page and it pops up a larger display of the pane. Then you can advance through the panes by swiping, just as you would to advance to the next page. The resulting images and text are very readable and I enjoyed the graphic novel.

This switch did exactly what I wanted: I plugged the power in and connected the eithernet cables and it worked. In testing the performance, I found it to be extremely fast.I had a couple of daisy chained Netgear switches before I got this switch. I was able to replace the switches with the single Linksys switch and simplify my network setup. This is always a good thing, since home networks can easily become complicated.My switch didn't come with any documentation. Which isn't that unusual for switches since you power them up, connect the cables and they work. One of the advertised features of this switch is that it supports quality of service (QoS) packet switching. It was not clear to me how you set this up, if you want this feature. Looking at the Linksys on-line documentation I didn't find anything. I assume that QoS is set up through the router connected to the switch, which is why Linksys advertises the switch as working with a Linksys router. But the documentation that I found is silent on this issue. Fortunately, QoS is not a feature that I'm concerned about (giving all devices the same network access is fine for my needs).

The network performance of this router is exceptional and the signal strength is very strong.I replaced a Netgear WNR1000 with the Linksys WRT AC1200 and I'm very happy with the way the new modem performs. My guests were having problems connecting in some rooms of the house. Especially with newer iPhones. These problems have disappeared. The coverage is also much better.Presumably because this model supports such high speeds, it is about twice the size of the Netgear modem. Where the Netgear had one antenna, the Linksys mode has two.I have a TP-LINK TL-R470T cabled router that sits between my cable modem and my home network. I connected the Linksys WRT AC1200 to the TP-LINK router. The TP-LINK router is on the internal address 192.168.0.1, so it does not conflict with the Linksys router which is on the internal address 192.168.1.1. However, I was unable to connect to the Linksys router. This may be a result of the fact that the 192.168.X.X addresses are non-routable and the TP-LINK may not have routed this address to the Linksys.Once I connected a laptop directly to a port on the Linksys router I was able to successfully connect to the router on 192.168.1.1.Most of the routers I've used have a simple "wizard" that take you though the router setup. I found the Linksys setup somewhat convoluted. There is a web style setup that runs on the local router. However, the router takes you to https://linksyssmartwifi.com and asks you to set up an account. The web site then allows you to set up the router name and passwords. The web site seems to be mirrored locally on the router (almost all routers come with embedded web servers). I didn't find that setup on the LInksys web site was as simple as the setup that I'm used to with the router "wizards" I've used in the past.When I connected my iPad via the Linksys Wifi I found that there was a guest account that seems to have been automatically setup. I didn't want a guest account, especially since I had not configured a password. I immediately went back to the router setup to disable the guest account. This account comes with a default password, so anyone who knows the Linksys default password can log in to your network.A number of features in the router web interface come with an on/off switch that acts like a light switch, not a radio button. I don't find the function immediately obvious (e.g., if it shows OFF, it is OFF, or is it ON because ON is covered). I believe that the guest account may have been enabled by default. I changed the password to something really long and then disabled the guest account.The linksyssmartwifi.com web site has some nice features. It will show all devices that are logged into the Wifi network. However,I am nervous about the https://linksyssmartwifi.com web site which has access to my router setup. Yes, the site is password protected, but if linksyssmartwifi.com gets hacked, it is possible that my network would be exposed. I have verified that I can access my router, via linksyssmartwifi.com, from outside of my home network. Apparently the Linksys router is routing through my TP-LINK firewall. All this suggests that it might not have been the best idea to set up the Linksys web access.I have marked the "star score" for the router down by one star due to the somewhat convoluted setup and the fact that Linksys leads you to setup the web site, which may be a security problem. I would have preferred the kind of straight forward setup that I've had with routers in the past. All the nice features offered by the web site are no good if Linksys gets hacked and their customer base is compromised.

Years ago I read Charles Glass' excellent book Tribes With Flags about Lebanon and Syria. Since I liked Glass' previous work, I ordered this book directly from the publisher since it was not available at the time from Amazon.The first thing to realize about this book is that its really a pamphlet, rather than a book. And an expensive pamphlet at that. When it arrived I was shocked by its small size. It's something like 5" x 4".Charles Glass is without question an expert on Syria and the book focuses almost entirely on Syria and the roots of the Syrian uprising against Bashar Assad. There is also a long digression on the history of Syrian uprisings against various occupiers, especially the French.Glass went to Syria in 2013 and 2014. Or at least the areas like Damascus where he could go with some measure of safety. He provides some interesting background on the Syrian uprising, from peaceful protest, to armed resistance, to a movement that is dominated by Islamic fundamentalists.Although ISIS is in the sub-title, the book is weak in its discussion of ISIS. ISIS does occupy part of Syria and it had its roots in an Al-Queda faction in Syria. But ISIS as the West is fighting it is something that came from Iraq, not Syria.A number of other authors have noted that ISIS is a reaction to the Shia domination of Iraq and the Shia death squads. As horrible as ISIS is, many Sunnis have chosen to ally with ISIS because it is a better option than more certain death at the hands of Shia death squads.The Iraqi dimension of ISIS is largely ignored by Glass' focus on Syria. For a reader wanting to read about ISIS, this book is a weak and expensive choice. With the long historical digressions, there is little substance in this book.

I read Scott Sigler's book Infected before I read his recent book Alive. I enjoyed Infected. The plot moved quickly and the determination of the exfootball star Perry Dawsey, one of the main characters in the novel, was memorable. The idea behind the plot was interesting as well.Infected was mind candy. It was an engaging book that didn't take too much thought. I expected more of the same with Alive. Unfortunately I was disappointed. Alive is plodding and the plot is nonsensical.Most science fiction books involve invented worlds. A future that has not happened yet. Perhaps in this future there is faster than light travel, which most current science suggests is impossible. But within the invented world there is logical structure and consistency. In the best novels you get the feeling that the author had a rich back-story in mind, that they only had space to partially explain. None of this is true of Alive. The world of the novel makes no sense, even when the technology is accepted. If there was any back-story in the author's mind, it was not apparent from the plot that made it onto the page.The novel seems to be a young adult novel. All of the characters are teenagers.  The plot starts well, but soon becomes, literally, a long slog. It is downhill from there. At the end of the advanced reader's copy the author asks reviewers to avoid giving away the plot. I have tried to honor this wish, but the final plot reveal is almost as tedious as the rest of the book.

University professors in the United States are not rewarded for teaching at most schools. At a research University, the professors may be great researchers, but they are sometimes reluctant instructors. These professors cover what you "need to know", but taking their courses can be a grid. Reading Life on the Edge: the coming age of quantum biology, I wish that I had the opportunity to take a class from the authors, Johnjoe McFadden and Jim Al-Khalili.Cell biology, biochemistry and quantum physics are complex topics. Like great teachers, Drs. McFadden and Al-Khalili build their explanations up piece by piece, with interesting minor digressions on some of the personalities involved.Life at a biological level is fascinating and profound. The foundations of life are the nano-machinery of enzymes and huge macro-molecules. Underlying these molecules is quantum physics.The authors do a good job of moving from the high level to the low level of quantum interactions. They clearly explain the basics of quantum interactions and the experiments that demonstrated that quantum theory is both true and seemingly nonsensical. For example, they clearly describe the "two slit" experiment that demonstrates that particles and even molecules can act like waves, unless they are observed, in which case they act like particles (a recent experiment, not mentioned in the book, provides evidence that the truth may be that they are particles and waves, not particles or waves).Once they lay the foundation of biology and physics the authors describe how it applies to photosynthesis, which is a remarkable process. The authors quote research that shows that photosynthesis is near 100% efficient in converting sunlight into energy that can be used by the plant. Several research groups have shown that this efficiency is do to a quantum process that the authors liken to quantum computing. Quantum processes also account for the ability of robins to navigate in the earth's magnetic field.Although modern quantum mechanics is nearing its its centennial birthday, it remains at the leading edge of science and what we understand. The authors discuss more speculative work at the end of the book and the suggestion that consciousness may have a quantum nature that is beyond the simple chemistry of neurons.The book is written for a general audience. Much of the material is going to be familiar to anyone who has taken University science courses. Initially I found the authors discussion of quantum biology annoying, since the quantum effects that they discuss underlie the organic chemistry of life. The quantum nature of chemical bonds is something that is covered in undergraduate inorganic and organic chemistry. The quantum effects at enzyme binding sites are standard areas of study for biochemistry. As the book unfolds and they authors describe photosynthesis and some forms of avian navigation, it does become clear that quantum biology can be seen as a special area of study.Science has not stopped delivering a sense of wonder. The world is stranger than we can imagine and constantly surprising. The quantum level underlies the macro-level of our existence. Life on the Edge provides a fascinating view into biological life and this quantum layer.

The Watchmaker of Filigree Street is set in 1884. This is not really a steam punk novel.  Most of the technology in the novel is the actual technology of the time (if you're willing to be flexible about some magical clockwork).The novel revolves around three characters: Thaniel Steepleton, Grace Carrow and Keita Mori. Keita Mori is a Japanese nobleman who has come to London, where the novel is set, to perfect his mastery of clockwork.The novel is really a historical novel, with some fantastic elements thrown in. For example, Mori makes clockwork that displays behavioral complexity that would be difficult to reproduce with modern microprocessors, lithium batteries and servo-motors. Mori is both a master of clockwork and someone with other remarkable skills.During the late part of the 19th century the Clan na Gael, an ancestor of the modern Irish Republican Army, had a bombing campaign in London which was referred to as the "Dynamite War". The terrorist bombings and their origin play a central role in the plot of the novel.Thaniel Steepleton is the main character around which Grace Carrow and Mori revolve. He is from an educated but poor background and is working as a telegrapher for the British Home Office when the novel opens.At the same time, Grace Carrow is attending Cambridge, hoping to perform seminal physics experiments that will result in her being granted a fellowship. Grace is trying to prove the existence of ether, which in this case is not the chemical but the "luminiferous aether" that was thought to be the medium through which light is transmitted. She was working with a light interferometer in order to do this.The experiments that she was doing in the novel broadly follow the famous experiments done by Albert A. Michelson and Edward W. Morley, who published their work in 1887 (Wikipedia is a great resource). Like Michelson and Morley, Grace is unable to show that the ether actually existed. As it turns out, this is one of the most famous negative scientific results in history, since it laid some of the foundation for Einstein's work a few decades later.With all of these interesting piece one might assume that this would be a fascinating novel. Unfortunately that is not the case. The plot meanders around. The interesting ingredients never come together in a compelling whole. The only character who has any real depth is Grace, with her burning desire for scientific discovery. I didn't think that either Thaniel or Mori where elaborated as they could have been. Which is too bad since the character of Mori had great promise. What was it like to be Mori and to have his talent?  We never really find out.By the end of the book, I thought it was dragging. I stayed up late reading it not because I couldn't put it down, but because I wanted to be done and move on to a new book. I think that Natasha Pulley may have a great book waiting to be written, but unfortunately this is not it.

I read Peter Clines book The Fold before I read "14". As it turns out, The Fold is a sequel to "14". Obviously I liked The Fold enough to buy a copy of "14".The book was an enjoyable, suspenseful read. The story follows a plot arc that was popular with Heinlein era science fiction. The main character is an underachiever. Nothing is going on in his life, he has no girl friend and most of the women he's interested in don't return his feelings. Then, out of no where, our hero is called upon to do Great Things. He grows as he rises to the challenge, he gets the girl and gets laid.One of the odd quirks in the plot is that most of the characters are always making wise cracks and satirical comments to each other, even under extreme life threatening stress. Death, it has been observed, tends to focus the mind and most people don't make smart ass comments when they face it.The other odd plot element was the steam punk part of the plot. It is never really explained how a machine, designed a hundred years ago, with moving parts that are constantly in motion, is still working. I don't think that we could design a machine today that could last that long without any maintenance.Since there are over 500 reviews I'll wrap up my review. I've compared the novel to Heinlein era science fiction, so it seems reasonable to use Heinlein's metric for whether the book was worth buying and reading. Heinlein's metric for worthwhile science fiction is science fiction that is worth foregoing six beers for. At a Kindle price of $7.99 I'll compare the book to the enjoyment received from six beers from a case of Sierra Nevada ale purchased at CostCo. Using this metric the book is, at best, equal to the beer and certainly not the clear winner that a book by Alistair Reynolds would be.

For my web application nderground (Amazon doesn't allow links), I needed a key/value database. I considered MongoDB, which has become so popular that its starting to resemble a fad. When I looked into MongoDB however, I read many accounts that discussed the problems of scaling MongoDB beyond one server. Yes, it can be scaled, but apparently you have to take extra steps to shard the database over multiple servers. Scaling is critical for nderground, so my search for a key/value database continued.Somewhere in my searches I encountered Riak. Riak is built to scale and I read a couple of discussions by people who had successfully migrated from MongoDB to Riak. I taked to Basho Technology about Riak and bought this book.Mathias Meyer provides a good introduction to Riak. Riak will scale naturally (e.g., you don't have to take extra steps to shard the database).
