However, I also learned that Riak was originally inspired by Amazon's DynamoDB paper, which was published before DynamoDB become available on Amazon Web Services (AWS).In my opinion Riak is an attractive solution if you are going to host a key/value store database (e.g., noSQL database) on your own servers. However, in my case nderground is hosted on AWS. In order to bring Riak up I would have to allocate EC2 instances to host it and manage the database. Or I could just use Amazon's DynamoDB, which has a similar design. Using DynamoDB means that you don't have to configure and manage the database. Also, DynamoDB will scale effortlessly. So for AWS the choice seemed pretty obvious.I've been writing software for DynamoDB for a couple of months now. I am still happy with my choice, although Amazon's documentation leaves something to be desired (their examples for referencing global secondary indexes in Java didn't work for me - I found what I needed in a Stackoverflow post).So, in summary, if you've decided to use Riak, this is a good reference. The writing is much clearer and more complete than Amazon's DynamoDB documentation.

I have all of Within Temptation's albums and I like them all. Within Temptation works to constantly evolve, not just produce the same music they always have. This album branches out in new directions. For me the great departure was the inclusion of rap, by Xzibit. I'm not a big fan of rap. The closest I get is 900 Foot Jesus' The City Sleeps. I had to listen to this album a few times before the rap started to grow on me. I think that it was a worthy artistic experiment and it works well in the Within Temptation pieces, but I hope that they will not go farther down this path.Other than the inclusion of rap elements, I think that most Within Temptation fans will like this album.

The batteries in the UPS power supplies get old and start to lose their ability to hold a charge. When that happens the UPS starts emitting an obnoxious alarm sound. Since Murphy's Law rules the universe, this happened late at night when we were asleep. I had to unplug the computer from the UPS and turn it off. I immediately ordered the replacement batter. The replacement takes a couple of minutes and is very easy.

The lab created Sapphire is as beautiful as natural sapphire. Lab sapphire is the same material as natural sapphire, at a much lower price. These earrings are attractive and they look good with the gold plated silver. These are small earrings so they can fall out. But they are also inexpensive to replace.

I have only read Interzone a few times in the past. Perhaps this should change. This issue of Interzone is a collection of wonderful stories. I bought the issue for Alistair Reynolds' story A Murmuration. I also discovered a fantastic story by Fadzlishah Johanabas (Songbird). In addition to publishing established writers like Alistair Reynolds, Interzone seems to be keeping alive the tradition of publishing very promising up-and-coming writeres like Johanabas.Now that Interzone is available as a Kindle publication it is both reasonably priced and accessible. If you enjoy science fiction stories, I think that you'll enjoy this issue of Interzone.

Few people describe the dark paths of advanced bio-engineering as well as Paolo Bacigalupi does. This is a rather dark story about two twin girls who have been bio-engineered, although they were naturally born. The girls live in a feudal society where feudal masters have the power of life and death over their serfs. However, even the masters must scramble to obtain resources.The character of Lidia is well developed, although tragic.I don't want to write much more, since it would give away the story. I can say that if you like Bacigalupi's other work (especially The Wind Up Girl), I think that you will like this story.

Joshua Dalzelle's book Warship is an entertaining read. If the book were a Hollywood screen play and I needed to do an "elevator pitch" I'd say that it was like the Battlestar Galactica reboot, mixed in with Leviathan Wakes by James S.A. Corey (James S.A. Corey and M.L.N. Hanover).There are almost seven hundred reviews of this book, so I'm not sure that I have much to add.The writing is good, as is the character development. With faster than light travel, the human race has expanded out to countless star systems. The only alien race that has been encountered lives is an environment that is incompatible with human life. At the opening of story, an aggressive alien race is encountered. The rest of the book is an account of the drawn out battle between the Bluejacket and the alien starship.The book was entertaining, but I don't think that I'll read the sequel when it comes out. I didn't find it as good as James S.A. Corey's work and it's certainly not as deep and rich as the new Battlestar Galactica (admittedly in a different medium).

I have not read Heda Margolius Kovly memoir, but from the reviews it sounds like she was a remarkable person who survived the Nazi death camps and then her husband's unjust execution by the Czech Communist state.The creator and the work they produce are two different things. The fact that Heda Kovly was a remarkable woman does not make this a good novel. In fact, I suspect that it never would have been published had it been written by someone else.Heda Kovly was, among other things, a translator who translated novels by Raymond Chandler into Czech. This appears to have influenced the style of the novel, where some of the characters speak in bad noir novel jargon.The novel seems to have been set in the 1960s when the worst of the Stalinist excesses of Czech Communism were starting to fade. While people are no longer being hauled off to basements and shot in the back of the neck, the Czech Communist state is oppressive and constantly spying on its citizens.At most the plot reaches tragedy, but there is little tension. The characters are all living gray iron curtain lives. The novel opens with a murder, there is a touch of espionage and another murder. The writing style is so flat that these events lose any of their power.I have no idea what the style is like in Czech, the original language for the novel, but the english style is poor and as gray as the characters. The few twists in the plot end up having little drama and the book plots towards it conclusion.An interesting contrast to this novel is Simon Sebag Montefiore "One Night in Winter", which is set in Stalin's Soviet Union. Like "Innocence", "One Night in Winter" is set in a totalitarian society. But the characters are deeply drawn and the novel is strongly plotted. All that "Innocence" is not.

My father took me to see the movie Chshingura (the 47 Ronin), by the Japanese director  Hiroshi Inagaki, when I was a kid. The story is based on true events, but it has gained mythical standing and has become a core tale of Japanese culture. I have seen the movie many times since. The story has been recreated by a number of artists. Here we have a telling by the graphic novelist Stan Sakai, who created the Usagi Yojimbo novels that I read with my son when he was young.The story that Stan Sakai tells closely follows the story of the Chshingura and Sakai was clearly influenced by Inagaki's movie. There is a scene before Lord Asano commits Seppuku, where he walks through the blossoming cherry trees that is in both the movie and the book. This scene has always stuck in my mind for its beauty and sadness.One of the themes that is stronger in the movie is the egotism of Asano. He is goaded and abused by Lord Kira. For a time he tries to put up with the abuse, but finally he snaps, he anger overcoming his control and he attacks Kira in the Shogun's palace. By the action he causes terrible pain for all of those around him.If Asano were stronger, as strong as his 47 loyal retainers and his wife, the tragedy would not have happened. So part of the story to me has always been about Asano's weakness and flaws.In enjoyed Stan Sakai's retelling of this complex tale. It was a change to revisit the story in the medium of a graphic novel.
From the first time I heard this song, I thought it was lovely.  The song writing is beautiful and McLachlan's voice provides a soft depth.

The Fold is the first novel that I've read by Peter Clines. I liked The Fold enough to buy a copy of his earlier novel "14".The Fold is well written, entertaining fiction with both science fiction and horror elements in it. From reading a little of Clines biography on his blog, it doesn't appear that he has a scientific background. But he does his homework, so there are plausible science fiction elements. But Clines also throws in an unusual twist, which I didn't see coming.The main character is Leland Erikson, who goes by the name of Mike. Mike has photographic memory and an extremely high IQ that can make use of all of the material that he can read once, but never forget.The portrait of Mike and his abilities is a nuanced one. Many of us would like to have that kind of intelligence and memory. But it also comes with a huge cost. Mike doesn't read much, for example, because he remembers everything that he reads, which ironically reduces the enjoyment. His intelligence also means that he doesn't fit in without carefully hiding his abilities.When the novel opens, Mike is a High School teacher, within a few minutes of summer break. An old school friend of Mike's, Reggie, is a program manager for the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), the government agency that originally funded the Internet (no, it was not Al Gore), supercomputer architectures and self-driving vehicles before Google existed.Reggie has been after Mike to come work for him for years, but Mike has always refused, preferring his mundane life as a teacher. As the book opens, Reggie has an offer that Mike can't refused. He wants Mike to act as Reggie's eyes and ears looking into a project that Reggie has funded that has developed what seems to be a way of creating a fold in space that allows people to travel through a gateway from point A to point B, instantaneously.Mike's character is the most deeply drawn character in the book. As the plot unfolds it becomes easier to understand how someone with Mike's remarkable abilities has made the decisions he has.The plot moves forward quickly and I found the book an engaging and enjoyable read. The mix between science fiction and horror provides some interesting twists.The women in The Fold are all strong characters. When the going gets tough they are there slugging it out along side the men. Mike has unusual mental abilities, but he's hardly a superman. He takes his knocks and is saved in a couple cases by the female characters.The only feature of the plot that I found annoying was the description of Mike's inner thought process. As a child Mike saw ant hives and ants became a sort of memory palace model for the organizational process that he uses to organize what he remembers flawlessly. We get sentences like:"The ants leaped into overdrive. They counted and cataloged and quantified. They gave him more details than he wanted to know"or"A few ants got out. They carried hypothesis and ideas and wild guesses"This is fine in a few places, but I found the references to the ants got old since they are the constant metaphor for Mike's thinking.The fold was a well written, enjoyable diversion. I'm looking forward to reading Clines' earlier book "14" (which apparently has some tangential connection to The Fold).[Later]I just finished Peter Clines book "14". It is a prequel to The Fold, although The Fold can be enjoyed without reading "14". I suspect that people who read "14" first are not going to find as much suspense, since the events in "14" foreshadow those in The Fold.

I just got the electronic token generator from Gemalto. As their notes specify, this is a specialized device for Amazon Web Services (e.g., you can't use it with your GMail account). It seems like a good product. The only reason I didn't give it a five star review is the Amazon definition for five starts is "I love it". How in love can you be with an electronic token generator? But I certainly like it.Anyone who is developing a significant web application should be thinking about security from the start . Amazon Web Services also gives you tools for locking down your application (although it can be time consuming wading through their sometimes obscure documentation). One area of weakness is your AWS root account (e.g., the account you use to login to the AWS consoles). This account has absolute power over your application. Obviously this account has the power to delete your databases and remove all of your EC2 instances, crippling or destroying your application.  If your application gets notice and starts collecting a user base, people will attempt to hack it.Two factor authentication makes your AWS root account unhackable. Only someone with your email address, your password and the token generator can log in to your account. Short of kidnapping, this is unlikely to happen. Two factor authentication removes a major security vulnerability. All for the cost of $13.Sure you could use the free Google App on your phone. Right now, phones are one of the items most targeted by thieves. Perhaps this will change as stolen phones are set up to be disabled. But if your phone is stolen, you will not be able to get into your AWS account until you can get support to reset it. So for me this token generator was a good choice.

I really enjoyed Joe Abercrombie's books Half a King and Half the World, so I thought that I'd give this book a try. Best Served Cold is set in Ambercrombie's "First Law" world, but the book is a stand alone novel (although there are some characters from the First Law book and having read them may add a little depth).Some Amazon reviewers have commented that the "heros" in the first law books are monsters: killers, guilty of many crimes. Abercrombie seems to specialize in this type of anti-hero (although this is less os in Half a Kind and Half the World).The world that Best Served Cold is set in has a technology level that appears to be equal to that of the late middle ages. Stone architecture is sophisticated and they have siege engines, along with the first appearance of something like gun powder. These are not sword and sorcery books, but sword and bloodshed books.Most readers are probably familiar with the saying that "vengence is a dish best served cold", so it should not give away much to write that Best Served Cold deals with vengeance. The main character is Monza Murcatto, a mercenary general. She has been through many wars, with all of the bloodshed and murder that these entail. As a woman mercenary general, she has to be tough, tougher than a male general would be. As a result, her personality seems almost flat, her only driving desire is vengeance at any cost. This includes the cost of her own life, but also the cost of any bystanders who happen to be near her target.One of the themes in the book is that doing good has no reward. Interestingly, another theme, elaborated at length by one of Monza's opponents, is the futility of vengeance.While the world that the story is set in may contain some admirable people, they make no appearance in the book. The endless campaign for Monza's vengeance is saved from tedium by Abercrombie's excellent writing and descriptions of the bloody world that the characters rampage through. Reading his description of the cities, you can almost see them. Monza is a flat character, consumed by the desire for death, but the other characters are more fully drawn.These are adult novels and if you object to descriptions of sex (along with the bloodshed) these are probably not books for you.After finishing the book, I had to wonder if Abercrombie really believes that good deeds are completely pointless and are frequently punished. Our civilization rose from a world somewhat like that in Best Served Cold. Somehow democratic republics emerged where we have science and law, not just the rule of the warrior. In fact, our generals frequently have Phds. One of the forces that drove civilization, in my view, is the human desire for justice. But such justice is completely missing from the dark First Law world.After reading this book I'm not sure that I want to read others in this series.

Facebook, as portrayed in Kate Losse's book The Boy Kings is a case study of Silicon Valley culture in the twenty-first century. In many dimensions, Facebook is an impressive achievement that has taken years of engineering work. As I write this, Facebook has a billion users, spread throughout the world. Ms. Losse was involved in the birth of some of Facebook's first overseas networks and was the program manager for the internationalization effort. Facebook has defined social networking and has changed the way many people interact.Along with its impressive achievements, the Facebook described by Ms. Loose can also be seen as an exemplar of many of the things that are wrong with The Valley.In 1956 William Whyte wrote a book titled The Organization Man. In Businessweek, David Leonard writes that The Organization Man was "A critique of society as much as business culture, the book diagnosed groupthink--a term Whyte coined--in the suburbs as well as the boardroom, and became one of the century's most influential pieces of commentary." Although Facebook claims that their ethos is "move fast and break things", what they have created in many ways mirrors the corporations of their Grandfather's generation.Corporations in the 1950s expected conformity and so it is with Facebook and many other Silicon Valley Companies. I once spoke to a start-up that was building a "App" for the Apple iPhone which, they claimed, was going to change the world (an iPhone App, really?) The actual nature of this change is rarely stated but everyone is supposed to buy into the idea that they are doing transformative work.From the beginning, Mark Zuckerberg has believed that Facebook has a mission that will change the world. The mission of connectedness and "transparency" (where all your information is public).  The "mission" is something that employees are supposed to endorse or at least never openly question. At one point in the book Ms. Losse recounts a conversation she had with a manager who said that one of the people in his group didn't "get" the mission and he was going to have to fire her. Facebook employees are expected to be enthusiastic users of Facebook, displaying their curated public personas.In the 1950s large corporations mostly employed white protestant men. Women were usually secretaries and the idea that a women could run the corporation would have been considered outlandish.As Ms. Losse describes Facebook, the culture is similarly homogeneous. Almost all of the engineering staff is under 30 and male. Mark Zuckerberg famously said:"I want to stress the importance of being young and technical," he stated. If you want to found a successful company, you should only hire young people with technical expertise."Young people are just smarter," he said with a straight face. "Why are most chess masters under 30?" he asked. "I don't know," he answered. "Young people just have simpler lives. We may not own a car. We may not have family." In the absence of those distractions, he says, you can focus on big ideologies. He added, "I only own a mattress." Later: "Simplicity in life allows you to focus on what's important." [quote from Venture Beat, March 2007]When Zuckerberg says "focus on what's important", he means focus on "the mission", focus on Facebook. The Organization Man was expected to have a family and a supportive wife - Facebook in Losse's book had dispensed with this. Facebook provided a living allowance so that staff could live near Facebook, all the better to dedicate their waking hours to the Company.The claim that Silicon Valley is a "meritocracy" where anyone can succeed based on their skills and intelligence is being exposed for its hollowness. Ms. Losse describes in detail what she sees as the gender discrimination of the "Boys" who run Facebook. Facebook doesn't value work outside of engineering and jobs occupied by women at Facebook, like Product Management and customer support are seen as lesser work. The exception to Facebook's engineering stratificaiton seems to be Sheryl Sandberg, who appears to be so brilliant that she's in her own category.Kate Losse's Facebook is hardly alone in populating engineering with young men. As an exercise, look at the web pages of any number of start-up companies. Many of them have team pictures. Most of these team pictures look so similar that it is difficult to tell them apart. You will see few women and even fewer people over 40 years of age.Age and gender discrimination are sometimes justified on the basis of "cultural fit". Ms. Losse describes the Facebook engineers as "Boys" who are still riding around on stake boards and going out after work drinking. Most people grow up and leave these things behind. As they mature, their engineering and system design skills mature as well. But this is lost on Ms. Losse's Facebook and most Silicon Valley companies where experience is discounted.Kate Losse is a good writer and the book is an easy and enjoyable read. Her book is not only an account of The Boy Kings, but also of her journey with Facebook from a small company to a globe spanning social network. She is good at describing some of her inner self. She seems to have a taste for rocker boys. But at Facebook the rocker boys are software engineers. She has a long friendship with an engineer she calls Thrax. In most of her relationships she substitutes the curated intimacy of Facebook for real world intimacy. It is not until the end of the book that she finally has sex with Thrax, although they have danced round it for years.There are a few strange omissions. Losse starts out as an hourly employee. At some point she must have become more of an official employee with stock options, but it's never clear when this happens.At another point she mentions to Zuckerberg that Facebook should get a house with a pool. He agrees and they rent a house which the engineers and support staff hang out in. Losse apparently moves into one of the rooms, but she never comments on this arrangement. For example, was she expected to clean up after the engineers who, no doubt, left pizza boxes and beer bottles scattered around? What was it like living in Facebooks early hangout house?I never got the feeling from reading the book that Losse burns with any particular passion. The closest she comes is her love of travel. But transience is an interlude, not a life. Hopefully Facebook, with its various pathologies, will not be the defining event of her life.

I first read Neuromancer when it was published in paperback, in 1984. Of the thousands of books that I have read since then, Neuromancer remains one of my favorite books. I have read the book several times and will, without a doubt read it again.Neuromancer is a singular work for Gibson. He said that he could never write another book like this again, that this is a work from the heat and passion of his youth (he mentions that all authority figures in the book end up dead).As countless people have commented, Neuromancer is one of the first imaginings of a vast globe spanning computer network and of a world on-line. The writing is unforgettable and the plot is complex and multifaceted.I have wondered if Neuromancer is like The Catcher in the Rye, a book that tends to have generational attraction. People who are a couple of decades younger than I am don't see to love the book as much as I do. Perhaps this is because I remember when what Neuromancer described was completely science fiction. At time before the Internet had changed everything.

This is my second pair of Dunham shoes. I have wide feet and they make shoes in the 4E size that fits me. I have been wearing these shoes for several weeks, in the rain and the snow. They are extremely comfortable and, so far, have shown no wear. The soles also have a good grip on slick surfaces. All in all, another great pair of Dunham shoes. I plan to buy another pair in a couple of years when these wear out.

This was a Christmas present for my wife and it was a great success. The photos didn't do justice to the bracelet which was even more beautiful than I expected.Lab created rubies are exactly the same material as mined rubies, except that the lab created rubies are flawless. The result was a beautiful bracelet at an excellent price.

I read this book soon after it came out and I have read it several times over these many years. I find the plot of All My Sins Remembered haunting. I agree with the reviews who have written that this is Haldeman's best book, even with The Forever War in mind.The main character, McGavin, is a Buddhist and a trained assassin. The conflict between the two poles of avoiding harm to sentient creatures and assassinating government targets is a constant tension in the book. Then tension is one of the features that makes the book so memorable.

Joe Abercrombie's novel Half the World is the second book in his Shattered Sea series, which begins with Half a King. The characters in Half the World overlap with those in Half a King, but I think that you will enjoy the book even if you have not read its predecessor. I liked Half the World better than Half a King because it is less dark, in both setting and the themes.If you liked Half a King, I think that you will definitely like Half the World. If you don't like any kind of plot summary then stop reading now and buy the book when it comes out.Abercrombie is an excellent world builder. The Shattered Sea is a cold sea that is partially ice bound in the winter. The Kingdoms that surround the sea have a long history of feuds and warfare There is a High King that, in theory, all of the Kingdoms owe allegiance to.  The people of the northern Kingdoms are closely modeled after the Vikings (they reminded me of the early books in Bernard Cornwell's Saxon Tales). They sail longboats and fight in shield walls. They are largely illiterate warriors where history exists only in songs sung by bards. In such societies the King is a war leader and must be a strong warrior, always ready to fight. Abercrombie adds an interesting twist.. To temper the constant warrior's refrain that "steel is the answer" to all problems, Kings have ministers who are almost always women (generally known as "Mother") who council restraint and, when possible, peaceful solutions.The novels so far have been set in Gettland. In Half the World the minister is, unusually, a man, named Father Yarvi. Yarvi is from the royal line of Gettland and briefly sat in the Black Chair of Gettland as its King. However, Yarvi's left hand is crippled and unable to hold a shield. His deformities mean that he can never be a war leader. In Half a King Yarvi realized that he can never be the King. But unlike the warriors, Yarvi is not illiterate and he is smart. He comes to the realization that although he cannot be Kind, he can be a power behind the King as a minister, which is what he always expected he would be before his brother and father were killed in battle.Yarvi is the puppet master behind the plot in Half the World, but he is not the central character. One of the elegant twists in Abercrombie's plots is that there are the rare woman warriors in this Viking like society. One of these woman warriors is Thorn Bathu, who is the central character and hero of this story.Half the World is the coming of age story of Thorn, as Father Yarvi maneuvers to save Gettland from the machinations of the High King and his minister, Grandmother Wexen. The fact that Abercrombie brought in a new character rather than just continuing a linear story with the same characters adds to the richness of the story. I never get as much time to read as I wish, but I still finished this book in a few days. I will impatiently wait for the Abercrombie's next book in the Shattered Sea series.

Peter Fugazzotto, the author of Black River, is an excellent writer. When the characters slog through the desert or through the cold glens of the North, you can almost feel the heat, cold and mist. From his biography it appears that he has spent most of his life honing his skills as a writer and it shows.Black River is a sequel to the Peter Fugazzotto's novella The Witch of the Sands. The central character is Shield Scyldmund, who is a Northern clansman. Shield is the leader of a band of warriors who call themselves The Hounds of the North. The Northmen come from a warrior culture of clans, something like a combination of the Scots and the Vikings (but without the long boats). Shield and his Hounds have been fighting for a couple of decades for the Dhurman Empire, which needed warriors like them as it was conquering its neighbors. But the wars are starting to wind down and the Hounds are aging warriors. Their beards are starting to grey and they can see their horizons closing in. As the Empire focuses inward on the purity of the Dhurman race, the Northmen become killers without a war or welcome.The Hounds have no clear path to follow. They became exiles from the North when Shield killed the Warlock King, who had killed Shield's father. The Warlock King had unified the Northern clans and tribes. With his death the Dhurman Empire conquered the tribes on the South side of the Black River. Many of the Northmen saw Shield Scyldmund as a traitor to the North.Between battles, the Hounds tracked down warlocks and witches and killed them. While some of the wielders of ancient magic are evil, many are healers. In The Witch of the Sands we see that in some cases the Hounds are no more than assassins for hire.The Hounds get one final commission - to go North, across the Black River and kill a powerful warlock who is again raising the Clans against the Empire.This is a dark story. The protagonists lived by the sword and are little more than killers groping for some kind of meaning. Other than a long trail of death, they have accomplished little. The hopes they had when they were young are fading. The quest across the Black River is a return home and a last attempt at fulfilling what they once dreamed of.Peter Fugazzotto is a skilled writer and the tale that I have outlined is not the kind of story that would be woven by a shallow sword and sorcery writer. I look forward to reading more of Peter Fugazzotto work, although I hope that future books will be less dark.

I am a great fan of K.J. Parker's Engineer trilogy, his novellas (Purple and Black and Blue and Gold) and his short stories (Academic Exercises). So far I have enjoyed all of Parker's work. Until I read The Company.Everyone has faults and The Company seems to collect all of Parker's faults as a writer.The Company is five men who have had a remarkable run as "line breakers" in the army. Line breakers break the line of pike men in medieval warfare. In many cases, once the line of pike men is broken, the rest of the infantry breaks and the army can be routed. Line breakers tend to have short lives, however. The men in The Company have had almost preternatural survival.The Company alternates between the history of Company A, the line breakers, and the current story. Neither of these story lines is very compelling and over a book which seemed very long, they became tedious.  The story meanders around and when I finally reached the end of the book, I didn't care much about the ending, but only that I'd finally finished the book.K.J. Parker has a rather jaundiced view of women. In the Engineer Trilogy the central character's wife never stand by him and is mercenary. The portrait of women is even worse in The Company where men don't trust women and this is justified by the duplicity of the female characters.If you're a K.J. Parker fan, I'd give this book a pass. Most authors have at least one book that doesn't work out and this is Parker's.

This little purple and pastel colored monkey is adorable to look at (but wait, theres more!)  Made by GUND, the workmanship is excellent.  Press his hand and the crystal ball lights up and makes noises, while the money introduces himself.  If  you press the question symbol on his foot, hell give you a silly response while his mouth moves  (picture a Magic 8 ball that talks.)I originally planned on giving this to a  five year old, but it never made it to her.  A woman in her twenties claimed it for her office where it entertains everyone with funny answers to their business questions.  Thats the nice thing about this little guy  hed be adorable for a child to play with, but the responses are also witty enough for adults.  I think he would also be a funny gift or decoration at a baby shower, where he can entertain the guests by answering questions such as "Will she have a boy or a girl?"Adorable present for a child, if you can get it away from the adults.

Pros:- Its cheap.- The display is easy to read.Cons:- Failed completely after a year of use. No reason whatsoever. Never dropped it. Never abused it. It just sat on a table. The first indication I got when it was about to fail was when it said the temperature was 180F- which clearly wasnt the case or I wouldnt be typing this review right now.

Pros:-  Good quality and well built (better than other ones at the same price range).-  Masks Panoramic view makes a lot of difference.-  Mask seals very well, used for hours without problems.-  Snorkel is easy to use, I tried at the surface and diving also.-  Easy adjustable clips.Cons:-  The fins are to tight.-  It took me a while to realize that the hard plastic part inside the fins were removable.-  mouth piece too small.
Pros- Full tang- German steel- Comes in attractive box and hence suitable to give as a gift- Light weight and sturdy- Thin sharp and flexible bladeCons- None that I can see

The braided cable and silver colored plug makes everything look like its made of metal but it really isnt.Whenever a vendor does not explicitly indicate something is made of metal it is more than likely it is just a plastic-based material for the simple reason that if it were really made of metal they would especially go out of their way to brag about it. The advertising department would have made sure of it, just as they had made it clear that the tip of the cable IS made of aluminium.But I cant really fault them for that as the cable feels sturdy and works as advertised.

Ive been using it / her for over 6 months and am still using her.Pros:Easy to use right out of the box.It has become my regular morning alarm clock, laundry timer, news reader, music player and traffic report. I only wish it could control my TV too.Music playback quality is good but not great.Speech recognition is very impressive. The blue LED that tells you the direction it is listening to is very helpful in making sure she is listening to you and not something else.Controlling speaker volume by voice command works really well.Talking over Alexa while she is talking also works very well.Cons:Would like to better control streaming music via Tunein rather than have to control it via my iPhone.Cant change her name other than "Amazon".Cant speak to her in a foreign language. I want to speak to her in Samoan, haha.

If you are waiting for XCOM-2 to come out and you need a need to scratch an itch, this is the game for you.For all intent and purposes it is an almost literal clone of the recent XCOM game except ported to the Falling Skies TV universe- whose backstory fits the concept of XCOM remarkably world.The meaning behind the cut-scenes may not be too meaningful for players who haven't watched the TV series before, but it doest really detract from game play too much.

Review from an SUP beginner...Part 1: Unboxing and Test InflationPros:- Carry bag is well constructed and big enough to casually fit the rolled up SUP and with room to spare for all the other parts, and then some. Zipper opens up the ENTIRE bag which makes it easy to put in and take out the SUP.- Inflated easily at a casual pace in 8 minutes. Towards the last two minutes it gets a little harder, but not enough to warrant getting an electric pump, unless you are particularly frail.- After inflation it is extremely stiff. It's hard to imagine it's an inflatable SUP.- Paddle is fiber glass.- Instructions are pretty straightforward.- Padding is made of stiff foam so easy on the knees and lots of grip.- One of the few paddle boards with enough D rings for carry pouch AND to attach a kayak seat.- Handles on front, middle and rear.- There is a sleeve on  the board to insert the paddle to make the board and paddle easy to carry together.Cons:- Amazon will not ship this to Hawaii so I ended up going to Sea Eagle direct. However, all parts arrived well padded via Fedex from New York to Hawaii via second day air ($100 shipping).- Pump and gauge is as you would expect- a cheap plastic pump. Gauge display itself is not particularly well designed- part of the markings are yellow, and yellow on a white background seen in broad day light is generally not conducive to visibility. But all you really need to know is that the inflation point is in the region between the Yellow and Red which marks the beginning of the 12lb point. Recommended pressure is 12-15lb.Part 2 : In the ocean with gentle waves.Pros:- It is incredibly stable since it is so wide and is 6 inches in thickness. The flat tail also helps with stability. I tried a similar sized "real" board and it was much less stable.- It remained very rigid throughout.- Paddle floated without problems.- Padded floor is a god-send, sparing your knees and giving you incredible grip.- Fits well in a small convertible car trunk. Essentially it's the size of a golf bag. The paddles separate in half also making it easy to fit in the trunk.Cons:- Since it is so thick, climbing back on board can be challenging. Recommend approaching from the rear pushing downwards on the thick padding to hoist yourself up.- It moves slower than a regular paddle board and also tends to not track as straight.

Note:I have never played any of the Sacred series so I am treating this game review on the games own merits rather than based on expectations of what this game should have been.Pros:- Plays like a Gauntlet-style hack and slash.- No inventory to manage. Ive played my fair share of RPGs dating as far back as the 80s with Wizardry. Ive played Skyrim, Diablo 3, Torchlight, and now and then its nice to just NOT have to deal with inventory management.- It actually has a black character for a change.- Technically the game is well executed. Audio/Visual quality are generally good. No noticeable glitches.Cons:- The dialog is truly terrible and the humor is forgettable. Oddly after a while you just completely tune it out. Its like a noisy jet engine. After a while you just dont hear it any more :)Summary:- Gauntlet-like repetitive hack and slash. Acceptable if that is what you are expecting and when sold at same price as Gauntlet (2014).If you are a fan of Sacred 1, 2, youve already seen the other reviews of this product- so stay away.

Product appears to work but one should be aware it takes time for slugs to ingest materials.Iron Phosphate in low concentrations is harmless to animals as well as earthworms.Would really like to know what the 99% "Other ingredients" are.
Pros:- It works.- Its so simple.- It requires NO batteries.Cons:- So low tech. No lasers or bluetooth or Wifi or Interweb connectivity :)

I have used a traditional heavy counter-balance-based steadicam system before which took a lot of practice. This unit however is pretty amazing.Pros- Without any practice I (literally) was able to shoot steady video with my GoPro.- Mounts GoPro 4 easily.Cons- Instructions for installing drivers, software, firmware is pretty horrible. They tell you to install software from their home page but no indication of what you are supposed to download. Would it be so much trouble to say: 1. Download USB driver. 2. Download Firmware Updater. 3. Download Firmware- then provide a simple link to these?  These guys really need to learn from Apple.- Installation requires a PC. Will NOT work with Mac, unless you are emulating PC.

Pros- low cost can opener- cuts very well- comfortable handle- lightweightCons- hand grip is not as sturdy as my other can opener with a heavier handle  but on the other hand that can opener is in the trash after less than a year because it couldnt grip onto the can.So its a cheap can opener that gets the job done. I dont need an innovative new way to open a can.
This tasted better than I thought it would.Strong dark flavor without acidity.
Pros:- Its made of metal- Its light- The snap top fits tightlyCons:- After only 4 uses the screw on lid leaks.Summary:I had expected this to leak eventually but not after just 4 uses.

Pros:- Bluetooth feature is a plus to synch to smartphones etc.- Noise cancellation appears to work- filtering out white noise. Yes there is a small hiss- but not noticeable when music is playing.- Good bass.- Charging dock is pretty cool.Cons:- Heavy and it clamps too tightly to your head making it really uncomfortable to wear for long periods of time.- Expensive.- Difficult differentiating between the different preset equalization levels.- Audio level appears rather low.- Interface is kind of difficult to operate at first since all the buttons are on the headset.

Pros:Extremely lightweight.Attractive.Watch was shipped from Japan and instead of arriving in a month as Amazon had predicted it arrived within a few days!Watch came in great shape. Brand new, including a pillow which the watch was wrapped around.Watch was already set to English and for the city in which I live including the current DST setting. Wow that's service.Inexpensive given the exceptional features. You can't find another analog + digital + atomic + solar watch that's reasonably water resistant in one package- ESPECIALLY not in a field watch.As far as its water resistance, I have swum with it numerous times in the ocean for a mile at a shot and it is still fully operational.Cons:Watch strap is indeed stiff as others had noted. I took advantage of the pillow that came with the watch and tightened the watch around the pillow to let it stretch over night. That seemed to help a little with the stiffness.Update: over time the stiffness reduces.Summary:This watch is essentially the WVA-M640-1ACR except it is rated only at 5 ATM depth rather than 10 ATM, and the strap is a nylon strap rather than a plastic strap.The nylon strap is what makes this watch look more like a military field watch, and also much easier to replace. I've always hated having a great Casio watch where over time the plastic strap would break and it would be impossible to replace. I guess that's probably what Casio intended...
Pros- Cable works - no fuss- Cable is matte black - kinda coolCons- none

Pros:- Picture is crisp and bright owing to the larger lens- Audio cancellation is excellent. I tested it against another location that was using a ClearOne system. No echoes and no chop off.- Speaker is loud making it easy to hear in a 25 seat room- Cables are long- Comes with wall mount for the camera- Can pair with your bluetooth phone to use it as a conferencing deviceCons:- I really cant think of any.Summary:- Excellent well performing video conferencing system suitable for a 25 seat conference room. If I were Polycom and LifeSize I would be very worried. Of course the only thing those systems do better is to provide an easy interface to dial into a meeting. The Logitech assumes you are using something like Skype or Google Hangout.

Pros:- Thermal stainless steel carafe is well made. I brewed a container of coffee and let it stand in an air-conditioned office for 24 hours and it was still warmer than luke warm.- There is no heating element underneath the carafe (which is good) so it wont sit and burn your coffee into oblivion.- Overall device is attractive in design.- Makes a decent cup of coffee.- If all the high tech stuff fails you can still push the on/off button on the coffee maker itself.Cons:- Takes up a substantial amount of counter space.- Expensive for what is essentially a timer and on/off switch. It really isnt clear what the real advantage of having the timer be wifi accessible is. You have to go to the coffee maker to fill it before using it anyway. Why add the complexity, and the extra landfill as a consequence of adding more technology.- The large reservoir has markings on it and it gives you the impression that you can perhaps make a smaller cup of coffee (like the Keurig), but there is no way to do this automatically other than to manually turn off the coffee maker at some point in the brewing process.- While I was able to turn the coffee maker on and off via wifi, I could never actually set a time. The software kept saying there was a scheduling conflict and I hadnt even created a schedule yet.- The opening to the coffee pot is too small to stick your hand in for cleaning.Note:- Does not come with any coffee filters. So order those too if you dont have any.

Pros- Well constructed- Includes extra filterCons- None that I can tellSuggestion- Make cold pressed coffee with it. Instructions:- Add 1 cup coffee grounds.- Fill with cold water.- Let sit in fridge with lid on (and no plunger) for a few days (I typically leave it for 3 days).- Attach plunger and remove grounds.- Serve the concentrated coffee essence with ice cubes and cream. Or just lots of milk.- Guaranteed a winner.

I own a Philips Flexcare so that will be my point of reference for this product.Also Amazon sent me a different brush to review than the one pictured here. My brush only has 1 button on it and  2 modes of operation.Anyway heres my review for the unit I received:Pros:- Much lighter and 2 inches shorter than the Philips. Makes it easier to wield and carry on travel.- Dock is more secure than Philips- It has the same 30 second timer as the Philips but unlike the Philips the unit doesnt stop after 2 minutes. It just keeps going. I much prefer this because after my 2 minute cycle I typically go on to do tongue cleaning anyway. The Philips requires me to press the go button again. Anyway, small detail...Cons:- This isnt really a true cons and perhaps a perceived one. If you are used to a Philips the first thing you will notice is that the vibration on the Panasonic feels substantially weaker than the Philips. So I decided to try a simple test. I put a dab of tooth paste on each brush and just let it vibrate to see what happens. Surprisingly the seemingly weaker Panasonic brush seems to disassemble the toothpaste blob almost immediately whereas the Philips did not. Thats suggesting to me that the Panasonic is just vibrating at a much higher frequency which might lead to the perception that the vibration is weaker. In all likelihood it is probably just as effective as the Philips.- From what I can tell on Amazon, the Panasonic brushes are a tad more expensive than the Philips. And like the Philips its also not quite clear which replacement heads Im supposed to buy.Summary:- A decent light weight travel toothbrush. Although it feels weaker than the Philips it may be due to the higher frequency at which it vibrates.

My experience with the printer was over wifi.Pros:- Very fast and quiet double sided printing.- Bright clear user interface.- All in one system.- Printer and scanner detected seamlessly by Mac.- Provides power saving functions to shutdown the printer when not in use.Cons:- To use things like cloud printing services you need to register with Epson's website. The printer itself doesn't give you any information about this, you have to go to the start up manual, which also doesnt tell you much except to go to the Epson website and figure it out for yourself.I did not try the Fax machine since I dont have a land line anymore.Overall an excellent all-in-one system for a very reasonable price. The only major difference between this printer and the 4640 is the extra paper capacity and the faster print speed on the 4640.

My experience with the printer was over wifi.Pros:- Very fast and quiet double sided printing.- Bright clear user interface.- All in one system.- Printer and scanner detected seamlessly by Mac.- Provides power saving functions to shutdown the printer when not in use.Cons:- To use things like cloud printing services you need to register with Epson's website. The printer itself doesn't give you any information about this, you have to go to the start up manual, which also doesnt tell you much except to go to the Epson website and figure it out for yourself.I did not try the Fax machine since I dont have a land line anymore.Overall an excellent all-in-one system for a very reasonable price.

The title says it all really. It is mint flavored hydrogen peroxide. Straight hydrogen peroxide triggers my involuntary gag response, the mint flavoring seems to help mitigate that to some degree. There is a small unknown quantity of citric acid and phosphoric acid in this, which is what gives your teeth that squeaky clean feeling. Both acids are known to contribute to enamel erosion- though I am not certain of the concentration and duration of exposure necessary.It just seems to me that if you want mint flavored hydrogen peroxide couldnt you just buy a bottle of HO and drop in a little mint before rinsing?

Pros:- Its not expensive.- It feels solidly made.- The LED display is big and bright so its visible in an oven that doesnt have a lamp (yes some do exist).- Easy to operate.- Instructions are comprehensive, though not really necessary.- Instructions use a large enough font so you dont need reading glasses.- Packing is backed with cardboard, so its easy to open. No annoying dangerous plastic clamshell packaging.- Appears to be accurate via ice and boiling water (at near sea level) test.- Hold button is convenient so you dont have to have the device in the oven to complete the reading.Cons:- Goes to sleep before a stable temperature can be read. Just need to press the On button again to resume. In fact it switches off just when the temperature is about stable. So close...Overall:- Good low cost functional product with a minor annoying flaw.

Pros:- Scent is "fresh" not perfumey. It is also a very light scent so after shampooing the dog does not have any strong residual smell.- Shampoo has a thick creamy opaque consistency so its easy to tell where the shampoo is going while its being applied.- Washes off quickly so you dont have to douse the dog for a long time to wash off any residual shampoo.Will see how fluffy my dog looks in a few hours.

Pros- Best pre-built Excelsior released by any manufacturer to date.- Audio digitization is very good compared to the old Playmates toys.- Plastic feels stronger than the model kit version I built over 10 years ago.Cons- Nacelles are missing horizontal fins.- Minor flash that can be filed off.Lets face it, this is a pretty rare ship. Its taken a long time for them to finally release it. The Playmates version was essentially  the Enterprise B that was relabeled as the Excelsior. And the Playmates nacelles sag! The nacelles on this replica don't!

I dont want to be redundant in my review since others who favor this item have pretty much covered all the bases.I just want to add 1 thing:It will fit a valet car key. So if you own a car that includes a valet car key, use that when you go to the beach, and you can leave the fob locked in your car.

Tested it with my 16 year old Lab and the neighbors much younger Bull Terrier and Shitzu.My Lab wasnt interested. Later he did eat one but Ive never been able to interest him since.The bull terrier and shitzu on the other hand were chowing them down like theres no tomorrow.However comparing this to just plane old Milk Bone biscuits, the milk bones work hands down every single time, even for my very picky Lab.

Pros:- Unit feels solidly built and has some weight but not so much as to be inconvenient to take on travel.- Buttons have a nice solid feel to them when pressed.- Lots of good auditory feedback in the system:  = LED light blinks when charge is low.  = Audio feedback (beeps) when you adjust volume level. Different beep sound when you have reached max volume.  = On max volume it is sufficiently loud for a small conference table.  = LED blinks when searching for Bluetooth connection.  = Additional LED lights up when muted.- Supports both USB and Bluetooth audio.- Unit includes a USB cable and an attractive faux wool case to protect it when taken on travel.Cons:Testing on my MacPro laptop:Audio output quality in Bluetooth is much better than with the USB connector. With the USB connector the audio sounds garbled as if it wasnt sampling enough.Music plays quite loudly over Bluetooth and for the most part does a good job, but do not expect a Bose! On the other hand audio output at voice frequencies appear to be very good. So clearly they are trying to optimize the frequency response for the intended use.Testing on my iPhone5:Audio input using Bluetooth seems to be an issue. When I test it with an audio recording app the recorded audio is decent. However when I engage in a phone conversation using the default iPhone phone app, the remote participant complained that they were intermittently losing parts of what I was saying, so I tried toggling back and forth between the built in mic on my phone and the philips to determine if the problem may be due to  "cellular" transmission problems. The philips seemed to be the problem.When I get a chance I may try out the other permutations.  But for now the device does not appear to be very effective.I began testing it again recently about 2 weeks since I wrote the review and now the microphone has ceased to work entirely. At first I thought it was a glitch with my iPhone connection so I tried connecting to my MacPro instead. With both Bluetooth and USB connector the microphone no longer works. So sadly I cannot review this further.

Pros- Very few cameras on the market provide wide angle view for meeting room conferencing with skype / google hangout. This one works perfectly.- Works on the Mac. No driver needed.- Definitely looks better than my Polycom which is only 720p.- Lens lets you adjust focus.Yes it's light and it's plasticky but for the price there is nothing to complain about. The product simply works as advertised.

0:11 MinsPros- The compact design is much nicer than the earlier generation of this product.Cons- After filling it with water and setting it up for a week at the same location where I had put the previous gen product a year ago, it attracted ZERO flies for  several weeks, whereas the previous generation product attracted flies on the same day. It may have something to do with the substantially smaller opening the flies have to navigate to get lured in.A few weeks later and with warmer temperatures things are starting to work significantly better.Now this trap is teaming with flies and the flies are also laying eggs and you can see tiny maggots as well.I am attaching a video I took to give you an idea of what I mean. Warning: it's pretty disgusting.

Pros:- Game is very stable. Haven't had any crashes.- It plays just like the Console version.Cons:- Mouse control is a bit unwieldy at times- clearly this game was designed for a console game controller- Elite pack doesn't really add much more to the game play other than randomizing stats and providing additional cosmetic accessories to armor.- Sometimes the camera is a little out of control when it tries to position itself for a cinematic shot.Playing it on my two year old 2.7 GHz Intel Core i7, 8GB RAM, with Intel HD Graphics 3000 (512MB) seems fine for the most part.All the graphics were set to low quality but the visuals all look sufficiently good. But I would definitely say that this is the MINIMUM config.
Awesome album with recasting of classic Samoan songs.Contrary to the earlier review, these songs are not Tahitian nor Hawaiian. They are Samoan.

The last version I used was X3. X6 does not stray far from the basic formula.The software continues to be very straight forward to use. I don't think I've ever used the user manual.The biggest new features are: support for 4K, motion tracking, variable speed, and HTML5 support. These tend to be only in the higher end video editors like Adobe Premiere.4K supports video from the GoPro HERO3 Black Edition without problems.  For those who own the RED camera, sorry you cannot import the files.The updated Stop Motion feature now lets you control a DSLR camera within the software.Video Studio, as far as I know, is still the only consumer video software that adds HTML5 web code creation for your movies.

Pros:Story of a group of Tibetans trying to escape from Tibet but were shot down by Chinese Authorities.The story is told from interviews of witnesses and while it is well written, it is not terribly surprising considering China's reputation with human rights abuses.The book provides a lesson in Chinese-Tibetan history, and insight into commercial mountaineering.ConsIf you have read Jon Krakauer's "Into Thin Air" you will find this story about climbing rather lacking.

An interesting device.At first when you connect it to the mains and turn on the water, you wonder whether you will have to keep pulling on the hose in order to keep it lengthened. But eventually it does and remains lengthened.Then you wonder how this hose is going to retract to its original form, and so you turn off the water and let it drain from the hose and it slowly recoils. Pretty nifty concept.The only thing I wasn't too impressed with was the screw on head that attached to the water mains. It doesn't really seal very well and so there is a small jet of water shooting from it.But I think given the choice between a non-retracting hose and this retractable one, I would go with this one. The water seepage is a minor nuisance.

Pros- Serves its purpose.Cons- It refuses to recognize H&R Tax files regardless of whether they are T11 or PDF files. So you are stuck with having to enter the data from scratch.- When filing the State form for Illinois it said I had to fill in a number in IL 1040 line 1a. That's all it said. No additional help and no indication what line 1a wanted.

Pros- Light weight- AttractiveCons- One side began splitting after only a few light runs, most likely owing to the light weight mesh material.- Toe area is constraining- presumably to give you sure footing.Verdict:Very unlikely to purchase another pair of adidas or at least their Climacool line.

Pros:- Strong tart flavor. More tart than the Liliko'i jelly from Maui Jelly Factory (MJF).Cons:- Flavor is mostly correct. There is a very small hint of a preserved fruit taste whereas the MJF product has a much fresher fruit taste.- Preserve is rather runny compared to MJF or compared to other preserves.Still for the price this is an excellent tasting product and close enough to the true taste of Passion Fruit that I would not hesitate to recommend it to others.

I used to own Case-mate's Tank for the 4S which was a tough case with a sliding screen protector. Though I liked the concept I wanted something slimmer for my iPhone 5. Imagine the Tank has a Hummer wrapped around an iPhone.The Xtreme case worked very well. It is one of the fewer cases that have an integrated screen protector as part of the case rather than a separate, and annoying, stick on protector. It feels solid with lots of "bumper" protection against falls but does not have the huge bulk as in the Tank or Otterbox cases. The Military green with orange stripe is also stylistically awesome and makes the phone easier to find in a dark room- though it isn't bright green as to attract a lot of attention.I had considered the Lifeproof case as well since it also had a built-in screen protector, but the reviews (and also a friend who owned one) have suggested that when the iphone is installed there was an air gap between the screen protector and the screen itself which made it a bit clumsy to operate. This is not the case with the Xtreme. Of course to be fair Lifeproof's case is intended to be completely submersible in water and Xtreme is not.Note: if you use the Apple 30-pin to lighting adapter, it will not fit with the case. You have to use the regular lighting adapter that came with the phone. This means that  old devices  like a Griffin AutoPilot, won't work for you.So overall, Xtreme is a great case for someone who wants a bit more protection for their prized investment without having to suffer the penalty of bulk and having to apply those horrid screen protectors.

When I first opened the box and looked at the instruction manual I thought - here we go yet another poorly designed device that requires me to dig through the instructions with small print to figure out how to use it.Granted the instructions are printed in small print and doesn't look like something Apple would have designed, but the device was actually pretty easy to set up.Customers should be aware that the only way to see the data on the  device is by connecting and uploading the data to the website at [...]. There you will need to create an account which will let you download the Mac and Windows software drivers. Uploading data is transparent. Just plug into the computer and it should just upload.The dashboard on the website is generally well designed. It gives you different goals you can choose to strive towards and awards you with medals when you succeed. You can also signup using your social media account which presumably means it posts your accomplishments for your friends to see. Again a good idea. These are all the right things a technology needs to do to help motivate a person toward better healthy behavior.You can download a report sheet as a pdf that summarizes your progress to date.The device appears to be pretty accurate.Lastly, if you can unlink the pedometer from your account in case you want to give it to someone else to use.Alright enough reviewing, time to go for a long walk :)

Really difficult to tell the difference between this product and the EfaGold organic extra virgin coconut oil I have used in the past.For those who had difficulty opening the jar, you need to pull the tab that runs around the circumference of the lid before you attempt to unscrew the lid.A small screwdriver will help you pop the tab out enough for you to get your fingers around it.Not really sure why this tab is necessary considering other competing products don't need to do this.Anyway, if you don't want to deal with the hassle of the jar, get EfaGold. The EfaGold also comes in a see-thru jar so you know when you're running low.

When this game first came out, I took one look at the cover art and the silly name of the title and never looked at it again.When it hit the bargain bins I again ignored it for the same reason. The cover art makes the game look like a cheap 90s game, whereas in fact this game has quite a lot of depth- the visuals, the characters, the gameplay and the plot are all quite engaging, and certainly more so than the popular critics give it credit for.Some highlights of the gameplay"- When the robots are shot they come apart piece by piece and continue to function. So they will continue to crawl at you and shoot you. If you shoot off their head they will walk around shooting blindly. This adds something new to the first person shooter genre.- You earn points as you play which you can cash in to either improve your skills or buy more bullets, med packs, nano enhancements, etc- not to dissimilar to Borderlands.- You get to choose your squad mates and when you are shot down you can either use a medpack on yourself to revive, or if you are out, you can ask one of your squad mates for help. And while you are in this injured state you can still crawl (e.g. into safety) and continue to shoot before you eventually die or are revived by your squad mate.- The script and voice acting are decent (for a Japanese title).  Each character has a distinct personality/attitude which makes them engaging though cliched perhaps, but surprisingly they are sometimes humorous. This is refreshing for a FPS. I don't think I have ever laughed at or with any of the Halo and Gears of War characters. Probably the most cheesy line in the game is "Holler if you're dead!" which later you discover was intended to be cheesy as the game laughs at itself.- I really appreciate being able to give voice commands to your squad mates using a microphone. It is something seldom used in a first person shooter but makes a lot of sense. Further I liked the fact that if you shoot your squad mates they will eventually lose trust in you and stop following your orders. Also if you compliment them too much they eventually get irritated. Lastly the trust system will determine who will fight with or against you in the finale.- Just when the game starts to feel repetitive toward the end they change up the story a bit and things quickly start to conclude.- Watch the end credits all the way through- there is a final cutscene.As others have mentioned, the multiplayer is rather weak. The character selection is very generic and there just aren't enough people online to make it worthwhile to play.

I own two pairs of Olukai flip flops because they are such great flip flops.I really liked the design of these shoes. But there are some issues.First the Pros:It is a great looking shoe.The wide toe area is great for people with wide feet.Foot bed is very comfortable.Cons:Ankle and heel needs some breaking into, so potentially expect some blisters.The sole wears quickly at two points where there is no rubber. This is probably the biggest flaw with the shoe and it only took a few months  for the leather part of the sole to begin to wear. See posted picture.Addendum: I spoke to customer service who responded very within a day and they said that the wearing is just cosmetic. Underneath the worn leather is still a rubber sole. So I am upgrading my original 3/5 star review to 4/5.

ProsThe product dissolves very rapidly in water.The taste is also very mild and it is very drinkable with water and therefore also mixes well with other flavors without overpowering it.It has a very light sweet taste because of the fructose. Again, very light sweetness not overpowering sugary taste.Minor ConsFor those trying to reduce the use of sugars in their diet since it tends to creep into everything, there is fructose. But it accounts for less than 1% of your daily allowance. So it should not be a concern. Especially if you are using it as a post workout drink the sugar is needed to prevent your body from consuming muscle tissue.For folks who like stats here is the amino acid profile. I am also posting the nutrition label in case anyone is interested.Typical Amino Acid Profile Per 26 g ServingEssential Amino AcidsIsoleucine (BCAA) 1.03 gLeucine (BCAA) 1.72 gValine (BCAA) 0.97 gPhenylalanine 0.57 gMethionine 0.42 gLysine 1.43 gTryptophan 0.40 gThreonine 1.17 gArginine (semi-essential) 0.40 gHistidine (semi-essential) 0.31 gNon-Essential Amino AcidsAlanine 0.84 gAspartic Acid 2.24 gCysteine 0.48 gGlutamine + Glutamic Acid 3.06 gGlycine 0.31 gProline 0.99 gSerine 0.84 gTyrosine 0.51 g
ProsThe model has heft. Solidly built. Great paint work.You can substitute lower engine shutters to be open or closed.ConsNone

I have used PSP since as far back as version 4. It is still my go-to image editor over Photoshop- which I have also used as far back as the early 90s when it was first introduced on the Silicon Graphics.For the past two years I've been primarily using X3, foregoing X4.X4 changed the Organizer from X3 and introduced the Manage tab whereby you need to put the images you are working with into trays. The problem with this approach is that whenever you want to go back to the Manage tab it assumes you are starting a fresh new workflow. So it requires you to either save things away or discard the changes. Fortunately in X5 they have removed this rather cumbersome restriction allowing you to move fluidly between Manage and Edit.Overall X5 appears stable (I am using the version with Service Pack 1). If you are switching folders too quickly when it is trying to cache them (especially if there are large animation files) there is a chance it will hang. Otherwise in a 4 hour test session of opening many files, copying and pasting between images, editing, touching up etc, it did not crash once.They also appear to have FINALLY fixed the scaling problem that has plagued PSP for as long as I can remember. In previous versions whenever you interactively scaled an object proportionally there is a chance that it will not. So objects appear stretched. So you have to undo and try again.The bundled add-ons: Facefilter Studio and NIK Color Efex filters aren't really worth it. Facefilter lets you touch up facial skin tones and expressions in photos- so that if someone wasn't smiling, you can make them smile. The problem of course is that sometimes these modifications tend to make people look creepy!NIK Color Efex filters - to be completely frank, I haven't figured out WHERE those actually reside. After installing it provides you with no guidance whatsoever. Once I figure it out I will report back.With regards to the so called dozens of royalty free brushes etc. Those have to be downloaded and most of them are the same ones that came free with previous versions of PSP.Conclusion:If you haven't updated PSP since X3, X5 is worth the jump (but get the standard edition, not the Ultimate). If you own X4, I don't see this upgrade as being necessary except perhaps to remove that limitation with transitioning back and forth between Manage and Edit modes. If that doesn't bother you then ignore X5. Upgrade ever other year or every few years.

Pros:Pictorial story books are important because pictures provide the context for the words aiding learning and understanding. This is especially important for the Samoan language where the meaning of a word depends so much on the context.Macrons are properly included.There is a small Samoan to English glossary in the back of the book.Stories are contemporary- there's even the mention of an iPod in one of them.Cons:Really wish there was also a complete English translation of the book.Would really like to see this book longer and would be willing to pay more for it- or a series of books.

Like any large office there is always the stash of mugs collected from various conference or corporate events.And like any office you will find a bunch of them unwashed on the kitchen counter but you can't tell because they are opaque (especially dark colored mugs).This mug makes it clearly obvious which ones are clean and which are not.The mugs appear to be well made and durable- thick glass.Yes it is made of molded glass so there is a seam, at the handle. But this is why they can sell them at such a low price. The seam does not impact its use.It's Microwave safe.Would definitely buy again in the future.

Beautiful Holiday Bowl! I was very curious as to what the size would be like - it is a "medium" size salad bowl that holds enough salad for 4-5 people. The wooden servers are wrapped in a sleeve that sits above the bowl, and it is all securely packed.The leaf and berry pattern looks really nice with most Christmas decor, and would especially pair well with green, red, or white dishes.If you are thinking of purchasing this as a gift, the bowl comes in an attractive red box. I have added a photo of it to my review.A great choice of dish to add to your holiday ware.

Fantastic for growning herbs in your own home all year long! My daughter loves to plant things and watch them grow. We live in the Midwest so the growing season is not very long. I was excited to get the Miracle--Gro AeroGarden so that she could put it in her room and grow herbs and small vegetables all year.The garden is very easy to set up, and the instructions are very clear. I like that you can purchase different kinds of starter kits to grow what you would like. The size is perfect for a small table top. When the light is extended it gives you ample room to work with your garden bed, and to work with the growing plants.The only issue is that the LED light is pretty bright in her room at night, so we moved it to under her high bunk bed so the light does not disturb her sleep.I will update further when her plants start growing.

What a life saver! I have not slept through the night in months. I started waking up a few times a night, and the last month I have been waking up 5 to 6 times a night, and then would have a hard time getting back to sleep. Some times it would take me 2 or 3 hours to get back to sleep. I have been so exhausted at work everyday, and generally miserable. I figured this must be due to my age and that there was nothing I could do about it. Sleeping pills wipe me out, and make me even more tired during the day.I had heard of Melatonin, but didn't really believe any natural product could fix such a serious issue. I had just given up hope when my Mom mentioned she had tried Melatonin and it was helping her stay asleep at night. I decided that maybe, just maybe it could help me.I saw this Nature's Truth Melatonin and was excited to give it a try.The bottle states that you can take 1/2 a pill at first to get used to the Melatonin, but after such a serious lack of sleep I decided to take an entire pill (they are very small and dissolve quickly in your mouth)  I took it 30 minutes before bed, and fell asleep quickly. I did wake up 5 times, but went right back to sleep (which in itself was wonderful!) The second night I woke only 3 times. And the third night only 2x's. I still found myself a bit groggy during the mornings though. So I decided to take half a pill on nights 4 and 5 and I slept the entire night! Never woke up! How wonderful! And I felt refreshed in the mornings.If you have trouble staying asleep at night, you really should try these tablets. I consider them a life saver, as I can only imagine what a toll lack of sleep was taking on my body.A Great Product!

I love this watch! Amazing quality. Nice and sturdy, yet looks amazing.  I love how it can be worn with casual clothes or a suit and still look great.The Day, Date, and 24 hour subdials are nice placed and easy to read, but seem to serve more of a decorative purpose.  The face of the watch is large, but looks nice on my sons medium size wrist. If you have a small wrist, it might look too large, depends on your preferences.The band is nice and sturdy, yet comfortable to wear all day.The fact you can swim or snorkel with this watch is a great bonus feature.My son has been wanting a watch that he can wear any time of day, and doing any activity without worrying about taking it off, or changing it to match an outfit. This truly is a watch for all occasions.
I collect antique canning jars and canning booklets. This one is great - and came in perfect condition. Love it!

I have been using a small blender for a couple of years, and unfortunately it stopped working a few weeks ago. I have been trying to decide which blender to get next, and was thrilled to get to try out the Oster Mason Jar Blender.I make vitamin shakes for my daughter and myself every morning. I used a vitamin/pro-biotic mix that I add Ice and almond milk too.  I need a blender that can chop up the ice as well as mix the ingredients.This blender does a great job of blending! It quickly chops the ice and mixes everything up to make a great morning shake.I love the cups - they are made of plastic, which I like because they are lighter to carry on the way to work each morning. They are made of a very sturdy plastic, and will last a long time. The lids attach securely and include a straw. Perfect for my daughter and I's use each morning.I am very happy with this blender, and think you will be too!

This Kaplan World History Book and DVD is loaded with tons of information. It is essentially a World History course with a DVD that contains practice tests.Looking through it, I can see that it definitely contains all the information you would ever need to know to do well on the test. If you already are well versed in World History you might find there is too much information. It would be easier to study if it was more of a outline and just important details to refresh your memory type of book. You will be well served though reading through the entire book to make absolutely sure you know as much as you can before the test.I have been out of school for many years, so I personally need the amount of information in this book to study for the AP Test. So for students that have been out of school for awhile, this would be a great resource for study.

I teach in a small private school, and have been hoping to get a new desktop for my classroom. My students love playing math and spelling games, but the desktop I have used the past several years is very old, and would not play videos or connect to the internet. This severely limited what games I could make available to them.The ASUS M32CD Desktop was ready to go right out of the box. I plugged it into the wall, and then plugged in my personal monitor, and the keyboard and mouse that were included.The desktop started up right away and only took a couple of minutes to do its initial load up. I was very surprised to see that it has wireless capabilities, I guess I am really behind the times! LOL  I was able to connect wirelessly very easily.I already have Windows 10 on my home laptop so I was familiar with it, but did not realize that it does not come with a DVD player app. I put in a movie for the kids and it would not play it. Turns out you have to pay $15 to download the Windows DVD player. I did an internet search and found that there are free DVD player apps you can use for Windows 10, but our school internet filter will not let me go to pages that have free apps. So, I will be paying for the download when I can.I use an external speaker that plugs in with USB when I show movies to my students, and I like that there are USB plugs in the front and in the back of the computer.I have been able to find several websites with games for my students to play and the computer has worked flawlessly since we have started using it.My son, who is an active gamer, read through the specs and let me know that it is a nice computer for school or office use, but did not have the graphics card and other things that would make it a computer he could use for his online games. It is a great computer though for Minecraft and Roblox.I have included a picture of the back of the computer so you can see what it looks like. My son wanted to look inside the computer, but there is a warranty seal sticker on the back, and if it is removed it voids the warranty. So you might not want to open it.

These earrings really surprised me - they look much more expensive than they really are.Amazon currated products are of really good quality, and I love wearing their jewelry.
