Really nice bottle! My husband loves to drink water that has lemon slices in it, and it is nice to load lemons into the center receptacle and it makes it so the lemons last through 3 refills of water in the bottle.Nice and sturdy too!

This has been very helpful for my dark circles.I have very light skin, and as I have aged my dark circles have gotten more and more noticeable.After using this for a couple of weeks, I am noticing my dark circles are lightening up.I will definitely keep using this treatment

I love the size of the Cubic Zirconia center. It looks so pretty when it reflects the light of a room.A nicely made necklace that looks more expensive than it really is. Great to wear for any occasion.Comes with a nice jewelry pouch for gift giving.

I got this for our cat Tiger - although he is just one cat, he can sure make a big stink when it comes to the litter box. I just couldn't clean it enough to get rid of the smell. I found that I had to use multi-cat litter which helped a whole lot with the smell, but the idea of a automatic cat litter box really intrigued me.The Healthy Home Automatic litter box was easy to set up, and works really well. I love that there are choices as to whether you want it to rake the liter hourly, every 4 hours, or every 8 hours. The rake glides through the litter and then lifts a trap door that then allows the waste to be deposited into the provided trash liners. (3 liners are included with the litter box)I followed the directions and set it up, while leaving the cats original litter box out so that he could get used to the new one. After he started using the new box I got rid of his old one.I'm giving it a four star rating because I came home the other day to find the rake part detached and litter all over the place. All I can imagine is that the cat was in the box when the hourly time to rake came around. I managed to put it all back together and cleaned up the mess. I was really worried my cat would not use the box anymore, but was happy to see that he still uses it. I am just really hoping the same problem doesn't happen again.I have also discovered that you need to use a fine littler and not a very chunky one ore else it pushes the litter up over the trap door when raking.This has definitely cut way back on the smell problem and I am very glad that we got this litter box system. I won't go back to the old litter box, but will keep using this.

Love this BBQ/Smoker so much!The MoJack arrived in a big box, and in great condition.I first want to say that it looks great on my back patio - very high quality, and sturdy. I expect to be using it for many years.I love how it uses pellets - I decided to order some from Amazon until I could find some where I live. Using the pellets gave my hamburgers a great taste. Didn't fill the water pan the first time we cooked on it, and realized we should have because the meat was a little dry. The next time we put water in the pan and it made a big difference. Also make sure you season the grill by following the directions before you use it for the first time.The only issue I have had is that the directions were a little hard to follow  so it took some time to get it all together correctly. In fact we had a couple of parts left over after putting it together and had to go back through and figure out what we did wrong. So you need to read them very carefully.This is a great product - wonderful for BBQ and for smoking meats. It is very well made, and should last for many years to come. MoJack has definitely improved this grill and I would highly recommend it!

If you have a thryroid problem, this supplement is worth a try!
I got these for my daughters arts and crafts projects. They are nice and sturdy and easy to paint and draw on!

This is a nice pack of flameless tea lights. I didn't really like the "flame" cover over the LED bulb so I popped it off and like the look much better. These look especially nice in a low light area. I have put them in my tea light holder and enjoy the light they give off.
Great to use at the BBQ - I hate put my hands anywhere near the BBQ grill. These gloves keep my hands safe and are comfortable to wear. I won't grill without them!!

These candles look so real! The top edges are fluted to give them a realistic look.  The remote works perfectly and allows you to choose from 12 different colors or a multi-color mode. My favorite is the multi-color as it cycles through the colors at a nice pace.I recently purchased an antique gas heater to use as decoration. I was looking for candles to put inside the insert area - these are perfect!!

My family and I love these SmartyPants gummy vitamins. They taste great and have no aftertaste. We find it more enjoyable to eat the gummies than swallow big vitamin pills. My teenage daughter was always forgetting to take her vitamins, but she loves the taste of the SmartyPants and is now remembering to eat her gummies each morning!The bottle recommends 3 gummies each day. This dose covers all your needed vitamins because it contains a Multivitamin, Omega 3, Vitamin D, added fiber, and no added sugar.A great choice for your family!
I purchased this as a gift. I took a look inside and it comes with a very beautiful Sea Urchin. It is carefully wrapped and boxed. A great gift idea!
Makes my eyelashes look fuller and longer. Brush makes it easy to apply. Lasts all day!

I love memory foam pillows - I was intrigued by the idea of a shredded foam pillow. I wondered if it would be more comfortable. I found this pillow very comfortable to sleep with. It conforms to my head and neck better than other memory foam pillows. The fact that there are foam pieces in the pillow allow the foam to be more flexible and adjustable. I have been sleeping great with it and am always comfortable. Love it!
Fits perfectly on the back of our passenger front seat. All the pockets you need with easy access. Perfect for long trips or just driving around town. Solid construction and attractive! Love it!

My master bedroom is a converted attic and it gets very hot in the summer! Our central air system does not cool the room off when it gets to be 80 degrees or more outside. This DeLonghi is the perfect size to cool off the entire upstairs attic area which is about 250 sq ft. I can now enjoy my room all year round!I was using window air conditioner but that caused us to loose 1 of our ways of escape in case of a fire emergency and now with this portable unit and window bracket we can still use the window as an emergency escape if needed.I love that it is is quiet, dripless and that the remote control works from every part of our room.  A great air conditioning unit!

The show itself is still great.  It does, in some ways, feel like a sitcom that has been on the air for a while, but they have been able to keep the show as fresh as a longer running sitcom can be.  This was done by doing a Cam and Mitchell engagement to wedding story arc throughout the season.  As in past seasons it does a good job giving all the characters stories, but there are times when the kids were kind of relegated to the background.As has been the case in prior seasons there were on location episodes.  This time one in Vegas and one in Australia.  The final two episodes of the season focused on the wedding day, and had the somewhat predicable disasters that almost ruined the day, but with everything being okay in the end.  They did get a little over the top and repetitive with the almost cancelling and moving the wedding, but by the end it was a funny and touching episode.For those who actually get the discs, the quality is very sub par.  First of all, after making the first 4 seasons available on blu-ray, the studio completely went the cheap route and made it only available on DVD, which many of the non-CGI heavy shows are doing.  Although Modern Family is still popular enough that it should have still been available on blu-ray.  Then to add insult to injury, the DVD transfer is horrible.  Unfortunately fox has focused far more on streaming their shows and made the physical media almost an afterthought.  On top of all that, there are very few extras.  Deleted scenes on disc 2, then a couple behind the scenes features on the location episode, a couple featurettes on the wedding episode, and a gag reel.  Okay for what is there, but not as much or as quality as in the past.

Bought these for doing cardio and plyometric workouts.  They are comfortable and very stable.  They are lighter.  Not quite the feeling of going barefoot, but they are much lighter than any other shoe I have worn.  I am very satisfied with them so far, and they seem well made.

This is the movie that, to me, proved The Rock had some bona fide acting chops.  That, of course, is not always a given (see Hulk Hogan and Jesse Ventura for the laughably bad end of the spectrum) when it comes to pro wrestlers turned actors.  It was a role that allowed him to be the action hero everyone thought he would be coming from the pro wrestling world, show off his sometimes underrated comedic side, and even allowed him to make fun of himself a little.The story involves his character, Beck, who is basically a bounty hunter for a rich loan shark.  He calls himself a retrieval expert.  He is tasked with tracking down the boss' son (played by Sean William Scott in his most "un-Stifler like role yet) in Brazil as his final job, after which he will be paid enough to open a restaurant and pursue his real passion as a chef.  Along the way he crosses paths with the head of a strip mining operation played wonderfully (albeit in an almost over the top "more cowbell" SNL parody of himself) Christopher Walken.  Rosario Dawson also stars as a member of the local resistance trying to get the mining company out of town.It is certainly not an overly complicated plot, nor does it take much thought or energy to watch.  That said, it is more than just a "shoot em up" kind of action movie, although there is also plenty of that.  If you are a fan of The Rock, or just a fan of action movies, it is definitely worth checking out and makes for a good way to kill a couple hours.For those who get the actual disc, for bonus material there are two different commentary tracks, one with The Rock and director Peter Berg, and another with a couple producers.  Then there are about 45 minutes or so worth of behind the scenes and making of features and deleted scenes.  Good for what is there if you like going through the extras.It is definitely not a movie that will appeal to everyone.  It would not ever win an academy award, but it is a good action movie that does not take itself too seriously.  Definitely worth a look.

It is more a nod to the spy movie genre than an outright spoof.  It is really a cross between the Bond films and movies like Kick Ass and Watchmen.  It is an extremely violent film, so if that turns you off to a movie then stop and do not even consider it.  There is not really any sex until the very end, and it really consists of a joke and a split second of nudity.  That said much of the violence is done in a very over the top and sometimes humorous way set to musical interludes.The story is set around Samuel L Jackson's character trying to purge the world of most of the human race in order to save the Earth from humanity, with a select few being spared.  The Kingsmen are a group of spies out to protect humanity and stop the plot.  Most of the plot around the actual Kingsmen story is Collin Firth's character Harry trying to get a street kid named Eggsy through the training.  Much of the story revolves around the training of potential recruits who get whittled down one-by-one.  I will not say any more about the plot to avoid giving too much away, but there are the requisite spy gadgets, a ton of action, some comedy, and behind it all an interesting story with a great cast.For those who get the blu ray, it looks and sounds great.  For extras you have an hour and a half behind the scenes/making of feature with the cast, crew, and producers along with Mark Millar who wrote the comic.  There is also a stills gallery of production photos and the trailer.  Good for what is there if you like to go through the extras.It is definitely not a movie for everyone, but if you are a fan of similar movies, this is a good way to fill a couple hours.

+++WARNING+++ this will contain some spoilers from season 1, but no major giveaways from season 2.  If you have not seen the first season, skip past the first paragraph.The second season picks up after the events that closed out season one that led to Masters being fired from the hospital, and telling Virginia how he feels about her.  It then follows through roughly a three year time period up to Kennedy's inauguration in 1960.  This includes a time jump (albeit a very subtle one) in the middle of the season  The jump ends up eliminating or pushing to the backburner many of the season one stories (Barton's arc dealing with his homosexuality for example is almost non-existent after the first couple episodes) and Ethan is heard from in the first couple episodes and does not resurface until the very end.The big theme of this season are the character's relationships with each other, whether they are strengthening or deteriorating.  Intertwined with that is the backdrop of the civil rights movement, and racial issues in general, for the most part involving Libby.  Sexual dysfunction also becomes a major theme as the study begins to look at people with sexual problems instead of rejecting them.  And of course the entire sex as a taboo subject is ever present as it was in the first season.It is very important to note that this is not a documentary or even a docudrama.  It is a very fictionalized version of the story of Masters and Johnson's work.  There are many made up characters, story lines and plots that are added in the show that never occurred in real life.  It is telling the larger story, but takes a lot of liberties getting there.  This is even more apparent in the second season than in the first.  There is a lot added for dramatic effect, and if that is something that would bug you, it is best to skip this.  There are also some ancillary plots, like one involving the sale of diet pills that Virginia starts out in that ends up involving doctor Langham, a story between Lester and a new character, Barb, played by Breaking Bad's Betsy Brandt, and a story involving a new character played by Sarah Silverman.  Some of them work better than others, and while none play a dominant role in the show they are all given time to play out.For those who get the Blu Ray discs, the show looks and sounds great as you would expect.  For extras there are deleted scenes on select episodes, a History of Sex feature where the show runners and some of the actors talk about the second season, and where the show has been and overall where it is going.  Then there is a Women of Sex feature that focuses on the female characters, and a Men of Sex, which is a roundtable discussion between the male actors and their characters in the second season.  All in all, good for what is there.

This book is really a story involving the precursor to the Jedi, called the Je'daii, which were really more like samurai than the Jedi knights we know of from the movies and the other books.  They wield swords that they make themselves, but do not use lightsabers.  The narrative is about finding balance between the light and dark sides of the force, but not adhering to one or the other.  There is really nothing in the story about the transition the Je'daii  took to becoming the Jedi.  That would have actually made for a better story in the long run.This story involves a Je'daii ranger named Lanoree Brock, who is on a mission to stop her brother Dal, from opening a hypergate (which seems to be akin to a wormhole) which would open a gateway to other galaxies.  It jumps back and forth between flashbacks of Lanoree and Dal's Je'daii training and the present day chase.  I think way too much was focused on the flashbacks, and a lot of that could have been removed.  It does help set up the confrontation itself, but also gets in the way at times.  It would have made for a better read to have the flashback material in the first few chapters, then flash forward and tell the chase story uninterrupted.Overall it is a good self contained story.  Given that it takes place thousands of years before the battle of Yavin, none of the characters from either movie trilogy are even hinted at in this book.  You can definitely see the set up for what will ultimately become the Jedi, and even how their philosophy of balance between light and dark could have created the Sith, but that is really all in the background.  While it makes for an interesting short read, it is not really one of the novels I would read multiple times.

The movie is really about relationships and interactions between men and women.  It stars Campbell Scott as Roger, a sharp talking, womanizing sleazeball who on the one hand fancies himself a pickup artist who can talk any woman into his bead, but on the other cannot get over being dumped by his boss and is totally childish and immature after she ends it.  It also stars Jesse Eisenberg as his 16 year old nephew Nick, who runs off to NY city to learn how to get women from his uncle.The movie really is dialogue driven.  It is not an action movie at all, and even though it is billed as a comedy, it is not really a conventional comedy (at least not in the vein of something like The Hangover or any of the comedies of its ilk that have come out recently).  Really the high point of the film takes place in a bar where Roger is trying teach his nephew how to talk to girls.  It really ends up showing that Roger is not all  he claims to be, and Nick realizing that he does not really want to be all that much like his uncle.The movie is definitely not for everyone.  If you do not like bad language and frank sexual discussions, this is definitely not for you.  If you are bored by movies that contain mostly conversation and are not chock full of action and violence again not for you.  But for a character driven story it is not a bad couple hours to spend.For those who get the DVD itself, the extras consist of making of and behind the scenes features with the film makers, and a NYC walking tour with Jesse Eisenberg.  There are also a couple different commentary tracks on the film.

The slicer is easy to put together, and so far (I have used it once) sturdy.  The slices came out even and were much better than my attempt to "eyeball" even slices before which always ended up either too thick or thin.  For the money (and lets face it this is cheap) it does what it should.  The only complaint I have so far is that you cannot slice an entire loaf at a time because the guide only goes about halfway down the board.  It would have been better (and would likely be sturdier with a couple more screws) for the guide to extend the entire length of the board so you could slice the entire loaf at one time.

The book is really as much, if not moreso, the story of Palpatine's rise to power as it is about Darth Plagueis.  Considering most reading the book will be well versed with the movies and know what the actual outcome of the Plagueis/Palpatine relationship will be, the author does a very good job of getting the readers to that point without making the story get boring or lacking suspense.  In fact as others have noted, by the end we see just how evil and manipulative Palpatine really is, and just how long his plan to become Emperor had been in effect.The book does tell the story of Plagueis killing his master, and taking Palpatine on as an apprentice.  The story essentially spans from when Palpatine was in his twenties until the events just after Episode I.  In fact some of the events of Episode I are seen from the sith's perspective and we learn of Darth Maul's origins, and how Dukou ended up as Palpatine's apprentice.  In all it does a good job of filling in the back story and leading up to the parts of the story we already know.  It is well written for what it is.  No, it is not a classic novel, but it does not try to be.  The pacing of the story is very good, and it is a pretty easy read.  Depending on how fast you read and how into it you get, you can easily finish it in a few days (or less).

As has been the case with the other extended editions, this is really for die hard fans of the story and/or those who love bonus material.  If you do not fall into either of those categories then you probably want to stick with the theatrical edition because this will be way more than what you are looking for.Most people who are considering this know the movie well enough that I am not going to spend a lot of time reviewing it.  The extended edition itself comes in just over 3 hrs in length if you count the credits.  It has tacked on about 25 minutes to the theatrical version of the film.  There is generally a lot more action in this movie than the first, and it really just launches into the story.  The only real setup is a flashback showing Gandalf and Thorin meeting at the Prancing Pony in a scene that was taken from the Lord of the Rings Appendices.  As most know this movie started to diverge more from the novel (because of in large part the decision to split the story into three movies), although many elements of the book are in the movie.  The highlight of course, is the full reveal of Smaug and the scene with Bilbo when he is trying to find the stone, which leads into the climax of the movie which is a battle between the dragon and the dwarfs.The real meat of the extended edition are the two bonus discs (which are titled appendices 9 and 10).  Between the two there are 10 hours of bonus material.  The first disc is really a bunch of behind the scenes and making of features showing the process of filming and creating the movie.  The 10th disc goes more into how they came up with various plot points, the look of the movie etc.  There is a great hour and sixteen minute feature on conceptualizing the look of Smaug and the process Benedict Cumberbatch went through to give his performance.  If you are a fan of bonus material you cannot go wrong with what you get here.Chances are if you are getting this you know what to expect because you have the other extended editions.  It is much the same as before.  You get a ton of material, and the movie looks as sounds great as you would expect.  Plus the movie is on a single disc unlike the LOTR extended editions, which is a nice plus.  The only downside is with both the movie and the bonus material, if you have to stop (and watching everything straight through is almost impossible) it will not pick up where you left off.  A relatively minor point, but it is easy enough to do that they should have done it.  Otherwise, everything is great and it is definitely worth adding to your collection.

WARNING....This will contain spoilers from season 1, and hints, but no major giveaways from season 2.  If you have not seen season 1 yet proceed at your own risk.Hannibal is an interesting show in that the audience is "in" on much more of the story than the characters are.  We know where the story is going, but the show is taking much more creative license with the path of how to get there.  So while we know who Hannibal is, and where he will ultimately end up, since the show predates the events of the novels and the other movies, it is definitely putting its own twist on the story.Season 2 picks up after the events of season 1, with Will (Hugh Dancy) in jail framed for Hannibal's (Mads Mikkelsen) murders.  He is still out to prove Hannibal is the Chesapeake Ripper, but has the additional obstacle of having to do so from behind bars.  The season actually opens showing part of the events from the season finale, so we know what the story is leading up to, and the rest of the season plays out the events that lead to that moment.The thing you have to accept from the series is that while it pays homage to, and uses the overall universe that the books and movies were set in, it twists events changes characters etc to meet its needs.  For example the reporter from Red Dragon, Freddie Lounds is now a female, Dr. Chilton has a much more expanded role then he ever had in the films, and the characters are all more intertwined in the film.  So if you cannot accept the fact that the show does not mirror the world of the novels and movies exactly, and does things that would ultimately change some of the mythos, then you should steer clear of this.Mads Mikkelsen does a great job making the Hannibal Character his own.  His take on Hannibal is much different than Hopkins' and you really do not see him turning into Hopkins' version. Every so often however he lets in a little of the snark that Hopkins brought to the character.  While a lot goes on throughout the 13 episodes, the season boils down to Will, Jack, Hannibal and Alana, and Will trying to convince the others of what Hannibal is, while playing a dangerous game of friend and enemy with Hannibal.  This season also introduces the Mason Verger storyline showing its twist on what Hannibal did to Mason, and also introduces Mason's sister Margo who was left out of the movie version of Hannibal.Like the first season not everyone makes it out unscathed, and the season ends on a pretty big cliffhanger that leads you wondering about many character's fates.For those who get the discs, the show looks and sounds great on Blu Ray.  The same stunning visuals that were prevalent in season 1 are here too.  As far as extras go, there are commentary tracks on many episodes.  All have Bryan Fuller, and one other person, which changes each time.  There are two different commentary tracks on the season finale.  There are also several deleted scenes a couple different making of features (including an 1hr 20 min one on the making of the 5th episode) and a great Post Mortem series in which Scott Thomson (who plays one of the Lab techs, Jimmy) interviews members of the cast and crew.  That is the only extra that Mads Mikkelsen actually appears in to discuss the character.  Then there is gag reel.  All in all a lot of content for those who like going through the bonus material.Like the first season the series is very violent and leaves little to the imagination when it comes to the kills and gore.  There is some sexual content, but that is relatively tame compared to other shows of Hannibal's ilk ( to the extent there are any) especially shows like The Americans or some of the basic cable shows.  It is definitely going to be hard to watch if you have a weak stomach.  But if that does not bother you, and you are a fan of the books and movies, yet can accept the series as being its own thing, then I highly recommend it.

It is big, and pretty heavy (about 50 pounds in the box with all the packaging). It will definitely take up a lot of desk or shelf space.  It can connect to your wi-fi or directly to a computer via a USB cable.  I have it set up in the living room via a wi fi connection so everyone in the house can print to it.The printer is very easy to set up.  Setting it up and connecting it to wi-fi only takes about 10 minutes.  The software installation probably takes another 10 minutes.  The install instructions are a bit confusing because they allow for setting up the printer at your desk too, which you do not have to do if you go through the printer's touch screen menu.  Once everything sets up it prints very fast both in black and color.  Especially if you are just printing mainly text.  It can also print and scan oversize paper (which was the appeal for me).  I would definitely recommend it if you need  or want a printer/scanner combo.  If not you could probably get by with a less expensive option.

WARNING...this will contain spoilers from season one, one spoiler (although since it is in episode 1 it is not much of one) and hints from season 2.  If you have not seen season 1 proceed with caution.You know what you get with a show like this.  It takes a lot of suspension of disbelief and not trying to break it down logically.  If you try to nitpick everything you will probably end up hating it.  If you can take it for what it is, then it is entertaining, even if silly at times.Season 2 picks up after the events of season 1 where Joe is blown up in the shed, and Ryan and Claire stabbed in Ryan's apartment.  We see the aftermath of the stabbing, then the show flashes forward 1 year.  At that point Ryan seemingly has his life together.  He is sober, out of the FBI and teaching.  We quickly find out that much of it is an act, and that he does not believe Joe is dead, and is working with his niece (played by Jessica Stroup) to try and track Joe down.There is also a new cult out there, who does not believe Joe to be dead, and commits a series of murders to try and lure Joe out.  We find out at the end of episode 1 (spoiler) that Joe really did survive the fire and has been hiding out separated from the other cult members who managed to get away at the end of season 1.  Mike and Ryan eventually end up teaming up again, along with Ryan's niece and the FBI (mainly in tow and a step behind) end up tracking Joe, and the new killers.  Mike and Ryan's relationship is strained after the events of season 1, and because of that and things that happen in season 2, Mike becomes a darker and darker character.The show definitely tries to go for the over the top shocking moments just as in season 1.  This season it is much less of who is bad vs good.  There was really only a couple instances of that, then the good guy/bad guy aspect was pretty clear with all the characters.  In that way the twists that do happen in this season are a little easier to swallow than those that occurred in season 1 where it seemed damn near everyone was a part of the cult.  The season was in danger of going off the rails a bit by introducing too many unnecessary characters, but did a good job of eliminating them by the final couple episodes and getting it back to the main characters.By the end of season 2, some of the plot lines are resolved, at least to the point where the character's roles are clearly going to change.  There is also a big unresolved plot line that you know will at least be part of the season 3 focus.  Like in season 1, not all the characters make it out alive, but they did a good job of not just doing a rehash of season 1.For those who get the physical discs, like all WB sets the series comes with blu ray discs and (whether you want them or not DVD).  There are 3 blu rays and 4 regular DVDs.  The show looks and sounds great on Blu Ray as you would expect.  For extras there are short "Inside The Following" behind the scenes features for most episodes, deleted scenes for select episodes, the comic-con panel, more behind the scenes features, and a gag reel spread across the three discs.  Unfortunately, again like all newer WB sets, there is no way to play it in a season mode.  So if you stop in the middle of the episode, you have to find where you were after the disc booting up from scratch again.  Not a major issue, but still kind of a pain.Overall, the series is well acted, but does have its moments with the writing.  Like I said above, if you cannot suspend your disbelief or have to have logic driven plot and story lines all the time, then this may not be the show for you.  Plus you have to accept it is ultra violent, with a lot of killing.  I cannot necessarily say if you liked season one you will like this one, but if you can accept the show for what it is, then I think it is still entertaining.  Certainly not a perfect show, or a perfect season, but still good, and sets up what could be a very compelling and better season three.

WARNING...this contains some season 1 spoilers and hints, but no major giveaways from season 2.  If you have not seen the first season proceed at your own risk.It can certainly be argued the second season of Banshee was even better than the first.  At the very least they are on par with each other.  In part because much of season 2 is a continuation of what was set up in season 1, and also fleshes out the story lines from season 1.  Given that they only have 10 episodes to pack everything in, a lot happens.Season 2 has the main storylines of Anna/Lucas/Rabbit, and the ancillary stories involving Anna's/Carrie's family.  Then you have Kai Proctor vs Lucas and Proctor vs Longfellow.  Intertwined in those story lines is the insertion of Rebecca, who like Proctor, was excommunicated from the Amish community.  The main stories intersect at times, are independent at others, and sometimes intersect with the ancillary storylines involving the other characters, including a visit from the real Lucas Hood's son, who discovered at the very end of season 1 that his father was being impersonated.Like in season 1, there is a lot of violence and sex.  I would not really call either completely gratuitous (with some exceptions).  In fact part of what was weaved into the story is Hood's desire to leave the violence that seems to follow him behind.  But he always seems to keep getting dragged back in.  All the characters walk the line between good and bad, even more this season than in season 1.  In fact, Brock is about the only character this season that stays on the "good" side of the line.  And while he does not trust Hood, he is becoming more accepting of the fact that he is the least bad of the bad guys, and wants to do good.Much of the season is spent fleshing out the Rabbit/Lucas/Anna storyline.  We get a lot of back story (told through flashbacks)  about what lead up to the events of Lucas going to prison, Anna becoming Carrie and ending up in Banshee.  It also sets up season 3 with more Proctor/Hood conflict and Introducing a new bad guy, Chayton Littlestone, a gangster on the Reservation.The season contained many great guest starring characters, among them Zeljko Ivanek as FBI agent Jim Racine who has been trying to bust Rabbit for years, and the stunning Odette Annable (of House and Cloverfield) who is Alex Longshadow's dangerous sister Nola (who made a brief appearance at the end of season 1.  The season again boasted great writing and acting.  Antony Starr and Ivana Milievi have great chemistry as the series leads when they do have scenes together, but both do a great job with their characters even in the story lines where they are not together.  Hoon Lee as Job continues the steal the show in almost every scene he is in.  The best was his "introduction" shown in a flash back in the last episode.For those who get the actual blu rays, the series looks and sounds great.  There is audio commentary on about 4 episodes.  A couple episodes with twitter commentary from the cast and crew, deleted scenes for nearly every episode, a few behind the episode featurettes, and deconstructing the title sequence features for every episode.  There is also a 45 min (or so) Banshee Origins series that show some of the events leading up to season 1.  All in all there is a lot for people who like to go through the bonus material.Banshee is definitely not a show for everyone.  It is very violent and sexual, but everything has a purpose.  It is certainly not what you would think of late night Cinemax fare, although there are definitely some Skinemax lite moments in the show.  That aside it is a very well acted, well written show with interesting and compelling characters.  Like a lot of the TV series (especially the cable series) it benefits from having a shorter season.  It packs a lot into 10 episodes, yet still gives all the characters something to do, and just as with season 1, by the time I got through all 10 episodes I was left wanting more, and excited to see where season 3 goes.  I highly recommend it!

Masters of Sex is a show about the famous 1950s study on human sexuality by Dr William Masters (played by Michael Sheen) and Virginia Johnson (played by Lizzy Caplan).  It is a fictionalized version of the events surrounding the study, with true elements woven into the story.  Like most of the cable shows the season is relatively short, just 12 episodes, but it packs a lot of story lines into the season.  Some of them get resolved, some are left open and some are even cliffhangers leading into season 2.What makes the show work is the quality writing and acting.  Sheen is great as the sometimes distant, sometimes off-putting  often times arrogant and sometimes very emotional Masters.  He plays the character very buttoned up, but in the moments where he has to let loose with any kind of emotion he does it very well.  Likewise, Caplan is great as Johnson a mother of two, who has no qualifications to assist in a medical study yet, in part because of the controversial nature of the work, manages to get herself a position first as Master's secretary, then as an assistant.  The two have seemingly great chemistry and portray the ups and downs of the relationship between Masters and Johnson extremely well.  Aside from the two leads all the ancillary characters and the actors playing them are done almost perfectly.The show does a great job of capturing the backdrop of the 1950s, from the absurdity of the duck and cover nuclear drills, to women's role in society vs men's roles, a hint of the racial divide that existed then (and still does in some way today) and so on.  The show even explores the issue of homosexuality involving one of the main characters and his effort to "cure" himself.  It also explored the science vs society debate that is still raging today.The show does have a lot of sex and nudity in it, obviously, but it is not there just for the sake of having sex in the show.  But for some that will make them just as uncomfortable as it did back in the 50's so if you are one you probably will want to skip this.  While there certainly are some soap opera like elements to parts of the stories, that part is toned down quite a bit, so if you hate soap opera like shows, be they daytime or prime time, don't worry about this one.For those who get the blu ray set, the show looks and sounds great.  For extras there are deleted scenes for select episodes, and making of and behind the scenes material spread across the three discs.  Probably about an hours worth of extras all totaled.  Enough to keep those who like going through the bonus material happy.  If you have heard great things about the show but have not yet checked it out, I would definitely recommend it.

This is a program designed to get you ready for the more intense workouts that beachbody offers.  Mostly to get you ready for the P90x series, but it could, for some people be a lead up to a program like Insanity, if you get to the point where you can really push yourself in the cardio workouts.  It is great for absolute beginners or for people who have fallen too far out of shape to jump right back in to a higher intensity workout.Like the P90X workouts this is a three-phase program.  A, B and C.  The great part about this program is that all the workouts for one phase are on a single disc, so you do not have to keep swapping discs in an out, aside from the Saturday Special disc, which is the last workout of the week.  Each phase has a resistance workout (Sculpt A, B and C), a Cardio workout (Sweat A, B and C) and an Ab ripper workout.  In every workout there is a low impact modifier that you can follow if you are a true beginner or very out of shape, and a higher impact/intensity modifier that you can follow if you are in great shape, then one person doing the "regular" workout.One good thing about this program is that if you hate all the pull ups in P90x, this one has no pull ups at all.  Everyone, including the higher intensity modifier uses bands for the pull up type moves.  The low impact modifier uses bands for every non-pushup resistance moves, where the others use free weights.  There is no stretch or yoga DVD with this set (although depending on where you get it, it may come with the P90X3 Dynamix workout which is kind of a moving stretch workout, but there are some yoga moves incorporated into the program itself.  The workouts in the first month are all very short, under 30 min including the cool down.  The ab ripper program in the first month is about 8 minutes.The second month the workout times increase to just over 30 minutes each including the cool down.  The ab ripper program in the second month adds 5 more moves to the original 10 from month 1, so you are doing the same moves as in Ab Ripper A, with just a few more added in.  In month three the workouts are about 45 minutes including cool down.  The Ab ripper program add a couple more moves on the end so it ends up being just under 15 minutes.You have the option of following a strength program which basically means doing the Sculpt workouts 3 times a week, or a more cardio based program where you to the Sweat workouts 3 times a week.  The final Saturday special workout is a more cardio based program that works in some flexibility and ab work as well.  In the resistance programs every move set is 16 repetitions, so you will be using lighter bands or weights for the most part.  The max amount you would likely need in terms of free weights are 25lbs if you are very strong, to do some of the bicep and shoulder exercises.  My weight ranges went from about 10lbs for some of the shoulder exercises, to 25lbs for the arc presses.  Mostly though I stayed in the 10-15lb range and a medium band for most of the band moves and was still able to get a very good workout.The big con for the program is that it does not stick with the shorter (30 min max) workouts that most of their recent programs have been.  But when compared against the length of the original P90X workouts, this is still far under the time commitment required for most of those.  It also comes with a pretty easy meal plan guide for those who want to follow the meal plan and not go with their own nutrition plan.  Finally on the Sculpt workouts every move is shown for about 23-30 seconds before the set starts so you can see proper form both for the modifier and the "regular" version.All in all it is a very good program that anyone, of any fitness level can use.  It may be a little too easy for those who are ultra fit, but you can tailor it to some extent.  For those who are a beginner and/or out of shape I would highly recommend it.

This was a movie that could have been very good, or very bad, depending on whether it was done right.  Fortunately, it was and the result was a very fun, and funny action movie.The story revolves around the formation of Marvel's "B Team" of heroes, or as the Honest Trailer calls them, Space Avengers.  It is set in the Marvel Universe, so while superheroes exist none of the guardians have powers.  The closest is Groot, who is a 7 foot plus tall tree looking thing.  There is some cross-over with the other films as well.  Thanos, who was last seen in the end credits to Avengers plays another background bad guy in this one, and the collector who was in Thor 2 also makes an appearance.The story revolves around an orb which is more powerful than most know.  It is in fact another infinity stone which can destroy almost anything (or anyone) who touches it.  Chris Pratt's Star Lord/Peter Quill character, who ends up the leader of the group, is basically a thief hired to steal the orb.  Which sets off a huge galactic chase leading to the end battle with Ronan the Accuser, played by Lee Pace.What makes these characters interesting is that even the good guys are not all good.  And they all have very different motives.  Drax is after Ronan on a mission of revenge, Gamora is an assassin for Thanos wanting to get away from him, Rocket, Groot and Quill are basically all bounty hunters in it for the money.  But what separates them from everyone else is when they need to do the right thing to save each other, and stop the bad guy, they do.Like I said in the beginning, this was totally a movie that could have bombed.  Considering 2 of the main characters were totally CGI, and one was an ex-wrestler who was never known to have what passes for good acting skills even in the world of pro wrestling, it could have gone bad quickly.  Luckily they wrote Drax's lines totally deadpan and made his character so monotone and serious that Bautista really did not have to do much other than be big and scary.  And the animators did so well with the CGI characters, that unlike how they would have looked back at the beginning of the CGI craze, they did not look fake or out of place at all.  Bradley Cooper brought great life to a wisecracking smart-a** racoon and the animators did such a great job giving Groot a personality, it ended up being Vin Diesel's best acting performance yet despite him only repeating the same line over and over.For those who get the discs, the movie sounds and looks great on blu ray.  I did not watch the 3D version, but the regular version was flawless.  As far as extras go, they pretty well mirror what was on Thor 2 and Captain America 2.  A couple behind the scenes and making of features, deleted and extended scenes, a gag reel, and short look at the making of Avengers 2.The movie does have a Star Wars meets Marvel Universe feel to it.  Or even more appropriately Spaceballs meets Marvel Universe feel.  It is as much a comedy as it is an action/adventure movie, and both aspects work very well.  If you are a fan of the other Marvel movies and are in any way on the fence about this one, I definitely think it is worth checking out.

The Dark world is a continuation of Thor and Loki's story after the events of The Avengers. Loki is brought back to Asgard and thrown in prison. Christopher Eccleston plays the lead bad guy Malekith, who is trying to not only bring down Asgard, but gain power over the 9 realms by taking advantage of the realms converging. Thor ends up breaking Loki out of prison to help him track down Malekith.Of course the movie is heavy on action and special effects, which look and sound great on blu ray. They tell enough of a story and do try to in a sense resolve the Thor/Loki storyline (at least from one of the character's standpoint), and also did a good job with, at least for the first part of the movie, avoiding the question of why not just get the Avengers to help? Theoretically they could have assisted in the final battle, but in the Asgard and Dark World battles there was no way for them to get there. That said, Captain America does make a pretty hilarious cameo.The movie also rekindles the Jane/Thor relationship as he continues struggling between his duties to Asgard and his feelings for her. Kat Dennings and Stellan Skarsgrd reprise their roles, but neither are really given much to do. Dennings is really there for comic relief, which she does well, and to an extent Skarsgrd is as well. While Jane is central to the plot, there are times when she cannot do anything because she is basically sitting on the sidelines of battles between essentially immortal beings (at least as compared to her).By this point you really have to look at the Marvel Movies (and even to some extent Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D) as one big intertwined story. This definitely had the feel of a filler movie to get to Avengers 2, where we know more will happen. Unlike Winter Soldier, which I think was on par with, if not better than First Avenger for Captain America's story, I do not think this worked as well as the first Thor movie. Partly because I think the fish-out-of water, god with no power on Earth thing had a great comedic element that this movie did not, and could not based on the story. That said, if you are a fan of the genre and the whole "Marvel Universe" movies I think it is worth checking out.For those who get the actual disc, as I said, the movie looks and sounds great on Blu Ray. For bonus features there is a mockumentary on The Mandarin (the villain from Iron Man III) that was included here for some reason. Then a multi-part making of/behind the scenes feature on the movie and the story. A first look at Captain America 2, a gag reel, deleted scenes and a feature on scoring the movie. All in all, good for what is there, with about an hour plus worth of extra content.

This is not a traditional television series.  It is really a mini-series or a 10 part movie, that has a beginning middle and end.  There is no thought of this story continuing over another season, which definitely worked for the story they were trying to tell.Like the 1997 movie it took its title from and was paying homage to, the show is a completely made up "true" story.  Using the same "This is a True Story..." opening from the movie.  It is set in MN, but unlike the movie was not actually filmed there.  This time set in the small town in North Cetral MN called Bemidji and the slightly less Northern and Eastern town of Duluth. To those of us who know the area, it is comical when they had the characters making a quick drive from one town to the other, when in reality it is a good 4 hr trip between the two.The story was centered around Lester Nygaard played by Martin Freeman, who at first glance is mirroring the character of Jerry from the movie.  We come to realize however that Lester is much more cagey and slick than Jerry ever was.  But he does start out as a bullied loser.  He runs into Lorne Malvo played wonderfully by Billy Bob Thornton, who is a bad guy almost in the Anton Chigur vein from No Country in that he is a hit man, but his motivation is more personal than it ever is for money.  For Malvo it is messing with people (especially the weak and/or stupid) and bringing out their dark side.  Lester is in a sense infected by Malvo, and becomes more and more of a bad guy as the series plays out.Allison Tolman and Colin Hanks play cops (one from Bemidji and one from Duluth) trying to crack the murder mystery involving Lester and Lorne.  Molly is about the only cop in Bemidji who has any sense of what is going on, and her investigation is impeded at all turns by the moron of a chief played by Breaking Bad alum Bob Odenkirk.  Hanks Plays Gus, an actual lovable loser character who first comes into contact with Malvo, and then almost becomes consumed with catching him.There are actually several stories going on at one time, which all end up interacting at points because they either involve Lester, or Malvo or both.  The only story that ties to the movie itself is that of grocery story kingpin Stavros Milos, which involves discovery of the ransom money buried in the movie.  Aside from that the series is treated separate from the movie, although there are several places where the series is paying homage to the movie (by having similar scenes) as well as many of the other Cohen brother's movies.What makes it work is the great writing and acting.  The writer of the series Noah Hawley was able to capture the feel of the movie without just blatantly copying it or making a spoof of it.  The show definitely belonged in that universe, but was its own animal, and while it was also had elements of dark comedy like the movie did, I think it was far more of a drama than the original movie was.  And even though the over the top Scandinavian accent and dialogue was there (done very well by Martin Freeman through the entire show and hilariously by Billy Bob Thornton for part of an episode) it was actually very toned down in the show.For those who get the discs themselves, the show looks and sounds great on blu ray.  For extras there are commentary tracks on three episodes. Two of them have Hawley and Thornton and the third has Hawley and Tolman.  Then there are a couple making of and behind the scenes features on the third disc and deleted scenes on all three discs.  Definitely enough to keep the people who like going through bonus material happy.Like the movie it is not for everyone.  It is very quirky and offbeat.  It is very violent in parts, and has as much swearing and nudity as a non premium channel cable show can put in there.  But if you are a fan of the movie, this is definitely worth checking out.

++Warning++ there are minor spoilers in the review summarizing the plot.  Most likely nothing who is looking at this now does not already know, but if you have not seen the movie you may want to skip the first paragraph.Fargo is a very quirky, very dark blend of comedy, drama and suspense. It tells the story of a local doofus, Jerry Lundegaard, played brilliantly by William H Macy, who is a used car salesman in Minneapolis running a scam operation. He hatches a plot to have his wife kidnapped, and plans to split the supposed 80k (really 1 million dollar) ransom with the kidnappers. Things go wrong when the kidnappers start murdering people, and the whole plan unravels.Like is the case with most of the Cohen Brother's movies, the quality writing and acting makes it work. The comedy comes in mainly with the over the top accents the characters had (and yes there are people in MN that have that accent, but usually not that pronounced), and how the kidnappers keep messing things up.Steve Buscemi and Peter Stormare play great polar opposite bad guys, one who won't shut up, the other who barely says anything, but both not above killing anyone in their way. The highlight of the movie is Francis McDormand playing the very pregnant police officer Marge Gunderson.For those who get the blu ray, the movie looks and sounds about as good as a movie that old can. As far as special features go, there is a commentary track on the film by the director of photography, a 27 minute documentary on the making of the film, a trivia track, the trailer and TV Spot. Not a ton of material, but good for what is there.Most people looking at this have likely seen the movie multiple times, or the recent TV show by the same name on FX. If you have seen the show, but not the movie, it had a very similar tone and theme to the movie. And sharp eyed viewers will note a tie in to the movie involving the ransom money. Like most Cohen brother's films it will not fit everyone's taste, but if you are a fan of any of their others, or have not seen the movie in a long time, this is definitely worth adding to your collection.
Paired up with the Bissell Spot Clean portable cleaner, this saves our carpets on a regular basis.

This movie bored me to death. This felt like being a fly on the wall as this movie moved through years in the life of this kid and his flawed family. Sorry, but I want more from a film than just observing life going by.

I use this as a small serving platter instead of as a dinner plate. The white goes with any pattern dinnerware and also fits easily inside the microwave. Quite versatile.

K-cup convenience, and tea in seconds. Perfect!

I had to leave my beloved coffee alone for personal reasons and had a terrible time not having a comfy mug of something hot with breakfast. I decided to try this through my Keurig machine. To get closer to my coffee, I add a little milk (as I had it in London) and a spoon of organic honey. I have become a convert.

Mysteries are a very popular genre. They are, however, often not written well. A good mystery requires more than suspense in order to be a satisfying read. We have all read debut novels that feel like reading someones homework from a writing class - flat characters, overuse of cliches, and uninteresting secondary characters. This is NOT that kind of book. This story is layered, complex, is well paced, and all the supporting characters are drawn well, And who doesn't love an injustice rectified? I am pleased to say I will be looking for more books from this new author.

If you have ever lived with a cat, they can be both wonderful and mysterious folk. I love reading about what some of their behaviors really mean. After all...they are not us, and we must not assume we understand them just because we seem to understand our dog.
They do exactly what they are supposed to do.

I read this book many decades ago. They say a book impacts your life depending on when you read it. The nation was discussing the rights of women, the hypocrisy flung at women regarding their sexuality, the effects upon women's lives as they were beginning to have access to reliable birth control. I remember this book further fanning those flames for me as I was still in high school. Now I want to read it again with more of an eye to understanding and appreciating why it has been an enduring piece of literature, and for that I wanted a bit of a guidebook as I take it in once more. This was exactly what I needed.
A stylist started me on this shampoo to help with my slightly thinning hair. Her salon stopped carrying this line, so I was happy to find it here. It is, however, expensive.

This is my fourth planner. These run with the academic year, from July to the following June. Each month has a grid layout like a calendar. The pages are full size, so each day's block has plenty of room to put a note, such s when the college has closures, grading dates, etc, and I can plan around them. Additionally, there are pages where each day is listed, with room to put data there as well. I primarily use the grid so I can figure out the schedule of classes for each semester and plot where I am going to place my tests. Since I am tracking more than one course for online students, this gives me a great visual guide as to where each group is within the semester. This is open on my desk at all times.

Have you ever read a book where you feel the author was fully engaged in the story, then at some point they just let it peter out? This struck me like that. Up to the point where a crisis happens with the mother of the family, Abby Whitshank, I was engaged. After the crisis, I found it harder to care about finishing the book. The difference was not Abby. Rather, the Whitshank family just unspools; goes nowhere.The book covers three generations: Red and Abby, Red's parents -- Junior and Linnie Whitshank -- and Red and Abby's children, all wrapped around the nexus of the house on Bouton St., Baltimore.The main character of the book, in many ways, is the house on Bouton St. Built by Red's father, Junior Whitshank, for wealthy client. Junior covets the house and finds an underhanded way to obtain it. Tyler does a good job helping you feel the nearly obsessive focus Junior develops about the house and the social standing one acquires living at such an address. Two thirds of the way through the book Tyler uses the device of going back in time to illuminate more about Red's parents, and how their image of themselves became tied to the house on Bouton St. For Junior it is a bit of an arrival, in his mind achieving a status he always deserved, while for Red's mother, Linnie, it takes her away from friends and a way of being where she is more comfortable. A front porch is a house's most public face, and the non-verbal war Junior and Linnie have over the appearance of the porch's swing (Junior insisting it be a sophisticated natural stain, whereas Linnie changes it to a friendly Swedish blue, causing Junior to have it stripped back to natural again) exemplifies how each wants to see their future life within the house's walls. This part of the story should lead us to understanding Red more clearly, and yet it doesn't. You expect Red to either fiercely love his parents' house, that he inherits, or want to flee. Instead it is all handled in a tepid fashion. Life just goes on.The story lines of Red, the 2 sons, Denny and Stem, continue to be only sketchily drawn. Without getting a better handle on Stem's background, an orphan brought into the family as a toddler, it makes it harder to understand the dynamic between Stem and Denny, let alone between all the Whitshank children. Abby and Red's 2 daughters seem like after thought characters. In many ways, beginning with Junior and Linnie, the characters proceed from being vibrant, even funny, to more and more faded as the generations unfold. At the level of Red and Abby's children, I really did not care about any of them anymore. Linnie's Swedish blue had faded to grey.

Let me start with the positive. I am always in favor of illuminating the horrors of our grandmother's era regarding the utter control men - fathers, husbands, doctors - had over the destiny of the women in their lives, and the laws that supported them. And we never shed enough light upon the abuses within the mental health facilities at the beginning of the 20th century. I appreciate Ms. Wiseman's research into the Willard State Hospital; what she revealed is both startling and sickening.I also do not have an issue with the story's overall device, that of following two characters, sequential in time, then bringing their stories together in the final chapters, even if I found the wrap up highly unlikely and quite saccharine. What I do have problems with is stilted unimaginative writing.We readers, after all, choose the medium of the written word because we enjoy it. In addition to plot, good writing is a bit like visiting a fine arts museum. You will never appreciate the wonder of what is before you unless you can fully enjoy the skillfllness of the technique. I want more than an interesting tale, and more than a wrong revealed. That could be done with a newspaper or magazine article. If I am to spend my time with someone's book, I also expect him or her to demonstrate their craftsmanship through the language they choose.When I began to loose track of how often both main characters (Clara whom we meet in 1929, and Izzy in the present) each responded to anxiety, fear, and distress of any sort with "her stomach clenched", or "she dug her nails into her palm", I began to find my own jaw clench. Surely a good writer could offer we readers variation and imagination. When the exact same phrasing is used over and over, it becomes thoroughly distracting. I found myself growling, "Really, we're clenching again?" Just as bad, all the secondary characters in the story are rendered in a completely flat manner, having no depth or complexity, no self-reflection or internal tension. I finished the book mostly out of pure stubbornness to recoup at least something from the purchase price.My opinion of this book may have suffered by my having recently read another historic novel that uses a very similar device, that of following two characters during World War II, children on opposite sides of the conflict, letting us follow them in alternating chapters. Where the books differ profoundly is in the subtlety and artistry with which they are written. All the Light We Cannot See by Anthony Doerr was a delight on every page. The main characters, as well as the supporting cast, were never drawn in simple back/white ways. You understand their heroism and flaws equally. Moreover, Doerr finds ways to be surprising, inventive and fresh at every turn.It seems to me the whole point of writing, particularly fiction, is to be read, offering the reader far more than story. Truly good books remind us that writing is an art form, language being the brush. Wiseman's What She Left Behind may have been informative regarding terrible wrongs committed upon vulnerable women who were, in some cases, nothing more than disobedient, but her job is writing. As readers, I think we deserve much more.

Like most folks here, we love this movie. We've watched it several times on TV, but getting our blu-ray player inspired us to buy a copy. Gee! We had forgotten the scenes snipped out of the TV showings. They were great fun to see again. And like many people who find the sound track a walk down memory lane, hearing it through our Klipsch 5.1 system and seeing it in blu-ray HD was a blast.

We live in a sub-division without street lamps. We've been looking for a flashlight that throws great light without being cumbersome. We liked this so much we now have them placed around the house for those pesky power failures in bad storms. Their size makes them so easy to fit in any drawer. Great product.

My husband and I brewed three different k-cup de-cafs, then did a blind taste test. We both had this one as our first choice, beating out a Vermont blend and a Sumatra. Stands up very well to milk/creamer, keeping it's full body.
Rich, round and smooth with low acidic after-bite. Rare to find a full bodied de-caf ---this is a winner!

When I was gagged by the sweetness of this drink, I went looking on the box for ingredients. They are listed in this order: coconut oil, corn syrup, fructose, dextrose, sugar - before it goes on to list other things. That's all sugars and oil!I fell it's important to point out that this particular product should NOT be taken as typical of Timothy's other offerings. We LOVE Timothy's Columbian de-caf as well as some of their tea offerings.

We bought the special edition mostly because of the mug size versatility plus the experience we had with a friends machine. Whenever I stop by, she and I catch up over a hot cup of coffee/tea/hot chocolate - whichever one each of us chooses and the other can have whatever they want too. My husband and I were willing to go out to the Keurig website and get a wide variety of coffees, teas and a couple of hot chocolates to try so that we can focus on what we like the best. Here's where the versatility is such a plus. We don't even have to compromise on one brand/type of coffee. My husband is happy with Caribou Co.'s Sumatra, whereas my perfect cup is Timothy's Columbian. When we want tea in the evening, he reaches for a Twinning's herbal and I want a different company's Chai Latte. Additionally we can choose from china cup size, small mug and a larger mug with this model. (Some models do not let you pick mug size). And last but not least, there is no more worrying if we remembered to shut off the coffee maker when we're out: this one can be programmed for auto shut off.And one more comment. Another reviewer remarked on the packaging waste of the K-cups. It's true you are throwing out a cup each time, but there are waste issues with standard makers as well: filters, grinds, the original packages the coffee came in and all that brewed coffee that goes down the drain when a pot is not finished. Just a thought.

My dog's nails are solid black and I occasionally misjudge when cutting them. I tried a gel variety but found it messy to use. With this you can put a little in the cap and if you nick the nail's quick you just press the nail end into the powder and it stops the bleeding right away.

I've used Snap 'N Store boxes in other sizes for other purposes as well. These hold exactly 26 DVDs in their cases without a problem. A couple of reviews mentioned the snaps coming undone while handling the boxes. My suggestion: if you don't plan on disassembling them again, put a dot of super glue on the snaps as you assemble them.By the way, if you are not familiar with them, they ship flat and snap together in seconds.

If you love your dog, if you love speed in a zen-like way, and especially if you have ever lost a close family member to cancer, you will be glued to this story. I guess my reaction to this book is very personal. We lost our only child to cancer when she was just five. Our dog would not leave her side and neither would our Main Coon. Those two animals were a steady force in her life and a tremendous source of comfort when she was gone. Sometimes when I felt overwhelmed I would go for long drives and I must admit there were times when speed did something strange--rather than being exciting, it calmed me, it made me concentrate, forcing me to feel the car as if it were alive. It took me somewhere else. The author really gets all of that. Stein has the dog Enzo explain this and more. Having the book written through Enzo's point of view allowed Stein to set much of his imagination free to great effect. Through Enzo we get to laugh at his frustration of missing thumbs (dexterity), we smell tragedy coming through his senses, we feel the rage at circumstances to the point where we would like to jaw-snap at some of the characters. There is more than one way to lose a child. Enzo's grief of his master's losing custody of his child is a completely different way of exploring the raw edges of a man's sensibilities when a family is torn apart. And in many ways this is also a buddy-story, a not always perfect relationship. I loved it so much I pressed my husband, who rarely chooses novels, to read it.Is this the best book ever? No. Did it grab me? You betcha. Hard. That's more than enough.

I have always wanted to own a vibrator like this and now I have one that exceeds all expectations.I received this item at a reduced rate in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

I have been struggling to lose weight for about a year now and it is so hard to rely on whether or not my clothes start fitting better. I invested in a very expensive scale that was supposed to measure my body fat but honestly, how can it? Not everyone's body is proportioned the same way. I have been using a regular measuring tape for about a month now and it is hard to hold and measure sometimes. I decided to order this Ozeri Body Tape and Body Fat Test Caliper and now I am having much better success with monitoring my overall body fat.The tape measure is easier to hold than just a plain tape measure by itself. The tape measures up to 78 inches and has push-button locking so that you can keep your place. Push the button again and the tape measure will retract so there is no more rolling it up by hand! The caliper is easy to use as well. Make sure that you have it pulled all the way out to 2 1/2 or else you might risk breaking the plastic.My only complaint about this product is that the caliper is a little thin. I am afraid that it might break because it is so fragile.I received this item at a  reduced rate in exchange for my hones and unbiased review.

I am obsessed with these yoga pants. I am used to paying almost $45 for good quality yoga pants at Victoria's Secret/Pink but now I don't have to waste all of that money. These yoga pants are just as good, if not better, than the name brand yoga pants that I normally buy. They are so comfortable and so soft. They are thick enough to wear them outside of the house and not look like a bum.I wear a size 16 in jeans and ordered an XL. They fit perfectly. Another plus to these yoga pants is that the band at the top provides a little bit of slimming action around my stomach. I love anything that makes me look skinnier! They are stretchy and I can move in them. I don't feel like I have to stuff myself into them or feel restricted with them on.I would highly recommend these yoga pants. I am even considering more in different colors.I received this item complimentary in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

I love this ring holder. It is so cute! I have a little chubby cat so I figured this chubby cat ring holder would fit me well. It is heavy enough to hold five of my wedding rings/bands so it can definitely take the weight.I would highly recommend this cat ring holder for anyone who is looking to keep their rings safe and dry. :)

I ordered this pillow case for my best friend. She loves all things giraffes. I ordered this armband for my brother. He just has to have his phone in his hands regardless of what he is doing. I have been using the libido enhancer supplement for almost a month now. This tape is very sticky! We were using some other brand of rug tape that just wasn't holding up. It didn't even last half a day before it started to lose its grip. This is a great-lightweight flashlight. We use it in cases of emergencies or if we are out walking our dog at night. It is very bright. My pup LOVES these treats! We put them in a container by the door so that they're ready for her when she's ready to outside and do her potties. She will do anything for these treats. I love that there aren't a whole lot of terrible ingredients in these treats.

This skillet was easy to put together right out of the box. It is deep and can hold and entire bag of one of those frozen Voila meals without any issue. The handle does not get hot at all when you are cooking. That was an issue I was running into with my old skillet and I have not had that issue at all with this new Utopia Kitchen skillet. So far it is cooking evenly but it is only a matter of time before my husband does something to mess that up :) We don't put our skillet in the dishwasher unless we absolutely have to but it does hold up to the sponge and hasn't been scratched. There's nothing chipping off yet. It is super easy to clean and it makes my life so much easier when it doesn't take 20 minutes to scrub it clean like it did my old skillet. I can't say enough good things about this skillet. I would highly recommend this skillet for your kitchen. We desperately needed a new one and I am considering purchasing another.I received this item a reduced rate in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

I ordered the socks that look like they have flowers on them and boy did they come at just the right time. I was sitting in my living room just as the storms were rolling in and I was freezing. I'm one of those people who refuses to turn on the heat until I absolutely need to so the second these socks arrived in my mail box I put a pair on my feet and I was satisfied. They kept my toes nice and warm. They come up about two-three inches above my ankles so they would be the perfect pair of socks to wear with my boots because they won't show. The material isn't too thick or too thin. Just the right amount of thickness to keep your warm enough during this fall weather.Another thing to point out that I really appreciated, was the packaging. Each individual pair of socks were packaged and labeled. I loved it! It just added a cute touch to an item. It wasn't like something you would buy in a store where everything is just clipped together with one boring label tacked onto it. It's just the extra little details that matter to me. The actual style of the socks fits my personality to a T. My husband says I have the style of an old lady sometimes and that's just fine with me. I would definitely recommend adding these stylish socks to your fall wardrobe.I received this item a reduced rate in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

I tried for a good hour to try to set this camera up and it couldn't get it to work. I followed the instructions exactly. I will try to get my husband to set it up and maybe he will have better luck. I ordered this silicone wedding ring set for my husband. I wanted him to have the option of trying on a variety of sizes so that he could wear the one that fits best. My husband has a tungsten wedding band but it is all scratched up after wearing it to work. The silicone wedding band hasn't scratched that I've noticed and they fit perfectly. I love sports bras and this one has become one of my top 3 favorites to wear. I will say that I am 36DDD and I wasn't anticipating this fitting as well as it did. It was comfortable the entire time that I wore it and I didn't feel like I was suffocating while wearing it.I ordered the blue and pink sports bra. The blue is a cute, bright, and playful shade of blue. It adds a nice splash of color to my workout tank tops. It has built in "pockets" to hold the padding/liner for the bra. This van cover ripped as soon as we tried to put it on. We were just trying to save some money and decided to order this brand even after reading the reviews... Won't make that mistake again.

My issue with these sheets and pillow cases is the inconvenient placement of the tags. Tags don't belong at the top of the flat sheet where it can touch you while you're sleeping. Hopefully they still fit well after being washed.I received this item at a  reduced rate in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

It was a little bigger than I was expecting but it does what it's supposed to do. It clasps on very easily and I can do it by myself rather than having to get my husband to do it for me. I ordered the correct size (XL) but it did not help smooth my curves out like I was expecting it to. It does help alleviate the sagging stomach issue a little but not enough to make a big difference.
