Overall though, this is an excellent mechanical keyboard which I'd buy again, I'm reducing this to four stars because of this minor, recurring annoyance.This is perfect for use as a home computer keyboard, I do not find the "click" overly loud or obnoxious, it did not scare the cats as one reviewer reported. What I particularly like is that it has a quality feel, weight and finish. It won't go sliding around on the desk and has fold-out feet to elevate it slightly if desired. This is best described as an off-white, it's neither blindingly white nor noticeably beige. The frame is glossy but shouldn't show fingerprints.I looked at its "quiet" brother, the Mini Quiet Pro, but it only came in black and the negligible difference in sound wasn't worth $40 extra which was being charged at the computer store where I saw it. Curiously, this came with two identical USB cords, with mini connectors which plug into the center rear of the keyboard. Regular USB ports are on the right and left sides and they serve as extra outlets. My first use of the Matias Mini Tactical Pro has been a positive experience. Maybe because I "came of age" using mechanical typewriters and keyboards, this doesn't feel foreign or different.I like it.

This film is written/produced/directed by the sister of one of the victims, and it clearly has been made with passion and sympathy towards this predator's countless victims.  But there's so much that needed to be said, even if just briefly.  The evildoer spends thirty years traveling the world preying on small boys.  He has the wherewithal to shuttle them back and forth across continents, somehow avoiding any questions from authorities.  I would like to know how a seldom-employed high school dropout became wealthy enough for such a lifelong enterprise.  Were there sponsors behind his nefarious activities?  Maybe this should be a separate film and investigation in itself.  A star is deducted for not even thinking about this aspect.Another star is deducted for sloppy editing.  He's not a vice-"principle."  The eastern European country is not "Hungry."This is a modest, semi-professional effort, but it's from the heart.

The numerous positive reviews indicate this is a great remote, and I pretty much agree. The price cannot be beat, and this now eclipses my Logitech 650 which had previously been my "go to" remote. I've always been in search of a perfect remote, but there's no such thing. My primary need these days is a remote which has strong key illumination (ancient eyes) and logical key placement. The Inteset fulfills both those requirements. Because a previous review has exhaustively covered this remote's features, I won't go over every detail. But a few observations:Smiles:Strong Orange Key IlluminationEasy ProgramabilityTranslucent Keys Easily Glow When IlluminatedHas An Input Key Which Many Remotes LackPerfect Balance In Hand, Nests Softly In PalmFrowns:No Dedicated Illumination ButtonIllumination Stays On For Only Five Seconds (See Workaround)Buttons Have No Positive Feedback, They're Just Mushy FeelingPIP Buttons Take Up Too Much Real EstateToo Few Dedicated Device ButtonsIt's hard to understand why PIP buttons are included on the remote. Does anyone use PIP anymore? Did anyone ever? Wasted real estate which could have been devoted to other functions and/or enlarging the important keys. The lack of a dedicated light button is a major failing, one must push a random key to light the display, which could, presumably, initiate an unwanted command. And the five second illumination period scarcely gives you time to locate a key before the keys go dark. I accidentally found a solution: Briefly touching the "set" key in the upper left hand corner will light the display for ten seconds without initiating a command.The Inteset will control up to four devices, those who need more should be aware of this limitation. I have it programmed for a Samsung TV, Sony Receiver, Apple TV and Google Fiber DVR, the latter had to be programmed button-by-button since it is not included in the device code listing, not a failing, only a few cities have Google Fiber available.I should mention the Inteset remote was provided to me at no cost for review purposes.

This is a sturdy, well crafted safe which will be more than sufficient to protect you from a grab 'n snatch burglary.  I live in a large apartment complex and who knows how many pass keys are floating around.  This is being used to store small electronics and prescription medication, and it does its job quite well. I have this mounted to the inside wall of a kitchen pantry, with virtually no space around it to use a pry tool.Smiles:--Large, bright, segmented display--Three mounting holes both on the back and bottom, this makes for an immovable installation--When open, the door springs out about 1" which makes access easier, and also gives a quick visual open/closed status--The padding which is included is slightly heavier than included with my Viking safeFrowns:--No warning beep if safe is left unlocked.  This would only be applicable if used as a gun safe, and children were in the home--The mounting hardware enclosed is not what is depicted, what I received could not be used in a standard 3/8th inch drywall mounting.  No biggie, toggle bolts are easily purchased.--Common circular emergency key, reportedly easy to pick.  The Viking safe has a 4-sided key which would be more secure--Warranty !There is a standard one year warranty, but read closely.  To obtain repair or replacement of a defective unit, you must1.  Pay shipping to Barska (UPS quote:  $48)2.  Send them a check for return shipping ($40 or $50, it's quoted differently on two enclosed warranty cards)3.  Allow them 6-8 weeks to fix or replace the safe.I call this a "non-warranty warranty."  Requiring a customer to foot shipping costs both ways  makes almost it cheaper to buy a new safe, and this does not even take into account the potential extensive loss of use.  6-8 weeks? Do they send it back to China for repair?  Before addressing this issue in an Amazon review, I wrote Barska customer service asking them to verify my understanding of the warranty, the reply I received was pretty much incomprehensible, but my reading of the warranty seems to be spot on. UPDATE:  I did eventually receive an email from Barska customer service advising me that my interpretation of their warranty was correct.  Advice:  buy this under Amazon Prime so you can return it if it's dead out of the box or fails within the first 30 days.As far as comparison overall with my Viking safe, flip a coin, they both have plusses and minuses, neither towers over the other.  A thief would have to put time and energy into opening this, it will keep out all but the most determined bad guys.

I've had several cat lasers and this is the best, it has a slightly wider and brighter dot than others I've owned.  Curiously,  it comes in a presentation-type gift box, packaged more like an expensive pen than a cat toy.  It's metal and has an ample link for a key chain attachment.A fine value for the money.

This works perfectly on my Panasonic FZ200.  Surprisingly high quality and packaging.  Make sure when you plug the angle-end into the camera you push it hard, all the way in.  The plug will stop short, appear firmly in the camera, but it's not.  I think this may be one of the reasons for folks thinking the device doesn't work.My only negative observation, and it's a small one, is the softness and lack of affirmative "clicking" on the hand transmitter button.  But you'll learn how to use it quickly.  For the price, this is really a bargain.  Tip:  leave the connector cord permanently plugged into the receiver unit, if you lose it you'll never find a replacement, it looks like a proprietary cord.

There's not much left to say which hasn't been already covered.  What I did not know is that there is a tiny light on top which momentarily glows green/yellow/orange to indicate battery level.  This is clearly designed for exercise activities, don't be too concerned about a designer color because it will be very hard for anyone to see anyway.I have used this for eight hours and still have a good charge.  I have loaded 50 songs, I have no idea how many it will hold.  I did not have too much trouble uploading music from iTunes, it just took a couple of tries though.  No matter how the size is described, you'll be surprised at how small the Shuffle actually is.  I'm attaching a photo.The clothing clip seems firm enough, but I either double over the fabric or keep it in a top pocket, even if it comes unclipped, the earphone jack is so secure the Shuffle would just dangle from your earphone cords, it would be probably hard to lose.  All in all, this delivers nice, separated channels.  Just don't buy it with the expectation it will do anything other than play music.

This was extremely accurate out of the box.  The temperature was accurate to .1 degree, with reference to a high end Netatmo unit.  The humidity was off by 4%, which is within the mfg. specs.  I was able to calibrate it to 100% accuracy using a Boveda One Step Kit.The surprising thing is how responsive this thing is.  Just getting near it will change the readings, virtually instantly, no lag time.  I think the fact this has an exterior sensor makes it far more responsive than one which is built into the unit, which many are.A note on the picture.  It looks much larger than it is, which is 4.25"x4", I wanted to show detail so I got in close.

I am a long time weather buff and purchased this to calibrate temperature sensors.  I am amazed at its accuracy.  I tested it against two known temperatures sources, a high end Netatmo weather sensor (accuracy claimed to .5 of a degree) and the surface temperature of an ice water bath (33 degrees).  Both measurements were accurate to within .5 of a degree.Be advised this is for light duty use only.  If you drop it on a hard surface there will be a plastic explosion.  The included carrying case is of sturdy, firm canvas, with a belt loop, which will provide some protection.  A fine buy for the price.Oh yeah, your cats will like it too.

You will not find a better timer on the market.  Of course it costs more than others this size, but a lot of the other ones are smallish and the inaudible unless you are right beside them.  This is VERY loud, and the sound output can be adjusted to different levels.  A surprising bonus is strength of the magnet, the timer adheres to a refrigerator without any question about it falling off.This one gets an A+

UPDATE:  For reasons unknown, the readout on this phone has suddenly started reading:  "12 missed  calls" or "15 missed calls" or other random numbers when only one is received.  This takes away a very important feature.  I am moving my rating from five stars to three.  As this is a new business phone I can't afford to return it under warranty service, I need the answering function NOW.  Everything else seems to work okay.This is a really good phone for the price, you probably won't get a better deal anywhere.  It has several excellent features, primary among them is the setup.  Even an old coot like me could figure it out right away, the instructions are barely necessary.  Also nice is the fact the phone has dedicated buttons for each item on the answering part, there are no uni-buttons to control multiple features.  If you want to listen to your message, hit the "listen" button, "delete," hit the delete button, and so on.  The listen button flashes when a message is received, and pushing it plays the message also.  The LED panel is a nice orange, it comes on only when making or receiving a call, so your bedroom, if that is where you place it, isn't lighted up all the time.Smiles:  An adjustable display panel which flips up to make it easier to see when used on a table.  You can answer the phone by simply pushing the speaker button if desired  You can skip or replay messages by pushing independent buttons  The mute button can be used to put a caller on hold, no need for two buttonsFrowns:  While the phone will function in a power outage, none of the other features will.  Even worse, you will have to reprogram  the entire phone from scratch.  Ditto if you simply want to move the phone to another location.  A battery backup to hold  the programing would have been helpful.  I do not know if the answerer works in an outage, but I can't see why it would.  This may be difficult to wall mount, I was lucky and already had a phone mounting plate on the wall of my apartment, so it  was a snap.  Speaker quality is poor, scratchy, but easily audible.In conclusion, this is a great buy for the money, easy to use, easy to setup, and attractive also.

I'm writing this review under the assumption that a timer's main function is to alert the user that something has been completed, typically, your dinner is cooked.  I purchased this in high hopes I'd be able to hear it just a room away from the kitchen.  Wrong.  While the unit itself is easy to set and has good sized numerals, the beeper speaker is on the back.  It is smaller than a pencil eraser, and is about as loud as an alarm on a wrist watch.  The magnet seems to be strong enough to hold it on the fridge, but that completely blocks the speaker, which is on the back.  I guess I will just have to carry this to whatever room I'm working in, it has to be very close to hear it at all.I will give it two stars for numeral size and ease of setting, but this is a major failure as alerting device.  And the price is way too high, when you see it you'll know you got gypped.

This is quite possibly the best weather station I've ever owned, and I've owned MANY during my lifetime.  The digits are large, easy to read, and can be seen from across the room.  The backlighting can be adjusted to levels of brightness and it changes color at various temperature levels, i.e. from dark red at the hottest, 100+ to light violet at the lowest, 10-.  The warmer colors will indicate more comfortable temperatures, while the cooler temps will be indicated by progressively cooler colors.  You get an actual barometer reading, the graph is fairly useless because the blocks are too big and look clumsy.  This is an initial review, I will update as needed.Smiles:Fairly easy to set up.Has calibration feature to fine tune the unit.Records highs & lows, can be set to clear manually at midnight or within what ever time parameter you choose.Accuracy specified to +/- 1 degree, unusual for a consumer weather station, seems spot on so far.Instruction manual is neatly presented and laid out, just English.Dew point can be displayed, this is more "telling" than the actual humidity metric.An uncluttered bezel with large buttons and clear labels.Entire unit is LARGE making it easy to work with, the display is 5" H x 4.5" W.An excellent price point.  There's a lot of junk out there costing more with fewer features.  LaCrosse is a great example.Frowns:I found the instruction manual a bit confusing.  This may be due to the fact this unit has so many parameters and configurable settings.  Customer service answered an email question in just a few minutes though.The forecast is based solely on a barometer's rise or fall.  Some units claim a forecast based on algorithms taken from a 14-day sampling period.  No big deal, just don't plan a picnic around the forecast icon.I did not find an outdoor battery power indicator as described, perhaps it turns on only when the power is low.Temperature/barometer graph is so blocky it's hard to read.  It occupies too much space for too little value.These are my initial impressions, I will report back with an update after this has been in use for a few weeks.

A piece of advice from someone who spent 25 years handling auto claims, some of them catastrophic.  This tool seems to be marketed around the concept of a water escape.  The far more likely event is a car fire.  Some reviewers have placed this in the driver's door pocket.  Bad idea.In the case of a "T-Bone" crash the door will be jammed against the seat and the door pocket and the tool inaccessible.  You won't be able to open the door either.  It's best to find a place within arm's reach where the driver compartment will be less susceptible to crash deformation.While the tool looks up to the job, I am marking it down for the following reasons:  mounting instructions are poor, and three tiny screws are included, their use unknown and not addressed in the instructions.  They could not possibly be used to mount the holder onto any firm surface since they are so small they barely extend beyond the mounting bracket holes.  Perhaps longer, self tapping screws could hold this bracket to a hard surface.I used the included double sided tape, which is shaped like the bracket, to mount the tool to a piece of metal under the dash.  Time will tell if it holds, I'll update this review with the results later.  This hammer is probably no different from the others sold here, just think about a practical place to mount it, and that's not the door pocket.Update:  Just as I suspected, the double sided tape is worthless.  I used machine screws to mount it to the side of the fiberglass console, easy for those who are just the slightest bit handy.

Ipad 2 fits snug in this case, all of the holes align perfectly with the iPad's various openings.  Some have noted the clasp is a bit tight, which it is, but that will provide extra protection from it opening accidentally  when traveling.  For casual use, such as reading,  the case can be kept slightly ajar without snapping down the cover.  What works perfectly compared to larger composite covers is the auto shut off feature.  It is precise and does not have to be wiggled around to assure proper contact.  It works with the cover lightly closed so it does not have to be snapped down all the way to activate.  Incredibly, the case adds almost no width or length to the iPad itself.  It's hard to see the iPad is even in a case.  My only doubt is how much protection this case will afford if dropped.  If you are clumsy with your gadgets this may not be for you.  The case is beautifully finished, tight and sturdy, and while expensive, at least you feel like you got what you paid for.  An excellent product made in China, how rare is that???UPDATE 11/15/2012  While this remains a sturdy and solid case, I do have a complaint about the unfinished edges, and sharp openings.  I have to be extremely careful not to get my fingers or clothing anywhere near the edges or openings, a painful pinch or cut could result.  The case is so inflexible it almost acts like a guillotine.  After a month's use, this is a deal breaker, I need something more user friendly.
This windsock is just beautiful and well made.  It glows beautifully.  Made in the U.S., it would be treason to buy an American flag from China!

Ken Park is a competently made effort, production values are acceptable and acting is adequate given the paltry script.  As noted by previous reviewers, the film is about youthful alienation in a small California town.  But everybody's alienated, even the parents.  There's a personality to fit every situation, from the super religious to closeted homophobe.  The kids and the parents  are screwed up of course, and the film spends its 90 minutes attempting to illustrate this without ever letting us know how they got that way, or showing us a path out.  I guess we are supposed to assume that society made them that way, which then makes  the film a snapshot of that culture at that time, with no narrative meat on its bones.There isn't much else worthy of comment except the extensive sexual situations, which propel the plot around in a circle rather than straightforward.  The female actors are attractive and easy on the eyes.  The boys are another matter.  Each is skinny, ugly and presumably  a drug addict in real life.  There are open sexual acts, the camera doesn't flinch, but if you are looking for a hardcore skin flick the internet can give you more with much better eye candy.  The real porn is in the dialogue.  I'm sure it's accurate given the extreme sexual situations, but it's jarring nonetheless.In summary, this is a string of vignettes looking for a plot, pushed forward by the  unsympathetic characters who populate the film. If you are looking for a good Larry Clark film try Bully, a film with similar trappings as Ken Park that knows how to advance a plot toward a real and scary finale.  Ken Park is a curiosity piece which is not  worth the time or the money.

I first saw this film when I was on R&R from Vietnam in 1970.  It was in Waikiki, Honolulu which was full of hippies and drug dealers.  Given the anti-war sentiment at the time, I was surprised to find a theater full of these types who loved Patton.  This is one of the few "war" movies which does not glorify it.  Most films fade in time as they have little relevance to generations which follow.  This film is perfect as the first time I saw it a lifetime ago.  George C. Scott was so into his role I've always believed he actually thought he WAS Patton.  A classic for everyone, for all time.

I can't review this movie fully because I was unable to get past the first half hour.  It looks like it was filmed with an old 8mm movie camera, the sound track is inaudible.  Your time is money, don't waste either on this tripe.

I am now retired and have spent my life traveling, always searching for a leak proof commuter bottle.  As with many others, I first bought my bottles at Costco, long since discontinued there.  I have since bought some from Amazon and they are perfect.  I'm using one as I write this review.  They have NEVER leaked after 2+ years of use every day.  These fit fine in my car cup holder, but a word of caution, the 32oz bottles do not.  Too bad these were not made 40 years ago. . .
This watch is as pretty as pictured and even comes with a spare battery, I've never seen that before!  If you like the look and the price you won't be disappointed.

0:41 MinsProbably everything has already been said about this wind spinner, so I'll try to add some pointers which may be helpful.1.  Absolutely seal this, I would advise Permalac Clear Satin, it's made specifically for copper.  It is available from ArtChemicals on the West Coast.  It shipped the day I ordered it and was delivered in three working days.  It costs $38.35 delivered, expensive, but don't get cheap, you have a beautiful work of art to protect.2.  The Permalac comes in a spray can and you can use the packing boxes as a spray backstop.  It is ULTRA important to spray this in a well ventilated location.  A garage is perfect, just keep the door open at least halfway.  The fumes are flammable so be careful to stay away from an ignition source, the pilot light on a water heater is easy to overlook.  The Permalac has about enough for two applications, front and back.  Let it dry an hour between applications.  The tubes are solid copper so don't forget them.3.  When installing the vertical support tubes, use a level to make sure they are absolutely on the bubble vertically.  I mounted mine on a fence since the ground here is too hard and rocky to even penetrate an inch.  It was easy to get it perpendicular this way.4.  Make sure the support tubes are very tightly screwed together.  The top tube will be slightly crooked otherwise.5.  Even if you want to make the neighbors jealous, do not mount this anywhere that copper thieves can get it, namely the front yard.  This type of crime is fairly new, they strip vacant houses, a/c units, even street lights, all for drug money.6.  Lastly, enjoy this!  Take the necessary preparatory steps, don't rush things, and you will find this more gorgeous than anyone has described.

I want to say I am only a few pages into this book and it is difficult to read, not because of the subject matter ( I haven't ventured that far yet) but because of the incredibly poor writing, editing and proofreading.  One error which shows up in every paragraph is "track housing," instead of "tract housing."  There are changes in tense from sentence to sentence, repeated punctuation errors, grammar and spelling are nonexistent.  This book looks like a third grader typed it with his feet.  As a writing rule, simple sentences can be powerful sentences, read: To Kill a Mockingbird.  Every sentence here  is almost a fragment, "I went to my desk.  I sat down."  I have a background in copyediting, so the errors here jump off the page at me, but you may find this book impossible to read even  if you have only basic high school English.  I was interested in the subject matter, not any prurient material, but this book is so terribly hard to read it may end up in the trash before I finish chapter one, assuming there are chapters.  The two sentence description on the cover even has six errors.Update:  Further checking, this got on the market via a "vanity" publisher, wherein the so-called author has to pay to have it published.  Rates start at $899.  Amazon, how could you be a party to such swill?  At least take a look at it before you market such trash.  Shame, shame!!!!!!!Further Update:  After reading further into this garbage, it is strictly written as a novel, not as an expose or documentary as the cover would have you believe.  The boy, a 3rd grader, is constantly subjected to medieval type torture:  rack, whips & chains, even crucifixion  hanging by his arms while being whipped by adults.  When he goes home his mother beats him bloody, several times a chapter.  He is gang raped by 16 men.  Also beaten almost to death by high schoolers.  Were this a true story it might have some social value, however slight.  Instead it is kiddie porn without the pictures.  Impossibly, the narrative seems to try and make us believe the boy enjoys it, or at least puts up with it, for money and gifts.  I have filed two complaints with Amazon about this and heard nothing.  How they could miss and publish vile sadistic trash like this is beyond all comprehension.  It will not do anything for you but send you to the bathroom to put your head in the toilet.

This film is taken from a stage play by John Patrick Shandly, and unfortunately he also wrote the screenplay for Doubt.  From the beginning we can see something is missing, the head nun's suspicions arise suddenly without time for exposition.  For anyone who had the misfortune to go to a Catholic grade school during this era (me) this film will bring back memories, most of them not good.  The ending purports to be dramatic, but it is ambiguous and will leave you confused.  The problem here is we have a three hour play trimmed down for a two hour script.  There is a glaring loss of continuity.  I worked in insurance claims for 25 years and handled a great number of identical claims.  This may be theatrical, but it gets nowhere near the actual way it was.

I received this today and it was simple to set up.  I was afraid of attaching it to the bottom of the garage door, but it went on like it was custom made (I have a newer home).  It penetrates two walls at about 100'.  I have it set up in my bedroom which is full of electronics, WiFi, etc.  no interference.  The antenna isn't even extended.  I have shut off the beeper because I cannot stand things beeping at me, nice to have this feature.  I've had several Chamberlains, only one worked and it had to be attached so near the sensor it was useless.  Nice to see a "made in China" product that actually works as advertised.

This is a handsome unit with a small footprint which won't look ugly or upset the neighbors.  It was easy to set up and the vanes are always turning, it even measures wind speed down to 1mph, something the Big Boys don't do.  I have mounted it on a 10' pole where it captures all the wind and is not blocked by trees or houses.  The signal is very strong and it captured the atomic time immediately.  Now why it only gets 4 stars:It mounts on a 3/4" pole, readily available at Home Depot.  Despite the admonitions that a metal pole might attract lightning, get one anyway.  A plastic pole will whip in the wind, and lightning will hit the highest object, your house not the anemometer.  Mounting this illustrates a true design flaw.  When this is placed on a 3/4" pole, it needs to be tightend onto the pole by two set screws which tighten the two halfs together.  Good luck.  The screws are deeply recessed and are so tiny you can barely even see them.  I do not exaggerate when I say you will need the smallest jewler's screwdriver on the planet, phillips head, to even make contact.  Then you cannot generate enough torque to tighten the screws.  This would be a deal breaker if the pole did not penetrate so far into the unit it could not fall off anyway.  Were it mounted on a plastic pole the wind would whip it around so much it would fall off.  Does the manufacturer ever test their products before rushing them to market???The final negative is something which is beyond control.  During the day the solar radiation gives a temperature about 2-3 degrees above normal.  It would be nice if there were a compensation feature which would allow this to be adjusted, but then the nighttime temperature would be off a few degrees.  Also, a backlight should have been included.  For you desert dwellers, the humidity level reads down to 1%, here in Las Vegas it is in the single degree range 6 months a year.  This is rarely spelled out in the summary of products.To conclude, this is a well constructed station with the console extremely easy to read.  If you can work around the limitations, you will enjoy it.To conclude, this

This clock may have snuck under the radar of those looking for a basic, easy to use clock.It picked up a time signal deep inside my house immediately upon inserting a battery.Its black hands against a white face make it visible across a large room, despite its compact size.Many in the clock reviews seem to be searching for a clock in which the second hands are silent.  This clock is completely silent, 3' from my bed, although nowhere does it lay claim to this feature.  This would be great for any senior who just wants to tell time.  Simple is better.

I am a long time weather buff and have gone through my share of weather stations over the past decades.  I purchased the Acurite Deluxe Wireless Weather Center based on the almost unanimous great reviews posted here.  I received this station today and can report the following, based on my reference station, an expensive Davis unit:*The temperature is accurate to the exact degree of my reference station.* The humidity is within 2% of my reference station.  Humidity is notoriously hard to measure, so this is excellent.*  The unit comes preset to the day and time, backed up by a button battery.  All you have to do is tweak the time zone.*  The backlight is a beautiful blue and easy to see at night.*  The setting buttons and the backlight are all controlled by simply touching the setting bar, this is apparently done by electrical conduction as no pressure is required.*  Alkaline batteries are included, a rarity to be sure.*  The signal transmits through three walls and still gets the maximum 4 bars.* The barometer is accurate but I cannot comment on the supposed algorithm for forecast modeling.  My Davis unit makes the same claim and it's rarely accurate.I put the outdoor sensor in a protected station which I've had for years; it costs more than the weather station now.  This was the only way to get the sensor away from my patio, which faces north, and causes a "heat island" effect 24/7 during the summer months in Las Vegas.  To conclude, this is an excellent product which more than lives up to its expectations.  I could not find it anywhere else but Amazon, which is why I do all my shopping here.  Happy weather watching!

I will keep this brief as quickly as I can get to the post office, assuming there are any left open.  I guess preople buy this because of its allegedly sleek looks, but all that serves is to make it easy to knock over.  The major problem is the tiny, dim ceiling projection which strains your eyes just trying to see it.  I have had several projection clocks over the years, and this one scrapes th bottom of the barrel.  Buyer BEWARE!!

I'm too old to be fooling with complicated setups like some of the other (younger) reviewers have done, so I'll stick to what works for me.  I started out with a cheapo pair of Sonys, still being sold after ten years.  Terrible mistake.  They hurt my ears and showed static when ever I moved my head.  The best selling point on the new one was the battery life, a brand new feature on this model.  A three hour charge lasts 20 hours, but you will rarerly completely  discharge the battery anyway.  A big plus.Since I only use my headphones for watching TV and my iPad  I cannot comment on the complicated setup most reviewers are enamored with.  Also, I don't notice the 7.1surround sound and dont know how this would be possible given you only have two ears.  That said, the headphones produce beautiful sound, are completely comfortably , and are well worth the extra price.  I would recommend them to folks who are getting on years and don't want the TV blasting and disturbing the wife.  This seems to be the only think decent thing Sony is making these days.

I received this in one day despite ordering standard delivery.  It was simple to set up, basically just put batteries in it and you're good to go.  Testing, it seems to work well, and conveys the rain information promptly.  It took overnight for it to catch a time signal, but at my location this always the case.  We only get 4" of rain a year (Mohave Desert), but this looks like it will do just fine.  There are several other rain gauges out there for much more which don't even have atomic time, at Amazon's price you can't go wrong.Update:  After months in service I can report this unit drastically under records rain measurement by about 50%.  I have a Davis reference weather station and it is exact.  While it is cheap, the tiny collector unit does not match weather service specs for accurate rain measurement.  The atomic time works well though.

I've had this for about a month (you can't find one anywhere now) and I have to report it's of excellent quality in keeping with the Ambient tradition for their radio controlled products.  It looks great on my kitchen table and is bright enough to be seen from across the room.  It has a three stage brightness adjustment for use in the bedroom.  The Cirrus has forecast two rain events at six days out, you can't find any weather station that can do that.  What's really neat is that you can view conditions and forecasts for 150 cities, and then easily program your five favorites for quick access; I have programed in the cities of my friends and family, this even shows the amount of snow expected in each location.  I am a weather buff and have had many such stations throughout the years and this the best by a long shot.  The only thing missing is a battery backup, but it would ruin the sleek architecture of this station.  I think I am a fair distance from the transmitter but I still get three bars, the maximum, for reception.  It may take a while for this product to return to the market, do your self a favor and get it from Amazon, they have the best price anywhere.  Weathershack sells them for $100+ and the "new" Sharper Image clocks in at $150.  All in all, a fine purchase.

It's probably a little early to start bragging about a product, I just received it yesterday, but contrary to some of the reviews it was surprisingly easy to set up.  Some have complained about the black clips breaking which hold down the watering cone, but if you look carefully at the pictures in the instruction book and put them gently on you will have no problem.  I've read that the max/min indicators are hard to see on the cone and they are, so I just took a  magic marker and drew a line which now makes the level lines easy to see.  So far my three cats have taken to it well despite some initial reluctance.  I live in a very hard water area and ruined a fountain because calcium deposits built up quickly.  Now I use distilled water which is cheap and does not build up any deposits.  So far, so good, I will post any problems that develop later.  At first blush, it's a winner.Update July 25, 2015:  This has now been in service four years.  I've had to order replacement parts for the fountain spout and filter, but everything else, including the pump, is continuing to work perfectly.  The stainless steel looks brand new.  The nice thing is that you can buy parts for this easily and relatively cheaply online.  Face it, plastic parts with water running over them 24/7 have a finite life span.
I got these because they said compatible with Ipad.  They lasted about a week of watching movies, then all you could hear was the music and not the dialogue.  STAY AWAY!!!!

The obvious source of inspiration for such off-the-wall metal groups as Cephalic Carnage, Unexpect, Fantomas, The Dillinger Escape Plan, and Gojira, Strapping Young Lad are easily one of the (if not THE) funniest and zaniest things to happen to the world of extreme metal since the days of Meshuggah, Mr. Bungle, Mike Patton, and Naked City. They started out as, essentially, a one-man supergroup, as frontman Devin Townsend plays virtually every instrument in the book (including guitar, most keyboards, programming, and production), but here  he gets more than a few helping hands on SYLs debut, 1995s Heavy As A Really Heavy Thing. (There is a plethora of guest musicians present, here, including a trio of drummers.)Devy has definitely been diagnosed with bipolar disorder, and he sure lets it show, here. Note that I said disorder and not disability, because as a result of said disease, the dude comes up with some of the most extremely great and memorably dynamic music that one can imagine. H.A.A.R.H.T. is a cyber/industrial-grind album, meaning it owes every bit as much to the likes of Ministry and Fear Factory as it does to, say, Napalm Death and the aforementioned Naked City. The end result is a chaotic and eccentric (to say the very least) mix of sounds. So for every grinding blast, monster riff, and brutal pig squeal, present, here, there is also at least the same amount of dub-step beats, techno-beat loops, samples, and synthesizers.At its heaviest, it is a tumultuous exercise in all-out calamity; but at its softest, it is restrained, docile, and even borderline rhythmic. Cuts like the brutal opener, S.Y.L., are furious blasts of barely controlled chaos with very little melodies to speak of. They motor ahead with foaming-at-the-mouth vocals, blistering riffing, and pummeling drums. And Happy Camper (Carpe BUM) is another three minutes of uncompromising, unbridled, unrelenting fury, a savage, grindcore-worthy beat-down of blasting drums, maniacally high-pitched screaming, and tempos that will require listeners everywhere to be prescribed a neck brace. It just oozes with viciously thrashing grooves and brutal instrumental interplay.On the flip side, though, there is also plenty of restrained industrial rock-like material. Take Cod Metal King, for one example. It is an early Ministry/KMFDM-flavored industrial/dance metal boogie with a heavy use of synthesizers, beeping bass lines, and repetitive, programmed-sounding drum beats. And the vocals, meanwhile, consist mostly of the distorted and electronic-heavy style. The Filler: Sweet City Jesus and King Me are two other techno-industrial-lite numbers. One boasts an addicting, staccato guitar riff, squealing keyboards, and faint backing vocals to create a really trippy and ethereal atmosphere; whereas the other is a borderline danceable tune, what with its groovy guitar/bass riffs, chugging rhythms, and rhythmic, Skinny Puppy-like beats.The remainder of the record falls somewhere in between these two styles described in the above songs. Goat offsets its alleged use of Chris Meyers-donated keyboard flourishes with chunky, lurching riffs, snarly, growly vocals, and strong, grumbling bass lines, while Drizzlehell lays harsh, dissonant vocals over thrashy guitar licks and brutal, adherent grooves that make your speakers shake and floors rumble. And the amusing, set-closing joke song, Satans Ice Cream Truck, is also of note, as it is a silly, childrens lullaby-sounding tune with hilarious vocals, vibes, techno-industrial-like keyboards, and noteworthy bass lines.But it is Critic that is actually a better representation of Heavy As A Really Heavy Thing, as a whole. It is another slab of psychotic cyber-industrial-grind-metal with memorable (and often even borderline catchy) thrash riffs. It boasts a tour-de-force on the vocal front, too, as Devy definitely pushes his pipes to the limit, here; but the track is actually mostly of note for the way it explodes from mid-tempo grooves to brutal, headbanging, neck-aching fury without warning.Heavy As A Really Heavy Thing never -- and I mean NEVER -- locks into any kind of cohesive groove for the listener to latch on to and sink their teeth into, but that is part of its charm. So while things like accessible hooks and organic-sounding musicianship might be a thing of the past, here, it is still a very strong release, and auspicious debut. And while it may not be as mind-blowing as Strapping Young Lads sophomoric effort, 1997s City, or 2005s Alien, it is nevertheless recommended for all objectively-minded fans of heavy music.

Continuing their forever-non-dying quest to constantly explore, innovate, expand, and never release the same album twice, Colorado's finest musical exports Cephalic Carnage deliver another great slab of technically-deranged death-grind by the name of "Misled By Certainty." The self-proclaimed hydro-grinders sixth full-length effort from the studio explodes with a truckload of blistering tech-metal riffs, immaculate drumming, and monstrous vocals, this fourteen-song set appears to at first be armed with all of the usual trademarks found on a technically-impressive extreme metal record. But once the surface is cracked, it becomes readily apparent that it is actually quite a unique and original-sounding affair.For one thing, it is armed to the teeth with a whole friggin' slew of guest musicains -- so many, in fact, that it almost seems like there is a cameo from some well-respected death metal or grindcore icon on most every track. Members of Immolation, Skinless, Krisiun, Cattle Decapitation, and Nashville P (among numerous others) all make a cameo from behind the mic. And not only that,but Pat Hanson and Bruce Lamont (of Yakuza fame) also chip in to help make the arrangements even fuller with some guest keyboards and saxophones, respectively.Furthermore, in addition to possessing an undeniably strong sense of humor, "M.B.C.' also stands out in that it is an expansive, shape-shifting, genre-melding affair. Indeed, as with any Cephalic Carnage release, elements of sludge metal, black metal, thrash/speed metal, jazz-spazz, NYC-era hardcore, and full-on jazz-rock all come into play into Cephalic Carnage's patented blend of hyper-speed death metal and grindcore. As a result, the group manages to attain an even more unique and borderline untouchable sound."Pure Horses," "P.G.A.D.," "Power And Force," and the intentionally humorous (scratch that, hilarious) "Aeyeucgh" are all explosive and bludgeoning barrages of unbelievably savage and cut-throat grindcore. And they all are really short blitzkriegs, too, thus making them evoke the genre's halcyon days. And they are all fueled by ferocious and destructive grindcore blasts, too, although said drumming mostly stands out on "Power And Force," where it is especially breakneck and jackhammer-fast. Other standouts, including "Abraxes Of Filth" and "Ohrwum" find Cephalic Carnage opting for the approach taken on their 2007 effort, "Xenosapien," in that they both feature some really dexterous and nimble-fingered bass work, including some really fast and technical bass soloing in the case of the former track and Brain Drill-like warbling bass grooves threaded into the mix of thunderous, earth-quaking rhythms in the case of the latter. (But only "Abraxes" can claim to also feature a little nicely melodic guitar soloing, in addition.)And even though the remainder of the record does not claim to be quite as epic as the above songs, there are certainly other highlights to be had. Opening salvo "The Incorrigible Flame" is a monstrous death-grinder that deftly switches from rapid-fire to ominously mid-tempo churning at the drop of a hat. And some bah-roo-tal vocals are laid over the whole thing, too, including low growls, high-pitched screams, unnerving shrieks, and near pig squeals. The tune's rhythms are also of note, as they are driven forward by stop-start blasts of blistering double bass propulsion. And the next one after that, "Warbots A.M.," takes a similar path, as it augments its monstrous guitar riffs and almost Black Dahlia Murder-like vocal stylings with breakneck blasts of trapkit annihilation (including plenty of grinding, mind-boggling blast beats).The almost shockingly mellow, melodic, and vapid "Cordyceps Humanis" ultimately comes across sounding like a grindcore cover of some song taken off of Metallica's "Load." The occasional huge, booming power chord and spot of monstrous vocals are dropped in, here, just to keep the listener on his/her toes, though. This anomaly is not without company, though, as the ensuing "Raped By An Orb" takes a concertedly jazzy route, offsetting massive, chugging riffs, killer vocals, machine gun-fast drumming, and utterly whiplash fast/slow tempo changes with some exotically melodic lead work. And so does "Repangaea," as it is primarily occupied by a basic, rock `n' roll-esque drum beat and some jazzy saxophone soloing, thus making it possess a very strong Naked City-esque vibe. (The song does build and eventually get increasingly experimental, complex, and epic, as it plays, though, and even goes so far as to include a cool-sounding piano line.)And a handful of other gems round out the set, including "Dimensional Modulation Transmography," a heavily groove-oriented piece of death-grind with some abnormally intelligible hardcore shouts. And speaking of vocals that differ from the norm, "When I Arrive" slips in some clean backing vocals into the mix -- and what memorable and wailing vocals they are, too. But that might be a tad misleading, as the remainder of the track is a vicious and blistering grindcore assault that spends its time spewing out impeccable double-time drum blasts, thrashy guitar leads, and dissonant, black metal-worthy shrieking. And lastly, we are also treated to "A King And A Thief," which is primarily occupied by propulsive, grinding blasts, and huge, meaty riffs, but is mostly of note for featuring a bunch of bowel-twistingly low death metal growls.A little uneven but always very enjoyable and greatly unpredictable, "Misled By Certainty"  might be more than a little bit weird; but hey, a little weirdness never hurt anybody, now did it? And besides, it is as good an album as it is a weird one (and that is really saying something! It is just Cephalic Carnage's way of trying to distinguish their current sound from not only the hordes of other extreme metal albums available on the market today, but from their own, previous successes, too. And if that was the band's intent, then they were very, very successful.

On their sixth full-length, Christian metallers Norma Jean sound hungry -- much hungrier than they have since the release of their sophomoric effort, O God, The Aftermath, in 2005. But even though the band has produced one of the heaviest -- if not THE heaviest -- efforts of their career, they have also turned out a record that steps outside of the comfort box, and explores experimentation beyond the mere realms of noise-inflected metal/hardcore.Being based out of Georgia, newcomers would be forgiven to think that Norma Jean are a sludge/doom/stoner metal group (since Mastodon and others of their ilk have come from said state). And on 2013s Wrongdoers, they do dabble a little bit in the world of sludgecore. (Its not exactly Eyehategod, but hey, its a start!) And furthermore, N.J. also sprinkle in a handful of undeniable progressive rock elements into the mix, here, too. By doing so, the end result is one of the most viscerally satisfying yet also well-rounded pieces of music ever to bare this bands name.Standouts If You Got It At  Five, You Got It At Fifty and The Lash Whistled Like A Singing Wind are both bludgeoning, decapitating assaults of grinding, throat-tearing noisecore, thus making them the heaviest songs that Norma Jean have ever dared to write (to date). The former is a breakneck ripper in the same vein as Botch and The Dillinger Escape Plan; and the latter evokes Converges most cut-throat stuff. If You Got It is filled with Dillinger-like math-y riffs, surging, jerking tempo changes, pounding bass lines, angular hardcore breakdowns, and dexterous drumming (including some blast beats); whereas The Lash is a blitzkrieg that just barely cracks the one minute mark, thus catching the listener totally off-guard. But there are plenty of cuts that lean more towards the melodic side of the line, with the excellent title track, which has staccato guitar hooks and vocals that range from semi-melodic to downright harmonic and pop-ish, being one example.Most of the remainder of the record, however, falls somewhere in between the above-two described styles: Brutal and tuneful. HiveMinds, with its shimmering, shaking line of feedback followed by thundering, sludgy, commanding guitar riff rooted in sludgy, grumbling bass lines, and The Bled-style hardcore screams, serves as a very strong set opener. Also make sure to check out the two pieces of more traditional and therefore accessible, pop-tinged hardcore punk/metalcore (Sword In Mouth, Fire Eyes, and the big chorusd Triffids); The Potter Has No Hands, which again adopts a punishing hardcore mentality, what with its shredded-throat screams and breakdown happy rhythms; and the bass-heavy/driven Funeral Singer. (Lots of great bass work abounds pretty much throughout this number, including plenty of sludgy, twangy bass lines, technical fills, and dirty-sounding riffs.)But the sets undisputed highpoint comes at the very end. Proof that sometimes the best is saved for last, Sun Dies, Blood Moon is a fourteen-plus minute long closing epic that takes Norma Jeans songwriting prowess to a whole new level. It is nicely textured piece with several different layers and dimensions, a docile near ballad that is layered in ethereal keyboards, gorgeous acoustic guitar strums, calmly crooned vocals, violin, cello, organs, and bow cymbals. And there is just enough throaty metalcore screams and electric guitar resonance to keep things tense, keep the listener on the edge of his or her seat, and add some much-needed dissonance to an otherwise totally melodic and progressive mix.Technical and challenging yet somehow simultaneously accessible and easy-to-digest, wholly satisfying, inventive, and unpredictable, this stands as the penultimate album to beat in Norma Jeans discography. (It rates as a close second behind only 2006s brilliant Redeemer.) And when considering how respectable (to say the very least) that discography already is, that is quite a compliment to Wrongdoers. It is definitely a worthwhile listen!

After spending several years experimenting with their sound and trying to prove to the world that they, too, hate nu-metal, Linkin Park finally returned to their roots with long-player number six in 2014. Although it cannot be deemed to be a true return-to-form for the band, "The Hunting Party" tries to recapture the same levels of musical friction, energy, and all-around irresistibility first heard on 2000's debut, "Hybrid Theory." And while it never quite successfully does so, several of its songs make a valiant attempt at it.As a result, the album does do what previous efforts (i.e. 2012's electronic rock-leaning "Living Things") failed at: Scratching your Linkin Park itch. Indeed, even though it by no means is an Earth-shattering affair, or a particularly deep one (some of the material races by without leaving much of a lasting impression on the listener), it is all-but guaranteed to satisfy both schools of fans: The old school and the new school. Indeed, does "T.H.P." possesses just enough new-ish-sounding elements to maybe turn a few new heads, while at the same time retaining that angsty rap-metal flavor that got the band to be so big in the first place. By doing so, they have created a heavy and adrenalized, yet simultaneously melodic and never out-of-control record, and one that is in the running for being the year's crowning nu-metal achievement.There are several cameos from guest instrumentalists/vocalists spread out over the course of these twelve tracks, but of those four guest spots, only half of them are noteworthy. Helmet's Page Hamilton chips in with a catchy, cleanly-sung chorus on "All For Nothing," thus offsetting the tune's fluid, youthful rap-rock stylings really well. (The rest of the track is occupied by hip-hop-ish vocal stylings and lyrics that are primarily centered around a few really good rhymes.) The end result is a sound that recaptures the one heard on the band's earliest recordings ("All For Nothing" kind of evokes the band's fourteen-year-old hit single, 2000's "Faint")And the other notable cameo comes in the very next song: "Guilty All The Same" finds Rakim chipping in with some great guest rapping, thus helping to further the tune's potential for heavy radio-rotation. With that said, though, it would have been one that stood out in its own right, as it is a pretty darn great mix of bobbing, lurching guitar hooks, heavy, grumbling bass lines, and tight, driving rhythms that flow perfectly into deftly sweeping and fist-pumpable choruses. Add what sounds like something that could pass for a little mini guitar solo (or a whammy bar/wah-pedal-abusing guitar lick, if nothing else), and the end result is a song that has all of the makings to be a new Linkin Park classic."The Hunting Party"'s other two cameos, though -- System Of A Down guitarist Daron Malakian on "Rebellion" and Tom Morello on "Drawbar" -- are both almost completely transparent. (A grave shame when considering what a great talent either of those guitarists is.) Fortunately, there are enough of other standouts found elsewhere to more-than-compensate for any of these shortcomings. Opener "Keys To The Kingdom" is one early highlight, as it is a potent mix of brutal, viscerally angsty and bratty screaming and supple, calm, sweet crooning; and "War," which almost plays like a blast of nearly full-on hardcore punk (and is a very muscular and propulsive song, needless to say), is another.Other standouts include the groovy, staccato guitar crunch and more deft, sing-scream-rap vocals of "Wastelands"; the touching "Until It's Gone," which is a much gentler and more docile piece, a near ballad if you will, and one that is centered around, sweetly-sung choruses that are big and epic enough to require their own area code; and "Final Masquerade." The latter of these three songs might have a catchy, funky, trip-hop-esque beat, but is ultimately a number that, thanks to its utilization of some of Linkin Park's all-time best and most accomplished clean singing, kind of reminds of L.P.'s "In The End."But the set's two biggest highlights are actually found elsewhere. "Mark The Graves" puts the album on heavier ground, as it is centered around a massive, thunderous, lumbering guitar riff. Said track also features some tricky tempo and arrangement change-ups, but again, how about that riff (!): It is as commanding and memorable as anything that six-stringer Brad Delson have ever produced! And the second arguable highpoint comes at the very end: "A Line In The Sand" is a very seamless, insanely hooky, and infectious shuffle. It transitions from effortlessly fluid rapping to hard-rocking guitar-driven crunch seemingly without even breaking sweat. The end result is the deepest and most epic tune on the whole record, hands down.In summary, "The Hunting Party" is Linkin Park's best effort since 2003's "Meteora," and one that might not be a true "classic," but is still one that shows definite signs of improvement for the band. It is not exactly a reinvention (or even drastic expansion) of the form, meaning it is not an absolutely essential or life-altering listen. But nobody could argue that it is anything less than a really fun and enjoyable one. And at the very end of the day, could you really ask for anything more?

Machine Head are exactly the type of band that seems just perfect to release a live album, seeing how they have a frontman whose frenetic energy really knows how to work crowds everywhere. And plus, with seven full-lengths under their mighty belts, they have quite a large back catalogue to choose songs from. So here we are, finding the band release of Machine Fing Head Live hitting store shelves in 2012.True, M.H. do already have a live album to their names. And even though this second one does not QUITE recapture the same levels of irresisitbility as 2003s Hellalive, it is still one of the best live thrash albums that this reviewer has heard since Metallicas S&M came out in 1999. And yes, these live renditions might adhere closely to the songs original versions -- meaning there are no added guitar or drum solos -- they are played with a sufficiently minimal amount of crowd noise, which is a plus. And furthermore, they are impeccably played (frontman Rob Flynn and Co. tear through them without any audible mistakes.) All of this considered, what we have on our hands, here, is a definite must-purchase for all hardcore fans of the band.With fifteen tracks spread out over the course of two discs, there are bound to be numerous standouts. Set opener I Am Hell is a monstrous wall of thunderous, staccato riffing and drumming, although it does splice in some memorable, wah-heavy guitar soloing into its mix of blistering thrash picking and impeccable, blast beat-centric drum beats. Be Still And Know, then, is another blistering, but this time groove-centric thrasher with more memorable and exceptional, shred-happy soloing; but it is the next track after that, Imperium, where it becomes first blatantly obvious that the mosh pit was working overtime going berserk. It boasts blowtorch riffage and shotgun blast-esque percussion, and is also home to a few well-placed fast tempo changes (which might showcase Machine Heads more math-y and technical side, but are nevertheless flawlessly-executed.)Beautiful Mourning continues these brutal ways, as it is a frenetic mosh pit anthem with elastically thundering, throbbing thrash grooves and biting, grinding guitar crunch. The only time the onslaught ever relents is to drop in a semi-sweet, cleanly-sung chorus, and ripping, surprisingly melodic solo. And the following The Blood, The Sweat, The Tears is every-bit the irresistible mosh pit anthem that the above-described two tracks were, and it in fact proves to be quite impossible for you, the listener sitting in the safe confines of your own home, not to bounce around with energy, headbang, and break some s**t. Yes, the energy is that freaking palpable in this one!Locust boasts plenty of huge, crunch-n-churn riffs, but is actually mostly of note for featuring some of the first discs best and most memorable and epic guitar soloing. Moving along, the misleadingly-entitled This Is The End kicks off with an excellent introductory drum solo before being followed by a rip-roaring barrage of Eighties-worthy thrash. It is a blistering thrash/riff-fest, needless to say, and one with a few extensive and very screaming solo flights. And rounding out the first disc are Aesthetics Of Hate, which is dedicated to our brother, Dimebag, and sure to get the circle pit acting stupid; and Old, which is highlighted by some abnormally strong, and prominently audible bass work, as well as plenty of excellent, fiery, groove-laden guitar licks, and an audience-involved chorus.Highlights on Machine Fing Head Lives second disc include the fiery, swirling thrash of the Sepultura/Soulfly-reminiscent Darkness Within; the blistering Who We Are (which is home to the extensive use of excellent, all-over-the-map guitar soloing); and Halo, which is seemingly tailor-made for head-banging (Flynn even admits it is!). It has abrasive buzzsaw riffing and towering, dizzying melodic solo flights to go along with its sweet, sing-song-worthy melodic singing, and crunching, skull-rattling grooves. And, of course, one must not forget to mention the inclusion of the sets final song, Davidan. It might now be a nineteen year-old hit single, but it is still every bit as potent and vibrant as it was when it premiered on Machine Heads 1994 debut, Burn My Eyes. (At the beginning of it, frontman Rob Flynn proclaims I wanna see this place explode -- and it almost surely did just that once the band lunged into the meat of the song.) Suffice it to say, it is a truly anthemic song, and I cannot think of a better way to close out the album.

After recruiting a new vocalist, one who goes by the name George "Corpsegrinder" Fisher, in 1996, New York death metal natives Cannibal Corpse released a slew of new recordings, each one of them as strong as the ones recorded with Chris Barnes behind the mic. This included the release of the band's second ever E.P., "Worm Infested," which saw the light of day in 2003 (in the downtime in between 2002's "Gore Obsessed" and 2004's "The Wretched Spawn"), despite having material that had floated around the marketplace in various locations over the course of the last seven years. It is primarily a compilation E.P., as it is comprised of three cover songs, and one re-recording of a C.C. classic; but it also features two brand-spankin'-new studio recordings.Opening with a bang, the blistering "Systematic Elimination" is just about as speedy, insane, viciously violent, and malevolent a two minutes and fifty-five seconds as you will ever hear from Cannibal Corpse. (And when considering the band's always high standards in that department, that is REALLY saying something!) It is backed by ferocious, barn-burning riffage, viscerally rumbling bass, stop-start drum blasts, and careening guitar soloing, and topped off by Fischer's trademarked growly, horse-throated bellowing. The title track then continues the album's brutal ways, as it might start out as a sludgy and brooding, bass-heavy piece, but soon takes off into blistering, blasting death metal-dom with searing, wall-of-sound guitar leads, pain-inflicting drums, and memorable vocal patterns. (Here, the usual abundance of brutally low growling is occasionally augmented by piercingly high-pitched shrieking.) And I must mention the fact that this song also boasts another wild, Slayer-ish solo, too.Next we have the set's first cover song, "Demon's Night," which was originally written and performed by German power metallers Accept. The Cannibal Corpse cover of it, though, is just as good as the original. Working up a steady, meaty chug and stomp from a brief bit of introductory near-silence, it eventually climaxes by becoming a rhythmically galloping number with oddly intelligible vocals and unorthodox guitar soloing. "Confessions," is the album's next cover, this one being a spot-on Possessed cover, and one that is, needless to say, very blistering, and full of densely churning, bone-crunching riffage and some of the short-player's absolute best guitar solo work.But do not overlook track four on the album, "The Undead Will Feast," just because it is sandwiched between these two already described covers. It is an excellent, vintage Cannibal Corpse-sounding breakneck surge of brutal bass lines, tight and precise cymbal rides, incessant double bass pummel, and grumbling guitar noise. And the solos in this song are of the screaming and frenetic variety. And rounding out the set is "No Remorse," a Metallica cover, and one that is loaded with fiery, thrashy tempo'ing, chugging riffs that are positively catchy, and abrasively grinding rhythms. Add some blazing guitar leads, memorably shredding solo runs, and surprisingly technical, slapped bass fills to the mix, and the end result is easily one of the finest cover songs in the history of death metal. And it retains the original version's catchy and memorable choruses, too!Again, "Hammer Smashed Face" is not great (or long) enough to be deemed an essential listen for everybody. But even if the necessity of its release is, at best, questionable, it is still nonetheless most certainly good enough to be a worthy purchase for everybody that claims to be a serious fan of the band or genre. It is, after all, one of the best E.P.'s ever released in the entire history of death metal music.

Emerging as a very talented and auspicious young power metal group, Germanys Sabaton are, if nothing else, then at least high in the running of being crowned the very respectable title of the Accept of the new millennium. They bare all of the workings of a prototypical power metal classic, and while it might come up a bit short of attaining such a prestigious attribute, there is plenty to like on this album, their seventh full-length. Among the attributes on this 2014 release include crunchy, industrial-strength riffing, pronounced, bubbling bass, solid, natural-sounding drum beats, fantastical lyrics, and epic-sounding arrangements/songs.Sabatons frontman, Joakim Broden, meanwhile, splits his time alternating equally between Bruce Dickinson-meets-Rob Halford impressions. So while he may not be the most original vocalist on the market, he does certainly prove to the world that he is nothing if not an accomplished singer. The end result produced of all these things is a good throwback traditional/power metal record, and a more than sufficient homage to the bands influences. With that said, however, it should be known that Heroes is not exactly an earth-shattering affair, nor one that can be deemed to be frequently amazing. (The guitar solos, in particular could use some work -- they could stand to be a bit longer, as could the songs, in general.) But man, is it rock solid!Cuts like Night Witches, a triumphant-sounding opener with unforgettable, chanted vocals and blazing melodic soloing that both evoke classic Judas Priest; and No Bullets Fly, a propulsive chugger with tons of really tasty guitar crunch to go along with its delicious, Iron Maiden-inspired guitar harmonies and solos, practically scream pure power metal. But there are a few curveballs thrown into the mix every now and then, too, including making Smoking Snakes a blistering, speed metal-lite anthem, and inmate 4859 take on a near industrial rock-esque vibe, what with its chanted, Rammstein-esque vocals (that are sung very dramatically and in Sabatons native tongue, German), and all. Also on the experimental front, To Hell And Back opens with a really cool, foreign instrument (a whistling wind instrument of some kind). But this is before, however, the tune falls into typical power metal territory, adhering to a rhythmic, toe-tappable groove and uncorking good guitar solos for the remainder of the song.The Ballad Of Bull is a big standout track, thus making it the perfect album centerpiece. It is a bit of an anomaly, too, as it is an epic and chilling power ballad with lush musical arrangements (including gorgeous strings and cool-sounding piano keys) laying the foundation for the frontmans excellent, triumphant, and often even borderline-soulful clean vocals to soar over the top of. But immediately following this, the record returns to its metallic roots, as Resist And Bite maxes-out its levels of guitar crunch. Plenty of wailing melodic soloing, memorable vocal patterns, and extra-dramatic-sounding drum fills also highlight the mix, here, too. And continuing these aggressive ways, Soldier Of 3 Armies is a hard-hitting, speed metal-inflected power metaller rooted in hard-hitting drum beats and thrashy picking. Here, a bouncy, thundering drum intro flows right into fiery, chugging riffage, humming bass lines, solid double kick drumming. And the tune hits its memorable climax when it tosses in some crystalline-sounding melodic solo flights which are nearly vertigo-inducing.Next after this comes Far From The Fame, which brings back that twiddly melodical soloing (some of the albums best!), and towering piles of it, too, and anchors the whole thing with some impressively dexterous drum fills. Then, following the extremely catchy, oh-so-Iron Maiden-ish galloping cadence and impressively soaring vocals of Hearts Of Iron, the listener is treated to the closing 7734, one last propulsive and steady chugger where excellent clean singing and abrasive guitar crunch are underpinned by heavy, grumbling bass lines.Although not a totally flawless and/or timeless masterpiece, Heroes is a highly enjoyable, promising, well-played, and certainly always very decent and listenable musical experience with more-than-a-few flashes of brilliance. And it is proof of the fact that Sabaton have all of the tools they need in order to be a very successful young power metal band, and arguably one that can play right up there with the big dogs. Essential? Nah; but a heckuva lotta fun!

Fallujah's sophomore effort, "The Flesh Prevails," is easily one of the finest and most original death metal albums of 2014. One of its original attributes is the fact that its bass tone is abnormally strong and meaty (especially for death metal), meaning it is mixed high in the mix, and thus easy to pick out and follow. Furthermore, the bass work, while very prominently audible, is also exceedingly technical. We're not talking Brain Drill-levels of technicality, here, but it is more complex and precise than you are probably used to hearing on the average DM recording.But what makes this the innovative, game-changer of an album that it is, and the sizeable leap forward from Fallujah's three-year old debut ("The Harvest Wombs"), is the fact that it skillfully balances equal parts of harmony and nuance with its heaviness. Indeed, for every moment of extremity, there is always a pocket of gorgeous melody waiting just around the corner. (Epic-sounding harmonious guitar runs are utilized to help aid in this cause, as are various other audio pleasantries, including keyboards.) You'll see what I mean, here, shortly...Opener "Sarlit Path" fades in with some ominously ambient noise before suddenly adopting punishing death metal elements, allowing smashing drum blasts, sludgy, twangy-sounding bass lines, blistering guitars, and tortured-sounding vocal howls to slam onto the scene with little-to-no warning. The number does open up a little bit the more it plays, though, as the nice twin guitar melodicism at around the four-minute mark filtered in at around the four-minute mark allows the arrangements to breathe nicely. "Carved From Stone," however, mostly plays like an uncompromising blast-fest in that it is laden with thunderous riffing and furious drumming. In a particularly weird move, there are some ethereally clean vocals in the mid-section of the track; but on the whole, "Carved From Stone" mostly plays like a no-holds-barred Deicide song in that it is so straightforwardly brutal and aggressive.Next up, "The Night Reveals" slips in some dreary melodic guitar lead-work in its intro before shifting back to blasting, roaring death metal brutality. Granted, though, this brutality is offset by some more neat little melodies, coming in the form of some middle Eastern/Arabian-sounding guitar leads, a technical, winding bass line, and female vocal-backing harmonization. This melodic angle is further-fleshed out on the ensuing title song, which brings back those female backing vocal lines and augments them with some more exotic guitar melodicism and shimmering synth ambiance, thus creating a song that is, for all but the last half-minute or so (which is again really heavy), an extremely trippy and proggy, ethereal-sounding interlude.An interesting, adherently complex and prominent bass line and some nicely layered vocal harmonization begin "Levitation," a nice touch by all measures. But from there, the song quickly jumps to a brutal, speaker-shaking death metal climax taut with pummeling, stop-start blast beats and visceral, borderline monstrous-sounding vocal roars. But as good as "Levitation" is, it is almost overshadowed by what comes next: "Alone With You," a heavily progressive and industrial-lite interlude that makes heavy use of electronics, dreary, dreamy synth textures, and other heavenly ambiance. And this piece, the album's sole completely instrumental piece, also features some martial-sounding percussion to boot.But once "Alone..." winds to a close, the heaviness storming back in full force, as "Allure" kicks off by lumbering out of the gate with massive power chords, and locomotive double-kick drumming creating some ultra-imposing and resonating rhythms. Like the album's best songs, though, this one does not totally discount melody, and in fact does an exceedingly good job at balancing it with the tune's aural aggression. And the end result is a very well-textured, epic, and deep piece of music, and one whose arrangements are made even further dynamic through the use of a pretty darn wailing guitar solo near the end."Sapphire" also continues in this relentless-yet-simultaneously-restrained manner, underscoring heavenly melodic guitar leads with a nearly crushing barrage of mean, blast beat-heavy percussion, crunching riffs, solid, grumbling bass lines, and a blisteringly tight interplay/give-and-take between the three instruments. And some more melodic lead/solo work is also interwoven on-and-off into the mix throughout this number, thus helping to further its undeniably epic vibe. From there, the album is capped off by "Chemical Cave," which begins by luring the listener in with a nearly trance-inducing, progressive rock-derived melody and thumping, if non-threatening drum beat. And this piece, the set closer, also features some nice, winding melodic solos, and plenty of harmonically jazzy guitar leads/scales which help to really further its epically mazy and unpredictable persona.All in all, "The Flesh Prevails" is without question one really great and standout-worthy release. It is such a good album, in fact, that it verges on being an essential purchase. It is much more than just tough-guy hardcore posturing or Cannibal Corpse worshipping metal; meaning that there is much more going on, here, than just the mere use of monster riffs and Cookie Monster bellowing. As such, there is no debating one thing: The fact that it is an extremely convincing take on the American death metal genre, and one that most certainly deviates from the norm.

In the world of extreme metal, there are really three sub-genres where it is okay to for a band to be comprised of only one or two members: Grindcore (see The Berzerker, etc.), black metal (e.g. Gorelord), and industrial metal (i.e. Hanzel Und Gretyl). Fortunately for Norways Anaal Nathrakh, the band fall somewhere in between these three sub-genres, meaning they are among the absolute most sonically extreme new groups in all of metal. And this also means that A.N. operate as a mere duo comprised of Dave Hunt (a.k.a. V.I.T.R.I.O.L.), and Mick Kenney (who is better known as Irrumator, and handles all instrumental and programming duties, in addition to designing album artwork for 2013s Vanitas, and producing said record.)And while things like variety, infectious melody, nuance, and live-energy have never been any of the bands strong-suits, they are still very well capable of stacking one seizure-inducing guitar riff and pummeling blast beat un top of another. By doing so, they keep the intensity level in the red throughout this records near thirty-eight-minute long playing time, even when they opt to explore the realms of nuance and atmosphere (which are rare occurrences)Peeling out of the gate with tires squealing (almost literally), blistering opener The Blood-Dimmmed Tide is a totally off-the-rails attack on the senses, a rabid, vicious, swirling barrage of brutal, hissing, venomous vocals, and bullet-fast blasting; while cuts like the token-grinder Of Fire, And Fing Pigs play more like a piece of more traditional grindcore in the same vein as, say, Nasum and some Napalm Death stuff. But with that said, it is actually tracks like To Spite The Face (which slips in some spooky clean vocals into its choruses) and You Cant Save Me, So Stop Fing Trying that are better representations of the album, as a whole, as both songs are bludgeoning and evoke Agoraphobic Nosebleed (or some other cyber-grind band) being fed through Cradle Of Filths meat-grinder.One of the records other biggest highlights is Todos Somos Humanos, a track that enters the realm of thrash territory with Slayer-esque picking, and machine-gun drums, but is actually mostly of note for its wide-range of vocals. Here, V.I.T.R.I.O.L. switches gears from hissing to low death metal growls to piercingly high black metal shrieks, and even drops in the occasional goregrind-derived pig squeal, too. (And trust me when I say this: That stuff hurts!) A Metaphor For The Dead also a stands out from a vocal perspective, as it offsets its memorably thunderous, churning riffs and pounding (if largely blast beat-free) drumming with some bizarrely soaring, tactful, and almost operatic-clean backing vocals.Other standouts include Forging Towards The Sunset, which sure cuts awfully deep, as it is a caustic musical stew comprised of monstrous vocals, battering ram-esque blast beats, and thunderous rhythms; In Coelo Quies, Tout Finis Ici Bas, which is another exercise in ferocious, paint-peeling brutality, as it brims with earth-quaking grindcore blasts and racing, blood-pumping guitar leads, and only occasionally flirts with the odd melodic flourish (including the use of a brief but nice melodic guitar solo in the songs outro). And, of course, one must not forget to mention the terrifically dark, ominous, and neck-hair-raising interlude called Feeding The Beast.Much like far-too-many bands (Rotten Sound, Circle Of Dead Children, etc., etc., etc.,) of their kind, Anaal Nathrakh are criminally underrated. They possess a sound that is so extreme that it not only turns most listeners off, but truly alienates and disgusts them. Even so, what A.N. have created, here, on Vanitas is one very unique sound, a solid black metal album, and an actually pretty darn good grindcore album. And also as a result of this, they have become a band that is more-than-deserving of some much-needed attention.

In a lot of ways, there are really two types of bands in the world of heavy metal music: Those that want to press forward and survive, and those that don't. Let's discuss is a little more, shall we? Following the release of "Unseen" in 2011, The Haunted endured a devastating, and totally acrimonious split with longtime vocalist Peter Doelving, and, subsequently, guitarist Anders Bjorler and drummer Per Morllers Jensen, thus leaving the future of the band up in the air. Couple this with the fact that they had recently released a couple of albums, "Versus" in 2008, and the horrendously-received (and already noted) "Unseen" 2011, and the end result is a time in the band's career where they, like most bands, very well might just split-up.
