(This would be following in the same footsteps as Pantera, who dissolved back in 2003 following the departure of their vocalist, Phil Anselmo, and bassist, Rex Brown. Or, for a more recent example, check out Chimaira, who disbanded after losing everybody except vocalist Mark Hunter)But The Haunted are not one of those bands. Realizing that this would be far-too-easy and that they have put too much effort into the band to call it quits now, The Haunted recruited a new singer, Marco Aro, and rhythm section (guitarist Ola Englund), and kicked out a safe-yet-fully-satisfying rifferama. No, "Exit Wounds" does not have the same level of landmark-worthy innovation that previous Haunted efforts like 2004's game-changing "rEVOLVEr," and 2006's wonderful "The Dead Eye," had. But it doesn't need to. It is nevertheless still such a strong album that it reaffirms this band's status as being the leaders of the now burgeoning Swedish thrash metal circuit. The songs on this 2014 release, the band's eighth full-length, are short but sweet. Indeed, they are compact yet still manage to cut deep -- and I mean right down to the bone! Saturated with the good stuff (i.e. great riffs, propulsive leads, and exceptional solos) "E.W." is guaranteed to tickle the fancy of just about any and every metalhead on the market today.The pounding, churning instrumental lead-off cut ("317") flows right into the blistering, metalcore-tinged "Cutting Teeth." Here, The Haunted motor out of the gate with fiery, razorwire thrash riffage and taut, interlocking blast beats in order to create thundering rhythms for the frontman to spill his throaty, phlegm-flecked aggression over. And immediately following this comes "My Salvation," another pounding, scorching thrasher with delicious buzzsaw guitar crunch, vehement vocals, and really, really memorable choruses, and the even more brutal and blistering "Psychonaut." The latter of these two tunes is a barreling, heads-down, circle pit-stoking thrasher with charging, Slayer-iffic guitar leads and Doelving-esque screams. But this bruiser does feature some melodic guitar leads/soloing, and interweaves them tastefully into its otherwise hard-hitting mix and At The Gates-esque galloping beats.The ensuing "Eye Of The Storm" is ever-so-slightly more mid-tempo, but it is still very heavy, a fact that is in a large part due to it being a bass-driven number that boasts uber-strong, grumbling bass throbs. But this piece is further highlighted by some nicely clean and melodic guitar soloing, too. "Trend (Will Not Heal)" is an even bigger standout, though, and one of this reviewer's personal favorites, despite it actually sounding more like a Slipknot song than anything else. It does feature some wailing, sweeping melodic guitar soloing, but it is actually the rhythm section that stands out the most, here, as it is home to a strong bass intro and tight and precise drumming throughout. (Ex-At The Gates skinman Erlan Erlandsson really nails his blasts and thrash beats, here, no matter how machine gun-fast as they might be.) And "Trend Killer" is also further highlighted by some varied vocal patterns which produce offets growling with screaming and even a few shrieks in order to produce some REALLY memorable choruses.The band's undeniable Pantera influence shifts to the forefront of the mix for the next two tracks, the ensuing "Time (Will Not Heal)" and "All I Have." The former of these two inclusions is an insanely hooky chugger that augments its rhythmic, "Dimebag" Darrell-sounding chunk with squealing pinch harmonics and tacks on a gently wailing melodic guitar solo for good measure; and the latter kind of evokes a "Vulgar Display  Of Power" b-side. Indeed, it does feature catchy, adherent grooves, a cascade of grinding, Pantera-esque licks, and even some Phil Anselmo-stylized growling. And yes, it is home to some more really memorable (and totally air-guitar-able) soloing, too.But the next two songs after that find a definite metalcore/modern day thrash influence coming into the fray, including thunderously chugging breakdowns in the Lamb Of God-like bruiser "Temptation," and "My Enemy," which are similar tunes in that they both stagger blistering thrash tempos with undeniable moments of restraint. But the next one after that, "Kill The Light," is a more traditional Haunted cut in that it brings together all three of the sources of inspiration, playing like a brutal, surging, lunging thrasher that evokes Slayer-meets-Pantera-meets-Hatebreed. And rounding out the set are two final songs, each one of them as solid as anything else on the whole record. "This War" is a really catchy speedster, no matter how scalding it may be, and is home to some blistering guitar solo runs; while the bookending "Infiltrator" and "Ghost In The Machine" both boast some deep, heavy, rolling bass grooves. With that said, though, this closing track actually mostly stands out on account of it utilizing a fairly extensive use of deliciously melodic guitar leads and soloing.No, "Exit Wounds" is not a groundbreaking or even particularly essential affair; but it never really pretends to be. What is it? A great album from a great band? Oh, heck yes! And when considering the history behind it (just think about the fact that it was produced by a mere two-fifths of a band), it is made even better. A satisfying and immensely enjoyable monster with scads of inspiring vocals, impassioned performances, and memorable riffs that will hang with you long after the record has done playing.

When you hear the phrase "Viking metal," what probably comes to mind are bands like Amon Amarth, Ensiferum, Destroy Destroy Destroy, and Amorphis. And while those two groups are definitely among the cream of the genre's crop, there is one band that has never gotten enough credit, but certainly deserves to be ranked right up there alongside the elite: Unleashed. And the kicker to the story is the fact that this Swedish metal band actually formed in 1989, making them quite a bit older than most Viking metal groups. Hence, they are held accountable for helping to spearhead the genre, and being one of the leading influences on groups like the ones named above.And while almost all of the songs on Unleashed's ninth full-length, 2008'S "Hammer Battalion," might follow the exact same structure (verse-chorus-verse-solo-outro), they are also chockablock full of great riffs and even greater solos. As a result, the songs capture an intensity so enormous and vibrant that any such notion of a cookie-cutter vibe is very soon forgotten about. (Heck, the solos are so darn virtuosic that they alone warrant purchasing this album.)Check out track twelve, "Home Of The Brave," an amazing collection of godly, insanely intricate, and nimble-fingered, string-busting death-thrash riffage that rivals the best stuff put out by the likes of Nile and Morbid Angel. The tune does not completely forsake melody, though, as it does feature a deliciously harmonic guitar lead section; and yes, this is one of those instances where the solos verge on near neo-classicalism. And also included, here, is another simple yet very potent and effective chorus. With that having been said, though, it is actually a song like opener "The Greatest Of All Lies" that is a better representation of the album, as a whole. It is an explosive and punishing opening blast with a galloping cadence, booming double kick-drum propulsion, and shriek-y, early Morbid Angel-esque vocals to go along with its crunching thrash riffs and wailing, trade-off melodic guitar solo section. And add another catchy and memorable chorus to the mix, and the end result is one song that actually closely evokes latter-day God Dethroned (even though, yes, this reviewer is well-aware that Unleashed predate G.D., too.)But does that mean those are the only standouts? Oh, heck no -- far from it, in fact! "Long Before Winter's Call," which boasts blistering blast beats, inventive and catchy, galloping riffs, buzzsaw-fast guitar leads, and solo flights that are equal parts epic and excellent, might be a great song for those reasons, alone, but this fact is made certain by its use of effective and well-placed fast tempo changes. And moving along, "Your Children Will Burn" is another early-album gem, as it is a slightly more restrained (and insanely catchy) chugger with crunchy, chugging guitar hooks, and equally-as-catchy and memorable, concert-ready choruses. Back on the breakneck side of the line, though, "Hammer Battalion" is an explosive and bludgeoning excursion -- an all-out blitzkrieg of pulverizing extremity played at brutal, blasting speeds.Following it comes "This Day Belongs To Me," a much more restrained and involved, mid-tempo brooder with some more epic, and highly infectious melodic solo work, doomy overtones, thudding skins, and unforgettable choruses. Hence, it is a tune that evokes "Monotheist"-era Celtic Frost. It is immediately offset, however, by "Marching Off To War," another blistering jaunt, this one home to pummeling death-grind blasts and ripping guitar leads, although it is also home to a mid-tempo breakdown with plenty of twiddly and wailing guitar melodies. And "Entering The Hall Of The Slain" continues in this same manner, with excellent, abrasively grinding riffs and strong, galloping hooks serving as the perfect compliment to stellar, unforgettably epic, and totally air-guitar-worthy melodious soloing.Then, after the buzzsaw-fast insistence of "Black Horizon," the record serves up one of its sole anomalies in the form of "Carved In Stone," which opens with a nice and peaceful acoustic guitar intro followed by a thunderous and pounding attack where ominously booming rhythms, dissonantly snarly/growly vocals, and blistering melodic soloing run the show. "Warriors Of Midgard," though, is a decapitating and uncompromising assault, a totally relentless and grindcore-worthy sprint of dexterously fast bass lines, rip-roaring guitars, smoldering rhythms, and pummeling drums.And rounding out the set are two final songs that simply must not be ignored. "Midsummer Solstice" is an especially catchy number with industrial-strength chugging. But its real highlight comes in the form of another epic, Exodus-style trade-off melodic solo section that is just plain fabulous. And, finally, "I Want You Dead" boasts another simplistic yet effective -- and, in this case, terrifically creepy and portentous --chorus (with staccato, chanted-esque vocals reciting the tune's title phrase), as well as plenty more crunchy and propulsive, chug and churn riffing, blazing melodic leads (that crop up in the background of the mix), and an ascending/descending solo run. The drumming also really stands out, here, as skinsman Anders Schultz, an all-too-often overlooked hero behind the trapkit, is granted to lay down plenty of really deft and machine gun-fast fills at various points throughout the song.Viking metal, death metal, death-thrash, blackened death metal, melodeath, death-grind -- "Hammer Battalion" is an excellent album, no matter what the genre, and one that is so full of the good stuff that it easily ranks amongst 2008's upper-tier for metal releases. And it makes the following fact very clear: Unleashed are one of the most criminally-underrated (or at least overlooked) bands in the history of extreme metal.

There is very little-to-no debate that Zakk Wylde (a.k.a. Jeffrey Phillip Wielandt) is a great guitarist (after all filling in for the absent seat vacated by Randy Rhodes, the original six-string virtuoso in the Ozzy Osbourne band, is no small feat.) And on the masterful "1919 Eternal," the third record from Black Label Society, the Zakk-fronted side project founded in 1999, Mr. Wylde plays a lot, thus quite frequently (to say the least) showing off his amazing, fretboard shredding skills. His talents are so great, in fact, that this 2002 recording argues the point that Zakk is a god of his instrument. And even though he probably might not be THE almighty guitar god (Jimi Hendrix and "Dimebag" Darrell Abbott edge him out), there is no question that he (alongside a few others, including Rhodes, Dave Mustaine, Yngwie Malmsteen, et al.) proudly sits at the right hand side of that throne.Zakk's instrumental mastery is, again, astounding pretty much all throughout "1919 Eternal." But it is at its most impressive on cuts like the very aptly-entitled "Battering Ram," which is, essentially, two and a half minutes of blistering buzzsaw riffage and thrashy tempo'ing; the uber-crunchy, meaty, and abrasively grinding riff cascade and thundering rhythms that back "Lords Of Destruction," and make it the irresistible headbanger that it is; the darkly dreary, dreamy, and docile acoustic balladry, splendidly jazzy, melodic soloing, and surprisingly decent clean singing of "Bridge To Cross" (which ultimately comes across sounding not unlike Pantera's cover of "Planet Caravan"); and the insanely, intricately gorgeous (and entirely instrumental) acoustic rendition of the appropriately-entitled set closer, "America The Beautiful."And, certainly, there are numerous other album highlights. Opener "Bleed For Me," with its galloping cadence, propulsive, chainsaw-stutter guitar leads, whammy bar-heavy solo flight, and really catchy and memorable vocal refrains make it one the best moments; and "Life/Birth/Blood/Doom," which augments its industrial-strength riffing and epic, several parted, and totally air-guitar-able soloing with funky, slapped bass lines (that are especially audible during a late-song bridge, and come courtesy of ex-Ozzy Osbourne/future Metallica bassist Robert Trujillo), is another.A handful of other choice standouts include the galloping, pounding, churning groove and memorable, sing-songy vocals found in "Graveyard Disciples"; the fiery, staccato lurch of "Demise Of Sanity"; and "Genocide Junkies," a nearly six-minute-long crunch-fest. Furthermore, The beautifully-plucked, flamenco-sounding string arrangements in the misleadingly-titled "Speedball" is not too shabby, either (making it much more than a mere minute-long interlude track); and the brutal, snarly vocals and machine-gun-like guitar licksmake "Refuse To Bow Down" also well-worth your time and attention.True, whether or not Zakk's songwriting is as stellar as his understanding of/grip on great riffs and wah-wah-drenched solos is very much up for debate. But it does not really matter, because "1919 Eternal" is pretty darn unforgettable either way. As such, it is absolutely essential listening for anybody that claims to be any kind of fan of sludge/doom/stoner metal, hard rock, and/or traditional heavy metal music, as a whole. And trust me when I say this: If you like virtuosic guitar work, you will fall deeply in love with this album.

Accepts fourteenth album proper is one of the more highly-anticipated heavy metal releases of the year. How did it get to such a prestigious status? Well, for starters, it is the bands first collection of new songs from the studio in over two and a half years. Secondly, after meeting with one postponement, debuted at number one on the German sales chart. Next, its release marks the thirty-fifth anniversary (believe it or not) of Accept being a band. And finally, but equally as importantly, 2014s Blind Rage proudly proclaims (on its cover) that Accept are the "gods of German metal" -- a risky statement to say the least.So does B.R. does it live up to the hype? The answer to that is, sadly, no, mainly because the Teutonic power metallers have very little earth left to scorch. But that in no way should imply that it is even in the same ballpark as a bad (or even mediocre) record. Indeed, the bands instrumental abilities remain as exceptional as ever, and their songwriting is finely honed and refined, too. As a result, it is a very, impeccably solid and unquestionably inspired effort, and one that is nothing if not extremely enjoyable.The pure, unabashed Judas Priest worship of aptly-entitled opener Stampede is very tolerable, and not just because of its crunchy, galloping beat, but because it is further highlighted by blistering, speed metal-lite tempoing, memorably aggressive, call-and-response vocal patterns, and a glass-shattering, dive-bombing guitar solo section. This is then succeeded by Dying Breed, an uber-crunchy and churning follow-up song, and Dark Side Of My Heart, a restrained, slow-motion chugger with more tasty and ripping solos galore. The ominous and foreboding Fall Of The Empire comes next, and it pins really, really memorable, chanted-like vocals against a tasty musical bed comprised of delicious harmonic lead work.The tempo might have dipped slightly over the course of the last couple of tracks, but the intensity level never fades even for a moment. And album centerpiece, Trail Of Tears, makes sure of this fact. It really revs up the engines again, playing like a no-holds-barred and blistering speed metal jaunt that races by like a sports car. And the nicely textured Wanna Be Free is an even bigger standout still, as it opens with a lovely bit of melody in the form of a colorful little acoustic intro. But this is then followed-up by a solid, grumbling bass line and steady guitar chug. And from there, the tune ascends to a speedy gallop iced off by another round of epic melodic-shred soloing.200 Years is another insanely hooky, industrial-strength chugger; and track eight, Bloodbath Mastermind, picks up pretty much right where the above-described song left off, starting out playing like a crunchy chugger before picking up steam. From there, it gradually builds to blistering speed metal-mania, complete with fiery chainsaw riffing. And the tracks epic scope is further illustrated by the fact that it boasts quite a few wailing solos, too.Then, following the nearly anthemic crescendo and great, climactic soloing of From The Ashes We Rise, Accept take one more venture through more restrained territory with The Curse, whose soaring, introductory harmonic leads lend the song an indisputably epic feel early on. And this vibe lingers pretty much throughout the duration of the tunes six and a half-minute-long playing time, even as it adopts crunchy guitar licks, wailing, Halford-esque vocals, and a rhythmic, militaristic-sounding cadence. And of course, the listener is also treated to another catchy and memorable chorus, and totally air-guitar-able solo section, to boot. But saving the best for last, aptly-named closing blast, Final Journey, is a full-on, heads-down, no-holds-barred thrash metal attack; an all-out speedster riddled with ferocious, rip-roaring riffage.Blind Rage is dragged down a bit by a dearth of surprises and truly excellent, timeless songs (the only thing that is at all surprising about it is how un-mind-blowing it is.) Even so, it is a very, very solid effort, and thus very strongly recommended if  you are a fan of traditional heavy metal, hard rock, and/or power metal. It is a good Accept album, just not a great one.

Like fellow hard rock revivalists such as Clutch, Bigelf, Brand New Sin, and (to a lesser extent) Avenged Sevenfold, Kentucky's Black Stone Cherry specialize in a brand of old-fashioned hard rock/alternative metal heavily influenced by the likes of Cream, Black Sabbath, Guns `N Roses, AC-DC, Led Zeppelin, Whitesnake, and the like. And if paying homage to the above-named groups was their intent, then they most certainly achieved said goal admirably well on their fourth full-length.On the whole, thoough, 2014's "Magic Mountain" feels a little bit on the limp side, as if the band is holding a little bit back, and not rocking quite as hard as they possibly could. As such, the record could stand to be a touch or two heavier. And furthermore, it is quite blatantly lacking originality. But that's not to say that it is without potential, because B.S.C. are clearly a group very competent musicians and decent-enough songwriters, and one that is very capable of producing an album that is not without a few flashes of brilliance.Among the standout tracks, it is cuts like opener "Holding On...To Letting Go," which gets things started on the right foot, as a b*lls-out hard rocker by brimming with meaty, Sabbath-y riffs reminiscent of Zakk Wylde, that seems to be the most irresistible And plenty of catchy swing/swagger, pounding rhythms, and unorthodoxly shredding, wah-pedal-wanking soloing helps to make sure of this fact. Elsewhere, "Peace Pipe" struts a catchy chug-and gallop-that evokes vintage Aerosmith -- and it is one threaded by steady, grumbling bass fills, and some more exceptional, twin-guitar-harmony heavy lead work.The wah-wah-heavy "Bad Luck & Hard Love" is among the most infectious and air-guitar-able moments on the whole record, but it is track four, "Me And Mary Jane," that is the set's lead-single. Quite obviously, too, as it plays like vintage Black Stone Cherry, what with its heavy, metallic verses iced off by pop hooks and radio-ruling melodies. Nevertheless, it is a pretty darn great hard-rock-boogie, as it boasts a thundering main guitar riff, pounding, propulsive drumming, wah-wah-inflected leads, and super strong chorus hooks.Moving along, the set's first hit-or-miss tune comes in the form of "Runaway," a much more melodic and open, ballad-esque jam with sing-songy vocal patterns that practically cry "arena-friendly." And moving to the next step up on the heavy ladder, the title song is fueled by industrial-strength guitar leads, and really hooky, sing-along-worthy vocal refrains. With that said, though, it is the track's Audioslave-like hand-clap that is what really ensures that this is the biggest and most bonafide party song to be found, here.The downtuned guitar crunch and pulsing bass throbs are offset very well by particularly catchy melodic chorus in "Never Surrender"; and "Blow My Mind" is another good inclusion, playing like an up-tempo and lively hard rocker, what with its pyrotechnically propulsive guitar shredding. But, unfortunately, soon thereafter, "Magic Mountain" dips a tad in quality, as the ensuing "Sometimes" is an entirely unplugged ballad. And it is not necessarily a bad one, either, but it is one that just comes across as overall a bit unnecessary, and actually kind of detrimental to the album's flow and momentum.Most memories of such mediocrity are soon all-but lost, though, by the time the surprisingly brutal and borderline anthemic "Fiesta Del Fuego" rolls around. And "Dance Girl" is also very decent, as it is another slab of pop-inflected hard rock where prominent bass fills swoop in and out of bobbing rhythms and crunchy, lurching guitar-grooves. And it all flows perfectly into an epically catchy and melodic, open-aired choruses. Unfortunately, following that, things again take a turn towards the downward slide, as "Hollywood In Kentucky" is a total throwaway of a track (it sounds like it could darn well be a Nickelback or latter-day Kid Rock outtake). And also on the weak front, "Remember Me" begins as a tasty, crunchy piece of swingin' hard rock (complete with plenty of refined guitar soloing); but soon becomes unglues once its huge, radio-ready choruses hit.Sure, there are numerous groups that do this brand of metallic, Southern-flavored hard rock better than Black Stone Cherry (see: Velvet Revolver, Black Label Society, and Rebel Meets Rebel, among others). So what this means is that "Magic Mountain" is definitely decent enough to check out, just so long as you do not expect it to be a watershed-worthy masterpiece. And to help ensure the fact that you won't come away from it sorely disappointed, think more along the lines of it being a release that is solid and certainly enjoyable, just not one that is overly unique or unforgettable, and one that is likely to leave the listener (and the genre, as a whole) largely unmoved.

Much like their fellow Illinois-bred extremists Lair Of The Minotaur, Indian a ferocious, beastly amalgam of most things heavy. They are rooted in Eyehategod/Sleep/The Melvins-inspired sludge metal, but do not stop there, as they filter in a lot of noisecore (a la Unsane, Botch, and Converge) elements, and also have more than a few leanings towards the doom metal genre. And as if that didn't make them extreme enough, they also filter in some progressive metal elements. With that said, though, make sure to note that their songs are only progressive in terms of epic and unorthodox song structures -- because speaking from a sound-wise perspective, they are maybe ten times more brutal, dissonant, and less melodic and tuneful than you are used to hearing from the progressive music world. Next up, there are a few faint Discharge/Black Flag-styled hardcore punk and Cradle Of Filth/Darkthrone-like black metal tinges present in these arrangements. And finally, like some Nineties sludge metallists (i.e. EHG, Acid Bath, Soilent Green, etc.), and new millennium groups (Mastodon, Gojira, Withered, et al.) do, Indian also adopt a harsh, ear-pinning-back approach when it comes to vocals. (They are so atonal and amelodic that they actually have much more in common with the grindcore genre than anything.)But just so we are clear: This is first and foremost a sludge metal band. Their fourth full-length, 2014's full-length, "From All Purity," just differs from most of the works put out by, say, the Crowbars, Downs, and The Swords of the world because it is essentially almost devoid of individually memorable riffs. But note that this reviewer said "devoid" and not "lacking" or "missing," because Indian's style of repeatedly churning out searing, droning, wall-of-sound guitar noise is not without its charm. So yes, there are very few hooks or air-guitar-able moments to be had, here, meaning that this is the kind of record that you put on and just let consume you. But even if it comes up short in the commercially accessible and traditionally catchy departments; it more than makes up for by having guitar work that could not be fuller of visceral aggression, urgency, resonance, and potency. And besides, it is a bit refreshing to hear some sludge/doom metal songs that aren't simple Black Sabbath re-warmings (there's a lot more going on in the riffs than to call them that), nor are they ones that will have the listener playing "name that guitar lick" for the duration of this set's thirty-nine-and-a-half minute-long playing time.It all makes "F.A.P." one album that will probably not put Indian anywhere near the front of the "next big thing" list, but one that should surely give them a front-running start towards becoming a pretty darn important group in the underground metal world. "Rape" plays very much like an Eyehategod b-side, as it boasts a wall of feedback-spewing guitars, mammoth, crunching riff chunk, and pounding rhythms. The vocals, meanwhile, scream away in an unnervingly dissonant and high pitched squeal, thus evoking some weird blackened-noisecore hybrid. From there, the opening blast segues through a terrifically dark and portentous section with droning, crawling, atmospheric guitar noise, before closing with some powerfully-pounding, rhythmically martial-sounding drum fills. And working similarly, "The Impetus Bleeds" is backed by another monstrous, thunderous guitar slice sandwiched between darkly droning, sludgy feedback and noise-derived sound effects. And when it is all topped off again by the frontman's larynx-lacerating, throat-scraping, eardrum-piercing shrieks, screams, and snarls, the end result is an extra urgent, violent, and angsty number that just might make you want to get into a fight and smash some faces."Directional" is another exercise in churning, blood-curdling sludge/doom metal, as it again finds the band kicking out one big, ominously dense, and uber-dangerous guitar line while the vocalist (Dylan O'Toole) is practically foaming at the mouth as he is howling all over it, and the band's drummer lays down a simple drum beat that consists mainly of crashing, slow-motion cymbal rides. As a result, what is created are some droning stoner metal rhythms that might obviously be quite repetitive, but never come across as being boring or redundant.Next come the record's two biggest curveballs in "Rhetoric Of No" and "Clarity." The first of which exercises some very surprising tempo variation in that it is an up-tempo jaunt reminiscent of EHG's "Dopesick"-era that captures an almost punk-like level of chaos and velocity. It also features some pleasantly surprising variation in its guitar work. Needless to say, it is one very crushing and thunderous number with lumbering guitar leads, squealing noise/sound effects, a beefy bottom-end, and momentous, pounding drum beats. And the latter of these two songs is a blaring, squealing, noise-drenched soundscape that evokes a blend of Superjoint Ritual, AxCx, The Melvins, and Fantomas. And needless to say, it is filled with guitar distortion, high-pitched sound effects, and distorted, perverted, electronic-heavy screams.And finally, we get the set closer, "Disambiguation," which is another superbly creepy and portentous piece/noise collage that boasts miles and miles of jarring, nightmarish figures. It has some Pelican-esque riffage, but for the most part is a psychotically, schizophrenically cluttered noise collage comprised of ominously grumbling bass lines, reverberated, part Mike Williams and part Dani Filth-esque scream-shriek vocals, and the like. "Disambiguation" is also home to a droning, towering doom metal riff and some on-again/off-again bursts of surprisingly fast, tight, and brutal double bass slamming. So, when arriving right at the point, it is a very, very strong way to conclude an already extremely promising album.As if the mere mention of Eyehategod's name in an Indian review weren't enough of a high compliment, let me put it in plain English for you, here: It is a definite, distinct possibility that this Chicago collective are the Eyehategod of this generation. They certainly have the potential, instrumental chops, and staying power to be. So again, "From All Purity" might not exactly be everyone's cup of tea, but that does not mean it isn't a resoundingly successful effort. After all, it is a nightmarishly dark, dense, and disturbingly dissonant affair that makes for a brutally exhausting and challenging listen. But it is also a pretty darn great one, too.

Iron Maiden. Judas Priest. Helloween. Blind Guardian. In Flames. Children Of Bodom. Slayer. Metallica. Megadeth. Dream Theater. Yngwie Malmsteen. These are all obviously heavy sources of influence for Dragonforce. But anybody that knows the first thing about heavy metal music knows that all of these bands are mere launch-pads for DF, because the U.K.-based extreme power/speed metal collective actually has a sound that, while not completely all their own, is very unique and inventive. It boasts miles and miles of spectacular solo skills, blazing leads, and propulsive thrash riffs, in addition to its usual truckload of overtly cheesy lyricism and soaring melodic vocals. But Dragonforce's sound differentiates from that of most modern day power metallists mainly in that it overflows with mind-boggling, face-ripping, head-spinning musicianship, including impossibly technical guitar work, and an airtight interplay between it and the rhythm section.But the sixth full-length studio effort from the much-ballyhooed sextet is much different from anything else that they have ever recorded before, except for maybe 2012's "The Power Within." (See, that two-year old album marked a bit of a turning point for Dragonforce, as it was the first to feature a song that was mid-tempo without being ballad-esque.) So while the speeds remain blistering for much of the duration of the fifty-minute playing time, DF do occasionally ease off of the gas pedal, exploring various other tempos and moods, and toggling back and forth between them and the band's usual cut-throat speed metal policy.As a result of this increasingly intelligent songwriting, the individual track identity has also gone way up this time around. Pounding opener "The Game" and "No More" are both highlighted by a great guest spot from Trivium frontman Matt Heafy. And his presence is almost transparent on the former of these two epics, because despite the cameo, it plays like a fairly prototypical Dragonforce epic, as it is a dizzying, squealing deluge of thrashing grooves, ridiculously tight drumming (including plenty of thunderous blast beats), and soaring clean vocals. And, naturally, the song, the album's wisely-chosen lead single, by the way, is also not without a section where the band rips out a lengthy, unorthodoxly strangulated and screaming guitar solo section. But Heafy is allowed to lend more of his personality to the latter song, because although this might be another rip-roaring speedster, it does feature some distinctly metalcore-esque/influenced/flavored vocal patterns in its choruses. This, however, is to go along with the usual abundance of machine gun drums, ripping guitar leads, and white-hot soloing.Sandwiched in between these two tracks (described above) is another good inclusion, if one that will probably be overlooked all too often because of its surroundings. Indeed, "Tommorrow's Kings" is another blast of furious speed where barreling, buzzsaw riffage and unforgettably epic choruses (that sound like they could have been ripped out of some long-lost Bruce Dickinson notepad) run the show. Needless to say, it all makes for one other really epic tune, and one that has plenty of longevity and un-forget-ability."Three Hammers" and "Symphony Of The Night" are similar in that they both epically stagger a variety of different speeds, and both open with a melodic, fade-in part before eventually kicking up massive amounts of blistering speed, and propulsion. "Three Hammers" opts for a harmonic guitar part (complete with epic-sounding melodic leads and even some acoustic strumming); whereas "Symphony..." chooses to instead include a cool, haunted house-esque harpsichord. And even though the band does immediately plunge into the depths of propulsive, uber-crunchy, and belligerent thrash/speed metal territory, they do also ease off of the gas pedal, allowing for some mid-song breathing in the form of slow tempo changes and jazzy melodic leads/soloing.And the former of the two tunes even goes a step further down this path of exploring different velocities and volumes by featuring some thoroughly restrained -- especially for Dragonforce -- pacing. And while "Three Hammers" does eventually transition through blustery chainsaw riffage and screaming, wild, shredding solos, it always retains a certain melodic edge, thanks mostly due to its harmonized, falsetto clean vocal hooks (which have more in common with an actual ballad than any real metal song.)Moving along, "The Sun Is Dead," is easily the album's most epic piece, and not just because it clocks in at well past the six and a half minute mark. See, even though this is a predominately speedy number dominated by gnawing, chugging guitar riffs, and fast, grumbling bass lines, it also explores a few various other approaches and shifts in mood, most notably when it slows almost all of the way down, filtering in some placid acoustic strings and jazzy, trade-off solos. And as if all of that weren't enough, the icing on "Sun"'s cake comes from it being further highlighted by epic vocal patterns, pyrotechnic guitar solos, technically-impressive bass soloing, and some excellent keyboard soloing, to boot. (Indeed, everybody in the band but the drummer gets in on the soloing action, here!)And working your way through the rest of the record, a track called "Defenders" plays like a never-ending cascade of solid, chugging riffs, chainsaw-stutter leads, and twiddly, neoclassical melodic soloing anchored by more punishing, blast beat-esque drumming. And this then proves to be only a stage setter for "Extraction Zone" and "City Of Gold," two other ripping, heads-down thrash scorchers with thunderous, dexterous drumming, huge, galloping guitar hooks, dazzling leads, and epic, harmonic, high-flying solos out the wazoo. And finally, we are also treated to one final inclusion in "Ring Of Fire," a spot-on-yet-simultaneously ten-times-heavier, thrashier, and fierier-than-the-original Johnny Cash cover song. Suffice it to say, it, too, is home to a catchy, galloping cadence, and plenty of blistering solos. On "Maximum Overload," Dragonforce make painfully obvious to the rest of the world that they have, like metal's elite, already mastered the art of letting off of the ignition slightly without ever losing even a single iota of momentum. By doing so, the band might not be looking to turn new heads, but they have nevertheless certainly crafted their finest and most well-rounded, accomplished, expansive, interesting, and dynamically textured effort to date.

This one is a monster, folks. The elventh full-length from Schledamn's Sinister is a slab of pure, grade A, 110% old-fashioned extreme metal intensity, conjuring up memories of early death metal bands such as Morbid Angel, Deicide, Cannibal Corpse, Vader, Vomitory, and latter-day Immolation. And some influence from a few younger acts like Nile, (latter-day) Krisiun, Dying Fetus, and Hate Eternal also come into play at several various points throughout 2014's "The Post-Apocalyptic Servant." The end result is a record that possesses the same motto as what a football coach should expect from his team on the eve of the biggest game of their lives: Fired up and ready to play! (What this translates to in a more literal sense is producing grinding, rip-roaring speeds, impeccable musicianship, and exceptional technicality.)The songs continuously balance ear-catching groove with all-out, nerve-damaging extreme metal chaos. The record begins in skull-cracking fashion, with "The Science Of Prophecy" being a jackhammer-fast blast fest of pummeling drums, thrashy, racing guitar leads, Frank Mullen-meets-Chris Barnes-meets-David Vincent-esque vocal stylings, and blistering solos. And "The Macabre God" follows this up in suitably crushing fashion, as it, too, overflows with thunderous riffage, cracking grindcore blasts, and evil, visceral vocals. (The drummer is of particular note, here, as he is heard riding a tight, stop-start pattern pretty much all-throughout "Macabre God," but another blazing, careening guitar solo also rips the air, in this song, too.) But immediately following up these two exercises in scorched earth devastation, "T.P.A.S." then proceeds to explore some more restrained territory, dipping into chugging, Bolt Thrower-sounding grooves on cuts such as "The Sculpture Of Insanity," "The End Of All That Conquers" (which features an unorthodoxly ripping guitar solo section), and "The Dome Of Pleasure.""The Masquerade Of An Angel" is another very possible highpoint, as it is a blistering and almost purely thrashy scorcher of a song with some noteworthy bass work (two excellent bass solos are slipped into the mix at various points throughout the number). And this track, the album's centerpiece, is also highlighted by some particularly strong and infectious hooks, a few well-placed and breakneck fast tempo change-ups, and another fiery, shred-happy solo section. Elsewhere, the title track is another thundering drum blast and blistering riff-fest that, again, sounds positively awesome, even as it beats the listener down into submission at 3,000 BPM; and the Slayer-iffic, foundation-shaking "The Art Of Skin Decoration" like-mindedly features careening, Slayer/Sepultura-esque guitar leads, and scalding riffage galore. And this is, naturally, to go along with the track's musical bed, which is comprised mainly of frenetic, machine gunning percussion. But the arrangements do make room for a very surprisingly melodic solo section to rip the air, though, too.And rounding out the set are two final gems in "The Saviour" and "The Burden Of Mayhem." The former is home to some of the record's most individually memorable riffs -- and what thunderous, abrasive, and gear-grinding riffs, they are too! -- as well as another especially excellent performance from drummer Toep Duin. Indeed, Duin might opt to fill this song with plenty of earthquake blasting, but also is sure to include plenty of variation, including some non-double-bass-driven sections, and smart, crashing cymbal patterns. And the latter of these two tracks ("Mayhem") is also highlighted by some more excellent, meaty riff slices and thunderously chugging rhythms, but is mainly of note for featuring a terrifically portentous and ominous, spoken-word dialogue vocal line. And some more respectably ripping solo flights are also utilized here, and to excellent effect. (The solo section is abnormally lengthier and more epic in this song than in most.)Brutal. Crushing. Uncompromising. All of which are phrases -- check that, compliments -- that could -- check that, SHOULD -- be used to describe "The Post Apocalyptic Servant." Seriously, folks, this is one piece of music that might not reinvent the death metal wheel, but one that most certainly greases the axles until they squeak. As a result, it is very highly recommended that all fans of satisfying, meat-and-potatoes death metal buy this platter of satiating, meat-and-potatoes death metal from Sinister. It is, after all, an easy to love effort from a band that has already all-but clinched its status as one of the most criminally under-appreciated and overlooked of the Nineties.

Is the "album" really dead? Well, in this day and age of mP3's, YouTube, and who knows how many iGadgets, I can certainly see how you would think so. Yet for all of the single song downloads and inclinations there are nowadays, there are a select few records that still exist with a very "album"-esque feel to them. What this means is that they have steadfast wall-to-wall sequencing, and track listings where each song is as good and important to the set as the last. For one example of this, proceed to long-player number eleven from Stockholm's Opeth, 2014's "Pale Communion."With this record, frontman Mikael Akerfeldt and Company have done the improbable, if not necessarily the impossible: Crafted a masterpiece that is equally as fitting for headphones and arena theaters alike. It is a very, if unsurprisingly well-disciplined effort, as it is one that might lack immediate sonic heaviness, but is also completely devoid of uneven consistency, diluted superfluous fat, and/or filler material. And with this album, Opeth continue to define what it means for a band to be firing on all cylinders, as evidenced by everything from its stellar musicianship to its brilliant songwriting to its infectious melodies, stellar, inspiring vocals, and hummable hooks, right down to its immaculate production job, impassioned delivery, and epic-yet-simultaneously concise delivery."Pale Communion" also achieves a perfect equilibrium from mixing epic yet accessible song structures and arrangements with more traditional-minded choruses and crispy, sunny melodies. As a result of crafting this record around such densely-assembled and written anthems, it seems like now would be a very inappropriate time for longtime fans to cry "sell out" at the band. If they were going to do that, it probably should have been done after 2003's entirely unplugged effort, "Damnation." As it is, however, what Opeth have created, here, is much less like a commercially accessible cash-in and more like the perfect follow-up to 2011's "Heritage."The gems are found in abundance over the course of this fifty-six-minute-long set. Opener "Eternal Rains Will Come" is surprisingly heavy, but mainly because of how its thundering, lumbering, Atheist/Cynic-esque bass line is skillfully slipped into its mix of dramatic-sounding keyboards, jazzy drum rolls, and orchestral/choral-tinged backing vocals. This, subsequently, leads to the song then swooping down into an ambient, keys `n' all interlude where a bit of placid piano playing adorns gentle string arrangements. And this, then, leads to things adopting an epic melodic groove, one that is replete with gently, melodically humming bass grumbles, jangly acoustic guitar strumming, and jazzy melodical soloing. And it is all topped off by a gorgeously accomplished, heavily layered clean vocal from Mikael. And equally as irresistible is the album's lead single, "Cusp Of Eternity," which is predominately driven by crunchy, chug and churn riffing and looming keyboard accents, and is also home to another simply fantastic vocal performance. But this tune's real highlight comes in the form of its epic, soaring melodic solo work, as it is easily one of the most amazing -- if not THE most amazing -- solo sections that this reviewer has ever had the pleasure of hearing Opeth attach their name to.Back on the heavier side of the line, "Moon Above, Son Below" kicks off with a strong, grumbling bass intro before turning to a bass-driven prog metal groove, and even goes so far as to be flirty with some surprisingly aggressive vocal stylings (some near death metal-esque growling is included, here). The number does then open up into colorful, soaring prog rock territory, with stellar, heavenly clean singing and spindly acoustics; but this is again before it leads back into the aforementioned locomotive groove. And "Moon Above..." continues wrestling back and forth between beauty and brutality for the remainder of its duration, offsetting said groove with blissful a capella vocals and harmonized melodic guitars. Some more splendid, crystalline-sounding soloing again finds its way into the mix, here, in this epically epic piece, a sprawling, ten-and-a-half minute long exercise in progressive music excess that also features a terrifically somber, stabbing organ, and places it right alongside a rolling groove concocted by a dirge-like keyboard line and deft, jazzy, drum roll-style fills."Elysian Woes" opens sounding like a "Damnation"-era outtake, as it is a gorgeous brooder graced by a lovely, dexterous, acoustic-plucked riff and soulful clean singing. Add some more jazzy melodic soloing to the mix, and the end result is one extremely light, heavenly, somber, and ethereal piece of progressive rock ambiance. And continuing this "album"-like tradition, the record then opts for a rather short instrumental interlude-esque track in "Goblin," which clocks in at a relatively scant four-and-a-half minutes in length, thus coming across as like a continuation of the already described epic that preceded it. This piece of full-on, Seventies-esque arena metal really adds to the set's powerhouse prog rock vibe, and ultimately comes across sounding not entirely unlike a Jethro Tull cover. It features a palm-muted arpeggio guitar riff, and its heavy use of jazzy bass lines and proggy synth blankets both help to aid it in the undeniably funky-sounding approach taken to its overtones.And picking up right where "Goblin" leaves off, Opeth drop in "River," another b-e-a-utiful prog-rock venture that blends together divinely harmonic, unplugged guitar strumming perfectly with more of Mikael's superb, harmonized vocals. But keeping things at least mildly unpredictable, at around four minutes into things, the track adopts a technical, beeping, slapped bass part and some more fantastic neo-classical melodic guitar soloing that is again harmonized perfectly into the arrangements. And some ringing, gently crashing drum cymbals intermittently pepper the mix, here, too. Next up comes "Voice Of Treason," a symphonic/orchestral-tinged piece with plenty of strongly pronounced, grumbling bass, cymbal-heavy drum beats, and lurching guitar hooks to go along with its usual abundance of ethereal keyboards, and soaring vocal melodicism. With that said, though, "Voice..." is actually mostly a highlight song for its brief but memorable flirtation with colorful, middle Eastern-inspired twin-guitar harmonies, and Arabian-like flamenco guitar splashes -- a move that rivals the works of Nile and Morbid Angel in the experimental departments."Pale Communion" then wraps up any and all remaining loose-ends in fittingly stunning fashion with "Faith In Others," one more positively unforgettable piece. It augments sinfully sweet and infectious vocal cooing (which you will find yourself singing along to, and maybe even humming from memory later on in the day) with orchestral tinges, beautiful acoustic guitars, and even what sounds like the use of some violin accompaniment. It all couples together to form a breathtaking soundscape that might not be particularly long (especially by Opeth standards), but one that is still undeniably epic. After all, what better way is there to describe the amounts of inventive breadth, sonic depth, and trippy texture on tap, here? In fact, come to think of it, one might even make a good case for arguing the point that "Faith In Others" is the epic to end all epics -- a fitting sentiment when considering it is the set's closer.In summary, do not let words like "experimental," "trippy," "sweet," and/or "ethereal" deter you: This is not only a definite standout in Opeth's discography, it is hands down one of the best pieces of musical psychedelia you are bound to hear all of this year. So do not miss out on what is easily already the best progressive music effort released in all of 2014. And don't be worried about genres and all, just embrace the album for the masterpiece of modern music that it is. Besides, "P.C." might lack the visceral satisfaction that previous Opeth epics possessed (i.e. see the brutal death metal-leanings of 1998's "My Arms, Your Hearse," or 2002's "Deliverance," for two examples of those), but as far as the big picture goes, this new stuff is actually quite a bit heavier.

Despite being overshadowed by the majority of the population thanks to the uprising of a batch of fellow New York-based hardcore stalwarts (including Sick Of It All and Prong), as well as some modern-day metallic-hardcore rockers (i.e. Sworn Enemy, et al.), and even a few New York-bred crossover hardcore/thrash titans (like Anthrax and Stormtroopers Of Death), NYC's Madball are actually every bit as good as the next band. They certainly have the instrumental skills and convincing delivery to rival anybody else -- that much is for certain on their new album, full-length number eight, 2014's "Hardcore Lives."And in this day and age of innumerable hardcore subgenres (i.e. post-hardcore, melodic hardcore, and, most prevalently, metallic hardcore/metalcore), it is so refreshing to hear a band do hardcore the right way, the way it was meant to be played. As such, you can expect lots of visceral aggression, very little technicality involved in the musical arrangements, straightforward song structuring, and only just enough melody to be memorable on this record. It's almost as if Madball are saying to the rest of the world: "This is hardcore, and anybody that does anything less than this is just imitating." All told, it seems like a heartfelt "thank you" very well-deserved from the heavy music world to frontman Freddy Cricien and Company.The album's "Intro" track is exactly that: A very thrashy and even-more catchy instrumental opener with headbanging, fist-pumping chugging that is sure to get many-a-pit revved up. And it flows right into the record's rousing  title cut, a mean, heads-down bruiser with thrash-derived pacing, picking, and raging vocals. "The Balance" is the first instance, here, where the rhythm section is really fleshed-out and allowed some time in the limelight, what with its pounding double-kick drumming and grumbling bass lines. But even without these two attributes, said song would still be a keeper on account of it being a blistering mosh pit anthem that also features fiery guitars and memorable, call-and-response vocal patterns."Hardcore Lives" then continues in this bass-driven fashion with "Doc Marten Stomp," another bass-heavy bruiser. But this one differentiates itself from the rest of the pack on account of it also being highlighted by some backing vocals that could almost verge on being called "borderline clean." And next up after that, we get "DNA," which plays almost like full-on Nineties thrash, what with its scalding, buzzsaw-fast picking and smashing skins. With that said, though, the tune does retain some of Madball's patented hardcore attitude, as it does not forsake the use of chugging, gut-checking hardcore punk breakdowns and chanted, constipated yelling.Track six, "True School," is an even bigger standout still, as it boasts a guest spot from Terror's Scott Vogel. And needless to say, he really helps to make this one unforgettable exercise in blistering and brutal, pain-inflicting hardcore-tinged thrash, and one that is home to some extra-memorable and ferocious vocals. The next two songs after that find Madball again delving  back into their traditional hardcore sound, as "The Here And Now" and "Nothing To Me" are both heavily reliant on the almighty chug and breakdown. (But two more really memorable and empowering choruses help to make sure that these two cuts are both better-than-your-average page out of the hardcore playbook.)"My Armor" might be relatively brief, as it clocks in at only ninety-seven seconds in length, but it nevertheless still packs one mighty forceful punch. It is a very, very Pantera-esque scorcher that opens with Cricien hollering "1,2,3,4" before diving headfirst into a rip-roaring river of blistering thrash riffage and pummeling drums. And what's more, but "My Armor" also utilizes a cameo from not one, not two, but three guest vocalists: Toby Morse, Chad Gilbert, and CM Punk, and does so to excellent effect. (There are some truly unforgettable vocal stylings in the song's choruses.) And some solid bass work (i.e. grumbling bass fills) also highlights the arrangements, here, as well."Beacon Of Light" might be another speedy, and ultra-abrasive number with grinding guitar licks and catchy, chanted vocals; but it is overshadowed by the three standouts that come next. "Born Strong" (which features Candace Puopolo on vocals) is a scathing assault of machine gun-fast riffing/drumming, clangy bass lines, and bellowed, chant-along vocal refrains; while the next two after that are both pieces of Latin-music-inspired metalcore. Indeed, both "Spirit" and the bass-driven "Mi Palabra" are fiery, thrashy jaunts home to Spanish-sung (or, more accurately, shouted) lyrics, thus evoking memories of Sepultura's "Chaos A.D." days. "H.L." serves up two final gems as a grand finale. The first of which, "NBNC," is a scant, twenty-seven-second long blast of hooky, staccato riffing and impressively acrobatic, near blast beat-esque drumming; whereas the second, "For The Judged" is one final mosh-pit stoking bludgeon that smells strongly of Biohazard influence. It is one super abrasive bugger, that's for sure, and is backed by solid, locomotive chugging and quick, pounding thrash beats."Hardcore Lives" is one darn solid record, and one that can stand toe-to-toe with the likes of Ringworm and Nausea in order to be a leading contender for the much-sought after "Hardcore album of the year (2014)" category. After all, Madball might not exactly be spring chickens anymore (in fact, with a quarter of a century under their belts, they are actually pretty old). But none of that matters because they are still on the top of their game. And so long as they continue playing to their strengths (lean, mean hardcore with a strict diet of red meat and potatoes), they will always keep releasing albums that are of this strong magnitude.

Has it really been six long years since the release of Bigelf's last album, 2008's fifth long-player "Cheat The Gallows"? Yes. And has the band endured a significant lineup hiccup in order to now returned with a new supporting cast of characters, including guitarist Luis Maldonato and Dream Theater drummer Mike Portnoy? Maybe so. But the Los Angeles band's vision remains as focused and unified as ever: To kick out some of the best and most psychedelic progressive hard rock this side of Mastodon and Wolfmother.The Eighties hard rock revivalists definitely possess a strong resemblance to Black Sabbath, Dio, UFO, Type O Negative, and Led Zeppelin, but they are every bit as equally influenced by, say, Pink Floyd, King Crimson, Mr. Bungle, and Jethro Tull. Various comparisons to the likes of Rush and Tool can also be made. And, of course, the Beatles are also another major source of inspiration -- and needless to say, it is very fitting when considering how Bigelf have long since described themselves as "the evil Beatles." And now all they have to do is live-up to such a prestigiously high description, and darned if they do not come awfully close on this 2014 recording.The heaviest song on "Into The Maelstrom" is "Control Freak," because it boasts a big, fat, sludgy, and instinctively memorable main riff, and a little shred-lite soloing. And all the while this is going on, the drummer, Portnoy, thumps away at his trapkit in a manner very similar to Led Zeppelin's John Bonham. It all makes for one very heavy and doomy song, and one that is not likely to be forgotten anytime soon, but not the only standout track there is to be had, here. "Incredible Time Machine" evokes Black Sabbath's drug-crazed period, as it augments a chunky, lurching, Sabbath-y riff with oh-so-0zzy Osbourne-esque singing to create one really experimental and ethereal number, and a fitting album opener. But if you think this song is weird, then just proceed to the ensuing second track, "Hypersleep," which, with its trippy, A.I.-esque intro, crashing drum cymbals, and really weird, synthesizer/flute-sounding melody, is an aural head-trip of a song, and one whose huge, pounding, sludge/doom metal riff and wailing vocal line get lost in the tune's out-of-this-world overtones."Already Gone" begins sounding like another heavily experimental number, as it opens as a slab of acoustic power balladry. But this is all before the song hits an energy crescendo, steadily gaining heaviness, and climaxes by segueing through a heavy section with a chunky electric guitar riff, and some shredding, Jimi Hendrix-stylized soloing. And next after that comes "Alien Frequency" is another heavily proggy piece, this one highlighted by some especially excellent and superbly dexterous drum fills that evoke memories of Zepp's forty-five-year old hit, "Moby Dick." And while we're on that note, let me mention the album's closing song, "ITM," because it again finds the drummer channeling his inner John Bonham. It is an eight-minute and twelve-second long bookending composition, and one that is divided into three epic movements: "Destination Unknown," "Harbinger Of Death," and "Memories." It is an intermittently heavy piece, although one that is mostly proggy and melodic, with plenty of Beatles-inspired tunefulness and ambiance.Elsewhere, "The Professor & The Madman" is highlighted by a heavily progressive intro that has been harmonized into little, tiny pieces before segueing through a section that utilizes a sitar, as well as some irresistible wah-wah-heavy guitar hooks. The next two tracks after that, "Mr. Harry McQuhae" and "Vertigod," both strongly conjure up memories of vintage Rush and Queen. The former opens as a piano ballad before escalating to guitar-driven sections iced with Ozzy-inspired vocals and looming keyboard ambiance, thus creating one pretty darn gorgeous and extremely jazzy soundscape, and an epic that clocks in at well past the six-minute mark. And the latter song ("Vertigod"), with its fuzzy guitar riff and high-pitched vocal harmonies, sounds almost like it could be a "2112"-era b-side.But the record's biggest highlights are actually found later on, as "High," is an epic venture into the nether-worldly realm of prog-rock psychedelia, and one that is backed by a piano intro, trippy, looming synth line, falsetto vocal hooks, jazzy drumming, and a steady guitar chug. "Theater Of Dreams," then, is a very dreamy and ethereal song with theatrical-sounding vocals, thus again heavily evoking memories of "Yellow Submarine"-era Beatles; but it is preceded by another, significantly heavy cut in "Edge Of Oblivion," a crunchy, doomy rocker with a heavy, grumbling bass line and some more Ozzy-indebted clean singing to go along with its extremely deft, inventive, and dexterous drum fills. And some nicely clean and jazzy-sounding guitar leads adorn the mix, here, too, just for good measure.Yes, "Into The Maelstrom" does suffer from a production job that is probably much too unnecessarily murky, distorted, and low-fi. And plus, there is very little material present, here, that grabs the listener with its scream of "instant classic," or is likely to convert absolutely zero new fans to the Bigelf crowd, but it does not need to. Why? Because an album as consistently good and unique as this deserves merit from anybody that knows what they are talking about when it comes to the world of hard rock. Solid and mostly satisfying, "Maelstrom" just might be Bigelf's best and most accompished effort to date.

Chockablock full of excellent riffs, commanding leads, and screaming solos, High On Fires second full-length, Surrounded By Thieves, is easily one of the heaviest non-death metal/grindcore recordings of 2002. And the guitar pyrotechnics are not the only attribute that the Oakland-based stoner metal experts have going for them, as H.O.F. also boast plenty of catchy, Lemmy-meets-Ozzy-inspired vocals, guttural bass rumbles, and dexterous drum beats. It all comes together to make for one of the finest stoner metal offerings of the new millennium. But hey, what else would you expect from a band that rose out of the ashes of primitive doom metal giants Sleep? (Frontman Matt Pike did used to front that genre-defining group back in the Nineties.)Much of the album, including bruising album standouts like the thunderously booming Nemisis, the pyrotechnic title cut, and the percussively-intense Razor Hoof, gets by on a commanding, sludgy riff slice and lumbering rhythm backed by really energetic and forceful drumming. The end result creates some deliciously pounding, head-rattling grooves. But the records two most outstanding cuts are actually found elsewhere, in The Yeti, a sprawling, seven-plus-minute long epic that interweaves some nifty, wah-tinged guitar leads and a blistering, careening shred-solo into its mix of ominous licks and viscerally rumbling bass. And an even greater behemoth is found two tracks later, as Thraft Of Caanan compliments another hugie-pugie, churning sludge/doom metal riff that is as meaty as it is gripping, with clattering cymbal crashes and a sludgy, heavy bass line. This epic piece, which clocks in at well past the eight minute mark, is also home to some of Thieves best and most epic and lengthiest guitar soloing, too.But do the highlights stop there? Oh, abso-friggin-lotuely not! After beginning with a slowly-burning ambient intro (consisting of portentous wind whooshes and footsteps), opener Eyes And Teeth storms onto the scene with a pounding, droning, Sabbath-y sludge riff, crashing drum beat, and ominously grumbling bass line. And this is all before the piece uncorks a strangulated, winding guitar solo, too. Another track to pay close attention to is Speedwolf, because it opens with a nice little guitar melody before slamming, like a brick wall, into a ginormous, devastating, towering doom-laden electric guitar riff and thunderous rhythm. And a brief but nicely dissonant and very screaming solo pops up later on, too. And Hung, Drawn, And Quartered isnt half-bad, either. It kicks off with a pounding, rhythmically martial-sounding drum solo (that lasts roughly half a minute) before settling down into a sludgy groove augmented by mammoth, churning riffage and steady bass lines (four-stringer George Rice is heard grumbling along pretty much for the duration of the song.)The production values of Surrounded By Thieves leave a lot to be desired, as it, for who knows what reason, opts for a dense, and unnecessarily murky, dull, and bass-heavy mix. And also on the downside, there are few songs present, here, that could be classified as instant classics. But even if you cannot help but wonder if the affair would have been better with somebody else turning the knobs, this is still a nasty little sludge/doom/stoner metal album, and a promising sophomoric effort that should satiate everybody that has a yearning for the good stuff.

Blending together heavily symphonic black metal with elements of European death metal, metalcore, and a tiny dollop of grind is not exactly a novel concept anymore. Winds Of Plague, Abigail Williams, The Faceless, and even Cryptopsy all experimented with this "symphonic deathcore" sound circa 2008. But none of that really matters when you are the originator. Such is the case when it comes to Austria's Hollenthon, who began specializing in melding together all four genres into one cohesive, huge sound, all the way back in 1999. (Hence, calling Hollenthon an imitator would be like saying Black Sabbath were a Johnny-come-lately to the sludge/doom metal scene.)The band continue striving towards a near-perfect, or at least seamless, equilibrium on their third full-length record, 2008's "Opus Magnum." And even though the attempt at attaining a perfect equilibrium is not yet entirely complete, no one should be able to argue that at least Hollenthon do this type of genre as well as, if not better than, the vast majority of the competition. And on the whole, "O.M." lands at some point between Dimmu Borgir, Cradle Of Filth, Arch Enemy, At The Gates, Hatebreed, Fear Factory, and Lamb Of God.Tracks like "Bazaar" and epic opener "On The Wings Of A Dove" skillfully balance abrasive, charging death metal and symphonic, Dimmu-esque black metal. They flirt with brief little symphonic flourishes, but are primarily centered around catchy, staccato chugging, punishing, interlocking blast beats, and Shagrath-styled black metal gargling. The end product perfectly contrasts melody, nuance, and atmosphere with blistering, heads-down death metal. Other cuts, like "Ars Moriendi" (which is adorned by some very exceptional and memorable guitar soloing), the bass-heavy "To Fabled Lands," and the blistering "Dying Embers" (a ripper backed by buzzsaw riffing and thundering drum blasts) play more like full-on death metal, utilizing symphonic touches only minimally, and instead choosing to terrorize the neighborhood in an old-fashioned kind of way.Conversely, however, there is also plenty of black metal-leaning melodic material to be had, here, though, too. "Son Of Perdition" and "Once We Were Kings" weave in a wailing female backing vocal line into its otherwise completely dissonant mix of snarly black/death metal vocals, thunderous riffing, and galloping drums. And if that weren't enough, the former of these two tracks is also highlighted by some trumpet accompaniment (!), and even goes so far as to drop in an exotic, Middle Eastern-sounding instrumental melody to help keep things a little unpredictable.And last but far from least, one must not forget to also mention the record's two final highlights: "Of Splendid Worlds" is a gorgeous, mid-tempo brooder that augments some decent guitar soloing with a docile, piano-driven section; and "Misterium Babel" opens with a few soulful, siren-like female vocals and foreboding, spoken-word male vocals before taking a page out of the "Transylvanian Hunger"-era Darkthrone playbook by delving into a seemingly Arabian-music-inspired instrumental melody. Needless to say, it all makes for one very complex and multi-faceted, eight-and-a-half-minute-long epic, let me tell ya!"Opus Magnum" is not without a few boring and thus forgettable parts. When taken on the whole, though, it is a very solid and convincing take on the black metal genre, and certainly one that differs from the norm. So when mining the material found on this record, it becomes readily apparent that "O.M." is, in a small part, useless rubble, and part diamond in the rough, but mostly pure gold. As such, it is a worthwhile endeavor for all black and death metal enthusiasts.

Seven years after first establishing themselves as Colorado's answer to Origin and Necrophagist, Allegaeon storm back onto the scene with another new album, their third, in 2014's "Elements Of The Infinite." And do not let the somewhat generic title fool you, because Allegaeon are not your everyday technical death metal band. They, in fact, have as much in common with the European melodic death metal circuit as anything, as is evidenced by their extensive use of dazzlingly melodic lead and solo work. So, on the whole, in addition to the aforementioned Origin and Necrophagist, "Elements" lands somewhere between Dying Fetus, Suffocation, At The Gates, and In Flames.The album's epic opener, "Threshold Of Perception," begins with a hauntingly peaceful and ambient intro before giving way to mazy melodic soloing, and in turn, slamming into punishing tech-death/grind fury with triggered, grinding blasts and blistering riffs. And the composition, which clocks in at well past the six-minute mark, later adopts some more exceptional melodic solo work, but its return to thunderous death metal roots is always waiting just around the corner. And other songs, like the steady tech-death beating that is "Dyson Sphere," slips in some decisively groovy leads, choral-esque backing vocal touches, and an infectious bit of nearly neo-classical soloing into its mix.And speaking of neo-classical, the lengthy, sustained, and involved melodic solo sections in cuts like the Black Dahlia Murder-influenced "1.618," "Gravimetric Time Dilation," the head-spinning "Our Cosmic Casket," and "Biomec II" cannot be more accurately described as anything but. Plus, the last of these four tunes is also home to a steady, flowing bass groove, and an actually catchy chorus (!), too.Other standouts include the slightly more mid-tempo chugger that is "Tyrants Of The Terrestrial Exodus"; the noteworthy bass work (including thundering bass fills and Origin/Cryptopsy/Brain Drill-like bass soloing) in "The Phylogenesis Stretch"; the epically epic, sprawling, and nearly thirteen-minute-long closer ("Genocide For Praise"); and "Through Ages Of Ice -- Otzi's Curse," a concertedly restrained venture, and a mix of swirling harmonic leads, melodic solos, grumbling bass lines, and steady, chugging riffs. And the fact that the first two and a half minutes of this song are completely instrumental further assists in helping "Ages" to stand out some more, as does the fact that it also features a lengthy, Arabian-inflected melody in its outro.Not every song on "Elements Of The Infinite" is great, and moreover, there are a few parts to these nine songs that are a little, if not generic, then at least not wholly remarkable or memorable. But even if there are a few spots of monotony present, here (as the constant use of jackhammer-fast rhythms does get a bit old by album's end), there are just as many (if not more) instances of wonderful, air-guitar-worthy tech-death fretboard wizardry and skillfully symphonic black metal-derived keyboard flourishes be had, here, too. And at the end of the day, it is a good trade.

Seeing how this is the third album in a row that frontman Ben Falgoust has recorded with Goatwhore, it seems like a pretty safe assumption to think that the dude has put Soilent Green on the far back burner for the foreseeable future in favor of this group, even if it is one that initially began as merely a side-project. And the almighty Goat remain as true to their roots as they possibly can get on their sixth full-length, 2014's "Constricting Rage Of The Merciless," in that they deliver another set of explosive, brutally pummeling, and certainly very ripping and rag-tag set of blackened death metal anthems streaked with strong elements of hardcore, grind, speed and thrash metal. "Constricting..."also picks up right where 2012's "Blood Of The Master" left off in that completely and quite simply forsakes Goatwhore's patented doom metal-derived breakdowns (which were found in just about every song on their first four albums) in favor of speed, speed, and, ah yes, more speed.Wasting absolutely no time getting right down into the thick of things, "Poisonous Existence In Reawakening" is a ferocious barn-burning opener that anchors blistering chainsaw riffage with pounding thrash beats. This track is also of note from a vocal front, as it utilizes some excellent vocal variation, offsetting Ben's typically high-pitched screaming with some brutally low, Dying Fetus-esque growling. And the ripping "Unraveling Paradise" brings back some more of those same vocals, and augments them with more solid lead work and cymbal-heavy blasting. "Barin g Teeth For Revolt," then, is a more groove-centric thrasher with steady, chugging riffs; but it is mostly of note for the way it steadily gains momentum and builds off of itself, generating heaviness and energy and eventually climaxing with blazing guitar leads and a ripping, wah-tinged solo.Two later tracks, "FBS" and the closing "Externalize This Hidden Savagery," both flirt with surprisingly melodic soloing, an unexpected surprise especially when considering how the latter of the two songs mostly plays like a piece of full-on grind. (With that said, though, the former of these two is a much more restrained venture that adheres to positively catchy and headbangable lurches and grooves.) But the track that immediately precedes it, "Cold Earth Consumed In Dying Flesh," deals the listener an even bigger curveball in that it has an intro that, laden with clean, echoing-out guitar strums to create a stellar bit of infectious ambiance, is positively startling. This is before, however, "Cold Earth..." adopts some ominous, pounding chug and churn riffs and roaring vocals. (Ben's vocals -- or, rather, vo-kills -- are of the grindcore-esque variety, here, in that they at times nearly verge on the goregrind-esque pig squeal-style. And needless to say, they lead the way, here, even when the number picks up speed and launches into scalding, earth-scorched territory.)Found in another place, "Heaven's Crumbling Walls Of Pity" has pummeling, stop-start death-grind blasts and subtle, fast tempo changes to go along with its memorable, blowtorch riffing in order to make for one other whopper of a standout song. And rounding out the set is "Nocturnal Conjuration Of The Accursed," which, boasting catchy, crunching riffs, chugging grooves, and a catchy vocal hook (early on), produces one positively hooky, contagious, and headbangable anthem, and one that compensates for the fairly lackluster (and thoroughly unremarkable) piece that comes next, "Schadenfreude."True, "Constricting Rage Of The Merciless" does not break any new ground whatsoever for Goatwhore. But that little drawback does nothing to prevent it from becoming a tremendously enjoyable listen, and a pure, unbridled success. "Constricting..." is a nastily savage and grotesque album, but it sure makes for a satisfying listen; and even though it might be almost perversely harsh and dissonant, it will surely make for one heckuva pleasurable sound to all extreme metallists' eardrums.

Think of Origin as like a group of mad scientists. They have frequently been described as such before, and the comparisons really are significant enough to mention. See, this Kansas-bred group of extreme metallists also are extremely smart, experienced, and influential collective that specialize in surgically-precise delivery in order to produce an end product that will only appeal to maybe five or ten percent of the population. But that control group, no matter how small it may be, is absolutely guaranteed to fall deeply in love with it.This end product of which I am referring to is the masterful 2014 album, Omnipresent, Origins, sixth album proper, and doubtlessly one of their finest hours. It takes a cue from Antithesis by being much more epic and realized than any of the works that Origin released subsequently to that watershed-worthy 2008 effort, and one that features actually audible bass work and excellent guitar solos. (For example, check out Unattainable Zero, which is adorned by both a viscerally grumbling bass line and epic, exotically melodic solo section.) And the end result is also one that produces a significantly greater amount of tempo variation, and individual song identity (i.e. standout tracks).Origins musicianship remains top-notch all-throughout this thirty-seven-minute-long playing time -- that much is an absolute no-brainer. And so is the fact that it is riddled with positively blistering riffage and jackhammer-insistent drum beats. But that the band delves into compact-yet-simultaneously-fleshed-out, and not only mature but also downright epic songwriting is what really sets the bar high, and makes them distinguish themselves as a cut above most of the rest of the extreme metal/technical death-grind playing field. And the rhythms, no matter dense as they might be, always fly by quicker than you can say speed metal. I would say they fly by so fast that you dont even know what hit you, but doing so would be a touch misleading, as these songs do certainly leave a lasting impression.Tracks like the opening All Things Dead are wildly frenetic blasts of energy loaded with careening guitars (i.e. chunky riffing, blistering leads, etc.), brain-rattling gravity blasts, and freaky, Cryptopsy/Dying Fetus-styled high/low vocal patterns; whereas cuts like the ensuing Thrall: Fulcrum: Apex evoke classic grindcore, what being one minute-long blast fests that are stuffed to the gills with head-spinning, face-ripping tempos, insane grindcore blasts, machine gun riffs, and the like. Later on, the band take a page out of the Nineties melodeath playbook by tossing in a couple of minute-long instrumental interludes in the form of Permanence and Continuum, both of which are tracks that feature serpentine, crystalline-sounding melodic leads and harmonies. But this is before the album pounds back in full brutality, with the pummeling Manifest Desolate succeeding the former case, and the thunderous Continuum following-up the latter.And the band continue to incessantly pummel the life out of your eardrums with songs like The Absurdity Of What I Am, which kick starts with a long-overdue drum solo from skinsman John Lengstreth (that is guaranteed to get you pumped up, by the way) before catapulting into pulverizing death-grind territory with screaming, shriek-happy vocals, and buzzsaw riffing. And the fact that an actual, honest-to-god catchy chorus comes into play, here, also helps make Absurdity the big highlight that it is. And the albums centerpiece, Source Of Icon O, again works up a frothing amount of energy and carnage-inducing instrumental interplay as it gallivants back and forth between sharp, barbed guitar hooks and stop-start grindcore blasts that evoke the sound of two machine guns firing at once.And later on, Origin continue adding a few new tools to their repertoire, as on the catchy, straightforwardly thrashy Redistribution Of Filth and the largely instrumental epic Obsolescence. The latter of these two tunes opens with a shockingly melodic and subdued, symphonic-sounding intro, thus making it a huge standout. Of course, the fact that this piece of pure, exotic ambiance is augmented by some nicely jazzy melodic solo work also helps aide this fact.
