As epic as Obsolescence is, though, it is nearly overshadowed by the two tracks that come next.Malthusian Collapse is a concertedly epic piece, one that clocks in at 4:10 in length, and segues through several different places, including restrained chugging but also completely blown-out, grindcore-worthy chaos. And this number also features a lengthy instrumental section that is strictly mid-tempo (not fast or slow, just mid-tempo), and adorned by chunky, serrated riffing. And the second-half of this epic late-album arrival comes in the form of The Indiscriminate, which also finds Origin thinking outside of the box, expanding their sonic scope, and dabbling with all sorts of tempo variation (including mid-tempo sections that set the stage well for breakneck excursions and blasts of catchy, stop-start picking and drumming.)Flawlessly played and impeccably delivered (yet done so in a way as to retain a certain level of live energy), Omnipresent is insanely intricate, inventive, enthralling, and utterly devastating body of work, and one that is an early contender for 2014s extreme metal/deathgrind album of the year honors.

Six years ago, Italian brutal/technical death metal collective Hour Of Penance began lighting a little bit of a fire under listeners' *sses with a good debut in 2008's "The Vile Conception." And now, midway through the next decade, the band has again returned to pour some diesel on that flame with another very satisfying (and this time realized) effort in 2014's "Regicide."True, Hour Of Penance can never claim to be the most original band out there, but they really, really know how to rock. And really friggin' hard, too! Simply tearing their way all throughout these eleven tracks and forty minutes, they blast out brutal, no-holds-barred death metal (clearly influenced by the Floridian DM scene) at grinding speeds, producing intensity levels that remain in the red, no matter how low the listener keeps the volume."Through The Triumphal Arch" sets the stage well, if in a misleadingly melodic kind of way, as it is a creepy and ambient little intro piece that flows into "Reforging The Crowns," which is a better representation of the album as a whole. It launches the listener into an uncompromising onslaught of blistering tremolo picking, "rat-tat-tat" machine gunning blast beats, and Deicide-al vocals. And this song is also of note for its use of a very decent and surprisingly melodic guitar solo, too. Of the latter half of the record, it is a cut like "The Seas Of Light," a satiating riff-fest, that seems to stand out and be the most memorable. It puts on a virtual symphony of riffage, including chugging riffs, thundering riffs, groovy ones, thrashy ones, and chainsaw-fast ones. And it is all anchored by taught, stop-start deathgrind blasts.But there certainly are other highlights, too. Take, for instance, a ripper like "Desecrated Souls," for one example of such. It is another inexorable death-metal jaunt, and a riff/growl/blast fest that is filled to the brim with jackhammering percussion that serves as an anchor to ferocious yet groovy guitar leads and full-bodied death metal bellowing. A couple of ripping solos crop up, here, as well. And "Resurgance Of The Empire," a biting, buzzsaw-riff and pummeling drum blast-backed sprint with menacing growls, and the occasional thunderous breakdown, is another. Of course, this tune is also of note for dropping in a little vocal variation into the mix, as the occasional shriek is also included, here.The title track completely decapitates the listener, playing like a suffocating aural rush of insane gravity blasts, bone-crunching guitars, and skull-rattling rhythms that simply overwhelms the listener. And for two other recommended tracks, also make sure to check out "The Sun Worship," the early Suffocation-worthy closer, "Theogony." The former of these two standdouts motors you over with its relentlessly pummeling, machine-gun-fast-blasting, careening guitar leads, and high/low vocal patterns that are memorable without ever coming across sounding like Black Dahlia Murder worship.But it has got to be the album's centerpiece, "Sealed Into Ecstasy," that takes the cake for being the highpoint of the set. Thanks to its abundant use of groovy riffing, memorable vocal patterns (in a very Glenn Benton-esque move, vocalist Paolo Pieri's shrieks of "Burn our mind -- unrestricted" in the choruses are prefaced by growls of "Burn alive this fake reflection" in the pre-choruses) and rhythmic, staccato grooves, "Sealed Into Ecstasy" is made into an extremely memorable and infectious anthem. Heck, one might even venture to say it is about as catchy a death metal tune as you're ever going to find!Hour Of Penance are still not the best at peddling individually-identifiable songs with memorable, accessible hooks; but not all of that matters, because they are nevertheless still an upper-tier death metal import. And it might prove that H.O.P. are still lacking originality, but they do utilize just enough, if not innovation, then at least musical growth (i.e. the inclusion of guitar solos and occasionally audible bass lines) to make this release mark a definite step forward for the band.

Despite being hands down one of the most influential heavy metal acts of the Nineties, and arguably the most important thing ever to happen to the  sludge metal subset, Eyehategod actually only have ever given fans very little effort from the studio. (Prior to the year 2014, EHG had only three proper records under their belt.) And said year's new album, a self-titled affair, is their first album in fourteen whole, friggin', insufferably long years!Or to put that another way, the last time Mike Williams and Company got together in the studio and churned out a long-player, Bill Clinton was president. (And the American people were still trying to recover from the emotional roller-coaster that was the Lewinsky scandal.) Furthermore, the last time Eyehategod wrote a full new album, the world was learning that the whole Y2K debacle was all just a figment of our imaginations. It has been so long since "Confederacy Of Ruined Lives" dropped in 2000 that, in the time that has passed since then, Pantera has disbanded, Metallica has reformed, the Colorado Rockies have lost 975 games (give or take a few), and Eyehategod have collected an entirely new rhythm section. (Gary Mader took over the four-string responsibilities in 2002, and Aaron Hill filled in for Joey LaCaze, who passed away while this new album was still in its tracking stage.)But despite being gone from the public eye for so darn long, and despite undergoing a whole host of internal band problems (including drug addiction, side-projects -- i.e. Soilent Green, and Arson Anthem - band member arrests, internal disputes, etc.), and despite undergoing the whole Hurricane Katrina disaster (which ripped through their home town of New Oleans, Louisiana), very little has actually changed in the world of Eyehategod. (They still churn out anguished, agonized sludgecore by the truckload.) And heck, one might even argue that the boys, having survived so many struggles, even made it out stronger than ever (as 2014's self-titled album possesses a strong sense of revitalization and inspiration).The set's most memorable piece is, fittingly, its sole anomaly: "Agitation! Propaganda!" is a bludgeoning album opener that verges on having grindcore tinges, and really fleshes-out the band's hardcore punk influences. It is a crushing blast of thrashy tempos, pounding, crashing drum beats, Melvins-esque rhythmic power, and really visceral and angsty screaming. But immediately following this number comes a more traditional Eyehategod anthem in "Trying To Crack The Hard Dollar," which is  a terrifically sludgy and ominous collection of plodding tempos, feedback-spewing guitars, densely sludgy, churning rhythms, and nightmarishly freaky and dissonant, full-bodied vocals.The murky, trudging, riff and bash approach that worked so well in the first two tracks does eventually get a little tiresome the more the record plays. But that is not to say that there is anything really wrong with the songs themselves, as a standout like "Parish Motel Sickness," which pins howling vocals against a bed of sludgy, pounding, Sabbath-gone-haywire riffing and fat, stomach-churning rhythms, could not be more satisfying or reminiscent of vintage EHG. And what is not to like about cuts like the groove-heavy "Quitter's Offensive" or the extra crunchy "Nobody Told Me," for example? They are two slabs of Southern sludge at its finest that find the guitars being tuned down extra low (to almost noggin-busting frequencies) in order to produce a truckload of really excellent and eminently memorable doom riffage.Elsewhere, "Worthless Rescue" finds the band taking a more strategic route, sandwiching a few really dark and ominous pockets of guitar feedback into its mix of serrated, stop-and-go guitar leads, abrasive, cohesive grooves, and banging skins, thus making this mostly instrumental epic a fitting album centerpiece, and another significant standout track. And it precedes "Framed To The Wall," a surprisingly up-tempo jaunt of really memorable and grumbling guitars, and "Robitussin And Rejection," which opens slowly before allowing a mammoth, moving riff slice to pound, lumber, and smash onto the scene."The Age Of Boot Camp," with its monstrous (and truly unforgettable) riff work and viscerally-rumbling bass lines, is another one of the more memorable anthems on tap, here,, although "Flags And Cities Abound," which begins with a chillingly ominous, feedback-drenched intro and near spoken-word vocal dialogue, and boasts extra dramatic-sounding drum rolls, does give it a fair dose of competition. And rounding out the rest of the set, "Medicine Noose" cuts equally-as-deep. It is a lean, mean, steamrolling groover with a monstrous, Pantera-worthy main riff, recklessly, raucously rollicking rhythm, and some more Melvins-esque percussion power.So much was riding on the release of "Eyehategod," but the band escaped the anticipation and anxiety with mostly successful results. Furthermore, often when a veteran metal outfit opts to release a selt-titled affair, it signals a watershed release of sorts -- one that marks the rearrangement of the battlefield, if you will. Or, if nothing else, then it is at least a move that is a telltale sign of a group becoming lazy and simply taking the easy way out mid-way through their career. But neither of these things proves to be true in Eyehategod's case, a band that has returned with an arresting and accomplished return to form, and one that is sure to garner the respect of literally everybody that currently occupies the American heavy music underground.

The ninth long-player from Swedish melodic death metal titans Arch Enemy is their first release with a new vocalist (Alissa White-Gluz replaced Angela Gossow earlier this year) in thirteen years. Even so, 2014's "War Eternal" is the sound of a band doing what they do best: Producing a highly infectious and groove-oriented brand of European death metal that is influenced equally by Iron Maiden and Iced Earth as by Slayer and Metallica, and latter-day Carcass and Soilwork as by Death and Morbid Angel.Gluz is certainly a very competent vocalist, as her growls and bellows are both visceral and simultaneously intelligible and believable. But it is, once again, Arch Enemy's instrumental prowess that takes over most of the spotlight over the course of this thirteen track, fifty-minute long playing time. As a result of both of these factors, "War Eternal" is not only a definite standout in A.E.'s discography, it is arguably their best album since 2001's "Wages Of Sin." Drummer Daniel Erlandsson lays the foundation for the songs with tight and precise double-time pummel, and Sharlee D'Angelo completes the rock-solid rhythm section with solid, grooving bass lines. But it is the axemen (Michael Arnott and Nick Cordie) that really light up the sky, doing so by uncorking one catchy guitar lick and unforgettably pyrotechnic lead/solo after another.The record's curveballs usually come from the band adopting an increased sense of melody, as evidenced by the symphonic opener ("Tempore Nihil Sanat"), and the closing "Not Long For This World," which is a completely instrumental piece that possesses a very dramatic, drawn-out, and epic feeling where a plodding tempo gives way to nicely harmonic leads and a cool, classical music-derived piano solo. But fear not, though, because this piano bit is before the number becomes an up-tempo and groovy death-thrasher with catchy, chugging riffs, and wickedly memorable, skin-crawling vocal patterns (including a fist-pumpable chorus). And elsewhere, as in the middle of the album, the band flirts with some Iron Maiden-like neoclassical melodicism, with "As The Pages Burn" beginning as a full-speed ahead thrasher with dueling/trade-off vocals before dialing things down a notch for a more subdued and melodic chorus where a neoclassical-tinged solo section pops up, and once again returning to the headstrong heaviness described above. And "No More Regrets" further flirts with such melodies, slipping in Necrophagist-style tunefulness into its solos, which, in turn, are slipped into a bed of chunky riffing and thundering drums. Indeed, the solos are truly very epic, infectious, and phenomenal all throughout this unforgettable song.But do not let all of this talk of experimentation fool you, because there is plenty of heavy -- check that, brutal -- stuff to go around, here. "Never Forgive, Never Forget" is but one example of Arch Enemy at their angriest, as it is a ripping maelstrom of belligerent riffing, punishing blast beats, and shriek-happy vocals, and although it does tuck in a neat, and fairly darn wailing solo section, it is still a track that is as close to pure death metal as you're gonna find on this whole record. And "War Eternal" works similarly, beginning by barreling out of the gate in thunderous fashion with blowtorch riffage before segueing into more melodic territory with fiery-yet-crystalline-sounding melodical solos. (These solos are sometimes wah-tinged and borderline chaotic, and sometimes more subdued and involved, but are always very memorable and exceptional.)"Graveyard Of Dreams," a brief little melodic guitar interlude that sets the stage perfectly for "Stolen Life," a piece of pummeling, chainsaw guitar-backed European thrash metal assailable to the likes of The Haunted and The Crown, is one late-album standout track. And "Time Is Black" is another. It opens with the sound of a children's lullaby-esque melody before slamming into forceful death metal punishment with booming breakdowns, a long cascade of huge guitar licks, and mosh-pit-stoking grooves. And in a more meticulous move, "T.I.B." is also sure to include some faintly ominous backing symphonic flourishes (that wouldn't be out of place on a Dimmu Borgir joint), and also features some more nicely melodic and even mildly jazzy-sounding solo runs. Other highlights include the throbbing, pulsating bass groove (augmented by more terrific, soulful melodic soloing and really memorable choruses) in "You Will Know My Name"; the tailor-made-for-headbanging "On And On"; the crunchy riffs and excellent, blistering, trade-off solo section in "Avalanche"; and "Down To Nothing," a charging death metal beat-down that utilizes melody only as an afterthought, and is complete with a round of bruising, machine gun-fast drumming.When all is said and done, a couple of these new songs could conceivably rub some longtime fans' feathers the wrong way, as it is often more melodic and groovy than what you might be used to. But do not let that deter you from thinking anything else aside from the fact that this is a very, very solid and extremely enjoyable effort from Arch Enemy, a band that, even with a new vocalist, is definitely entering its third decade of existence by continuing to fire on all cylinders. "War Eternal," which just might be the premiere melodic death metal release of 2014, is very highly recommended to fans and newcomers alike.

Just two short years after dropping his eleventh solo studio effort, 2012's "Metal Clone X," six-string ace Marty Friedman returns with another collection of heavy riffs and unpredictable twists in 2014's "Inferno," a record that trumps all of his previous solo works (including 2003's "Music For Speeding," which was previously his best album before this one), and one that even goes so far as to rival all of the excellent works that the man put out while in Megadeth and Cacophony. Since this is a Marty Friedman joint, one can expect it to be loaded to the gills with terrific licks and even greater solos. But you probably did not plan on it being so full of intelligent songwriting and inventive curveballs. As a result, "Inferno" is far more meticulous, infectious, and all-around better than anything that any fan probably could have ever expected. The highlights are many. And I mean many. In fact, they are so abundant and close to each other that this reviewer might even go so far as to say that to have a non remarkable track is almost unheard of.Only three of the eleven songs presented here are home to some sort of vocals, with the first of which being "I Can't Relax," which features a cameo from vocalist Danko Jones. And what rapid fire vocals, they are, too! And when they are combined together with Friedman's exceptional guitar fireworks, the end product is one mighty swinging, swaggering, and fun-loving hard rocker, and one that is complete with blistering melodic solo runs. The second of these three songs, "Sociopaths," finds Dave Davidson chipping in, and doing so with vocal styles that vary between dirty and harsh-sounding growls and emphatic clean singing that evokes some Avenged Sevenfold stuff. And it is all underpinned by chugging thrash verses, and some surprisingly forceful double bass drumming. And it all leads in to create a whopping, six-minute-and-thirteen-second long epic, and one that features a really memorable chorus, and three other solos from Marty, each of which rip the air like a serrated knife. And finally, the last track of its kind, "Lycanthrope," features guest vocalists Danko Jones and Children Of Bodom mouthpiece Alexi Laiho. With that said, though, this tune is actually mostly of note from a musical front, as it is a steady, groove-centric thrasher that is home to guitar soloing that can only justifiably be described as simply blistering and virtuosic.Elsewhere, the title tune, with its crunchy licks and surprisingly tight and thrashy drumming, sets the stage perfectly for the rest of the album. But, it is almost needless to say that it is the guitars that again dominate the maelstrom, here, doling out truckloads of pleasant backing guitar harmonies, and pyrotechnic, wailing solos to create one of the densest, trickiest, and most highly technical and fleet-fingered epics this reviewer has heard since Cacophony. And following it up is "Resin," which is misleadingly slow and doomy -- at least at first -- before erupting into a ball of punching, staccato guitar hooks, and chugging grooves. And it all leads up to a really dramatic and sizeable climax, coming in the form of a truly dazzling solo section.But track number three, "Wicked Panacea," is an even bigger highlight still. It is primarily based around funky, fleet-fingered flamenco guitar picking (from Spanish guitar virtuoso couple Rodrigo Y Gabriela), but it also features plenty of belligerent, chugging thrash riffs that help the number to gain momentum and gradually become heavier, before being topped off by an unorthodoxly shredding, whammy-bar-heavy solo from Marty. And next up is "Steroidhead," a humourously-entitled anthem that continues this steady thrash attack with charging, chunky riffs offset by only occasional slow breakdowns (which are aided by wailing solo flights).Working your way through the rest of the record, there is a track called "Meat Hook," that is peppered with cool, memorable piano solo lines dueling with zany, John Zorn-esque jazz-inflected saxophone lines, and doing so to excellent effect. And it is all topped off by Friedman, who gets some more substantial time in the limelight, uncorking one squealing solo and crunchy riff after another with seemingly impossible ease. As a result of all of this, "Meat Hook" is made into a crazy, head-spinning, and highly frenetic number, and a definite mid-album curveball. And another is the very appropriately-named "Hyper Doom," which features dramatic, ominous, and yes, even at times mildly doomy-sounding guitar licks to go along with its usual abundance of thrashy tempos and screaming solos. The end result makes for a gem that, like many on here, evokes many a "Rust In Peace"-era Megadeth classic."Undertow" opens with a symphonic sounding intro and piercing solo run before emerging as a gorgeous, strings `n' all-led ballad with wailing melodical solos, docile harmonic leads, harp-like acoustic/flamenco-plucked strings, and gently crashing drum cymbals. As good as "Undertow" is, though, it is immediately overshadowed by the epically epic, nearly-seven minute-long whopper that succeeds it. "Horrors," featuring guest fret-shredding by Jason Becker, opens with a mournful violin and heavenly acoustic guitar intro before letting a huge electric guitar riff come smashing onto the scene. It then segues through a seriously proggy and pretty melodic guitar section (that might lead some listeners to believe that Rodrigo Y Gabriela made another appearance) before leading back to the song's hard, heavy, and propulsive main riff slice. And "Horrors" is also noteworthy for transitioning through a series of white-hot melodic solos, each one of them seemingly more tuneful and crystalline-sounding than the last."Inferno" is so chockablock full of the good stuff that it likely cannot be all consumed in just one sitting (it takes at least one repeat listen to absorb the whole thing.) And it is, again, probably the best work that this fleet-fingered axeman has ever turned out without being attached to some other group of equally-as-talented-musicians. But in any event, then the fact at least remains true that this is, without question, the best piece of thrash metal to come on the market in 2014 thus far. So does all of this make it out to be an essential purchase? Well, it has "Marty Friedman" in the title, so what do you think?!

Incantation's 2012 album, "Vanquish In Vengeance," was the New York-bred death metal group's first recording of all new material in six years (as their last new album before that, "Primordial Domination," was released all the way back in 2006.) But even if album number nine, 2014's "Dirges Of Elysium," cannot be said to be a true comeback, it most certainly still marks a triumphant return to form for the band. And so doesn't it make perfect sense, then, for "Dirges" to be arguably the band's best effort to date?!Granted, the album does begin with a terrifically dark and foreboding instrumental piece in the title song, but this is before it really lets rip with two earth-scorching attacks of visceral extreme metal. "Debauchery" is a skull-crushing onslaught of ferocious blasting, thunderous riffing, and evil, possessed-sounding vocal growls. It is also home to a couple of blistering guitar solos, as well. And "Bastion Of A Plagued Soul" is even more brutal still, as it is another earth-scorching deathgrind maelstrom that constantly abuses the listener's eardrums with its murderous, grindcore-worthy blast beats and booming guitar noise. Following these two grindcore-leaning assaults, however, comes "Carrion Prophecy," which is an exercise in a slight bit of tempo variation that opens on a mid-tempo and even borderline doomy note. But fear not, though, because plenty of chugging, muscle-bound guitar licks kick in, taking the song to an elevated (and almost out-of-control) speed where it segues through a catchy gallop to get to an explosively climactic conclusion where buzzsaw riffing and disturbing death metal bellowing run the show.With its epic scope and towering, seven-and-a-half minute long playing time, "From A Glaciate Womb" is a wonderful album centerpiece, and far-and-away better than anything heard thus far. It begins by sounding ominously mid-tempo, with a brooding vibe and lingering sense of impending doom. But it, of course, eventually speeds way up, maxing out intensity levels with breakneck picking and drumming. The song then goes back over this slow-fast build-0up a few times, thus concocting a terrific contrast and juxtaposition -- and each time it does this is just as intense and nerve-frying as the last. Next comes "Portal Consecration," which finds a brief harmonic intro being smashed to bits by ensuing riffs and monstrous vocals. But even still, despite this briefly devastating death metal respite, "P.C." remains a mostly mid-tempo and ominously brooding piece. But hold on to your buts, because a fast tempo change (that launches the listener into frenetic picking and drumming) kicks in later on, and it is nothing short of breakneck! Top it all off with a climactic, Slayer-esque careening-shred solo, and the end result is a mini, mid-album epic."Charnal Grounds," which opens with another skin-crawling, doom metal-derived breakdown, and closes with a somber-sounding bass solo, is another highlight. And two other more unforgettable moments include the frenetic, hold-nothing-back blast of insane, bludgeoning death metal (played at blinding, grinding speeds) in "Impalement Of Divinity" (which is propelled forward by a flurry of warp-speed riffing, blasting skins, and hoarse-throated growls occasionally punctuated by shrill, black metal-esque shrieks); and the barreling speed, corrosive main groove, steady bass work, pummeling thrash beats, and totally-off-the-rails guitar soloing that pepper the mix pretty much all throughout "Dominant Ethos." And as if the second of these two songs weren't already awesome enough, it is also further highlighted by a cool, three-second long drum solo near its end.But it all seems like mere poppycock when compared to what comes next: "Elysium (Eternity Is Nigh)," the album's obvious high point. Clocking in at sixteen-and-a-half minutes in length, this epic begins by descending from a dramatic mid-tempo march to even slower territory (with doomy peaks and bass-aided valleys) where momentous, reverberating, doom-soaked power chords and ringing drum beats do battle against killer (if still mostly intelligible) death metal vocal stylings. From there, the song does pick up a little speed and energy, but nevertheless remains a subdued and involved piece for the vast majority of its playing time. And following an up-tempo stretch (with chunky, serrated chug and churn riffs), "Elysium" again delves right back down into Autopsy/Grave-worthy doomy death metal, with groovy bass fills complimenting sustained, reverberating power chords. The number never fully explodes into Incantation's usual wall of blistering death-grind madness, but that is part of what makes it such a big standout -- well, that, and the fact that it is one terrifically expansive and sprawling closer whose latter half is largely instrumental. (Indeed, the band opt to let their instruments do most of the talking, here, thus helping to further the track's undeniably epic feel.)It serves as the mere icing on the cake that is "Dirges Of Elysium," an already decadently sweet offering. Or, to word it more literally, this is a masterful extreme metal album, likely one of Incantation's finest hours, and an irrefutable shoo-in for 2014's end of the year top-five list.
Came in an unmarked package without instructions, squeegee. Also, came with a very flimsy cloth. Seems like a bad knockoff to me. Okay for price I guess, but definitely not high quality.

This is very well made (all stainless) and easy to use. Just understand that you can only make about 6 eight ounce cups of coffee at a time. Also, it takes a little more effort than simply turning on a automatic coffee maker. But if you're willing to spend a few minutes, this is really a great product.
Read the description carefully. Unlike other ankle weight sets, the weight for these is specified for the pair. So the 2 lb weights are actually two 1 lb weights.

The price gouging on the Origami covers is so incredibly abhorrent that Amazon should include a slip of paper inside with the famous quote credited to P.T. Barnum about there being one born every minute. Good quality compared to plastic cases, sure. But at this price, they should be made from hand-crafted Italian leather by a craftsman named Luigi. I do hope that when the Kindle buying frenzy calms down a bit, Amazon decides to price the accessories a bit more reasonably.

The Voyage is a great little device, bright, lightweight, and capable of storing a huge library of books. I downgrade it to three stars for three reasons. First, Amazon requires that you pay $20 to keep from being bombarded by ads -- calling them special offers only seems that much more dishonest. Second, even if you pony up the $20, they still ship the devices with the lower 1/2 of the screen filled with advertisements for other books. You have to go into the menu system to turn this off -- again, blatant advertising that frustrates many users. And third, I take a star off for the high price of the unit and the accessories. Having to pay $60 for a simple case and $20 for a wall charger (which should be included) for a device that is already overpriced is again a bit offensive. With all that said, the device is handy, so for many it will still prove to be a worthy investment.

I'm a huge Justified fan, and I would say that the final season was good, but not great. The flash ahead at the end of the final episode was a bit odd, especially with the situation with Raylan's wife who he ostensibly left Kentucky to be with. I did like up and down tension between Boyd and Eva, although the ending seemed rather tragic. The showdown with the young gunslinger was also well done. The series has been very entertaining, and the ending, while not quite perfect, was fairly satisfying.

The Gaiam Thirsty towels are expensive but comfortable to use at the gym. I bought three, and after trying the first one decided that they were worth the money. The size is also just right for carrying around the gym when you need a quick face wipe. Overall, satisfied, just with they were a few bucks cheaper.

Being a huge fan of Season 1, I must confess that I was a bit worried about Season 2. The first handful of episodes were a cut below their predecessors. Fortunately, the season recovers and continues what I consider to be a fantastic series.

The Blacklist is such a refreshing series that I hardly know how to describe it. It hinges on powerful performances by nearly every actor involved. The stories are are clever and concise, and they often have incredible surprises that leave the viewer saying "Wow, did they just do that?!" Very good stuff.

I've been on a beef jerky kick lately, trying out various brands. I thought I'd try this beef and pork stick to see how it compares. From the very first bite, I was pleasantly surprised. The meat is tender, and it has a delicious smoky flavor. The package that I received had a Best Buy date that was eight months from the time of purchase. I'll be surprised if they last eight days. The fact that the meat is free of MSG and nitrates makes it that much better!
My wife says these foot files are the best she's ever tried. They're heavy duty and have large working areas. Great product.

My daughter is a level 2 gymnast, and she needed a beam on which to practice. This one is really great. Full-sized, well built, and covered in a durable material. Overall, very satisfied. Comes in a giant box, so be ready.

I had high hopes for the Bayou Blend jerky. I bought this variety pack because I really didn't know which I'd like. Unfortunately, I didn't care for any of them. They have a strange "swampy" taste--okay, that's me just reading something into the taste based on the name. But the truth is no one in my family cared for it. Also, the cuts are rather strange, very small and cut in odd shapes. We've tried several types of jerky over the past few months, and so far Pacific Gold is our current favorite. Not perfect, but good.

I bought a double pack of Pacific Gold from Costco, and it is surprisingly good. The meat is tender and has a very good taste. Not too peppery either, which is an objection that I have to brands like Jack Links. Also, it contains no nitrates or MSG, which is important to my family.
When I received the Clyppi toenail clipper, my first thought was "Wow, this thing is BIG." It does seem to be good quality and has a sharp edge, but honestly, I can't quite justify the price.

The Ultimate Liquid Wax is a great wax. It goes on very easy, doesn't leave much residue behind, and comes off with a modest wipe. It's so much better than the old waxes that dried pasty white. I can wax the entire car in 30 minutes. I'm not sure how long the shine holds up, but I do like working with the product.
The Meguiar's glass cleaner smells great and seems to clean well enough. I'm not sure that it cleans any better than cheaper Windex, but I feel like I'm spoiling my car.

We wanted to add a little security to our two back doors. They already had a deadbolt and door handle lock, but those can easily be drilled. We decided to try this door blocker, and I couldn't be more pleased. The device is sturdy, and it comes with long screws to go into the frame. It takes a moment to learn how to unlatch it, but the design is really clever and compact. I feel much better knowing that these our on the doors. They're impossible to see from the outside, and would give someone a very hard time if they wee trying to shoulder or kick in the door.

We hadn't tried the Kind Bars in the past, so we figured it made sense to buy a variety pack. I'm not sure how many different types of Kind bars there are, but there must be dozens. We broke each bar into several pieces and shared with everyone in the family. We then compared notes on which were the best tasting. Honestly, most were quite edible, so I don't think you can go too wrong. Our very favorite was dark chocolate with peanut butter.

I have eaten Jack Links products for years, usually purchased at our local Wal Mart, and I like most all of them. I thought this box would make for great mid-day snacks. After sharing one stick with my entire family, yes, it took all of us to get it down, we agreed that this is pretty bad. Out of the six of us, only our four year old seemed to enjoy it. The meat was very pepper, and lacked the usual tastiness of what we've had in the past. I also could do without the MSG and nitrates.

If you buy many shipping labels, you quickly come to realize that the two problems are double feeding (two or more sheets sticking together) and curling of sheets. The DigiOrange are better than some I've tried, but they do double feet a lot (due to static electricity). Also, the adhesive sheets are more difficult to remove than others.
My three year old loves Curious George. She was delighted to receive this plush animal as a birthday present. So far, it's holding up well, and she enjoys watching the show while holding her animal.

I switched from Wellness to Merrick Before Grain because my cat seemed to be tiring of the Wellness dry food. The Merrick and Wellness products are both very high quality, and both have small morsels, which my cat likes. So far, he's really enjoying the Merrick product, and it's not giving him any problems.
My wife wanted something with a long chain and a simple pendant. This fit the bill perfectly. She wears it to remind her to "be in the moment", and so far it's held up perfectly.

The Slim Leather Wallet Case seems well made, and fits the iphone 5 perfectly. I personally found it a little small for my credit cards, and I was a little worried about losing anything that I put in the magnetically closed section. Still, it's a nice replacement to a clip wallet.

As I read this outstanding story, I couldn't help but feel that I was following along on an adventure of a young Indiana Jones. The story is fast paced, filled with secret weapons, spies, German soldiers, gun battles, submarines, and brilliant heroes. It begins some three hundred years earlier when a Navajo Chief unleashes an almost magical devastation on warlike Apaches. His secret that was hidden for centuries is eventually uncovered, leading forces of evil to begin their diabolical plotting. Only Rex Chase can stop them!The writing is very crisp and well edited. Anyone who enjoys science fiction pre-WWII adventure will enjoy this book. It compares well to titles like Rocket Ranger and any of the Indiana Jones adventures. I would be the first in line to read the next Rex Chase adventure. A job well done!

Ping Two (Across the Valley) is the sequel to Ping (From the Apocalypse), and I encourage readers to enjoy both of these delightful books.What is perhaps most interesting about Ping Two is that it manages to bridge a post-apocalyptic survival adventure with a touching human story. The main survivors, Lucy, Travis, Christopher, Sarah, Kate, Jack, Rose, and Kevin are all very real, with individual flaws, ambitions, and strengths. The story blends together their interpersonal relationships, some loving and some sad, in a setting that is truly unique and interesting.Travis (the young boy) was my favorite character because he seemed like the glue that held this "family" together. The author's incorporation of telepathic powers  was a unique complexity that served to better interconnect the characters and events. The writing itself was skillful and the editing professional. This is a story as much about the people who survived as it is the apocalypse they survived. Well done!

You Got the Job! is a very useful collection of advice relating to building an effective resume to actually land the job - not just tell what you've done and when. The author points out that a resume is your "personal brand," your chance to make a first impression. I know first hand that sometimes a good resume can essentially line you up as a front runner even before the interview. At that point, it's up to you to mess up (or not).The book addresses several common employer concerns, such as you've been out of work a while, appearing too old for the job, making a transition to a new job, having a focus on management (or avoiding responsibility), and being over (or under) qualified. It points out that a resume should start out with a statement not only of what you are looking for, but also what the employer wants to see. It goes on to tell how to "make your case" - yes, sell yourself in a professional manner. It highlights the importance of being specific about your accomplishments (e.g., Increased sales revenue by 30% in 2013).Overall, the book is well organized and filled with great advice.

Overall, the tenth season was enjoyable and flowed well. It wrapped up the death of Ziva's father and Director Vance's wife fairly well. The only reason I give it four rather than five stars is that the final couple of episodes were borderline unbelievable. The witch hunt with an ever changing target, which ultimately settles on Gibbs for no apparent reason just seemed to be a reach. Then the "send Gibbs away on a mysterious secret mission" to have some kind of cliff hanger was a questionable ending to an otherwise great show. Keep up the good work guys. I'll be sorry to see Ziva leave next season.

The XBOOM Ceramic Mini is a great little speaker system. I use mine for my iphone - plugs into the audio port - and it provides a clear, modestly loud sound. It won't get a room full of people dancing, but it's perfect for a person or two who want to sit and enjoy some iTunes. I have a couple of other portable speaker systems, and this one was the smallest and offered the best sound quality. It collapses into a little rubberized ball, and can play up to 20 hours on a charge. Overall, it's a very good quality (and useful) product. I definitely recommend this little speaker for those who like to listen to their iphone music. I also find it really useful for listening to podcasts at work.

I'm a big fan of Jane Smiley and will read anything she writes. (Don't miss the two novellas Ordinary Love and Good Will--stunning!) Some Luck doesn't disappoint--it's the kind of insightful, sweeping family saga for which she's become renowned (think A Thousand Acres)., and it's the first book in a trilogy she has planned. But while her characters, as usual,0-[ are fully drawn and. in the case of Frank, absolutely fascinating, the book itself is very episodic. The end result is that it holds the reader's attention but ultimately feels as if there's a little missing from the plate--we get snippets from their lives but are left wanting a bit more meat.Some Luck traces the members of the Langdons, a farming family in rural Iowa, from 1920 to 1953, starting with the young couple Walter and Rosanna and their firstborn, Frank, when he's a baby. They go on to have several more children and experience their share of joys and tragedies, triumphs and disappointments. Each of the children has a distinct personality, and nearly all the characters could carry an entire novel as the main protagonists on their own, but the fact that their stories are so intertwined tends to give them short shrift. I'd have loved more about Eloise, Rosanna's sister, who moves to Chicago and becomes a Communist (maybe that's in store for the second novel in the trilogy),and Joe, the second son (what makes him tick)? And it seemed as if Frank decided to marry Andy very suddenly--a bit out of character for someone who had never really connected with anyone before and who prided himself on being something of a ladies' man. How did Arthur come to work in federal intelligence services?Each chapter covers significant events a single year, and the points of view change as the different characters take center stage during the chapter. it may be that the format is hampering the story a bit as well, though it's also an effective way of covering ground without filling in every detail.Some Luck absolutely held my interest, and I fully intend to read the other two books in the trilogy once they're released, but Smiley's previous books set the bar very, very high, and I've deducted a star the reasons I've delineated. But it's well worth reading and enjoyable on many levels.

I loved Mona Simpson's first novel, Anywhere but Here, but never got into The Lost Father and hadn't read any of her other books until picking up Casebook. The cover copy in no way conveys what an utterly delightful protagonist and narrator Miles Adler-Rich is or how the nuanced the storyline is. Simpson has created several memorable characters, especially Miles and his mother's love interest, Eli Lee. His mother, Irene, a mathematician on the UCLA faculty, and his best friend, Hector, are also worth mentioning, as is his mother's friend, Marge, and Ben Orion, the private eye the boys consult. I really enjoyed the book, pretty much from start to finish. The only minor quibble I had, and it may be me more than the author, is that I couldn't always keep all of the parents of Miles's friends straight, especially since a few couples split up.Casebook spans several years in the life of Miles, a self-proclaimed underachiever, and his friends and family. It's a coming-of-age story, but with a twist. Miles is an inveterate snooper, and he and his friend Hector, who practically lives with him, devote considerable energy to rigging up various ways to spy on his parents, whose marriage is falling apart. Along the way, among other entertaining touches, he and his friends also develop a hobby of disassembling his twin sisters' stuffed animals and sewing them back together with mismatched parts, a la Frankenstein. Miles and Hector also have a string of business ventures that tend to get them into trouble. And, inevitably, life happens to all the characters, lending a certain poignancy as an undercurrent to much of the story.But most of the story is devoted to Miles's and Hector's efforts to suss out the truth about his mother's lover, Eli. Miles comes to love Eli over the six years he dates his mother (it's a long-distance romance, so Eli comes and goes), but some things don't add up, and he and Hector set out to determine what's really going on. They get more than they bargained for when their suspicions prove legitimate.One of the things I especially enjoyed about the book was how Simpson never inserted herself into the prose. It's hard to explain, but Miles's voice was so strong and distinctive and so believable that I was totally caught up in his narrative and never became aware of, e.g., a nifty turn of phrase (though some of his analogies were indeed very funny).Is the book flawless? Of course not. The ending seemed a bit rushed, for one thing, and a few of the relationships that developed a bit pat. But overall, it was a wonderful read, and I highly recommend it to fans of accessible and amusing literary fiction that also happens to ring true.

I've been in a quandary over how to review this book. I ordered it because I really liked Christian Jungersen's earlier book, The Exception. And You Disappear reflects the same facility with language and focus on psychological themes (in this case, neurological). But I didn't love this book, even though it kept me reading. Mostly I felt sorry for every single character. I could relate to Mia's dilemma in dealing with her brain-injured husband, whose brain tumor caused a personality change that completely transformed their lives (and not for the better). But it was a painful read, in which each character was a victim of some kind.Interspersed among a number of chapters are excerpts from research literature about brain injury and neuroscience, and while I understand why Jungersen included them, they became fairly tedious, especially the longer ones. Another gripe I have is that the ending leaves readers hanging, with no resolution.Three and a half stars--a little better than okay, but not one of my favorites. I imagine You Disappear will appeal to people who are fascinated by neuroscience and questions of identity and responsibility and don't particularly care about plot and characterization.

I loved this book when I was a kid and ordered a used copy to give to someone's child after we saw a deer in my backyard. And when it arrived, I still found the illustrations lovely. But my, how times have changed. The story focuses almost entirely on the male fawn--the female one is a complete afterthought. I'm actually having second thoughts about giving it to the child because its world view is so out of date. (Nice artwork, though.)

The true story of a wolf who was an anomaly in Juneau, Alaska, for the six years or so he hung out near the Mendenhall Glacier, A Wolf Called Romeo manages to be both highly informative and incredibly moving. Romeo, as the lone black wolf was dubbed, readily befriended the many dogs who came to the area, seeking them out and playing with them, to where they served as kind of a surrogate pack. Year after year he returned when Mendenhall Lake froze over, incredibly tolerant of the humans who accompanied the dogs and in one or two cases, even behaving in a friendly way toward them. No one had ever seen a wild wolf act like this before, and no one knew why he was neither aggressive nor fearful.Anytime a wild animal becomes too acclimated to human contact, however, it sets off alarms, especially when the animal is a large predator, and Romeo had his advocates and detractors. Author Nick Jans, one of the first to encounter Romeo, was squarely in the advocate camp, but he was all too aware of how little it would take for things to go wrong, especially with the attention the wolf was attracting, and if it did, Romeo could pay with his life. At the same time they reveled in the unique experience of Romeo's company, Jans, his wife, and the wolf's other friends worried about the precariousness of the situation, as people with no common sense flocked to the lake to see and interact with him. Romeo's detractors included longtime Alaskans who were handy with guns and traps and had no use for wolves. Caught in the middle were state wildlife officials, who were damned if they did nothing about him and something went wrong and damned if they acted before something did.It's hard not to fall in love with Romeo while reading this book. He was a remarkable animal who united a community and gained renown around the world. At first, I thought A Wolf Called Romeo was basically an exceptionally well-written nature book, deserving of four stars, but as the narrative progressed, it became more and more gripping, to where, by the end, I was totally caught up in the story of this unique spirit and the people who loved him and moved to tears. Unequivocally, this wonderful tribute merits five stars. Highly recommended.

Everything I Never Told You is so insightful, confident and self-assured that it's hard to believe it's author Celeste Ng's first novel. This is literary fiction at its finest.I have to admit, though, that for most of the book, I figured I'd award if four stars, not five. It was excellent but not as gripping as some others that have bowled me over from day one, and the subject was uncomfortable. But as the story progressed and especially as it reached its denouement, I found I couldn't put it down and by the time I finished it, the fifth star was a foregone conclusion.Everything I Never Told You is a beautifully wrought, if sometimes disturbing exploration of a dysfunctional biracial family. Set mainly in the late 1970s, when Lydia, the elder daughter of Marilyn and James Lee, is found dead at the bottom of the local lake, it traces the stories of her, her parents and siblings. In the period it depicts (something Ng has done very well), ethnic "diversity" as we know it today was an unfamiliar term, and especially in their small Midwest college town, a family where the wife was blonde and blue-eyed and the husband Chinese-American, was an anomaly and not a particularly welcome one. In this book no one really feels comfortable in his/her skin or environment.At its core the book is about the tug-of-war between parents who want different things--to stand out from the crowd vs. fitting in--and the excruciating toll that dichotomy takes when parents who have given up their own dreams attempt to project them onto their children. To Marilyn, Lydia embodies everything she wanted for herself before she got pregnant and had to drop out of Radcliffe. She is relentless in pushing her daughter to become the doctor she herself never will be, never stopping to consider that Lydia may not share her dream. James, by contrast, the son of immigrants, earned a Ph.D. from Harvard in American history but only managed to land a faculty position at a small, second-rate college in Ohio, not the Ivy League appointment of his dreams. He wants nothing more than for his daughter to be popular and fit in with her peers, pushing her to take part in social activities that she abhors and where she is ignored. Even as Lydia is the focus of her parents' competing aspirations, her older brother, Nathan, finds himself largely dismissed by them, and the youngest, Hannah, is practically invisible. As the story progresses, their complete failure to understand and connect with their children takes a heavier and heavier toll.This is not an especially uplifting book, though by the end there's enough reconciliation that it doesn't leave you bummed out. But if you appreciate exceptional writing and powerful themes, you'll want to spend some time with Everything I Never Told You. It really is a remarkable book, and I'll watch eagerly for whatever else Celeste Ng produces in the future.

Make no mistake--I really enjoyed reading Lucky Us. Amy Bloom is a fabulous writer with a gift for creating memorable characters, placing them in unusual situations and putting completely believable words in their mouths. Her pacing is right on target. My only quibble is that I didn't find the resolution of the plot entirely satisfying (and I can't say more without giving things away). But suffice it to say that I would have much preferred a different outcome for Eva, the young woman at the center of the story.Eva lives with her single mother, on the edge of poverty in the 1940s, and her father, Edgar, who's married to someone else, visits them weekly. When her mother learns that his wife has died, she packs up Eva and drives to his home, then leaves her on the porch and drives away. Eva's father, Edgar, has another daughter, Iris, and the two half-sisters eventually bond. There are many twists and turns to the plot--how the two girls set off on their own and create a surrogate family, how Edgar isn't who he seems, how Eva is swept along in Iris's wake, how family doesn't necessarily mean the traditional nuclear family, and much more. World War II is a key event, of course, but it doesn't really dominate; this is Eva's story.There is much to like about this book; it was enjoyable and absorbing, and I'm glad I took the time to read it. It was only the end that seemed a bit false to me, and I've deducted a star, accordingly.

Painted Horses is hands down one of the best books I've read in the past year. I ordered it because the subject (archaeology, the West, a female protagonist) intrigued me, but I had absolutely no idea what a treat was in store.Exquisitely written, Painted Horses is at once bold and nuanced, a tale of passions and greed, naivete and cynicism, trust and betrayal, grief and redemption, and the tug-of-war between progress and tradition. And a whole lot more. It's a hell of a story, as expansive as the Montana landscape it describes so well, and as another reviewer has noted, it's mind-boggling that this is author Malcolm Brooks's debut novel. Painted Horses is so assured, so perfectly paced and peopled with characters so fully drawn that it reads like the work of a seasoned writer. To say I'm impressed is a gross understatement.It's the 1950s, and Catherine Lemay, who hails from a well-to-do family in New Jersey, has forsaken the musical career her mother had dreamed of for her in favor of her first love, archaeology. After taking part in a dig in London, she lands in Montana, hired by the Smithsonian to determine whether a valley slated to be flooded for a dam holds any sites of archaeological value. Catherine knows little about Native American culture or how to begin looking for the sites she seeks. A local man, Jack Allen, has been assigned the job of serving as her guide, but he has little interest in truly helping her because he's more determined to round up a herd of wild horses and selling them for meat. She enlists the aid of a young Native American woman to accompany them. At the same time, a man named John H is living in the back country, as determined to save the horses as Allen is to lead them to slaughter. John, who is something of a horse whisperer and who ran away from home at a tender age, is a complex character, devoted to the memory of a Basque man who served as a surrogate father to him and to living a quiet life away from civilization. Allen is mean to the core, John H his opposite.Needless to say, nothing goes as anyone has planned. Brooks seems to have boundless knowledge about postwar London, archaeology, horses, Montana and Native American culture. The research alone is impressive, let alone how he wove it all together.If I could give this book six stars, I would. Failing that, I'm recommending it to all and sundry. Painted Horses is an eminently satisfying book that will appeal to men and women alike.

I'm a big fan of Henri, le chat noir, and I've seen all the Internet Cat Video Festival entries that have been posted online. So I get the appeal and thought this book was a cute idea. And the execution is pretty clever for the first three sections.Unfortunately, there isn't enough material for the 128 pages this book runs, so it peters out pretty quickly after that. The sections on how to make a video and the business end aren't particularly funny--mostly they come across as trying too hard, as if an editor had wanted more, and the author was grasping at straws to expand the material.Ultimately, I think this would have worked best as a blog. If you have a friend who's super into cat videos, then this could make a good gift, but overall it's pretty thin on the entertainment after the initial 77 pages.

When I need air to circulate in a room, I usually rely either on ceiling fans or floor fans with rotating grilles. (I don't have any conventional oscillating fans). I was hoping this diminutive fan would serve a similar function to the those with rotating grilles,as mine are all getting along in years.It is, however, quite small, and for that reason alone, its uses are more limited.Like all Vornado fans, it's well built and solid. I don't really have a problem with the noise on the highest setting, as others do--I've heard worse. But unless I'm directly in line with the stream of air, I don't get the circulation that it's supposed to have. In my master bedroom, which is large, it wouldn't even reach across the room. In my office, which is much smaller, it was better, but still not as effective as my ceiling fan.Its small size makes it easy to perch on a shelf, and you can position it either vertically or horizontally and pivot it to direct the air where you want it, which is great if you have an appropriate place to put it where and when you need it and, like me, like a steady stream of air blowing on you when it's hot. But I can't see how it circulates all the air in a room, as advertised. Perhaps once the heat hits, and I can test it for a more extended time, I'll change my mind. But for now, it's simply a nice adjunct to my current fans and one I may or may not use much.

Jim Stegner, Peter Heller's protagonist in The Painter, is a man possessed--by the memory of his murdered daughter, by the need to paint to soothe his soul, by his passion for fishing (also to soothe his soul). And at the same time, he doesn't really understand what drives him when he's overcome by rage and commits acts of violence. He's a complex character, and that complexity, plus Heller's exquisite prose and astute observations about life, are what make The Painter a satisfying and memorable book.That said, it's also very much a man's book, IMO. That isn't so say that I didn't appreciate Heller's artistry or his philosophical insights. I did. But it seemed to me that the themes are very much ones dogging the heels of men in American society, and as a woman, I didn't relate to them as readily. Give this book to the art-loving, outdoor-loving and literature-loving males in your life. I imagine it will be a big hit.The cover copy and other reviews have covered the plot and characters well--how Stegner, who did time for nearly killing a man who was eyeing his young daughter, attacks a man abusing a horse and later kills him. How the man's family come after him and how he plays a game of cat and mouse with them and law enforcement, all while leading up to a painting commission he doesn't really want. Stegner is a loose cannon, but he's also likable and usually on the side of what's right, even if he doesn't necessarily go about it the right (or legal) way.All the characters in The Painter are interesting and multidimensional, even when they only put in a short appearance. Stegner's longtime friend Irmina, who's somewhat psychic and utterly steadfast; his model and new lover, Sofia, who's an independent woman who doesn't conform to any stereotypes; the family commissioning a portrait of their twin daughters; even the cops, Stegner's neighbor and the guy who runs the local gas station--all come across as real people you might want to get to know better, and it makes for a completely believable novel.Heller is clearly an immensely gifted writer, and I will be interested to read his future books. Four and a half stars for a book well worth the time to read it.

I've read most of Jo Nesbo's Harry Hole books, so I already knew what an accomplished writer he is (even if I take issue with some of the more gruesome and graphic elements of the Hole series). But I wasn't sure what to expect of this standalone novel. Would it be more graphic than I could stomach? How could I relate to a junkie in jail?As it happens, any trepidation disappeared within the first few chapters, when it became clear that it was going to be a book about corruption in the police force and the long reach of organized crime. It's also about innocence and culpability, as well as justice, however you might define it. It's a tautly written and intricately plotted novel, with plenty of cliffhangers. Shortly after starting the book, I was already crazy about Sonny Loftus, who's quite an original character. While I doubt Nesbo will resurrect him for future books, I'd sure love to make his acquaintance again. Nesbo even addressed one of my gripes by the end of the book--how the yellow house, unoccupied for 12 years, still had utilities connected.The premise of the book has been covered in the synopsis and other reviews--the young man, son of a late police officer, who has been framed for murders he didn't commit and kept addicted to heroin until he learns something he never expected about his father, which changes his life. The characters are all interconnected, and the story well paced and gripping. These aren't the two-dimensional characters you find in other books but the creations of a master storyteller who has created a highly satisfying story.Five unequivocal stars.

I read and enjoyed Julia Glass's Three Junes when it came out, though I didn't really remember much about the characters. One of them, however, figures prominently in And the Dark Sacred Night, albeit posthumously: Malachy Burns, who died of AIDS. When he was just a teenager, he befriended a young woman, equally young, at a music camp they both attended, and she never picked up on the fact that he was gay. She fell head over heels in love with him and, it being the 1960s, decided to lose her virginity to him. He reluctantly went along, and she got pregnant. That girl, Daphne, now in her 60s, and their son, Kit, middle-aged, are at the heart of the story, which is really about secrets, family ties and identity.Daphne never told Kit who his biological father was, and because Kit has been foundering, his wife basically throws him out of the house to go see his stepfather and attempt to get the information he needs about his provenance. Embarking on a journey of self-discovery, Kit eventually meets his paternal grandmother and grandfather, aunt and uncle, and begins to forge a relationship with them, to the dismay of his mother.The story skips back and forth between different characters' points of view, between past and present, and the writing is masterful, as one would expect of an author of Glass's caliber. There were times, though, when it seemed to drag a bit, and certain elements seemed to be tied up too neatly in the final section. Hence my deduction of a star.But those are minor quibbles, and And the Dark Sacred Night is bound to please Glass fans and anyone who enjoys literary fiction.

...with emphasis on the intellectual part. The Blazing World is a complex, sometimes dense novel structured as a series of journal entries, interviews, memories, etc. concerning the life of the artist Harriet (Harry) Burden. Harry's journals are being published posthumously, and the editor has reached out to various people in her life--her children, lover, friends, hangers-on--to gain more insight into this enigmatic woman.Harry, the widow of a renowned art dealer/philanderer, has despaired of gaining any recognition for her own art, which she attributes to the fact that she's female. So she contrives a scheme wherein she makes art for three exhibitions, then persuades male artists to pose as the creators of her works. It comes off well enough the first two times, but the third is another matter, and the show is such a success that her front cruelly betrays her and claims her work as his. And no one but her friends and family believe her insistence that she was the artist.Siri Hustvedt is a gifted writer and her Ph.D. shows in the highly academic approach to her subject. Harry is something of a polymath, with a keen memory and extensive knowledge of philosophy, art, history and culture. It's that very knowledge, however, that sometimes bogs down the novel, even when the footnotes are couched in the context of the fictional editor making notations for the publication of Harry's journals.At least one other reviewer has noted that it's very hard to connect with any of the characters, and with the exception of Phineas, I have to agree. This is an accomplished work, but that doesn't mean it's easy to digest or, necessarily always an enjoyable read. There were large swaths of Harry's notebooks that I skipped over because they were just too academic and tedious.Three and a half stars.

It's hard to believe that author Violet Kupersmith only graduated from college in 2011 and that The Frangipani Hotel is her first book. This collection of short stories is so mature, confident and accomplished that a writer three times her age would be proud to claim it as his/her own. That she wrote many while still in college makes them even more remarkable.Each of the stories has an element of the supernatural, real or imagined, and all are reportedly based on traditional Vietnamese stories. Kupersmith is a fluent--and fluid--storyteller who knows how to capture your attention and then take you in directions you don't expect. Ordinary people leading humdrum lives cross paths with malevolent spirits, grateful shapeshifters, vengeful ghosts, yet often those encounters are subtle, fleeting and/or perplexing. Set both in Vietnam and America, her tales are haunted as much by the two countries' shared past as they are by the other-worldly creatures who inhabit them.Reading The Frangipani Hotel is like taking a vacation from the everyday, and I highly recommend it. Five enthusiastic stars and votes of confidence in this young, extraordinarily talented writer. Violet Kupersmith is definitely someone to watch.

I missed Mr. Selfridge when it first ran on PBS, so have been catching the first season on Amazon video, through Amazon Prime. It's been thoroughly enjoyable (still have a few episodes to go). Although I lived in London briefly 20+ years ago, and went to Selfridge's from time to time, I had no idea it was founded by an American or how revolutionary it was at the time.This series is well-written and well-acted, as you might expect. Highly recommended to aficionados of British drama.

I've only used resistance bands at my local health club, and while I retrieved a set from my parents' house when my dad died, my cat decided to chew through them before I could use them, so I figured I'd try these to replace them (and keep them away from the cat).I don't pretend to be an expert on resistance bands, but they seem to do the job for the light exercises I wanted them for. It's a bit strange having to switch the handles when I want to change resistance, but I've gotten used to it. Believe it or not, the feature I like the best is the door loop, which allows me to thread cables through it and position them where I want. It makes it easy for me to use them at home and would undoubtedly be a great feature for someone who travels a lot and wants to stay in reasonable shape.These are clearly not top quality, but that doesn't really matter to me. They are adequate for my needs and give me an option when I don't make it to the gym.

Although I've been aware of Anna Quindlen and read her journalism from time to time, I had never read any of her fiction before picking up Still Life with Bread Crumbs. Since finishing the book, I've been asking myself why I waited so long. This is a lovely, adult story about a June-November romance, but it's also a whole lot more. In a way it's a coming-of-age story about the transition from middle age to encroaching old age. It's also about pursuit of artistic vision and about reinventing oneself when circumstances change. Quindlen has mapped out Rebecca Winter's story beautifully, and I could relate to almost every page. It's been a while since I've enjoyed a book this much.Rebecca Winter, a renowned 60-year-old fine art photographer,  is on a downslide professionally and financially as her work has lost its cachet and its market. Her mother is lost in dementia, and Rebecca is helping to pay for the nursing home she's in. That's just one of many major expenses she has, though, and her bank account has dwindled to almost nothing. To save money, she reluctantly sublets her beloved NYC apartment and repairs to the countryside, where she rents a rundown cabin near a small town. When a raccoon invades her attic shortly after her arrival, she turns to Jim Bates, a local roofer, who also has a host of other talents, including a knowledge of the local wildlife. A respectful friendship of sorts blossoms between them. As she struggles with the transition from big city life to country life, Rebecca also becomes a regular at a local coffee shop, known for its proprietor, Sarah Ashby, whose baked goods are legendary.There are many threads in the story--Rebecca's history and relationship with her parents, her failed marriage, her relationship with her son, her dealings with her not-so-supportive agent, Sarah's relationship with her ne'er-do-well husband, the back story of Jim's late wife and his sister. When Rebecca stumbles on some simple tableaux in the woods and begins to photograph them, her life takes a different turn.If you enjoy well-crafted literary fiction, I highly recommend Still Life with Bread Crumbs. Five enthusiastic stars.

I've read most of Jo Nesbo's Harry Hole books, and for most of Cockroaches, I was pretty sure I was going to give it five stars. Although only the second book in the series, it is well-written, with interesting characters, and unlike some of the later books (like The Leopard--yikes!), it lacked the really gruesome elements that had prompted me to briefly swear off future volumes in the series.But I'm afraid Cockroaches kind of fell apart at the end, so I've deducted a star.Harry in this book is the alcoholic but very talented Norwegian cop we've come to know, but here he's sent to Thailand to clear up the murder of the Norwegian ambassador. Thailand being Thailand, he has various encounters with the sex trade, drugs, corruption, etc. He's also working closely with a bald, half Thai woman named Liz, who's heading the investigation for the local police. The book has many twists and turns, and it completely held my interest, but the last few chapters, which encompassed the denouement, were confusing and hard to follow. It was kind of a let-down after the brisk pace of everything preceding it.While some reviewers have reported missing the frigid Norwegian settings of the later books, I didn't see that as a problem. Nesbo is just as good at describing the heat, humidity and breakneck development of Bangkok, and Harry is still Harry.Worth a read if you like Scandinavian noir in general and Harry Hole in particular. Just know it may not come together at the end quite as well as you'd like.

Line of Duty had me on the edge of my seat for all five or so hours of the series. (I'm hoping the fact that this is labeled "Series 1" means there's more to come.) It's British crime drama at its best--intelligent and complex, with well-rounded characters.The series centers around Detective Chief Inspector Tony Gates, who's got an outstanding record clearing up crimes, but the anticorruption unit of the police think it's too good to be true and are investigating his methods. Gates is a cop's cop, whose team is almost rabidly loyal to him. Heading up the investigation is Superintendent Hastings and a new member of his team, Steve Arnott, who's left his previous assignment under a cloud and who feels intense pressure to prove himself.A series of brutal murders take place, and as Gates investigates them, and anticorruption investigates him, it soon becomes clear that no one is entirely clean, and there are intricate connections among the various characters. What's real and what's merely suspicion--as well as who is behind the murders and why--keeps you guessing until the final episode.Highly recommended if you're a fan of the genre!

At a very unrealistic low price of this mid quality selections of music, who could resist buying this for my own collections?  Music artists and recording engineers might not be famous, but their performances are not be sneezed about.

It's no wonder why this Altec Lansing set of powered speakers for computers and MP3 players is offered at lower price.  The mid-range and high-range sounds are acceptable, but the lower range of the sub-woofer is boomy, not acceptable to persons who are used to listening to good speakers' sound.  This set of speaker might be okay for the below forty USD price, and free shipping.  Furthermore, this could be acceptable to younger persons who just use this for video games, but not for listening to good music.  The design of the two speakers (L & R), also has something to be desired due to obtrusive sharp corners, but it might be okay for non-discriminating persons. The power switch is located at the inaccessible back of the enclosure.  I do not want to return it to the seller that's why I modified the location of the switch by connecting a top-mounted black rocker switch on top of the box in "series connection" to the original switch at the back.  Moreover, I plug the bass reflex port (the hole in front) with a tightly rolled kitchen rubberized pad used for cleaning dishes to reduce too much booms of the sub-woofer.  Whoever designed this at the Altec Lansing should be sent back to a good design school in U.S. or European countries.  He or she is a bad engineer/designer who will ruin the good reputation of Altec Lansing Company. I hope this company will not go "belly-up" in the future for producing and selling below average merchandises.

My powered speakers set has a switch sub-woofer box that has a rocker power switch at the back of the enclosure.  I used this to modify the location of the power switch to be placed on the top of the enclosure in order that I can just push this switch to turn on the power using my foot under the table.  I am electrician, but anybody with basic knowledge of basic electrical circuit and safety can do this with simple tools like soldering iron, soldering lead, power drill, electrical friction tape and Epoxy glue.

I used this slim cover case for my Lenovo tablet.  I found it is very convenient to watch my tablet while taking my breakfast on our breakfast nook.  I'm sure this will also protect my tablet if I accidentally drop this on our tile-floor, and prevent dents on my Lenovo metal case.

Very good camera charger that I recommend to my friends and relatives.  This is also multi-voltage that you can use in the U.S. 120VAC and in most Southeast Asian countries using 220VAC.Very good camera charger that I recommend to my friends and relatives.  This is also multi-voltage that you can use in the U.S. 120VAC and in most Southeast Asian countries using 220VAC.Very good camera charger that I recommend to my friends and relatives.  This is also multi-voltage that you can use in the U.S. 120VAC and in most Southeast Asian countries using 220VAC.

I ordered this in a hurry because I have to connect my newly bought digital 61-key piano's headphones female jack to my stereo component that require 15 ft long extension cord.  This short patch cord is needed to connect the other end of the extension cable to the back of my preamp which require male RCA plugs.

I'm enjoying this digital player these days using my earphones, and at certain times I hook this up to my component stereo for more realistic listening pleasure.  However, the owner should buy the proper "Y-connector" to play the component stereo systems.  I used a 3-ft patch cord with stereo 1/4" plug (male plug with two black tiny rings) and two RCA male plugs (not the Females) at the other ends to connect to the back of the input of the component.  The battery is good and will hold satisfactorily for more than about four hours (my usual and personal listening time).

I gave away my first one of this charging pod to my nephew in the Far East during my vacation, so I ordered this second one in a hurry when I came back to U.S.  For a few dollars more that I spent on this charging pod, compared to my time and frustrations looking for tangles of power cords in my storing box, this is the convenient, tidy and less stressful way of charging my Black Berry that I planed to keep longer than 5 years.  Furthermore, I'm afraid that the jack (the female socket) in my mobile phone will wear out faster beyond repair due to constant plugging and pulling out of the charging cord.

This is my second OEM Desktop Cync Charging pod because I found this very much convenient to use at reasonable price.  These days, people are are buying new and expensive models of popular brands other than Black Berry, and maybe this type of charging pod will no longer be available in the market in the future.  And, I am not replacing my Black Berry that I use mainly for calling and text messages in the next 5 or 7 years unless it failed on me.  I am still satisfied with my mobile phone, and I am not planning to part with my $400 or so, just to browse online stores and/or spend my precious time on social networking sites.

Every-time I play this song on our piano during a party, I will notice a few of our guests are dancing to this old time favorite.  I'm sure decades, and even centuries in the future, this music of Julio Iglesias will lingers on among the heart of music lovers.

This is my favorite among others, like those in-ear buds whose bass output is superb, but...I said but due to the tendencies to hurt your ear canal after a while.  Most of my older headphones are made by Sony and Sennheiser.  This Sony MDR-G45LP is light and comfortable to my ears and ear cannals, but Sony has something to do about it because the slit below that part of the plastic headband which hold the tiny electrical cord to the other speaker is "biting" the top skin of my ears due to its weight after long hours of wearing it.  If you're planning to buy this style of headphones, and you use this for exercising or jogging/running, you are better off to buy that other style that has the slit positioned at the side (not at the bottom) of the head-band.  I don't want to return my headphones to Amazon that's why I wrap that portion of headband with soft fabric, and planned to replace it with a short transparent plastic tubing later.  You cannot buy a pre-split tubing, therefore a sharp kitchen knife or an Exacto-knife will be handy for this; just watch out, and avoid slitting your fingers ;-)
Very soft to my butt, only a quart of water will beat it for price and convenience.  Will buy more of this in the near future.

Less and less people want to use this style of MP3 player, but it's about time to buy this.
